subsection.text: In this article the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Clock hour” means a minimum of 50 minutes of actual class time for each 60–minute hour.
“Consumer member” means a nonprofessional member of a regulatory unit who is appointed from the general public.
“County” means a county of the State and, unless expressly provided otherwise, Baltimore City.
“Department” means the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.
“Partnership” includes a partnership registered as a limited liability partnership authorized by Title 9A of the Corporations and Associations Article.
“Person” means an individual, receiver, trustee, guardian, personal representative, fiduciary, or representative of any kind and any partnership, firm, association, corporation, or other entity.
“Secretary” means the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.
“State” means:

paragraph.text: a state, possession, territory, or commonwealth of the United States; or
the District of Columbia.

subsection.text: A requirement in this article that a document be under oath means that the document shall be supported by a signed statement made under the penalties of perjury that the contents of the document are true to the best of the knowledge, information, and belief of the individual making the statement.
The oath or affirmation shall be made:

paragraph.text: before an individual authorized to administer oaths, who shall certify in writing to have administered the oath or taken the affirmation; or
by a signed statement that:

subparagraph.text: is in the document or attached to and made part of the document; and
is made expressly under the penalties for perjury.

subsection.text: If the procedures provided in subsection (b)(2) of this section are used, the affidavit subjects the individual making it to the penalties for perjury to the same extent as an oath or affirmation made before an individual authorized to administer oaths.

section.text: Before any license or permit may be issued under this article to an employer to engage in an activity in which the employer may employ a covered employee, as defined in § 9-101 of the Labor and Employment Article, the employer shall file with the issuing authority:

paragraph.text: a certificate of compliance with the Maryland Workers’ Compensation Act; or
the number of a workers’ compensation insurance policy or binder.

subsection.text: This section does not apply in Baltimore City or Prince George’s and Worcester counties.
Except as otherwise provided in this article or Article 24, Title 11 of the Code, a county, municipal corporation, or other political subdivision of the State may not:

paragraph.text: require a local license in that county, municipal corporation, or political subdivision to engage in a business or occupation for which a State license is required under this article; or
impose a local fee or tax to engage in a business or occupation for which a State license is required under this article.

subsection.text: A county, municipal corporation, or other political subdivision of the State may require a local license if necessary for regulatory purposes in the interest of the public health, safety, or morals.
A public local law passed after October 1, 1941 does not repeal any provision of this section unless the public local law expressly refers to and repeals the provision.

Before any license or permit may be issued under this article, the applicant shall certify to the issuing authority that the applicant has paid all undisputed taxes and unemployment insurance contributions payable to the Comptroller or the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation or has provided for payment in a manner satisfactory to the unit responsible for collection.

Before any license or permit may be renewed under this article, the issuing authority shall verify through the office of the Comptroller that the applicant has paid all undisputed taxes and unemployment insurance contributions payable to the Comptroller or the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation or that the applicant has provided for payment in a manner satisfactory to the unit responsible for collection.
This section does not apply to a licensed real estate associate broker or salesperson affiliated with a licensed real estate broker as an independent contractor.

By August 31 of each year, the Department shall provide to the Department of Assessments and Taxation a list of persons issued licenses, certificates, or permits under this article during the previous fiscal year, to assist the Department of Assessments and Taxation in identifying new businesses within the State.
The list provided under this section shall:

paragraph.text: be provided free of charge; and
include, for each person on the list:

subparagraph.text: the name and mailing address of the person; and
the federal tax identification number of the person or, if the person does not have a federal tax identification number, the Social Security number of the person.

subsection.text: A person who must have a license issued by the Department under this article but does not get the license on time shall pay, in addition to the required license fee, a late fee.
The late fee shall be the sum of:

paragraph.text: up to 20% of the required license fee for the calendar month following the calendar month when the required license fee is due; and
up to 4% of the required license fee for each calendar month or part of a month after that.

subsection.text: In this section, “license” means all or any part of permission that:

paragraph.text: is required by law to be obtained from a unit;
is not required only for revenue purposes; and
is in any form, including:

subparagraph.text: an approval;
a certificate;
a charter;
a permit; or
a registration.

subsection.text: This section:

paragraph.text: applies only to a fee for an initial license issued for a 2-year term under the provisions of this article;
does not apply to a fee renewal of a license; and
may not affect any other law that requires a unit to prorate a fee on any basis for the issuance or renewal of a license.
For a license issued at any time during the first year of the term of the license, the issuing authority shall charge the full amount of the fee to the license applicant.
For a license issued in the second year of the term of the license, the issuing authority shall charge the license applicant:

subparagraph.text: one-half of the fee, if issued in the first 6 months of the second year; or
one-quarter of the fee, if issued in the last 6 months of the second year.

subsection.text: If payment of the fee for the issuance or renewal of a license, issued by the Department or by a unit within the Department, is made by a check or other negotiable instrument that is dishonored, the license for which the fee was paid shall be suspended by operation of law. Except as provided in subsections (b) and (c) of this section, the suspension is effective beginning on the tenth business day after the day on which notice is sent in accordance with subsection (b) of this section until the date that payment of the fee, and any late charge provided for in this article, has been made.

paragraph.text: When the Department or a unit within the Department receives notice that a check or other negotiable instrument, given by an applicant in payment of a license issuance or renewal fee, has been dishonored, it shall inform the applicant by regular mail sent to the applicant’s last known business address, that the license will be suspended by operation of law if within 10 business days from the date of the notice the applicant fails to make payment of the fee, and any late charge, or fails to present evidence to the Department or unit that the notice of dishonor was in error.
An applicant shall be given a prompt opportunity to make payment of the fee, and any late charge, or to present evidence to the Department or unit that the notice of dishonor was in error.

subsection.text: If a license is suspended under subsection (a) of this section, the license shall be reinstated effective the date that the license was suspended, if within 5 business days after the date of the suspension the applicant:

paragraph.text: pays the late fee and any late charge; or
presents evidence to the Department or the unit that the notice of dishonor was in error.

subsection.text: Suspension of a license under this section may not affect any otherwise valid claim under any guaranty fund made by a person who dealt in good faith with a licensee, without knowledge of the suspension.
“Authorized person” means:

paragraph.text: a professional engineer who is licensed under Title 14 of this article;
a professional land surveyor who is licensed under Title 15 of this article; or
an authorized representative of the professional engineer or the professional land surveyor who is executing a survey.

subsection.text: If entry is for the purpose of using the horizontal or vertical position data in controlling surveys of land for cadastral purposes or for other private or public engineering purposes, an authorized person may enter on any private land on which there is a marked survey station for which the horizontal or vertical position has been determined:

paragraph.text: by or under the direction of the National Geodetic Survey;
as a part of the Maryland coordinate system; or

by or under the direction of any other organization whose survey stations have been established by or in accordance with the requirements of the State agency authorized to administer the Maryland coordinate system.

subsection.text: An authorized person may not unnecessarily damage the property on which a survey station stands.

paragraph.text: Prior to entry on the property, an authorized person and the owner of the property shall agree on the amount to be paid for any damage to the property.

On the completion of the work at the survey station, the authorized person shall promptly reimburse the owner of the property for any damage done to the property by the authorized person who entered on the property.

subsection.text: If, prior to entry on the property, the authorized person and the owner of the property have not agreed on the amount to be paid for any damage to the property, the authorized person shall file a surety bond in the circuit court of the county in which the property is located in an amount to be approved by the court, conditioned on the payment of all damages and costs as provided under subsection (d) of this section.

paragraph.text: The circuit court shall appoint three appraisers who are residents of the county in which the property is located to determine the amount to be paid for any damage to the property.

The proceedings for the ascertainment of damages shall be in accordance with the provisions of Title 8, Subtitle 3 of the Transportation Article relating to the acquisition of private property for a public purpose.

subsection.text: If the damages awarded under § 1-302(d) of this subtitle do not exceed the amount tendered by the authorized person under § 1-302(b) of this subtitle, the owner of the property shall pay the costs of the proceeding under § 1-302(d) of this subtitle.
If the damages awarded under § 1-302(d) of this subtitle exceed the amount tendered by the authorized person, the authorized person shall pay the costs of the proceeding.
This section applies to any survey station established by or under the direction of:

paragraph.text: the National Geodetic Survey;
the State agency administering the Maryland coordinate system;
any other organization whose survey stations have been established by or in accordance with the requirements of the State agency authorized to administer the Maryland coordinate system; or
any other State, municipal, or county agency.

subsection.text: Any person who willfully injures, defaces, or destroys the mark or monument at any survey station described in subsection (a) of this section or offers any obstacles to the proper, reasonable, and legal use of the station is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction shall be sentenced to pay a fine not to exceed $250 for each offense and costs, or shall be imprisoned for a term of not less than 6 months, or both.
In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“AICPA” means the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants.
“Attest” means to provide the following financial statement services:

paragraph.text: an audit or other engagement performed in accordance with the Statements on Auditing Standards issued by AICPA;
a review of a financial statement performed in accordance with the Statements on Standards for Accounting and Review Services issued by AICPA;
a compilation;
an examination of prospective financial information performed in accordance with the Statements on Standards for Attestation Engagements issued by AICPA; and
any engagement performed in accordance with the Auditing Standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board.

subsection.text: “Board” means the State Board of Public Accountancy.

“Compilation” means a presentation of information in the form of a financial statement that is performed in accordance with the Statements on Standards for Accounting and Review Services issued by AICPA.
“Home office” is the location specified by a client of a certified public accountant as the address to which a service described in § 2–401(a) of this title is directed.
“License” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a license issued by the Board to practice certified public accountancy.
“License fee” means the fee paid in connection with the issuance or renewal of a license.
“Licensed certified public accountant” means, unless the context requires otherwise, an individual licensed by the Board to practice certified public accountancy.

“Permit” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a permit issued by the Board to allow a partnership or corporation to operate a business through which an individual may practice certified public accountancy.
“Permit fee” means the fee paid in connection with the issuance or renewal of a permit.
“Practice certified public accountancy” means to perform any of the following accountancy services:

paragraph.text: conducting an audit, review, or compilation of financial statements; or

providing a written certificate or opinion offering positive or negative assurance or full or limited assurance on the correctness of the information or on the fairness of the presentation of the information in:

subparagraph.text: a financial statement;
a report;
a schedule; or
an exhibit.

subsection.text: “Practice privilege” means the right granted to an individual who is licensed by another state to practice certified public accountancy in this State without a license issued by this State.
“Principal place of business” means the office location designated by the licensee for purposes of substantial equivalency and reciprocity.
“NASBA” means the National Association of Boards of Accountancy.
If the person does not engage in any activity expressly included in the definition of practice certified public accountancy, this title does not prohibit:

paragraph.text: an individual from serving as an employee of or assistant to a licensee or permit holder;
a public official or public employee from performing the duties of the position of that individual; or
a person from providing or offering to the public bookkeeping and accounting services, including:

subparagraph.text: development or installation of a bookkeeping system;
recordation or presentation of financial information;
preparation of:

sub-subparagraph.text: a financial statement;
a compilation of a financial statement that:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: does not reference the Statements on Standards for Accounting and Review Services issued by AICPA; and
expressly states that the person has not undergone and is not required to undergo peer review;

sub-subparagraph.text: a report;
a schedule; or
an exhibit; or

subparagraph.text: any similar activity.

subsection.text: This title does not prohibit a licensee or permit holder from:

paragraph.text: employing a certified public accountant licensed by another state or a foreign country; or
listing that individual as a certified public accountant, if the individual qualifies for a practice privilege under § 2–321 of this title.

subsection.text: The Board shall adopt regulations that specify the language of the disclosure statement relating to exemption from peer review that is required to be included in a compilation of a financial statement prepared under subsection (a)(3)(iii)2 of this section.

section.text: There is a State Board of Public Accountancy in the Department.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of 7 members.
Of the 7 members of the Board:

subparagraph.text: 5 shall be licensed certified public accountants, of whom:

sub-subparagraph.text: 4 shall practice certified public accountancy actively; and
1 shall be a full-time professor of accounting at an accredited college; and

subparagraph.text: 2 shall be consumer members.

paragraph.text: The Governor shall appoint the members with the advice of the Secretary.

subsection.text: Each member of the Board shall be:

paragraph.text: a citizen of the United States; and
a resident of the State.

subsection.text: Each consumer member of the Board:

paragraph.text: shall be a member of the general public;
may not be a licensee or otherwise be subject to regulation by the Board;
may not be required to meet the qualifications for the professional members of the Board; and
may not, within 1 year before appointment, have had a financial interest in or have received compensation from a person regulated by the Board.

subsection.text: While a member of the Board, a consumer member may not:

paragraph.text: have a financial interest in or receive compensation from a person regulated by the Board; or
grade any examination given by or for the Board.

subsection.text: Before taking office, each appointee to the Board shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 3 years and begins on July 1.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on October 1, 1989.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member may not serve more than 2 terms consecutively, but following the 2nd term, may serve again after an interval of at least 3 years.
The Governor may remove a member for incompetence or misconduct.
The Governor shall remove a member who ceases to meet the requirements under which the member was appointed, as provided under subsections (a) and (b) of this section.

subsection.text: From among its members, the Board shall elect:

paragraph.text: a chairman; and

subparagraph.text: a secretary and a treasurer; or
a secretary-treasurer.

subsection.text: The manner of election of officers and their terms of office shall be as the Board determines.
A majority of the members then serving on the Board is a quorum.
The Board shall determine the times and places of its meetings.
Each member of the Board is entitled to:

paragraph.text: compensation in accordance with the State budget; and
reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Board may employ a staff in accordance with the State budget.

section.text: In addition to any other remedy authorized under this title, the Board, with the approval of the Attorney General, may sue in the name of the State to enjoin any act that is prohibited under Subtitle 6 of this title.

subsection.text: On request of any person and payment of a verification fee set by the Board, the Board shall certify the licensing or permit status and qualifications of any person who is the subject of the request.
Each certification under this section:

paragraph.text: shall include a statement of the licensing or permit status of the person who is the subject of the request; and
may include:

subparagraph.text: information about the examination results and other qualifications of that person;
information about the dates of issuance and renewal of the license or permit of that person;
information about any disciplinary action taken against that person; and
if authorized by that person, information about any complaint against that person.

subsection.text: In addition to any powers set forth elsewhere, the Board may adopt:

paragraph.text: any bylaw that is necessary to do the business of the Board; and
any regulation to carry out this title.

subsection.text: In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere, the Board shall:

paragraph.text: adopt rules of professional conduct as appropriate to establish a high standard of integrity and dignity for practicing certified public accountancy; and
keep a record of its proceedings.

subsection.text: The Board shall maintain a listing of the names and mailing addresses of all licensees and permit holders.
The Board may release its list to the public.
The licensee or permit holder shall designate the mailing address at the time of issuance of the original license or permit and on the renewal of the license or permit.

paragraph.text: Beginning on July 1, 2008, the Board may set by regulation reasonable fees for its services.
The fees shall be:

subparagraph.text: set so as to produce funds to approximate the cost of maintaining the Board; and
based on the calculations performed by the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation under § 2–106.6 of the Business Regulation Article.

subsection.text: The Board shall publish the fee schedule set by the Board.

paragraph.text: Beginning on July 1, 2007, the Board shall pay all fees collected under this title to the Comptroller.
The Comptroller shall distribute the fees to the State Board of Public Accountancy Fund established in § 2–106.5 of the Business Regulation Article.

section.text: Any person aggrieved by a final decision of the Board in a contested case, as defined in § 10-202 of the State Government Article, may take an appeal as allowed in §§ 10-222 and 10-223 of the State Government Article.
The Board exercises its powers, duties, and functions subject to the authority of the Secretary.
Except as provided in § 2–321 of this subtitle, an individual shall be licensed by the Board before the individual may practice certified public accountancy in the State.

subsection.text: To qualify for a license, an applicant shall be an individual who meets the requirements of this section.
The applicant shall be of good character and reputation.
The applicant shall be at least 18 years old.
The applicant shall meet the educational requirements under § 2-303 of this subtitle.
Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, the applicant shall pass an examination given by the Board under this subtitle.
The applicant for an initial license shall complete practical work experience that is approved by the Board and that:

paragraph.text: is obtained over a period of:

subparagraph.text: not more than 3 years; and

sub-subparagraph.text: not less than 6 months if the applicant applies before October 1, 2000; or
not less than 1 year if the applicant applies on or after October 1, 2000;

paragraph.text: includes providing any type of service or advice involving the use of accounting, attest, management advisory, financial advisory, tax, or consulting skills;
is performed under the direction of:

subparagraph.text: a licensed certified public accountant; or
an appropriately qualified professional as determined by the Board;

paragraph.text: is obtained through employment in government, industry, academia, or public practice; and
amounts to:

subparagraph.text: 1,000 hours if the applicant applies before October 1, 2000; or
2,000 hours if the applicant applies on or after October 1, 2000.

paragraph.text: In order to take the examination, an applicant shall have satisfactorily completed 120 semester hours or their equivalent, and hold a baccalaureate or higher degree that meets the requirements of this section.

In order to become licensed, in addition to the other qualifications for a license set forth in this subtitle, an applicant shall have satisfactorily completed 150 semester hours or their equivalent, including the attainment of a baccalaureate or higher degree that meets the requirements of this section.

subsection.text: The applicant shall have completed for the degree a curriculum that the Board considers to constitute:

paragraph.text: a major in accounting; or
a substantial equivalent to a major in accounting, of which required credits or courses may be taken at any 2– or 4–year regionally accredited institution of higher education.

subsection.text: The degree required under this section shall be awarded by a school, college, university, or other institution that:

paragraph.text: is a member of the American Assembly of Collegiate Schools of Business;
is a member of the Association of Collegiate Business Schools and Programs;
is accredited by or is a constituent unit of an institution accredited by:

subparagraph.text: the Middle States Association of Colleges and Schools; or
the equivalent regional accrediting association for other regional areas; or

paragraph.text: is recognized and approved by the Board.

The Board may use the services of any institution that it considers appropriate to determine what constitutes a substantial equivalent to a major in accounting under subsection (b)(2) of this section.
If the Board uses an institution to determine curriculum equivalencies, the Board may accept as final the determination of that institution.

section.text: An applicant for a license shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the Board an application on the form that the Board provides; and
pay to the Board or the Board’s designee:

subparagraph.text: a nonrefundable application fee set by the Board; and
an examination fee set by the Board in an amount not to exceed the cost of the required examination.

subsection.text: An applicant who meets the educational requirements established by the Board is entitled to be examined as provided in this section.
The Board shall give examinations to applicants at least twice a year, at the times and places that the Board determines.
The Board shall give each qualified applicant notice of the time and place of examination.

paragraph.text: The Board shall give the examination prepared by the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants or an equivalent examination as determined by the Board.

The Board may use the services of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants to prepare or grade an examination. If the Board uses the services of the Institute, the Board may accept as final the grades that the Institute determines.
The Board may use the services of any person whom the Board considers appropriate to proctor an examination.

subsection.text: The Board shall adopt regulations that establish the passing score for an examination.

paragraph.text: The Board shall mail to each applicant notice of the applicant’s examination score.
Any applicant who requests an appointment within 60 days after the date on which the notice is mailed may review the applicant’s answers to the examination.

If the Board uses the services of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants to grade an examination, the Board may send the examination answers to the Institute by electronic transmission, by mail, or by a private delivery service.

If the Board sends out examination answers for grading in accordance with paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Board is not liable for the loss or destruction of any of the examination answers while the answers are out of the possession of the Board.

section.text: The Board may adopt regulations that, under the conditions that the Board considers appropriate, allow an applicant who obtains a passing score on any part of an examination to:

paragraph.text: be given credit for that part; and
be reexamined only in the remaining parts.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of this section, an applicant who fails an examination given under § 2-305 of this subtitle may retake the examination.

paragraph.text: Subject to the provisions of this subsection, the Board may not limit the number of times that an applicant may take an examination.
The Board may adopt regulations to set conditions for retaking examinations, including requirements that an applicant:

subparagraph.text: wait a reasonable period between examinations; and
prepare for reexamination in a manner specified by the Board.

paragraph.text: An applicant for reexamination shall:

subparagraph.text: submit to the Board an application for reexamination on the form that the Board provides; and
pay to the Board or the Board’s designee a reexamination fee set under this subsection.

paragraph.text: The Board shall set fees for reexamination so that:

subparagraph.text: the fee for reexamination on the entire examination does not exceed the cost of the required reexamination; and
the fee for reexamination on less than the entire examination is less than the fee set for the entire examination.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of this section, the Board may waive any examination requirement of this subtitle for:

paragraph.text: a certified public accountant licensed by another state; or

the holder of a license, certificate, or degree that is issued by another country and is recognized as authority for the holder to practice public accountancy in that country in a manner comparable to practicing certified public accountancy in this State.

subsection.text: The Board may grant a waiver under this section only if the applicant:

paragraph.text: is of good character and reputation;
is at least 18 years of age;
pays to the Board:

subparagraph.text: a nonrefundable application fee set by the Board; and
a license fee set by the Board; and

paragraph.text: provides adequate evidence that the applicant has met educational, examination, and experience requirements that are:

subparagraph.text: substantially equivalent to those required by the laws of this State;
substantially equivalent to those required by the laws of the State at the time the applicant was licensed in another state; or

after passing the Uniform Certified Public Accountancy Examination, has obtained 4 years of practical work experience, as defined in § 2–302(f) of this subtitle, within the last 10 years immediately preceding submission of the application.

paragraph.text: For the purposes of this subtitle, “substantial equivalency” means a determination made by the Board or its designee that:

subparagraph.text: the education, examination, and experience requirements contained in the laws or administrative rules of another jurisdiction are comparable to, or exceed, the education, examination, and experience requirements contained in the Uniform Accountancy Act; or
an individual’s education, examination, and experience are comparable to or exceed the education, examination, and experience requirements contained in the Uniform Accountancy Act.

paragraph.text: In determining substantial equivalency, the Board shall take into account an individual’s qualifications without regard to the sequence in which the education, examination, or experience requirements are met.

subsection.text: If an applicant qualifies for a license under this subtitle, the Board shall send the applicant a notice that states that:

paragraph.text: the applicant has qualified for a license; and
on receipt of a license fee set by the Board, the Board will issue a license to the applicant.

subsection.text: On payment of the license fee, the Board shall issue a license to each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle.
Unless a license is renewed for a 2–year term as provided in this section, the license expires on the first December 31 that comes:

paragraph.text: after the effective date of the license; and
in an even–numbered year.

subsection.text: At least 1 month before a license expires, the Board shall mail to the licensee, at the last known address of the licensee:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

subparagraph.text: the date on which the current license expires;
the date by which the Board must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the license expires; and
the amount of the license fee.

subsection.text: Before a license expires, the licensee periodically may renew it for an additional 2–year term, if the licensee:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be licensed;
pays to the Board a license fee set by the Board; and
submits to the Board:

subparagraph.text: a renewal application on the form that the Board provides; and
satisfactory evidence of compliance with the continuing education requirements set under this subtitle for license renewal.

subsection.text: The Board shall renew the license of each licensee who meets the requirements of this section.
The Secretary may determine that licenses issued under this subtitle shall expire on a staggered basis.

paragraph.text: The Board shall adopt regulations that set, in accordance with this section, continuing education requirements as a condition to the renewal of licenses under this subtitle.
A continuing education requirement does not apply to the first renewal of a license.

subparagraph.text: To qualify for any further renewal of a license under this subtitle, a licensee shall complete, for each 2–year license term, at least 80 hours in programs that the Board approves.
If a licensee completes more than 80 hours during a 2–year license term, the Board shall credit the excess hours to the requirements for the following term.

paragraph.text: Except as provided under paragraph (5) of this subsection, a licensee may not be required to take an examination to qualify for license renewal under this section.

On request of a licensee, the Board may allow the licensee to substitute the passage of an examination for a number of program hours. If the Board grants a request under this paragraph, the Board shall determine the number of program hours that the licensee may satisfy by passage of the examination.

subsection.text: The Board shall set continuing education requirements under this section:

paragraph.text: to ensure reasonable knowledge about the current practice of accountancy by certified public accountants and, thus, to ensure a high standard of practice in the profession;
to provide for programs in the various specialized areas of accountancy in which certified public accountants practice;
to provide a licensee with alternative ways by which to qualify through a variety of programs, which may include:

subparagraph.text: professional development programs;
technical sessions of professional societies or chapters;
college courses;
formal, organized, in–firm educational programs of certified public accounting firms;
seminars provided by governmental units; and
other seminars or symposiums related to the practice of accountancy; and

paragraph.text: to ensure that the programs approved for compliance with the continuing education requirements are available at reasonable intervals throughout the State.
The Board may appoint a continuing education committee to help the Board in carrying out this section.
Each member of a continuing education committee shall be a licensed certified public accountant.
A continuing education committee shall have the duties that the Board assigns.

subsection.text: The regulations adopted under this section shall provide for a system for reporting and recording the program hours that each licensee earns. However, the Board may not require a licensee to submit scores or grades earned during participation by the licensee in a program.

paragraph.text: The Board may enter into written agreements with qualified persons wishing to conduct approved programs.
A person seeking approval by the Board for this purpose shall:

subparagraph.text: submit to the Board an application on the form that the Board provides; and
pay a continuing education provider fee set by the Board.

paragraph.text: Agreements entered into under this section shall expire on April 30 of each even–numbered year.

subsection.text: The Board shall place a licensee on inactive status and issue an inactive status certificate to the licensee, if the licensee:

paragraph.text: submits to the Board an application for inactive status on the form that the Board provides;
pays to the Board an inactive status fee set by the Board; and
except for the continuing education requirements set under § 2–312 of this subtitle, qualifies for an active license.

subsection.text: A licensee on inactive status may not practice certified public accountancy in the State.

paragraph.text: Unless a licensee on inactive status renews it as provided in this section, the licensee loses that status on the first December 31 that comes:

subparagraph.text: after the inactive status certificate is issued to the licensee; and
in an even–numbered year.

paragraph.text: At least 1 month before the inactive status of a licensee expires, the Board shall mail to the licensee, at the last known address of the licensee:

subparagraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

sub-subparagraph.text: the date on which the inactive status expires;
the date by which the Board must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be mailed before the inactive status expires; and
the amount of the inactive status fee.

paragraph.text: Before an inactive status expires, the licensee periodically may renew it for an additional 2–year term, if the licensee:

subparagraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be placed on inactive status;
pays to the Board an inactive status fee set by the Board; and
submits to the Board a renewal application on the form that the Board provides.

paragraph.text: After an inactive status expires, the former licensee may reapply for inactive status without meeting the continuing education requirements to qualify for an active license under § 2–312 of this subtitle, only if the former licensee:

subparagraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be placed on inactive status;
pays to the Board an inactive status fee set by the Board; and
reapplies to the Board for inactive status within 2 years after initial expiration of inactive status on a form that the Board provides.

paragraph.text: The Board shall renew the inactive status of each licensee or grant the reapplication for inactive status of each former licensee who meets the requirements of this subsection.

subsection.text: The Board shall reactivate the license of a licensee who is on inactive status, if the licensee:

paragraph.text: complies with each continuing education requirement that the Board sets for this purpose;
submits to the Board an application for reactivation; and
pays to the Board a reactivation fee that is equal to the license fee set by the Board under § 2–311 of this subtitle.

section.text: In accordance with its regulations, the Board may reinstate the license of an individual who has failed to renew the license for any reason if the individual:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be licensed;
complies with each continuing education requirement that the Board sets for this purpose; and
pays to the Board a reinstatement fee set by the Board.

Subject to the hearing provisions of § 2–317 of this subtitle, the Board, on the affirmative vote of a majority of its members, may deny a license to any applicant, reprimand any licensee, or suspend or revoke a license if the applicant or licensee:

subparagraph.text: fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a license for the applicant or licensee or for another;
fraudulently or deceptively uses a license;
under the laws of the United States or of any state, is convicted of:

sub-subparagraph.text: a felony; or
a misdemeanor that is directly related to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to practice certified public accountancy;

subparagraph.text: is guilty of fraud or other dishonesty in the practice of accountancy;
is guilty of gross negligence in the practice of accountancy;
violates any provision of Subtitle 6 of this title;
has had the right to practice as a certified public accountant in another state denied, revoked, or suspended;
has been sanctioned in another state in a matter relating to the practice of public accountancy;
has had the renewal of the right to practice as a certified public accountant in another state denied for any cause other than failure to pay a renewal fee;
has had the right to practice as a certified public accountant before any unit of the State or federal government revoked or suspended;

has been sanctioned by any unit of State or federal government, or any regulatory entity established by law, for an act or omission that directly relates to the fitness of the applicant or licensee to practice public accountancy; or
violates a rule of professional conduct adopted by the Board.
Instead of or in addition to reprimanding the licensee or suspending or revoking a license under this subsection, the Board may impose a penalty not exceeding $5,000 for each violation.
To determine the amount of the penalty imposed under this subsection, the Board shall consider:

sub-subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the harm caused by the violation;
the good faith of the licensee; and
any history of previous violations by the licensee.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: The Board shall consider the following facts in the granting, denial, renewal, suspension, or revocation of a license or the reprimand of a licensee when an applicant or licensee is convicted of a felony or misdemeanor described in subsection (a)(1)(iii) of this section:

paragraph.text: the nature of the crime;
the relationship of the crime to the activities authorized by the license;
with respect to a felony, the relevance of the conviction to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to practice certified public accountancy;
the length of time since the conviction; and
the behavior and activities of the applicant or licensee before and after the conviction.

subsection.text: On suspension or revocation of a license, the holder shall surrender to the Board the license certificate of the holder.
At the end of a suspension period, the Board shall return to the licensee the license certificate surrendered under this section.

section.text: On its own initiative or on a written complaint made to the Board by any person, the Board may commence proceedings under § 2-315 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 10-226 of the State Government Article, before the Board takes any final action under § 2-315 of this subtitle, it shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Board.
The Board shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Board may administer oaths in connection with any proceeding under this section.

paragraph.text: The Board may issue a subpoena for the attendance of a witness to testify or the production of evidence in connection with any proceeding under this section.
If a person fails to comply with a subpoena issued under this subsection, on petition of the Board, a circuit court may compel compliance with the subpoena.

subsection.text: If, after due notice, the individual against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, nevertheless the Board may hear and determine the matter.

paragraph.text: For the limited purpose set forth in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a license shall remain in effect and may not expire by operation of law while the licensee is under investigation by the Board or awaiting a hearing or disposition on charges subject to disciplinary action under this subtitle.

Any extension of a license term caused under this subsection is effective only for the purpose of retaining the jurisdiction of the Board over the licensee during the course of disciplinary proceedings and does not prevent the license from expiring for any other purpose.

subsection.text: Unless the Board agrees to accept the surrender, a licensee may not surrender a license while the licensee is under investigation or awaiting a hearing or disposition on charges subject to disciplinary action under this subtitle.
Subject to the provisions of this section, the Board may reinstate:

paragraph.text: any license that has been revoked; or
before fulfillment of the conditions of the suspension, any license that has been suspended.

subsection.text: A license may be reinstated under this section only if:

paragraph.text: the individual whose license has been revoked or suspended submits a written request to the Board;
the Board holds a hearing on the request;
the Board, by an affirmative vote of a majority of its members, votes to reinstate the license; and
the individual pays to the Board a reinstatement fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: In this section, “practice certified public accountancy” includes the practice of public accountancy.

paragraph.text: An individual whose principal place of business is outside the State is exempt from the licensing requirement under § 2–301 of this subtitle and shall be considered to have qualifications that are substantially equivalent to a licensee if:

subparagraph.text: the individual holds a valid license as a certified public accountant from another state; and
the requirements of that state have been verified by NASBA as substantially equivalent with the licensure requirements of the Uniform Accountancy Act.

paragraph.text: An individual who qualifies for an exemption under paragraph (1) of this subsection may exercise all of the privileges of a licensed certified public accountant.

An individual who is licensed by a state that the NASBA National Qualification Appraisal Service has not verified to be in substantial equivalence with the CPA licensure requirements of the Uniform Accountancy Act may exercise all of the privileges of a licensed certified public accountant if the individual:

subparagraph.text: retains a principal place of business outside of the State;
holds a valid license as a certified public accountant; and
has qualifications that the NASBA National Qualification Appraisal Service has determined to be substantially equivalent to the CPA licensure requirements of the Uniform Accountancy Act.

paragraph.text: An individual who has passed the Uniform CPA Examination and holds a valid license issued by another state prior to January 1, 2012, may be exempt from the education requirements in the Uniform Accountancy Act for purposes of this subsection.
Notwithstanding any other provision of law, an individual who qualifies for a practice privilege under this section may practice certified public accountancy in the State:

subparagraph.text: by any means, including mail, telephone, or electronic communication; and
without any notice, fee, or other submission to the Board.

subsection.text: As a condition of the practice privilege, an individual who is licensed by another state and qualifies for a practice privilege under this subtitle and any firm that employs the individual to practice in the State shall both consent to:

paragraph.text: the personal and subject matter jurisdiction and disciplinary authority of the Board;
complying with State public accountancy laws and regulations adopted by the Board;

the appointment of the State Board of Public Accountancy that issued the individual’s license to practice certified public accountancy as the agent upon which process may be served in any action or proceeding by the Board against the individual; and

ceasing to offer or provide services in the State that are subject to this title if the license issued by the state in which the individual’s principal place of business is located is no longer valid.

subsection.text: An individual authorized to practice certified public accountancy under this section and under the practice privilege may represent to the public, by use of a title, including “licensed certified public accountant”, “certified public accountant”, “public accountant”, or “auditor”, by use of the abbreviation “CPA”, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the individual is authorized to practice certified public accountancy in the State.

A sole practitioner who is practicing in the State under the practice privilege may only perform attest services as defined in § 2–101(c)(1), (4), or (5) of this title, through a firm that holds a permit issued under § 2–401 of this title.
A firm shall hold a permit issued by the Board if the firm:

paragraph.text: has an office in this State that performs attest services as defined in § 2–101(c) of this title;
has an office in this State that uses the title “CPA” or “CPA firm”; or
performs attest services described in § 2–101(c)(1), (4), or (5) of this title for a client with a home office in this State.

subsection.text: A firm that does not have an office in this State may perform attest services as defined in § 2–101(c)(2) and (3) of this title for a client with a home office in this State without a permit if the firm:

paragraph.text: meets the application and peer review requirements under §§ 2–402, 2–402.1, 2–403, and 2–4A–02 of this title; and
performs services through an individual with a practice privilege under § 2–321 of this title.

subsection.text: The Board shall grant or renew a permit to practice as a CPA firm to a partnership, limited liability company, or corporation that demonstrates its qualifications in accordance with this section.
If a firm does not meet the requirements of this section, the firm may perform other professional services while using the title “CPA” or “CPA firm” in this State without a permit, if the firm:

paragraph.text: performs those services through an individual with a practice privilege provided under § 2–321 of this title; and
performs those services in the state where the individual with a practice privilege retains a principal place of business.

subsection.text: To qualify for a permit, a partnership shall meet the requirements of this section.
The partnership shall:

paragraph.text: have at least a simple majority of the partners, officers, shareholders, members, or managers, in terms of financial interest and voting rights, be licensed in a state;

subparagraph.text: have a permanent office in the State from which an individual is licensed to practice certified public accountancy; or
have at least a simple majority of the partners, officers, shareholders, members, or managers retain a principal place of business in this State;

paragraph.text: hold a valid license issued under § 2–301 of this title; and
comply with regulations promulgated by the Board.

subsection.text: An individual who is not licensed to practice certified public accountancy in this State or another state may have an ownership interest in the partnership if:

paragraph.text: a simple majority of the ownership of the partnership, in terms of financial interests and voting rights, is held by individuals licensed to practice certified public accountancy in this or another state;
the individual is an active participant in the partnership or its affiliated entities;
the partnership designates, to the Board, a licensee of this State, or a qualified licensee of another state who is responsible for the registration of the partnership; and
the partnership complies with regulations adopted by the Board.

subsection.text: At least 1 general partner and any other partner who practices or intends to practice certified public accountancy in the State shall be licensed by the Board to practice certified public accountancy in the State or qualify for a practice privilege under § 2–321 of this title.
To qualify for a permit, a limited liability company shall meet the requirements of this section.
The limited liability company shall:

paragraph.text: have at least a simple majority of the officers, shareholders, members, or managers, in terms of financial interest and voting rights, be licensed in a state;

subparagraph.text: have a permanent office in the State from which an individual is licensed to practice certified public accountancy; or
have at least a simple majority of the officers, shareholders, members, or managers retain a principal place of business in this State;

paragraph.text: hold a valid license issued under § 2–301 of this title; and
comply with regulations adopted by the Board.

subsection.text: An individual who is not licensed to practice certified public accountancy in this State or another state may have an ownership interest in the limited liability company if:

paragraph.text: a simple majority of the ownership of the limited liability company, in terms of financial interests and voting rights, is held by individuals licensed to practice certified public accountancy in this or another state; and
the individual is an active participant in the limited liability company or affiliated entities.

subsection.text: To qualify for a permit, a corporation shall meet the requirements of this section.
The corporation shall meet the applicable requirements of the Maryland Professional Service Corporation Act or of the comparable law in another state.
The corporation shall:

paragraph.text: have at least a simple majority of the officers, shareholders, members, or managers, in terms of financial interest and voting rights, be licensed in a state; and

subparagraph.text: have a permanent office in the State from which an individual is licensed to practice certified public accountancy; or
have at least a simple majority of the officers, shareholders, members, or managers retain a principal place of business in this State;

paragraph.text: hold a valid license issued under § 2–301 of this title; and
comply with regulations adopted by the Board.

subsection.text: An individual who is not licensed to practice certified public accountancy in this State or another state may have an ownership interest in the corporation if:

paragraph.text: a simple majority of the ownership of the corporation, in terms of financial interests and voting rights, is held by individuals licensed to practice certified public accountancy in this or another state; and
the individual is an active participant in the corporation or affiliated entities;

the corporation submits to the Board the name of a licensee of this State, or, if applicable, a licensee of another state with a practice privilege in this State who is responsible for the registration of the corporation; and
the corporation complies with any other requirements that the Board imposes.

subsection.text: An applicant for a permit shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the Board an application on the form that the Board provides; and
pay to the Board a nonrefundable application fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: In addition to any other information required on an application form, the form shall require:

paragraph.text: for a partnership applicant, a list of each partner who practices or who intends to practice certified public accountancy in the State;
for a limited liability company, a list of each member who practices or who intends to practice certified public accountancy in the State; and
for a corporate applicant, a list of all of the shareholders of the corporation.

subsection.text: If an applicant qualifies for a permit under this subtitle, the Board shall send the applicant a notice that states that:

paragraph.text: the applicant has qualified for a permit; and
on receipt of a permit fee set by the Board, the Board will issue a permit to the applicant.

subsection.text: On payment of the permit fee, the Board shall issue a permit to each applicant that meets the requirements of this subtitle.
Subject to subsection (b) of this section and while a permit is in effect, it authorizes the holder to:

paragraph.text: operate a business through which an individual practices certified public accountancy; and
represent to the public that the business provides the services of a licensed certified public accountant.

subsection.text: A permit authorizes the holder to provide a service that constitutes practicing certified public accountancy only if the service is performed by an individual who is licensed or otherwise authorized under this title to practice.
A firm may use the title “CPA” or “CPA firm” without a permit issued under this section if the firm is performing other professional services that do not require a permit if:

paragraph.text: the firm performs those services through an individual with a practice privilege under § 2–321 of this title; and
the firm performs those services in the state where the individual with a practice privilege retains a principal place of business.

subsection.text: Unless a permit is renewed for a 2–year term as provided in this section, the permit expires on the first December 31 that comes:

paragraph.text: after the effective date of the permit; and
in an even–numbered year.

subsection.text: At least 1 month before a permit expires, the Board shall mail to the permit holder, at the last known address of the holder:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

subparagraph.text: the date on which the current permit expires;
the date by which the Board must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the permit expires; and
the amount of the permit fee.

subsection.text: Before a permit expires, the permit holder periodically may renew it for an additional 2–year term, if the holder:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to a permit;
pays to the Board a permit fee set by the Board; and
submits to the Board a renewal application on the form that the Board provides.

subsection.text: The Board shall renew the permit of each permit holder who meets the requirements of this section.
Within 1 month after the change or occurrence, a partnership that holds a permit shall give to the Board written notice of:

paragraph.text: a change in the name of the partnership;
the admission of any partner who practices or intends to practice certified public accountancy in the State;
the death of any partner who practiced certified public accountancy in the State; and
the withdrawal of any partner who practiced certified public accountancy in the State.

subsection.text: Within 1 month after the change or occurrence, a limited liability company that holds a permit shall give to the Board written notice of:

paragraph.text: a change in the name of the limited liability company;
the admission of any member who practices or intends to practice certified public accountancy in the State;
the death of any member who practiced certified public accountancy in the State; and
the withdrawal of any member who practiced certified public accountancy in the State.

subsection.text: Within 1 month after the change or occurrence, a corporation that holds a permit shall give to the Board written notice of:

paragraph.text: a change in the name of the corporation;
the death of any stockholder; and
a change in stockholders.

section.text: The surviving partner of a partnership that holds a permit may use the partnership name for 1 year after the death of the next to the last partner.

subsection.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 2–412 of this subtitle, the Board, on the affirmative vote of a majority of its members, may deny a permit to any applicant, reprimand a permit holder, or suspend or revoke a permit:

paragraph.text: for any applicable ground under § 2–315 of this title;
if the applicant or permit holder fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a permit;
if the applicant or permit holder fraudulently or deceptively uses a permit;
if the applicant or permit holder fails to meet or continue to meet the qualifications or requirements set forth under § 2–402 or § 2–403 of this subtitle; or
if the applicant or permit holder has a partner, member, or corporate officer whose license has been suspended or revoked by the Board.

subsection.text: On suspension or revocation of a permit, the holder shall surrender to the Board the permit certificate of the holder.
At the end of a suspension period, the Board shall return to the permit holder the permit certificate surrendered under this section.

paragraph.text: Instead of or in addition to reprimanding the permit holder or suspending or revoking a permit under this subsection, the Board may impose a penalty not exceeding $5,000 for each violation.
To determine the amount of the penalty imposed under this subsection, the Board shall consider:

subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the harm caused by the violation;
the good faith of the permit holder; and
any history of previous violations by the permit holder.

subsection.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

section.text: On its own initiative or on a written complaint made to the Board by any person, the Board may commence proceedings under § 2-410 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 10-226 of the State Government Article, before the Board takes any final action under § 2-410 of this subtitle, it shall give the person against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Board.
The Board shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Board may administer oaths in connection with any proceeding under this section.

paragraph.text: The Board may issue a subpoena for the attendance of a witness to testify or the production of evidence in connection with any proceeding under this section.
If a person fails to comply with a subpoena issued under this subsection, on petition of the Board, a circuit court may compel compliance with the subpoena.

subsection.text: If, after due notice, the person against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, nevertheless the Board may hear and determine the matter.

paragraph.text: For the limited purpose set forth in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a permit shall remain in effect and may not expire by operation of law while the permit holder is under investigation by the Board or awaiting a hearing or disposition on charges subject to disciplinary action under this subtitle.

Any extension of a permit term caused under this subsection is effective only for the purpose of retaining the jurisdiction of the Board over the permit holder during the course of disciplinary proceedings and does not prevent the permit from expiring for any other purpose.

subsection.text: Unless the Board agrees to accept the surrender, a permit holder may not surrender a permit while the holder is under investigation or awaiting a hearing or disposition on charges subject to disciplinary action under this subtitle.
Subject to the provisions of this section, the Board may reinstate:

paragraph.text: any permit that has been revoked; or
before fulfillment of the conditions of the suspension, any permit that has been suspended.

subsection.text: A permit may be reinstated under this section only if:

paragraph.text: the partnership, limited liability company, or corporation whose permit has been revoked or suspended submits a written request to the Board;
the Board holds a hearing on the request;
the Board, by an affirmative vote of a majority of its members, votes to reinstate the permit; and
the partnership, limited liability company, or corporation pays to the Board a reinstatement fee set by the Board.

section.text: After the Board issues a permit, the permit holder shall continue to comply with the respective requirements of § 2-402 or § 2-403 of this subtitle.
In accordance with its regulations, the Board may reinstate the permit of a firm that has failed to renew the permit for any reason if the firm:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to a permit; and
pays to the Board a reinstatement fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Engagement review” means a peer review that evaluates whether there is a reasonable basis for expressing limited assurance that:

paragraph.text: financial statements with which the individual or firm is associated conform in all material respects with professional standards; and
reports and internal documentation of the work performed by the individual or firm conforms with professional standards.

subsection.text: “Fail” means, in connection with a report of a peer reviewer, one or more significant deficiencies in performing or reporting in conformity with professional standards in the individual or the firm being reviewed.
“Peer review” means a study, appraisal, or review of one or more aspects of the professional work of an individual or firm performed by a person licensed as a certified public accountant.

“Report indicating pass with deficiencies” means a report of a peer reviewer that indicates one or more deficiencies in performing or reporting in conformity with professional standards in the individual or firm being reviewed.
“Review” means the analysis of a financial statement that:

paragraph.text: is performed in accordance with the Statements on Standards for Accounting and Review Services of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants; and

provides a licensee with a reasonable basis for expressing limited assurance that there are no material modifications that should be made to the statement in order for it to be in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, or, if applicable, with any other comprehensive basis of accounting.

subsection.text: “System review” means a peer review evaluating whether there is reasonable assurance that:

paragraph.text: the system of quality control of the individual or firm being reviewed is designed and operated in such a manner as to meet professional standards;
financial statements with which the licensee or firm is associated conform in all material respects with professional standards; and
reports and internal documentation of the work performed by the licensee or firm conforms with professional standards.
A licensee or permit holder who performs any of the services described in § 2-4A-04 of this subtitle shall be required to undergo, at least once every 3 years, a peer review.
The Board may modify the peer review requirement for a licensee or permit holder upon a showing of good cause.

subsection.text: A peer review shall be performed and recorded in accordance with standards no less stringent than those set forth in the standards for performing and reporting on peer reviews of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants.
The Board must approve a peer review program other than the peer review program of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants prior to its use to satisfy the requirements of this section.
A licensee or permit holder shall affirm under the penalties of perjury on a standard form provided by the Board compliance with the peer review requirement at the time of license or permit renewal.
A licensee or permit holder who provides services requiring peer review on or after October 1, 2005, shall comply with the peer review requirement within 3 years after initiating those services.

A licensee or permit holder who provides services requiring a peer review and who submits a renewal application after October 1, 2008, shall affirm under the penalties of perjury on a standard form provided by the Board completion of the licensee or permit holder’s most recent peer review.

If the 3-year period in subsection (a) of this section has not expired prior to the date of the license or permit renewal, and the licensee or permit holder has had no peer review within the last 3 years, the licensee or permit holder must notify the Board in writing within 30 days of the date the peer review is completed.
A system review is required for a licensee or permit holder that performs any of the following services:

paragraph.text: engagements governed by the Statements on Auditing Standards of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants; or
engagements governed by the government auditing standards issued by the U.S. Government Accountability Office;
examinations of prospective financial information under:

subparagraph.text: the Statements on Standards for Attestation Engagements of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants; or
the government auditing standards issued by the U.S. Government Accountability Office; or

paragraph.text: audits of issuers not registered with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission that are performed under standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board.

subsection.text: An engagement review is required for a licensee or permit holder not required to have a system review that performs any of the following services:

paragraph.text: review of historical financial statements in accordance with the Statements on Standards for Accounting and Review Services of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants;

compilation of historical financial statements with disclosures performed under the Statements on Standards for Accounting and Review Services of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants;

compilation of historical financial statements that omit substantially all disclosures performed under the Statements on Standards for Accounting and Review Services of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants; or

engagements performed under the Statements on Standards for Attestation Engagements of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants other than the examination of prospective financial statements.

subsection.text: Prior to conducting a peer review, an individual must be approved by the Board.
In order to receive approval from the Board, a peer reviewer shall:

paragraph.text: have and maintain an active license as a certified public accountant in this or any other state;
possess a level of knowledge of applicable professional standards acceptable to the Board;
possess at least 5 years recent experience in the practice of public accounting;
have received a passing report on the most recent peer review of the prospective peer reviewer; and
complete an appropriate training course as determined by the Board.

subsection.text: In order to serve as a team captain of a system review, a peer reviewer must have and maintain ownership or management of a firm or comparable responsibility.
A peer reviewer shall have no connection to the licensee or permit holder being reviewed that might impair the peer reviewer’s independence.
A peer reviewer shall:

paragraph.text: prepare a report of findings in accordance with the standards for performing and reporting on peer reviews of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants; and
maintain the report for a period of 3 years.

subsection.text: A peer reviewer shall provide a copy of the report to the Board only if the licensee or permit holder being reviewed has:

paragraph.text: been directed to take corrective action and has failed to satisfy the peer reviewer that such action has been completed in a timely manner;
received a second consecutive report indicating pass with deficiencies; or
received a failing report.

subsection.text: A peer reviewer shall comply with all Board regulations and directives regarding the peer review process.
The Board may revoke its approval of a peer reviewer under this section if the peer reviewer:

paragraph.text: violates any provision of this title;
violates any regulation adopted by the Board; or
is sanctioned by any state board of accountancy or any unit of State or federal government.

subsection.text: Upon the receipt of a report from a peer reviewer, the Board shall review the report to determine what disciplinary or corrective action is appropriate.
The Board may require a licensee or permit holder to:

paragraph.text: undergo peer review more frequently than once every 3 years; and
complete additional continuing professional education courses.

subsection.text: Prior to taking any final action under subsection (b) of this section, the Board shall give the licensee or permit holder against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Board.

If the peer review report reveals evidence that the licensee or permit holder has engaged in conduct that is prohibited under § 2-315 or § 2-410 of this title, the Board may file formal charges against the licensee or permit holder.

paragraph.text: The Board may adopt regulations to:

subparagraph.text: require that each office maintained in the State for the practice of accounting by an individual accountant or partnership or corporate permit holder be registered every 2 years with the Board by the individual, partnership, or corporation; and
set the procedure to carry out the registration.

paragraph.text: The Board may not charge a fee for any registration required under this section.

subsection.text: If a licensee or a permit holder fails to register any office as required by a regulation adopted under subsection (a) of this section, the license or permit shall:

paragraph.text: be suspended automatically; and
remain suspended until the licensee or permit holder complies with the registration requirements adopted under this section.

subsection.text: In this section, “accountant’s document”:

paragraph.text: means any of the following documents, if the document is prepared by an accountant in the course of professional service provided to a client:

subparagraph.text: a memorandum;
a record;
a schedule;
a statement; or
a working paper; and

paragraph.text: does not include any document provided by the client to the accountant.

subsection.text: Unless the client to whom an accountant’s document relates and the accountant expressly agree to the contrary, the accountant’s document is:

paragraph.text: the property of the accountant who prepared it; or
if the accountant is a partner or employee of an accounting firm, the property of the firm.

subsection.text: Unless the client or a personal representative or assignee of the client consents, an accountant who holds an accountant’s document that relates to a client may not give, sell, or otherwise transfer the accountant’s document to anyone other than a partner of the accountant.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, a person may not practice, attempt to practice, or offer to practice certified public accountancy in the State unless licensed by the Board or qualified for a practice privilege under § 2–321 of this title.

Except for a licensed certified public accountant or an individual practicing under a practice privilege under § 2–321 of this title who operates a business as a sole practitioner, a person may not operate a business through which certified public accountancy is practiced, unless:

paragraph.text: the business is a partnership, limited liability company, or corporation; and
except as otherwise provided under § 2–401 of this title, the partnership, limited liability company, or corporation holds a permit issued by the Board.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section and unless authorized under this title to practice certified public accountancy, a person may not represent to the public, by use of a title, including “licensed certified public accountant”, “certified public accountant”, “public accountant”, or “auditor”, by use of the abbreviation “CPA”, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person is authorized to practice certified public accountancy in the State.
Subsection (a) of this section does not prohibit:

paragraph.text: the description of a principal, officer, or employee of an organization by the position, title, or office that the individual holds in the organization; or

a partnership, limited liability company, or corporation that holds a permit or is exempt from the permit requirement under § 2–401 of this title from using, in connection with the name of the partnership, limited liability company, or corporation, any of the terms or the abbreviation to which subsection (a) of this section refers.

The display, distribution, or other use by a person of the person’s name, in conjunction with any of the following list of titles or abbreviations in a card, sign, advertisement, directory listing, or other instrument or device, is, in any proceeding under this title, prima facie evidence that the person represents to the public that the person is authorized to practice certified public accountancy:

subparagraph.text: “licensed certified public accountant”;
“certified public accountant”;
“public accountant”;
“auditor”; or
an abbreviation of any of these titles.

paragraph.text: In a proceeding under this title, evidence of a single representation described in paragraph (1) of this subsection is, without evidence of a general course of conduct, adequate to justify a finding that a person has represented to the public that the person is authorized to practice certified public accountancy in the State.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section and unless a person holds a permit issued by the Board or is otherwise authorized under this title to practice certified public accountancy, the person may not represent to the public, by use of a title, including “licensed certified public accountants”, “certified public accountants”, “public accountants”, or “auditors”, by use of the abbreviation “CPA”, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person holds a permit or otherwise is authorized to operate a business through which certified public accountancy is practiced in the State.

Subsection (a) of this section does not apply to a licensed certified public accountant or an individual practicing under a practice privilege under § 2–321 of this title who operates the business as a sole practitioner.
A person who violates any provision of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $500 or imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or both.

paragraph.text: The Board may impose on a person who violates any provision of this subtitle a penalty not exceeding $5,000 for each violation.
In setting the amount of the penalty, the Board shall consider:

subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the harm caused by the violation;
the good faith of the violator;
any history of previous violations by the violator; and
any other relevant factors.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

section.text: This title may be cited as the “Maryland Public Accountancy Act”.

Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, this title and all regulations adopted under this title shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2015.
