subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Architect” means an individual who practices architecture.
“Board” means, unless the context requires otherwise, the State Board of Architects.
“Code official” means a public official responsible for the review of building permit documents or the issuance of building permits.
“Contact hour” means a minimum of 50 minutes of actual class time for each 60–minute hour.
“Design coordination” means the review and coordination of services provided by individuals licensed or certified under Titles 3, 8, 9, 14, and 15 of this article.
“License” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a license issued by the Board to practice architecture.
“License fee” means, as applicable, the fee paid in connection with the issuance and renewal of a license and the issuance of a reciprocal license.
“Licensed architect” means, unless the context requires otherwise, an architect who is licensed by the Board to practice architecture.
“Permit” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a permit issued by the Board to allow a partnership or corporation to operate a business through which an individual may practice architecture.
“Permit fee” means, as applicable, the fee paid in connection with the issuance and renewal of a permit.

paragraph.text: “Practice architecture” means to provide any service or creative work:

subparagraph.text: in regard to an addition to, alteration of, or construction of a building or an integral part of a building; and
that requires education, training, and experience in architecture.

paragraph.text: “Practice architecture” includes:

subparagraph.text: architectural design and preparation of related documents;
consultation;
design coordination;
evaluation;
investigation; and
planning.

subsection.text: “Public use” means the use of a building or other structure for the primary purpose of human use or habitation.
“Residential use” means the use of a building or other structure as a dwelling.

section.text: The purposes of this title are to safeguard life, health, public safety, and property and to promote the public welfare by regulating persons who practice architecture in the State.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, all architectural documents prepared in connection with the addition, alteration, construction, or design of a building, an integral part of a building, or a group of buildings which are intended for public use or residential use shall be signed, sealed, and dated by a licensed architect in accordance with § 3-501 of this title.
A licensed architect may perform design coordination for a project or portion of a project provided that the licensed architect:

paragraph.text: holds a current license issued by the Board; and
has adequate experience in, and understanding of, achieving the purpose of the project or portion of the project being coordinated.

subsection.text: This title does not limit the right of:

paragraph.text: a construction contractor to administer construction contracts;

a developer, builder, or contractor to provide design services related to the developer’s, builder’s, or contractor’s own construction of new or existing single-family or two-family dwellings, or structures ancillary to them, or farm buildings;
a certified interior designer or other individual to provide interior design services as that term is defined in Title 8 of this article; or

an individual to prepare plans, drawings, and other documents in connection with the addition, alteration, construction, design, or repair of a single-family dwelling and appurtenances that are for the personal use of that individual or a member of the immediate family of that individual.
A person may not be required to employ a licensed architect in connection with the alteration or repair of an existing building or structure in a municipal corporation if the alteration or repair:

subparagraph.text: does not exceed $5,000 in estimated costs, including labor and materials;
is limited to:

sub-subparagraph.text: interior alterations or repairs;
storefronts or facades;
fixtures, cabinetwork or furniture; or
exterior stairways, landings, decks, and ramps; and

subparagraph.text: does not adversely affect the structural system of the building, including foundations, footings, walls, floors, roofs, bearing partitions, beams, columns, joists, or the mechanical, electrical, or plumbing systems.

paragraph.text: Any work performed under this subsection shall be in compliance with the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Maryland Building Performance Standards set forth in Title 12, Subtitle 5 of the Public Safety Article.
The exclusion provided for in this subsection shall be used only once per building or structure in a 12-month period.
A building permit issued under this subsection:

subparagraph.text: shall contain an affidavit signed by the person who has submitted the permit stating that the repair or alteration is in compliance with this subsection; and
may not be amended or revised in any way to cause the alteration or repair to exceed $5,000 in total costs, including labor and materials.

paragraph.text: Any building permit issued under this subsection that contains technical submissions that fail to conform to the requirements of this subsection shall be invalid.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (d) of this section, a code official may require that architectural documents for alterations or repairs of existing buildings or structures be signed and sealed by a licensed architect if the code official determines that the signature and seal of a licensed architect is necessary to provide conformity with the Maryland Building Performance Standards or to otherwise provide for the health and safety of the public.

section.text: There is a State Board of Architects in the Department.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of 7 members.
Of the 7 members of the Board:

subparagraph.text: 5 shall be licensed architects; and
2 shall be consumer members.

paragraph.text: The Governor shall appoint the members with the advice of the Secretary and the advice and consent of the Senate.

subsection.text: Each member of the Board shall be a resident and citizen of the State.
Of the 5 architect members of the Board:

paragraph.text: at least 3 shall be graduates of schools of architecture accredited by the National Architectural Accrediting Board; and
each shall have practiced architecture in the State, in private practice as a primary vocation, for at least 10 years before appointment.

subsection.text: Each consumer member of the Board:

paragraph.text: shall be a member of the general public;
may not be a licensee or otherwise be subject to regulation by the Board;
may not be required to meet the qualifications for the professional members of the Board; and
may not, within 1 year before appointment, have had a financial interest in or have received compensation from a person regulated by the Board.

subsection.text: While a member of the Board, a consumer member may not:

paragraph.text: have a financial interest in or receive compensation from a person regulated by the Board; or
grade any examination given by or for the Board.

subsection.text: Before taking office, each appointee to the Board shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 5 years and begins on July 1.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on October 1, 1989.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: The Governor may remove a member for incompetence or misconduct.

section.text: From among the members of the Board and with the advice of the Secretary, the Governor shall appoint a chairman.

subsection.text: A majority of the authorized membership of the Board is a quorum.
The Board shall determine the times and places of its meetings and hearings.
A member of the Board:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.
The Board may employ a staff in accordance with the State budget.
The Board may require the staff to be covered by a surety bond in the form and amount required by law.

section.text: At least annually, the chairman of the Board, the chairman of the State Board of Certified Interior Designers, the chairman of the State Board of Examiners of Landscape Architects, the chairman of the State Board for Professional Engineers, and the chairman of the State Board for Professional Land Surveyors shall meet to discuss issues of mutual importance to the design professions.
With the advice of the established architecture societies, the Board shall adopt, by regulation, a code of ethics for practicing architecture.

subsection.text: To enforce this title, the Board:

paragraph.text: may conduct investigations and hold hearings on any matter covered by this title, at any time and place in the State; and
subject to the State budget, may employ an investigative staff to:

subparagraph.text: investigate a complaint; and
perform any other related duty, as assigned by the Board.

subsection.text: To enforce this title, the Board may:

paragraph.text: administer oaths;
examine witnesses; and
receive evidence.
The Board may issue a subpoena for the attendance of a witness to testify or the production of evidence in connection with any investigation or hearing conducted under subsection (a) of this section.
A subpoena shall be signed by 3 members of the Board.
If a person fails to comply with a subpoena issued under this subsection, on petition of the Board, a circuit court may compel compliance with the subpoena.
The Board may sue in the name of the State to enforce any provision of this title by injunction.
In seeking an injunction under this subsection, the Board is not required to:

subparagraph.text: post bond; or
allege or prove either that:

sub-subparagraph.text: an adequate remedy at law does not exist; or
substantial or irreparable damage would result from the continued violation of the provision.

paragraph.text: A member of the Board or its staff may not be held personally liable for any action taken under this subsection in good faith and with reasonable grounds.

subsection.text: On request of any person and payment of a fee of $10, the Board shall certify the licensing or permit status and qualifications of any person who is the subject of the request.
Each certification under this section:

paragraph.text: shall include a statement of the licensing or permit status of the person who is the subject of the request; and
may include:

subparagraph.text: information about the examination results and other qualifications of that person;
information about the dates of issuance and renewal of the license or permit of that person;
information about any disciplinary action taken against that person; and
if authorized by that person, information about any complaint against that person.

subsection.text: In addition to any powers set forth elsewhere, the Board may adopt:

paragraph.text: any regulation to carry out this title; and
a seal.

subsection.text: In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere, the Board shall keep a record of its proceedings.
In this section, “code official” means a public official responsible for the review of building permit documents or the issuance of building permits.
The Board shall:

paragraph.text: keep a list of the names and mailing addresses of all licensees;
provide each code official with a copy of the list annually; and
provide any other person who makes a request with a copy of the list at a reasonable fee set by the Board.
The Board shall provide all licensees and code officials with a periodic newsletter not less than semiannually on the activities of the Board.

The Board shall publish, on the Department website, the newsletter jointly with the State Board for Professional Engineers, the State Board of Certified Interior Designers, the State Board of Examiners of Landscape Architects, and the State Board for Professional Land Surveyors.

subsection.text: The Board shall distribute:

paragraph.text: to each applicant for a license and each code official, a copy of the Maryland Architects Act and the Board’s rules and regulations;

on each renewal of a license, to each licensee, a copy of any amendments to the Maryland Architects Act and the Board’s rules and regulations that took effect during the 2-year period ending on the date of renewal; and
to each code official, a copy of any amendments to the Maryland Architects Act and the Board’s rules and regulations.

subsection.text: A licensee shall designate the licensee’s mailing address at the time of issuance of the license and on each renewal of the license.

paragraph.text: The Board may set reasonable fees for its services.

The fees charged shall be set so as to produce funds to approximate the cost of maintaining the Board and shall be based on the calculations performed by the Secretary under § 2–106.2 of the Business Regulation Article.

subsection.text: The Board shall publish the fee schedule set by the Board by regulation.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay all fees collected under this title to the Comptroller of the State.
The Comptroller shall distribute the fees to the State Occupational and Professional Licensing Design Boards’ Fund established in § 2–106.1 of the Business Regulation Article.

subsection.text: Any person aggrieved by any final action of the Board may take an appeal as allowed in §§ 10-222 and 10-223 of the State Government Article.
The Board may appeal from a decision of the circuit court.

section.text: The Board exercises its powers, duties, and functions subject to the authority of the Secretary.
In this subtitle, “Council” means the National Council of Architectural Registration Boards.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, an individual shall be licensed by the Board before the individual may practice architecture in the State.

paragraph.text: An architect who resides outside the State and meets the requirements for a license by reciprocity under § 3-306 of this subtitle may:

subparagraph.text: offer to practice architecture in the State; and
accept a commission to practice architecture in the State.

paragraph.text: Notwithstanding paragraph (1) of this subsection, the architect shall be licensed by the Board before the architect may practice architecture in the State.

subsection.text: To qualify for a license, an applicant shall be an individual who meets the requirements of this section.
An applicant shall be of good character and reputation.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the applicant shall:

subparagraph.text: hold a degree in architecture from:

sub-subparagraph.text: a school of architecture that is located in the United States and that, within 2 years after the applicant’s graduation, holds accredited status from the National Architectural Accrediting Board; or
a foreign school of architecture that the Board determines is comparable to an accredited school of architecture in the United States; and

subparagraph.text: have practical work experience or additional academic training in architecture that the Board considers appropriate.

paragraph.text: The Board shall exempt an applicant from the degree requirements of paragraph (1)(i) of this subsection if the applicant has practical work experience and academic training in architecture that the Board considers appropriate.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, an applicant shall pass the examination given by the Board under this subtitle.

In addition to the other requirements of this section, the Board may require an applicant to satisfy any additional licensing requirements that the Board adopts from the licensing guidelines published by the Council.

section.text: An applicant for a license shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the Board an application on the form that the Board provides; and
pay to the Board or the Board’s designee:

subparagraph.text: a nonrefundable application fee set by the Board; and
an examination fee set by the Board in an amount not to exceed the cost of the required examination.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 3-305.1 of this subtitle, an applicant who otherwise qualifies for a license is entitled to be examined as provided in this section.
The Board shall give examinations to qualified applicants at least once a year at the time and place that the Board determines.
The Board shall give each qualified applicant notice of the time and place of examination.

paragraph.text: The Board shall determine the subjects, scope, and form of and the passing score for examinations given under this title.
The Board may adopt an examination or a recommended grading procedure of the Council or any similar organization.

subsection.text: The Board may use a testing service to administer examinations given under this title.
If the Board uses a testing service, the testing service, subject to the requirements set by the Board, may:

paragraph.text: set the time and place of examinations;
give qualified applicants notice of the time and place of examinations; and
furnish any other information that the Board may require the testing service to provide.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of this section, the Board may issue a license by reciprocity to practice architecture in the State to an individual who:

paragraph.text: is licensed to practice architecture in another state or country; or
is certified by the Council under subsection (c) of this section.

subsection.text: The Board may issue a license by reciprocity under this section for an applicant who is licensed to practice architecture in another state or country only if the applicant:

paragraph.text: is of good character and reputation;
pays to the Board:

subparagraph.text: a nonrefundable application fee set by the Board; and
a license fee set by the Board; and

paragraph.text: provides adequate evidence that:

subparagraph.text: the applicant became licensed in the other state or country after meeting, in that or any other state or country, requirements that were at least equivalent to those then required by the laws of this State; or
at the time of application for a license by reciprocity under this section, the applicant meets the requirements currently required by the laws of this State.

subsection.text: The Board may issue a license by reciprocity under this section for an applicant who is certified by the Council only if:

paragraph.text: the applicant:

subparagraph.text: is of good character and reputation; and
pays to the Board:

sub-subparagraph.text: a nonrefundable application fee set by the Board; and
a license fee set by the Board; and

paragraph.text: the Board receives from the Council a certified copy of its certificate for the applicant that certifies that the applicant is licensed to practice architecture in another state or country.

subsection.text: An architect who is granted a license by reciprocity by the Board may not be required to maintain licensure in any other state or country as a condition of maintaining the license granted by the Board.
If an applicant qualifies for a license by passing an examination under this subtitle, the Board shall send the applicant a notice that states that:

paragraph.text: the applicant has qualified for a license; and
on receipt of a license fee set by the Board, the Board will issue a license to the applicant.
On payment of the license fee, the Board shall issue a license to each applicant who meets the requirements for a license through examination under § 3–305 of this subtitle.
The Board shall issue a license to each applicant who meets the requirements for a license by reciprocity under § 3–306 of this subtitle.

section.text: While a license is in effect, it authorizes the licensee to practice architecture.

subsection.text: Unless a license is renewed for a 2–year term as provided in this section, the license expires on the first June 30 that comes:

paragraph.text: after the effective date of the license; and
in an even–numbered year.

subsection.text: At least 1 month before a license expires, the Board shall mail to the licensee, at the last known address of the licensee:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

subparagraph.text: the date on which the current license expires;
the date by which the Board must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the license expires; and
the amount of the license fee.

subsection.text: Before a license expires, the licensee periodically may renew it for an additional 2–year term, if the licensee:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be licensed;
pays to the Board a license fee set by the Board;
submits to the Board a renewal application on the form that the Board provides; and

upon request by the Board, submits to the Board the original certificate of completion or transcript of completed courses verifying the licensee has complied with the continuing professional competency requirement under § 3–309.1 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Board shall renew the license of each licensee who meets the requirements of this section.
An architect has a grace period of 30 days after the architect’s license expires in which to renew it retroactively, if the architect:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to have the license renewed;
pays to the Board the license fee set by the Board; and
meets the continuing education requirement for renewal of a license under § 3–309.1 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Secretary may determine that licenses issued under this subtitle shall expire on a staggered basis.

section.text: The Board shall adopt regulations to require a licensee to demonstrate continuing professional competency by completing at least 24 hours of professional development activities as a condition of renewal of a license under this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Board may issue a retired status license to an individual who:

paragraph.text: is currently licensed by the Board to practice architecture;
has been a licensed architect for at least 25 years, of which 5 years have been in Maryland;
is not the subject of a pending disciplinary action related to the practice of architecture in this or another state;
submits to the Board an application on the form provided by the Board; and
pays to the Board a fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: The holder of a retired status license issued under this section:

paragraph.text: may use the designation of “architect emeritus”; but
may not engage in the practice of architecture.

subsection.text: The Board may reactivate the license of an individual who holds a retired status license if that individual:

paragraph.text: submits to the Board an application for reactivation on the form provided by the Board;

meets all continuing professional competency requirements that would have been required for renewal of a license under § 3–309.1 of this subtitle if the individual had not been issued a retired status license;
is not the subject of a pending disciplinary action related to the practice of architecture in this or any other state; and
pays to the Board a reactivation fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: The Board shall reinstate the license of an architect who, for any reason, has failed to renew the license by the end of the 30–day grace period if the architect:

paragraph.text: meets the renewal requirements of § 3–309 of this subtitle;
except as otherwise provided in subsection (b) of this section, pays to the Board a reinstatement fee set by the Board;
submits to the Board a reinstatement application on the form that the Board provides; and
meets the continuing professional competency requirement that would have been required for renewal of a license under § 3–309.1 of this subtitle, if the license had not expired.

subsection.text: The Board may waive a reinstatement fee for a licensee who provides evidence satisfactory to the Board that the licensee did not practice architecture during the time the license lapsed.

paragraph.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 3–313 of this subtitle, the Board, on the affirmative vote of a majority of its authorized membership, may deny a license to any applicant, reprimand any licensee, or suspend or revoke a license if:

subparagraph.text: the applicant or licensee fraudulently or deceptively obtains or renews or attempts to obtain or renew a license or permit for the applicant or licensee or for another;
the applicant or licensee fraudulently or deceptively uses a license;
the applicant or licensee is guilty of any fraud, gross negligence, incompetence, or misconduct while practicing architecture;
the applicant or licensee violates any regulation adopted by the Board;
the applicant or licensee violates any provision of this title;
the applicant or licensee aids or abets an unauthorized person to practice architecture;
under the laws of the United States or of any state, the applicant or licensee is convicted of:

sub-subparagraph.text: a felony; or
a misdemeanor that is directly related to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to practice architecture; or

subparagraph.text: the applicant or licensee has had a license to practice architecture in another state revoked or suspended for grounds that would justify revocation or suspension of a license under this title, except for failure to pay a license fee.
Instead of or in addition to reprimanding the licensee or suspending or revoking a license under this subsection, the Board may impose a penalty not exceeding $5,000 for each violation.
To determine the amount of the penalty imposed under this subsection, the Board shall consider:

sub-subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the harm caused by the violation;
the good faith of the licensee; and
any history of previous violations by the licensee.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: The Board shall consider the following facts in the granting, denial, renewal, suspension, or revocation of a license or the reprimand of a licensee when an applicant or licensee is convicted of a felony or misdemeanor described in subsection (a)(1)(vii) of this section:

paragraph.text: the nature of the crime;
the relationship of the crime to the activities authorized by the license;
with respect to a felony, the relevance of the conviction to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to practice architecture;
the length of time since the conviction; and
the behavior and activities of the applicant or licensee before and after the conviction.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of this section, the Board shall commence proceedings under § 3-311 of this subtitle on a complaint made to the Board by a member of the Board or any other person.

paragraph.text: A complaint shall:

subparagraph.text: be in writing; and
state specifically the facts on which the complaint is based.

paragraph.text: If the complaint is made by any person other than a member of the Board, the complaint shall be made under oath by the person who submits the complaint.

subsection.text: If the Board finds that a complaint alleges facts that are adequate grounds for action under § 3-311 of this subtitle, the Board shall act on the complaint as provided under § 3-313 of this subtitle. If the Board does not make that finding, it shall dismiss the complaint.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 10-226 of the State Government Article, before the Board takes any final action under § 3-311 of this subtitle, it shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Board.
A hearing shall be held within a reasonable time, not exceeding 6 months, after the complaint is made.

subsection.text: The Board shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
At least 30 days before the hearing, the hearing notice and a copy of the complaint shall be:

paragraph.text: served personally on the individual; or
mailed to the last known address of the individual.

subsection.text: The individual may be represented at the hearing by counsel.
If, after due notice, the individual against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, nevertheless the Board may hear and determine the matter.

section.text: In this subtitle, “responsible member” means a director of a corporation, a member of a limited liability company, or partner who is appointed under § 3-404(c) of this subtitle to be in responsible charge of architecture practiced through the corporation, limited liability company, or partnership.

paragraph.text: Subject to the provisions of this subtitle, a licensed architect may practice architecture for others through:

subparagraph.text: a corporation as an officer, director, employee, or agent of the corporation;
a limited liability company as a member, employee, or agent of the limited liability company; or
a partnership as a partner, employee, or agent of the partnership.

paragraph.text: Subject to the provisions of this subtitle, a corporation, limited liability company, or partnership may provide architectural services through a licensed architect.

subsection.text: A licensed architect who practices architecture through a corporation, limited liability company, or partnership under this subtitle is subject to all of the provisions of this title that relate to practicing architecture.

paragraph.text: A corporation, limited liability company, or partnership that provides architectural services under this subtitle is not, by its compliance with this subtitle, relieved of any responsibility that the corporation, limited liability company, or partnership may have for an act or omission of its officer, director, member, partner, employee, or agent.

An individual who practices architecture through a corporation, limited liability company, or partnership is not, by reason of the individual’s employment or other relationship with the corporation, limited liability company, or partnership, relieved of any individual responsibility that the individual may have regarding that practice.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a corporation, limited liability company, or partnership shall hold a permit issued by the Board before the corporation, limited liability company, or partnership may operate a business through which architecture is practiced.
A corporation may provide architectural services for itself or for an affiliated corporation without a permit issued by the Board.
To qualify for a permit, a corporation, limited liability company, or partnership shall meet the requirements of this section.

paragraph.text: At least two-thirds of the directors of a corporation shall be licensed in this or another state to practice architecture, engineering, or landscape architecture.

subparagraph.text: At least two-thirds of the partners of a partnership shall be licensed in this or another state to practice architecture, engineering, or landscape architecture.

If the partnership is a limited partnership, at least two-thirds of the general partners of the limited partnership shall be licensed in this or another state to practice architecture, engineering, or landscape architecture.

paragraph.text: At least two-thirds of the members of a limited liability company shall be licensed in this or another state to practice architecture, engineering, or landscape architecture.
A corporation, limited liability company, or partnership shall have appointed at least 1 responsible member of the corporation, limited liability company, or partnership.
A responsible member shall be in charge of architecture practiced through the corporation, limited liability company, or partnership.
Each responsible member shall be:

subparagraph.text: a director of a corporation, a member of a limited liability company, or a partner of a partnership; and
a licensed architect.

subsection.text: An applicant for a permit shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the Board an application on the form that the Board provides; and
pay to the Board a nonrefundable application fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: In addition to any other information required on an application form, the form shall require the name and address of:

paragraph.text: each responsible member of a corporation, limited liability company, or partnership;
each officer and director of a corporation;
each member of a limited liability company; and
each partner of a partnership.

section.text: The Board shall issue a permit to each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle and pays to the Board a permit fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section and while a permit is in effect, it authorizes the holder to:

paragraph.text: operate a business through which a licensed architect practices architecture; and
represent to the public that the business provides the services of a licensed architect.

subsection.text: A permit authorizes the holder to provide a service that constitutes practicing architecture only if the service is performed by an individual who is licensed or otherwise authorized under this title to practice architecture.
Unless a permit is renewed for a 2–year term as provided in this section, the permit expires on the first June 30 that comes:

paragraph.text: after the effective date of the permit; and
in an even–numbered year.

subsection.text: At least 1 month before a permit expires, the Board shall mail to the permit holder, at the last known address of the permit holder:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

subparagraph.text: the date on which the current permit expires;
the date by which the Board must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the permit expires; and
the amount of the permit fee.

subsection.text: Before a permit expires, the permit holder periodically may renew it for an additional 2–year term, if the holder:

paragraph.text: meets the qualifications for a permit under § 3–404 of this subtitle;
otherwise is entitled to a permit;
pays to the Board the permit fee set by the Board; and
submits to the Board a renewal application on the form that the Board provides.

subsection.text: The renewal application form shall require the same information required on the original application form under § 3–405(b) of this subtitle.
The Board shall renew the permit of each permit holder who meets the requirements of this section.

A corporation, limited liability company, or partnership has a grace period of 30 days after the permit of the corporation, limited liability company, or partnership expires in which to renew it retroactively, if the corporation, limited liability company, or partnership:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to have the permit renewed; and
pays to the Board the permit fee set by the Board.

section.text: Within 1 month after the effective date of the change, a permit holder shall submit to the Board an application form that shows a change in the name of:

paragraph.text: a responsible member of the holder;
an officer or director, if the holder is a corporation;
a member, if the holder is a limited liability company; or
a partner, if the holder is a partnership.

subsection.text: Before a licensed architect issues to a client or submits to a public authority any final drawing, plan, specification, report, or other document required for the issuance of a building permit, the licensed architect who prepared or approved the document shall sign, seal, and date the document.

Subject to exceptions stated and rights granted under § 3-103 of this title, a public authority may not accept any architectural drawing, plan, specification, report, or other document, unless the document is endorsed as required under subsection (a) of this section.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, a person may not practice, attempt to practice, or offer to practice architecture in the State unless licensed by the Board.
Except for a licensed architect who operates a business as a sole practitioner, a person may not operate a business through which architecture is practiced, unless:

paragraph.text: the business is a corporation or a partnership; and
the corporation or partnership holds a permit issued by the Board.

section.text: Unless authorized under this title to practice architecture, a person may not represent to the public, by use of a title, including “architect”, “licensed architect”, or “registered architect”, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person is authorized to practice architecture in the State.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section and unless a person holds a permit issued by the Board, the person may not represent to the public, by the use of the titles “architects”, “licensed architects”, or “registered architects”, by the use of the term “architecture”, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise that the person holds a permit or otherwise is authorized to operate a business through which architecture is practiced in the State.
Subsection (a) of this section does not apply to a licensed architect who operates the business as the sole practitioner.

A person who violates § 3-601, § 3-602, § 3-603, or § 3-604 of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $3,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.

paragraph.text: The Board may impose on a person who violates § 3-601, § 3-602, § 3-603, or § 3-604 of this subtitle a penalty not exceeding $5,000 for each violation.
In setting the amount of the penalty, the Board shall consider:

subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the harm caused by the violation;
the good faith of the violator;
any history of previous violations by the violator; and
any other relevant factors.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

section.text: If the Board believes that a person has violated § 3-601, § 3-602, § 3-603, or § 3-604 of this subtitle, the Board immediately shall report the alleged violation to the appropriate State’s Attorney or, if the alleged violation affects more than 1 county, to the Attorney General.
This title may be cited as the “Maryland Architects Act”.

Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, this title and all regulations adopted under this title shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2023.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Apprentice barber” means an individual who, under the supervision of a master barber, is learning to practice barbering in a barbershop that holds a barbershop permit.
“Barber” means an individual who practices barbering.

paragraph.text: “Barbershop” means any commercial establishment, except a beauty salon, in which an individual practices barbering.
“Barbershop” does not include a clinic in a barber school.

subsection.text: “Barbershop permit” means a permit issued by the Board to operate a barbershop.
“Board” means the State Board of Barbers.

paragraph.text: “License” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a license issued by the Board to practice barbering.
“License” includes, unless the context requires otherwise, each of the following licenses:

subparagraph.text: a master barber license; and
a barber license.

subsection.text: “Master barber” means a barber who:

paragraph.text: has at least 15 months experience as a licensed barber; and
has passed a test approved by the Board.
“Practice barbering” means to provide to an individual for compensation the service of:

subparagraph.text: cutting, razor cutting, styling, relaxing, body waving, shampooing, or coloring the hair;
shaving or trimming the beard;
massaging the face;
designing, fitting, or cutting a hairpiece; or
performing any other similar procedure on the hair, beard, face, or hairpiece of the individual.

paragraph.text: “Practice barbering” does not include:

subparagraph.text: the mere sale of wigs or hairpieces; or
the services performed by an employee under the supervision of a master barber in a barbershop that holds a barbershop permit that are restricted to:

sub-subparagraph.text: shampooing;
removal of a hair solution;
sterilization of equipment; or
similar activities.

section.text: This title does not prohibit an individual who is authorized to practice cosmetology under Title 5 of this article from practicing cosmetology.
There is a State Board of Barbers in the Department.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of 7 members.
Of the 7 members of the Board:

subparagraph.text: 5 shall be master barbers; and
2 shall be consumer members.

paragraph.text: The Governor shall appoint the members with the advice of the Secretary.

subsection.text: Each master barber member of the Board shall have practiced barbering in the State continuously for at least 5 years before appointment.
Each consumer member of the Board:

paragraph.text: shall be a member of the general public;
may not be a licensee or otherwise be subject to regulation by the Board;
may not be required to meet the qualifications for the professional members of the Board; and
may not, within 1 year before appointment, have had a financial interest in or have received compensation from a person regulated by the Board.

subsection.text: While a member of the Board, a consumer member may not:

paragraph.text: have a financial interest in or receive compensation from a person regulated by the Board; or
grade any examination given by or for the Board.

subsection.text: Before taking office, each appointee to the Board shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 5 years and begins on July 1.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on October 1, 1989.
A member may not serve more than 2 consecutive terms.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: The Governor may remove a member for incompetence or misconduct.

section.text: From among the members of the Board, the Governor shall appoint a president, treasurer, and secretary.

subsection.text: A majority of the authorized membership of the Board is a quorum.
The Board shall determine the times and places of its meetings.
Subject to the State budget, each member of the Board is entitled to:

paragraph.text: a reasonable fee set by the Board for each day on which the member is engaged in the duties of office; and
reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations.

subsection.text: The Board may employ a staff in accordance with the State budget.
On request of any person and payment of a certification fee, the Board shall certify the licensing, registration, or permit status and qualifications of any person who is the subject of the request.
Each certification under this section:

paragraph.text: shall include a statement of the licensing, registration, or permit status of the person who is the subject of the request; and
may include:

subparagraph.text: information about the examination results and other qualifications of that person;
information about the dates of issuance and renewal of the license, registration, or permit of that person;
information about any disciplinary action taken against that person; and
if authorized by that person, information about any complaint against that person.

subsection.text: The Board shall collect the certification fee established by the Board in accordance with § 4-206 of this subtitle for each certification under this section.

paragraph.text: In addition to any powers set forth elsewhere, the Board may adopt any regulation to carry out this title.

subparagraph.text: The Board shall establish reasonable fees for examinations, licensing, licensing renewal, reinstatement, certification, applications, preopening inspections, per diem fees for Board members, compensation for inspectors appointed by the Board, and any other service performed by the Board necessary to carry out the provisions of this title.

sub-subparagraph.text: Except for examination fees which the Board shall establish in amounts not to exceed the costs of the required examinations and subject to subsubparagraph 2 of this subparagraph, the fees established by the Board shall be set in a manner that will produce funds sufficient to cover the actual direct and indirect costs of regulating the barber industry in this State in accordance with the provisions of this title.
The Board may not set fees for licensing and license renewals that exceed $50.

subparagraph.text: The total cost of regulating the barber industry in this State in accordance with the provisions of this title may not be more than the revenues generated by the fees established under subparagraph (i) of this paragraph.

paragraph.text: The Board shall adopt regulations that establish detailed curriculum standards for use by the State Board of Education or the Maryland Higher Education Commission in approving applications for instruction in the practice of barbering at public schools or private career schools.
The curriculum standards established under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall:

subparagraph.text: incorporate modern methods and practices of barbering;
include a reference to each topic and the emphasis of each topic required of a comprehensive barbering curriculum; and
be reviewed and updated periodically as determined by the Board.

subsection.text: In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere, the Board shall administer and enforce this title.

section.text: The Board shall pay all money collected under this title into the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: Any person aggrieved by a final decision of the Board in a contested case, as defined in § 10-202 of the State Government Article, may take an appeal as allowed in §§ 10-222 and 10-223 of the State Government Article.
The Board may appeal from a decision of the circuit court.

section.text: The Board exercises its powers, duties, and functions subject to the authority of the Secretary.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, an individual shall be licensed by the Board to practice barbering before the individual may practice barbering in the State.
This section does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a student while the student practices barbering in accordance with § 4-301.1 or § 4-301.2 of this subtitle;
a registered apprentice barber; or
an individual authorized in the discretion of the Board to practice barbering under special circumstances.
Subject to the provisions of this subsection, a student who has completed at least 80 hours of training at a school of barbering may practice barbering, without a license, at the school.
A student may practice barbering under this subsection only:

subparagraph.text: in the course of the practical work required as part of the training of the student;

while the student is under the direct supervision of a teacher who meets the requirements established by the Department of Education for public school programs or the Maryland Higher Education Commission for private school programs; and
if the individual to whom a service is to be provided agrees to the service after being informed that a student in training is to provide the service.

paragraph.text: Subject to the provisions of this subsection, a student who has completed at least 850 hours of training at a school of barbering may practice barbering, without a license, in a:

subparagraph.text: hospital;
nursing home; or
correctional facility that does not house a barber school.

paragraph.text: A student may practice barbering under this subsection only:

subparagraph.text: in the course of the practical work required as part of the training of the student;

while the student is under the direct supervision of a teacher who meets the requirements established by the Department of Education for public school programs or the Maryland Higher Education Commission for private school programs; and
if the individual to whom a service is to be provided:

sub-subparagraph.text: is confined to a hospital, nursing home, or correctional facility that does not house a barber school; and
agrees to the service after being informed that a student in training is to provide the service.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of this section, a student who has completed at least 850 hours of training while enrolled in public school courses in barbering may practice barbering without a license.
A student may practice barbering under this section only if the student:

paragraph.text: is enrolled in an approved barbering program and has a record of satisfactory school performance and school attendance, as determined by the local education agency;
has a letter of authorization signed by the student’s teacher or work-study coordinator, to practice barbering in a specific licensed barbershop;
practices barbering only in that specific licensed barbershop; and

while practicing barbering, works under the direct supervision of an individual who is a licensed master barber who agrees to periodically report on the progress of the student to the barbering teacher or the work-study coordinator.

subsection.text: Under this section, there may not be more than one student working under the supervision of a licensed master barber.
A barbershop may pay a student for work authorized under this section.

A student authorized under this section to practice barbering without a license shall conspicuously display a letter of authorization, as required by this section, at the student’s work station in the specified licensed barbershop.
To qualify for a license to practice barbering, an applicant shall be an individual who meets the requirements of this section.

paragraph.text: An applicant for a barber license shall have completed successfully:

subparagraph.text: a required program of at least 1,200 hours of training in a barber school that is approved by the State Department of Education or the Maryland Higher Education Commission, in consultation with the Board; or
an apprenticeship of at least 2,250 hours within 2 years in a barbershop that holds a barbershop permit under the supervision of a master barber.

paragraph.text: If the applicant for a barber license is an individual trained and currently licensed as a cosmetologist in the State, the Board shall:

subparagraph.text: credit the applicant with having met one-half of the training requirement of paragraph (1) of this subsection; and
determine the manner in which the credit will be applied.

paragraph.text: The Board may credit an applicant with the number of hours of training the applicant completes in a barber school toward the number of hours required for an apprenticeship if the barber school where the applicant completes the training:

subparagraph.text: is located in a detention center or correctional facility; and

sub-subparagraph.text: is approved by the State Department of Education or the Maryland Higher Education Commission; or
has a curriculum similar to one that is approved by the State Department of Education or the Maryland Higher Education Commission.

paragraph.text: The Board may not credit more than 600 hours of training to an individual under paragraph (3) of this subsection.

subsection.text: An applicant for a master barber license shall have at least 15 months of experience as a barber.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, an applicant for a master barber license shall pass an examination given by the Board or the Board’s designee under this subtitle.
Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, an applicant for a barber license shall pass an examination given by the Board or the Board’s designee under this subtitle.

section.text: An applicant for a license shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the Board an application on the form that the Board provides; and
pay to the Board an examination fee established by the Board in an amount not to exceed the cost of the required examination.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 4-304.1 of this subtitle, an applicant is entitled to be examined as provided in this section if the applicant:

paragraph.text: otherwise qualifies for a license under this title; and
pays an examination fee established by the Board in accordance with §§ 4-206 and 4-303 of this title to the Board or the Board’s designee.

subsection.text: The Board periodically shall give examinations to applicants at the times and places that the Board determines.
The Board shall give each qualified applicant notice of the time and place of examination.

paragraph.text: The Board shall determine the subjects, scope, and form of and the passing score for examinations given under this subtitle.
An examination may consist of written and practical parts.

Subject to § 2-110 of the Business Regulation Article, an applicant whose primary language is not English may use a Board approved interpreter for the written part of an examination, but not for the practical part of an examination.

The passing of the practical part of an examination without an interpreter demonstrates that the applicant possesses sufficient command of English to understand and properly respond to an English-speaking customer.

subsection.text: Subject to § 2-110 of the Business Regulation Article, in the case of an applicant who demonstrates dyslexia or other reading impairment to the Board:

paragraph.text: the Board may grant 1 or both of the following:

subparagraph.text: additional time to complete all or part of the examination; or
oral examination for all or part of the written part of the examination.

paragraph.text: the Board shall approve for licensing an applicant who:

subparagraph.text: passes the examination; and
demonstrates to the Board that the applicant's dyslexia or other reading impairment, if any, does not significantly impair the applicant's ability to function as a licensee.

subsection.text: If an applicant fails to appear for a scheduled examination, the Board may require the applicant to pay another examination fee under § 4-303 of this subtitle before rescheduling an examination for the applicant.
The Board may use a testing service to administer examinations given under this title.
If the Board uses a testing service, the testing service, subject to the requirements set by the Board, may:

paragraph.text: set the time and place of examinations;
give qualified applicants notice of the time and place of examinations; and
furnish any other information that the Board may require the testing service to provide.

subsection.text: The Board or the Board’s designees shall mail to each applicant notice of the applicant’s examination results.

Subject to the provisions of this section and of § 4-306 of this subtitle, the Board may waive any requirement of this subtitle for an individual who is licensed to practice barbering in another state.
The Board may grant a waiver under this section only if the applicant:

paragraph.text: pays the examination fee required under § 4-303 of this subtitle;

provides adequate evidence that the applicant has been licensed as a barber or master barber, whichever is applicable, in another state for at least the 6 months immediately preceding the filing of the application; and
passes the applicable examination.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of this section, the Board may waive any examination requirement of this subtitle for an applicant for a master barber or a barber license who is licensed to practice barbering in another state.
The Board may grant a waiver under this section only if:

paragraph.text: the applicant pays the application fee set by the Board under § 4-206 and any applicable examination fee required under § 4-303 of this subtitle for any examination requirement that is not waived by the Board;
the applicant provides adequate evidence that the applicant:

subparagraph.text: meets the qualifications otherwise required by this subtitle; and
became licensed in the other state after passing, in that or any other state, an examination that is similar to the examination for which the applicant is seeking the waiver;

paragraph.text: the applicant practiced barbering in the other state as a master barber or barber during the 2 years immediately before applying in this State;
the applicant provides:

subparagraph.text: a notarized statement from a previous employer certifying that the applicant has the experience required under item (3) of this subsection; or
if the applicant was self-employed, other proof that is acceptable to the Board;

paragraph.text: the applicant submits a letter from the licensing board of the other state certifying that the applicant is in good standing with the board of the other state; and
the applicant certifies in writing that the applicant has read, understands, and will comply with the provisions of this title and the regulations of the Board.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of this section, the Board may waive the written part of the master barber or barber examination for an individual who is licensed to practice barbering in a foreign country.
Subject to subsection (c) of this section, the Board may grant a waiver under this section only if the applicant:

paragraph.text: pays the examination fee required under § 4-303 of this subtitle that is attributable to the practical part of the examination;
passes the practical part of the master barber or barber examination given by the Board; and

provides adequate evidence that, at the time the applicant was licensed in the foreign country, the applicant was required to pass an examination and meet qualifications that were substantially equivalent to those then required by the laws of this State.

subsection.text: To meet a minimum standard of training, the Board may require an applicant licensed to practice barbering in a foreign country to complete successfully a required program of training in the practice of barbering not exceeding 1,200 hours.
If an applicant qualifies for a license under this subtitle, the Board shall send the applicant a notice that states that:

paragraph.text: the applicant has qualified for a license; and
the Board will issue the license to the applicant, on receipt of the appropriate license fee established by the Board in accordance with § 4-206 of this title.

subsection.text: On payment of the appropriate license fee, the Board shall issue a license to each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle.
Subject to § 4-605 of this title, while a master barber license is in effect, it authorizes the licensee to:

paragraph.text: practice barbering; and
supervise an apprentice barber.

subsection.text: Subject to § 4-605 of this title, while a barber license is in effect, it authorizes the licensee to practice barbering.
The initial term of a license is 2 years.
A license expires on the date set by the Board unless the license is renewed for an additional term as provided in this section.
At least 1 month before a license expires, the Board shall mail to the licensee, at the last known address of the licensee:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

subparagraph.text: the date on which the current license expires;
the date by which the Board must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the license expires; and
the amount of the renewal fee.

subsection.text: Before a license expires, the licensee periodically may renew it for an additional 2–year term, if the licensee:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be licensed;
pays to the Board a renewal fee established by the Board in accordance with § 4–206 of this title; and
submits to the Board a renewal application on the form that the Board provides.

subsection.text: The Board shall renew the license of and issue a renewal certificate to each licensee who meets the requirements of this section.
The Board shall reinstate the license of an individual who, for any reason, has failed to renew the license if the individual:

paragraph.text: applies to the Board for reinstatement within 5 years after the license expires;
meets the renewal requirements for that license under § 4-310 of this subtitle; and
pays to the Board a reinstatement fee established by the Board in accordance with § 4-206 of this title, in addition to the renewal fee required under § 4-310 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: If an individual has failed to renew a license for any reason and then applies to the Board for reinstatement more than 5 years after the license has expired, the Board shall reinstate the license only if the individual:

paragraph.text: meets the renewal requirements for that license under § 4-310 of this subtitle;
pays to the Board a reinstatement fee established by the Board in accordance with § 4-206 of this title, in addition to the renewal fee required under § 4-310 of this subtitle; and
passes the examination required by the Board.

section.text: Each licensee shall display the license conspicuously in the barbershop where the licensee practices barbering.

paragraph.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 4-315 of this subtitle, the Board may deny a license to any applicant, reprimand any licensee, or suspend or revoke a license if the applicant or licensee:

subparagraph.text: fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a license for the applicant or licensee or for another;
fraudulently or deceptively uses a license;
is incompetent;
habitually is intoxicated or under the influence of any drug;
falsifies a record submitted to the Board;
fails to use proper sanitary methods while practicing barbering;
fails to keep a barbershop in a sanitary condition;
under the laws of the United States or of any state, is convicted of:

sub-subparagraph.text: a felony; or
a misdemeanor that is directly related to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to practice barbering;

subparagraph.text: violates any provision of this title or any regulation adopted by the Board under this title; or
fails to pay a civil penalty imposed by the Board under § 4-608 of this title.

Instead of or in addition to reprimanding a licensee or suspending or revoking a license under this subsection, the Board may impose a penalty not exceeding $300 for all violations cited on a single date.
To determine the amount of the penalty under this subsection, the Board shall consider:

sub-subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the good faith of the violator;
the violator’s history of previous violations;
the deleterious effect of the violation on the complainant, the public, and the barber industry; and
any other factors relevant to the determination of the financial penalty.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: The Board shall consider the following facts in the granting, denial, renewal, suspension, or revocation of a license or the reprimand of a licensee when an applicant or licensee is convicted of a felony or misdemeanor described in subsection (a)(1)(viii) of this section:

paragraph.text: the nature of the crime;
the relationship of the crime to the activities authorized by the license;
with respect to a felony, the relevance of the conviction to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to practice barbering;
the length of time since the conviction; and
the behavior and activities of the applicant or licensee before and after the conviction.

subsection.text: The Board shall commence proceedings under this section on a complaint to the Board by a member of the Board or any person.

paragraph.text: A complaint shall:

subparagraph.text: be in writing;
include the name and necessary contact information of the individual filing the complaint, as determined by the Board;
state specifically the facts on which the complaint is based;
be submitted to the Executive Director of the Board; and
be served on the person to whom it is directed:

sub-subparagraph.text: personally; or
by certified mail, return receipt requested, bearing a postmark from the United States Postal Service, to the person’s last known address as shown on the Board’s records.

paragraph.text: If service is made by certified mail, the person who mails the document shall file with the Board verified proof of mailing.
If a complaint is made by any person other than a member of the Board, the complaint shall be made under oath by the person who submits the complaint.

Except as provided in subsection (f) of this section, if the Board finds that a complaint alleges facts that are adequate grounds for action under this section, the Board shall act on the complaint as provided under § 4-315 of this subtitle to deny, suspend, or revoke a license, reprimand a licensee, or assess a penalty.
If the Board does not make the finding, the Board shall dismiss the complaint.

If the Board makes the finding under subsection (e)(1) of this section for a violation that relates to the sanitary practice of barbering, the Board shall provide the licensee an opportunity to correct the alleged violation.

If the licensee fails to correct each alleged violation within 10 days of written notification of the violation by the Board, the Board shall act on the complaint as provided under § 4-315 of this subtitle.
If the licensee corrects each alleged violation within 10 days of notice, the Board shall:

subparagraph.text: dismiss the complaint; and
provide the licensee written notification of the dismissal.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 10-226 of the State Government Article, before the Board takes any final action under § 4-314 of this subtitle, it shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Board.
The Board shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Board may administer oaths in connection with any proceeding under this section.
The hearing notice to be given to the individual shall be sent by certified mail to the last known address of the individual at least 10 days before the hearing.
If, after due notice, the individual against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, nevertheless the Board may hear and determine the matter.

section.text: An individual shall be registered by the Board before the individual may serve as an apprentice in a barbershop in the State.
An applicant for registration as an apprentice barber shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the Board an application on the form that the Board provides;
pay to the Board an application fee established by the Board in accordance with § 4-206 of this title; and
submit to the Board adequate evidence of the following:

subparagraph.text: the intention of a barbershop in the State to allow the applicant to affiliate with it as an apprentice barber; and
in the case of an applicant who does not speak English, the intention to participate in an English comprehension course during the apprenticeship.

section.text: The Board shall register and issue a certificate of registration to each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle.

subsection.text: While registration as an apprentice barber is in effect, the registration authorizes the individual to learn to practice barbering:

paragraph.text: in a:

subparagraph.text: barbershop that holds a barbershop permit; or
beauty salon that holds a beauty salon permit; and

paragraph.text: under the supervision of a master barber.
An apprentice barber shall practice barbering only at the barbershop or beauty salon with a barbershop permit issued under § 5-504 of this article.
An apprentice barber may only be paid for work authorized under this section performed while assisting a master barber in starting or completing an operation.
The initial term of registration as an apprentice barber is 2 years.
An apprentice barber may renew the apprentice barber registration one time.

subsection.text: The one–time renewal of an apprentice barber registration expires on the date set by the Board.
At least 1 month before registration as an apprentice barber expires, the Board shall mail to the apprentice barber, at the last known address of the apprentice barber:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

subparagraph.text: the date on which the current registration as an apprentice barber expires;
the date by which the Board must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be approved, issued, and mailed before the registration expires; and
the amount of the renewal fee.

subsection.text: Before the registration of an individual expires, the individual may renew it for an additional term if the individual:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be registered;
pays to the Board a renewal fee established by the Board in accordance with § 4–206 of this title; and
submits to the Board a renewal application on the form that the Board provides.

subsection.text: The Board shall renew the apprentice barber registration of and issue a renewal certificate to each apprentice barber who meets the requirements of this section.

section.text: Each registered apprentice barber shall display the certificate of registration conspicuously in the apprentice barber’s place of employment.

subsection.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 4-408 of this subtitle, the Board may deny registration as an apprentice barber to any applicant, reprimand any individual registered as an apprentice barber, or suspend or revoke the registration of any individual registered as an apprentice barber:

paragraph.text: for any applicable ground under § 4-314 of this title;
if the applicant or individual fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain registration for the applicant or individual or for another; or
if the applicant or individual fraudulently or deceptively uses a certificate of registration.

Instead of or in addition to reprimanding an individual registered as an apprentice barber or suspending or revoking the registration under this section, the Board may impose a penalty not exceeding $300 for all violations cited on a single day.
To determine the amount of the penalty imposed under this section, the Board shall consider:

subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the good faith of the violator;
the violator’s history of previous violations;
the deleterious effect of the violation on the complainant, the public, and the barber industry; and
any other factors relevant to the determination of the penalty.

subsection.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this section into the General Fund of the State.

Except as otherwise provided in § 10-226 of the State Government Article, before the Board takes any final action under § 4-407 of this subtitle, it shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Board.
The Board shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Board may administer oaths in connection with any proceeding under this section.
The hearing notice to be given to the individual shall be sent by certified mail to the last known address of the individual at least 10 days before the hearing.
If, after due notice, the individual against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, nevertheless the Board may hear and determine the matter.
A person shall hold a barbershop permit issued by the Board before the person may operate a barbershop in the State.
A separate barbershop permit is required for each barbershop that a person operates.
To qualify for a barbershop permit, an applicant shall be a person who meets the requirements of this section.
An applicant shall own the barbershop for which the application is made.
An applicant shall satisfy the Board that the location and equipment of the barbershop for which the application is made meets the requirements of:

paragraph.text: the Board;
the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene; and
the applicable local zoning code.

subsection.text: As a condition of the issuance of a barbershop permit, the barbershop for which the application is made shall pass a pre-opening inspection conducted under § 4-512 of this subtitle.
An applicant for a barbershop permit shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the Board an application on the form that the Board provides; and
pay to the Board an application fee and a pre-opening inspection fee established by the Board in accordance with § 4-206 of this title.

subsection.text: For each barbershop permit for which a person applies, the person shall submit a separate application and pay separate application and pre-opening inspection fees.
The Board shall issue a barbershop permit to each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle.
The Board shall issue a barbershop permit and a beauty salon permit to an applicant of a single establishment if the applicant:

paragraph.text: meets the requirements of:

subparagraph.text: this title; and
Title 5 of this article;

paragraph.text: submits a separate application for each permit; and
pays a separate fee for each application.

section.text: While a barbershop permit is in effect, it authorizes the barbershop permit holder to operate a barbershop.

subsection.text: Unless a barbershop permit is renewed for a 2-year term as provided in this section, the permit expires on the first May 31 that comes:

paragraph.text: after the effective date of the permit; and
in an odd-numbered year.

subsection.text: At least 1 month before a barbershop permit expires, the Board shall mail to the permit holder, at the last known address of the holder:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

subparagraph.text: the date on which the current permit expires;
the date by which the Board must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the permit expires; and
the amount of the renewal fee.

subsection.text: Before a barbershop permit expires, the barbershop permit holder periodically may renew it for an additional 2-year term, if the holder:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to hold the permit;
pays to the Board a renewal fee established by the Board in accordance with § 4-206 of this title; and
submits to the Board a renewal application on the form that the Board provides.

subsection.text: The Board shall renew the barbershop permit of and issue a renewal certificate to each barbershop permit holder who meets the requirements of this section.
The Secretary may determine that barbershop permits issued under this subtitle shall expire on a staggered basis.
The Board may reinstate a barbershop permit that has expired if the owner of the barbershop:

paragraph.text: applies to the Board for reinstatement within 45 days after the permit expires;
otherwise meets the requirements of § 4–506(c) of this subtitle; and
pays to the Board a reinstatement fee established by the Board in accordance with § 4–206 of this title, in addition to the renewal fee required under § 4–506(c)(2) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: If an owner of a barbershop has failed to renew a barbershop permit and applies to the Board for reinstatement more than 45 days after the permit has expired, the Board shall reinstate the permit only if the barbershop owner qualifies for a barbershop permit in accordance with §§ 4–502 and 4–503 of this subtitle.
A barbershop may not employ at the same time more than:

paragraph.text: 1 apprentice barber for each master barber employed; and
a total of 3 apprentice barbers.

subsection.text: A barbershop may have a separate shampoo area.
The Board may not require a barbershop to have a minimum number of sinks.

paragraph.text: An apprentice barber under complete and constant supervision of a master barber may assist the master barber in starting or completing an operation. The master barber or barbershop may charge the usual fees for the operation.
A fee may not be charged for an operation performed completely by an apprentice barber.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a barbershop may not be integrated with any other business.
A person may conduct another business on the premises of a barbershop only if the business and barbershop are separated by a permanent wall or partition.
An individual licensed to practice cosmetology may practice cosmetology in a barbershop.
The owner shall designate a master barber to supervise each apprentice barber who is learning to practice barbering in the barbershop.
The owner or a designated master barber shall file monthly a report, on a form supplied by the Board, that:

paragraph.text: states the progress of each apprentice barber employed by the barbershop; and
identifies the master barber supervising each apprentice barber.

subsection.text: The owner and the master barber supervising an apprentice barber immediately shall advise the Board in writing of:

paragraph.text: the date on which an apprentice barber ceases learning to practice barbering at the barbershop, temporarily or permanently; and
the reason for the cessation.

subsection.text: The Board may adopt regulations to ensure that each barber school approved by the State Board of Education or the Maryland Higher Education Commission is operated in a sanitary manner.
The regulations adopted under subsection (a) of this section shall provide for:

paragraph.text: the reporting of violations of the regulations to the Department of Education or the Maryland Higher Education Commission; and
the imposition of a fine not to exceed $300 for a violation of the regulations.

subsection.text: In determining the amount of financial penalty to be imposed under this section, the Board shall consider the following:

paragraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the good faith of the violator;
the violator’s history of previous violations;
the deleterious effect of the violation on the complainant, the public, and the barber industry; and
any other factors relevant to the determination of the financial penalty.

subsection.text: The Board shall commence proceedings to assess a penalty under this section on a complaint to the Board by a member of the Board or any person.

paragraph.text: A complaint shall:

subparagraph.text: be in writing;
