include the name and necessary contact information of the individual filing the complaint, as determined by the Board;
state specifically the facts on which the complaint is based;
be submitted to the Executive Director of the Board; and
be served on the person to whom it is directed:

sub-subparagraph.text: personally; or
by certified mail, return receipt requested, bearing a postmark from the United States Postal Service, to the person’s last known address as shown on the Board’s records.

paragraph.text: If service is made by certified mail, the person who mails the document shall file with the Board verified proof of mailing.
If a complaint is made by any person other than a member of the Board, the complaint shall be made under oath by the person who submits the complaint.

If the Board finds that there is a violation that relates to the sanitary condition of the barber school, the Board shall provide the owner of the barber school an opportunity to correct the alleged violation.
If the school owner fails to correct each alleged violation within 10 days of written notification by the Board, the Board shall act on the complaint as provided under § 4-514 of this subtitle.
If the school owner corrects each alleged violation within 10 days of notice, the Board shall:

subparagraph.text: dismiss the complaint; and
provide the school owner written notification of dismissal.

paragraph.text: With the approval of the Secretary, the Board may appoint inspectors to conduct inspections.
An inspector serves at the pleasure of the Board.
Subject to the State budget, each inspector is entitled to:

subparagraph.text: reasonable compensation as determined by the Board for each day on which the inspector is engaged in the duties of the inspector’s appointment; and
reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations.

paragraph.text: The Board shall inspect barbershops.
The Board or an inspector shall inspect each barbershop before the barbershop:

subparagraph.text: initially opens for business;
opens for business at a new location; or
continues business under a new owner.

paragraph.text: A barbershop that remodels and reopens with the same owner is not subject to the inspection requirement of this subsection.

The Board or an inspector may enter and inspect a barber school approved by the State Board of Education or the Maryland Higher Education Commission at any time during business hours to determine the sanitary condition of the barber school.
If, during an inspection of a barber school, an inspector finds an unsanitary condition, the inspector promptly shall report the condition to the Board.
A barbershop shall allow an inspector, on presentation of credentials, to enter and inspect the facility at any time during business hours.
During inspection of a barbershop, the owner, lessee, or manager of the barbershop shall accompany the inspector.
An inspector shall make an inspection report after an inspection and give a copy to the individual who accompanied the inspector during the inspection.
The individual shall sign the inspection report for the barbershop to acknowledge receipt of a copy of the report.
Subject to the hearing provisions of § 4-514 of this subtitle, the Board may deny a barbershop permit to any applicant, reprimand any permit holder, or suspend or revoke a barbershop permit:

subparagraph.text: for any applicable ground under § 4-314 of this title;
if the applicant or holder fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a barbershop permit for the applicant or holder or for another;
if the applicant or holder fraudulently or deceptively uses a barbershop permit; or
if the holder fails to pay a civil penalty imposed by the Board under § 4-608 of this title.

Instead of or in addition to reprimanding a permit holder or suspending or revoking a permit under this subsection, the Board may impose a penalty not exceeding $300 for all violations cited on a single date.
To determine the amount of penalty imposed under this subsection, the Board shall consider the following:

sub-subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the good faith of the violator;
the violator’s history of previous violations;
the deleterious effect of the violation on the complainant, the public, and the barber industry; and
any other factors relevant to the determination of the financial penalty.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: The Board shall commence proceedings under this section on a complaint to the Board by a member of the Board or any person.

paragraph.text: A complaint shall:

subparagraph.text: be in writing;
be signed by the complainant;
state specifically the facts on which the complaint is based;
be submitted to the Executive Director of the Board; and
be served on the person to whom it is directed:

sub-subparagraph.text: personally; or
by certified mail, return receipt requested, bearing a postmark from the United States Postal Service, to the person’s last known address as shown on the Board’s records.

paragraph.text: If service is made by certified mail, the person who mails the document shall file with the Board verified proof of mailing.
If a complaint is made by any person other than a member of the Board, the complaint shall be made under oath by the person who submits the complaint.

Except as provided in subsection (e) of this section, if the Board finds that a complaint alleges facts that are adequate grounds for action under § 4-514 of this subtitle, the Board shall act on the complaint as provided under § 4-514 of this subtitle to deny, suspend, or revoke a barbershop permit, or reprimand or assess a penalty against the holder of the permit.
If the Board does not make the finding, the Board shall dismiss the complaint.

If the Board makes the finding under subsection (d)(1) of this section for a violation that relates to the sanitary condition of the barbershop, the Board shall provide the owner of the barbershop an opportunity to correct the alleged violation.
If the barbershop owner fails to correct each alleged violation within 10 days of written notification by the Board, the Board shall act on the complaint as provided under § 4-514 of this subtitle.
If the barbershop owner corrects each alleged violation within 10 days of notice, the Board shall:

subparagraph.text: dismiss the complaint; and
provide the barbershop owner written notification of dismissal.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 10-226 of the State Government Article, before the Board takes any final action under § 4-511 or § 4-513 of this subtitle, it shall give the person against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Board.
The Board shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Board may administer oaths in connection with any proceeding under this section.
The hearing notice to be given to the person shall be sent by certified mail to the last known address of the person at least 10 days before the hearing.
If, after due notice, the person against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, nevertheless the Board may hear and determine the matter.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, a person may not practice, attempt to practice, or offer to practice barbering in the State unless licensed by the Board to practice barbering.
A person may not operate a barbershop in the State unless the person holds a barbershop permit issued by the Board.
An individual may not serve as an apprentice barber unless registered by the Board as an apprentice barber.

subsection.text: Unless authorized under this title to practice barbering, a person may not represent to the public, by use of a title, including “licensed barber”, “master barber”, or “journey barber”, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person is authorized to practice barbering in the State.

Unless an establishment holds a barbershop permit under this title, a person may not represent to the public, by title, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the establishment is a barbershop.
Except as provided in §§ 4-301.1 and 4-301.2 of this title and subsection (b) of this section, a person may not practice barbering in any place other than:

paragraph.text: a barbershop that holds a barbershop permit under this title; or
a beauty salon that holds a beauty salon permit under Title 5 of this article.

subsection.text: A licensed master barber or a licensed barber may practice barbering outside a barbershop or beauty salon if:

paragraph.text: the master barber or the barber is sponsored by a barbershop that holds a barbershop permit or a beauty salon that holds a beauty salon permit;
the patron is a customer of the barbershop or the beauty salon;
the implements transported to the site where barbering services will be performed are sanitized and disinfected;
the sponsoring barbershop maintains complete records of all services performed outside of the barbershop or the beauty salon; and
Board inspectors are permitted to conduct inspections of:

subparagraph.text: the implements used outside of the barbershop or the beauty salon; and
the premises where the barbering services are performed.

section.text: A barbershop in Montgomery County may not open for business more than 6 days a week.

subsection.text: A person who violates any provision of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $100 or imprisonment not exceeding 30 days or both.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided by this title, the Board may impose on a person who violates any provision of this title a penalty not exceeding $1,000 for all violations cited on a single day.
In setting the amount of the penalty, the Board shall consider:

subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the harm caused by the violation;
the good faith of the violator;
any history of previous violations by the violator; and
any other relevant factors.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: Following an inspection of a barbershop, if a Board inspector determines that a licensee or permit holder has violated this title or a regulation adopted by the Board, the inspector may issue a citation to the licensee or permit holder.
A citation issued by a Board inspector shall be in writing and shall state:

paragraph.text: a brief description of each violation;
the amount of a civil penalty, as prescribed by regulation, for each violation; and
as provided in this section:

subparagraph.text: the time within which the civil penalty is to be paid;
the opportunity to contest the citation; and
the finality of the citation if it is not contested.

subsection.text: The citation shall be served on the licensee or permit holder alleged to have committed the violation by:

paragraph.text: hand-delivery; or
certified mail to the last known address of the licensee or permit holder.

subsection.text: Subject to subsections (e) and (f) of this section, the civil penalty set forth in a citation shall be paid within 60 days of its receipt.

A citation and the applicable civil penalty shall be considered a final order of the Board unless, within 60 days of being served with the citation, the licensee or permit holder notifies the Board in writing of an intent to contest the citation.

paragraph.text: Upon the receipt of a written notice of a licensee or permit holder’s intent to contest a citation, the Board shall hold a hearing, in accordance with § 4-315 or § 4-514 of this title, regarding the cited violations.
A hearing held in accordance with paragraph (1) of this subsection may not be delegated to the Office of Administrative Hearings under Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Board shall establish by regulation a schedule of civil penalties for violations of this title and regulations adopted by the Board.
The civil penalties imposed under this subsection may not exceed $300 for all violations cited on a single day.

section.text: This title may be cited as the “Maryland Barbers Act”.

Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, this title and all regulations adopted under this title shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2021.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Apprentice” means an individual who is learning to practice cosmetology or any limited practice of cosmetology in a beauty salon that holds a beauty salon permit under the supervision of:

paragraph.text: if learning to practice cosmetology, a licensed senior cosmetologist;
if learning to provide esthetic services, a licensed senior cosmetologist or a licensed esthetician with 2 years’ experience; and
if learning to provide nail technician services, a licensed senior cosmetologist or a licensed nail technician with 2 years’ experience.
“Beauty salon” means any commercial establishment, except a barbershop, in which an individual practices cosmetology.
“Beauty salon” does not include a clinic in a cosmetology school.

subsection.text: “Beauty salon permit” means a permit issued by the Board to operate a beauty salon.
“Board” means the State Board of Cosmetologists.
“Cosmetologist” means an individual who practices cosmetology.

paragraph.text: “License” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a license issued by the Board.
“License” includes, unless the context requires otherwise, each of the following licenses:

subparagraph.text: a license to practice cosmetology;
a license to practice as a senior cosmetologist;
a limited license to provide esthetic services; and
a limited license to provide nail technician services.

subsection.text: “Licensed cosmetologist” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a cosmetologist who is licensed by the Board to practice cosmetology.
“Licensed senior cosmetologist” means a person who:

paragraph.text: has at least 2 years of experience as a licensed cosmetologist; and
has passed a test approved by the Board.
“Limited license” means a license issued by the Board to practice cosmetology as limited in § 5–301 of this title.
“Limited license” includes, unless the context requires otherwise, each of the following licenses:

subparagraph.text: a limited license to provide esthetic services; and
a limited license to provide nail technician services.

paragraph.text: “Practice cosmetology” means to engage in any of the following for compensation:

subparagraph.text: beautifying, cleaning, or embellishing the hair of an individual by:

sub-subparagraph.text: arranging the hair;
bleaching the hair;
cleansing the hair;
coloring the hair;
curling the hair;
cutting the hair;
dressing the hair;
singeing the hair;
permanent waving the hair;
waving the hair; or
performing any other similar procedure intended to beautify, clean, or embellish the hair;

subparagraph.text: arching or dyeing eyebrows;
dyeing eyelashes;
providing esthetic services; or
providing nail technician services.

paragraph.text: The practice of cosmetology does not include:

subparagraph.text: the mere sale, fitting, or styling of wigs or hairpieces;
the mere shampooing of hair; or

a service that results in tension on hair strands or roots by twisting, wrapping, weaving, extending, locking, or braiding by hand or mechanical device, provided that the service does not include the application of dyes, reactive chemicals, or other preparations to alter the color of the hair or to straighten, curl, or alter the structure of the hair.

subsection.text: “Provide esthetic services” means to provide to an individual, for compensation, the service of:

paragraph.text: cleansing, exercising, massaging, stimulating, or performing any other similar procedure on the skin or scalp by electrical, mechanical, or any other means;
applying to the face an alcohol, cream, lotion, astringent, or cosmetic preparation; or
removing superfluous hair by the use of a depilatory, tweezers, or wax.

subsection.text: “Provide nail technician services” means to provide to an individual, for compensation, the service of:

paragraph.text: manicuring or pedicuring the individual’s nails;
applying artificial nail enhancement products; or
maintaining artificial nail enhancement products.

section.text: This title does not prohibit:

paragraph.text: an individual from practicing a health occupation that the individual is authorized under the laws of the State to practice; or
an individual who is authorized to practice barbering under Title 4 of this article from practicing barbering.

section.text: There is a State Board of Cosmetologists in the Department.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of seven members.
Of the seven members of the Board:

subparagraph.text: four shall be licensed cosmetologists;
one shall be affiliated with a private cosmetology school as an educator or owner; and
two shall be consumer members.

paragraph.text: The Governor shall appoint the members with the advice of the Secretary.

subsection.text: Each cosmetologist member of the Board:

paragraph.text: shall have practiced cosmetology actively for at least 5 years before appointment;
shall be a citizen of the State;
may not be affiliated directly or indirectly with any cosmetology school;
may not be affiliated with any person who manufactures or sells any article, supply, or merchandise that is commonly used in a beauty salon; and
may not be a graduate of the same school of cosmetology as any other member of the Board.

subsection.text: Each consumer member of the Board:

paragraph.text: shall be a member of the general public;
may not be a licensee or otherwise be subject to regulation by the Board;
may not be required to meet the qualifications for the professional members of the Board; and
may not, within 1 year before appointment, have had a financial interest in or have received compensation from a person regulated by the Board.

subsection.text: While a member of the Board, a consumer member may not:

paragraph.text: have a financial interest in or receive compensation from a person regulated by the Board; or
grade any examination given by or for the Board.

subsection.text: Before taking office, each appointee to the Board shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 3 years and begins on July 1.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on October 1, 1989.
A member may not serve more than 2 consecutive terms.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: The Governor may remove a member for incompetence or misconduct.
From among its members, the Board annually shall elect a chairman.
The manner of election of the chairman shall be as the Board determines.
A majority of the members then serving on the Board is a quorum.
No formal action may be taken by the Board without the approval of a majority of the members of the Board eligible to vote.
The Board shall meet at least once a month, at the times and places that the Board determines.
Subject to the State budget, each member of the Board is entitled to:

paragraph.text: a reasonable fee set by the Board for each day on which the member is engaged in the duties of office; and
reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations.

subsection.text: The Board may employ a staff in accordance with the State budget.
The Board shall have its principal office in Baltimore City.
In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere, the Board shall adopt:

paragraph.text: bylaws for the conduct of its proceedings;
regulations for qualification and examination of applicants for licenses, registration, and permits and issuance of licenses, certificates of registration, and permits;
regulations to govern the conduct of persons regulated under this title;
regulations to govern sanitation and safety in practicing cosmetology, including regulations that establish precautions to prevent the spread of infectious and contagious diseases; and
regulations to govern the direct supervision of the operation of limited practice beauty salons.

The Board shall establish reasonable fees for licensing, licensing renewal, examinations, reinstatements, certifications, applications, preopening inspections, per diem fees for Board members, compensation for inspectors appointed by the Board, and for any other service performed by the Board necessary to carry out the provisions of this title.

subparagraph.text: Except for the examination fees which the Board shall establish in amounts not to exceed the costs of the examinations and subject to subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, the fees established by the Board shall be set in a manner that will produce funds sufficient to cover the actual direct and indirect costs of regulating the cosmetology industry in the State in accordance with the provisions of this title.
The Board may not set fees for licensing and license renewals that exceed $50.

paragraph.text: The total cost of regulating the cosmetology industry in the State in accordance with the provisions of this title may not be more than the revenues generated by the fees established under paragraph (1) of this subsection.

The Board shall adopt regulations that establish detailed curriculum standards for use by the State Board of Education or the Maryland Higher Education Commission in approving applications for instruction in the practice of cosmetology, the provision of esthetic services, and the provision of nail technician services at public schools or private career schools.
The curriculum standards established under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall:

subparagraph.text: incorporate modern methods and practices for:

sub-subparagraph.text: practicing cosmetology;
providing esthetic services; and
providing nail technician services;

subparagraph.text: include a reference to each topic and the emphasis of each topic required of a comprehensive curriculum in the appropriate licensing area; and
be reviewed and updated periodically as determined by the Board.

subsection.text: On request of any person and payment of a certification fee established by the Board in accordance with § 5-205 of this subtitle, the Board shall certify the licensing, registration, or permit status and qualifications of any person who is the subject of the request.
Each certification under this section:

paragraph.text: shall include a statement of the licensing, registration, or permit status of the person who is the subject of the request; and
may include:

subparagraph.text: information about the examination results and other qualifications of that person;
information about the dates of issuance and renewal of the license, registration, or permit of that person;
information about any disciplinary action taken against that person; and
if authorized by that person, information about any complaint against that person.

subsection.text: The Board shall collect the certification fee established by the Board in accordance with § 5-205 of this subtitle for each certification under this section.
In addition to any powers set forth elsewhere, the Board may administer oaths.
In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere, the Board shall:

paragraph.text: adopt a seal;
keep a record of its proceedings;
keep records at its principal office; and
provide copies of its regulations to persons regulated by the Board.

subsection.text: The Board shall keep a record that, for each application for a license, registration, or permit, shows:

paragraph.text: the name of the applicant;
the place of business or employment of the applicant;
the address of the place of business or employment; and
the action of the Board on the application.

section.text: The Board shall pay all money collected under this title into the General Fund of the State.

Any person aggrieved by a final decision of the Board in a contested case, as defined in § 10-202 of the State Government Article, may take an appeal as allowed in §§ 10-222 and 10-223 of the State Government Article.
The Board exercises its powers, duties, and functions subject to the authority of the Secretary.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, an individual shall be licensed by the Board to practice cosmetology before the individual may practice cosmetology in the State.
If an individual holds the appropriate limited license, the individual may practice cosmetology in a manner limited to:

paragraph.text: providing esthetic services; or
providing nail technician services.

subsection.text: Subsection (a) of this section does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a student while the student practices cosmetology in accordance with § 5-302 or § 5-303 of this subtitle; or
a registered apprentice.
Subject to the provisions of this subsection, a student who has completed at least 350 hours of training at a school of cosmetology may practice cosmetology, without a license, at the school.
A student may practice cosmetology under this subsection only:

subparagraph.text: in the course of the practical work required as part of the training of the student;

while the student is under the direct supervision of a teacher who meets the requirements established by the Department of Education for public school programs or the Maryland Higher Education Commission for private school programs; and
if the individual to whom a service is to be provided agrees to provision of the service after being informed that a student in training is to provide the service.

paragraph.text: Subject to the provisions of this subsection, a student who has completed at least 1,000 hours of training at a school of cosmetology may practice cosmetology, without a license, in a hospital, nursing home, or correctional facility.
A student may practice cosmetology under this subsection only:

subparagraph.text: in the course of the practical work required as part of the training of the student;

while the student is under the direct supervision of a teacher who meets the requirements established by the Department of Education for public school programs or the Maryland Higher Education Commission for private school programs; and
if the individual to whom a service is to be provided:

sub-subparagraph.text: is confined to the hospital, nursing home, or correctional facility; and
agrees to provision of the service after being informed that a student in training is to provide the service.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of this section, a student who has completed at least 1,000 hours of training while enrolled in public school courses in cosmetology may practice cosmetology without a license.
A student may practice cosmetology under this section only if the student:

paragraph.text: is enrolled in an approved cosmetology program and has a record of satisfactory school performance and school attendance, as determined by the local education agency;
has a letter of authorization, signed by the student’s teacher or work-study coordinator, to practice cosmetology in a specific beauty salon;
practices cosmetology only in that specific beauty salon; and

while practicing cosmetology, works under the direct supervision of an individual who is a licensed senior cosmetologist who agrees to periodically report on the progress of the student to the cosmetology teacher or the work-study coordinator.

subsection.text: A beauty salon may pay a student for work authorized under this section.

A student authorized under this section to practice cosmetology without a license shall conspicuously display a letter of authorization, as required by this section, at the student’s work station in the specified beauty salon.

paragraph.text: To qualify for a license to practice as a cosmetologist, an applicant shall be an individual who meets the requirements of this section.
The applicant shall be at least 17 years old.
The applicant shall have completed successfully a 9th grade education or the equivalent.

subparagraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, an applicant shall have received training by:

sub-subparagraph.text: serving as a registered apprentice as provided under §§ 5–404 and 5–405(e) of this title; or

successfully completing a required program of at least 1,500 hours of training in a cosmetology school that is approved by the State Board of Education or the Maryland Higher Education Commission in consultation with the Board.

subparagraph.text: If an applicant is a barber or master barber currently licensed in this State, the Board shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: credit the applicant with having met one–half of the training requirements of subparagraph (i) of this paragraph; and
determine the manner in which the credit will be applied.

subparagraph.text: An applicant meets the requirements of this subsection if:

sub-subparagraph.text: the applicant has held a cosmetologist license in another state or foreign country and has actively practiced cosmetology in the other state or foreign country for a period of 6 months; or

the applicant has been trained in a cosmetology school in another state or foreign country that has standards substantially equivalent to or more stringent than the standards of a school that is approved by the State Board of Education or the Maryland Higher Education Commission in consultation with the Board.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, the applicant shall pass a written and practical examination given by the Board under this subtitle.

subsection.text: To qualify for a license as a senior cosmetologist, an applicant shall:

paragraph.text: have 2 years of experience as a licensed cosmetologist; and
pass an examination approved by the Board.

subsection.text: To qualify for a limited license to practice cosmetology, an applicant shall be an individual who meets the requirements of this section.
An applicant for a limited license to provide esthetic services shall:

paragraph.text: be at least 17 years old;
have completed successfully a 9th grade education or the equivalent; and
have received training by:

subparagraph.text: serving as a registered apprentice for at least 6 months as provided under §§ 5–404 and 5–405 of this title; or

successfully completing at least 600 hours of instruction in providing esthetic services in a cosmetology school approved by the State Department of Education or the Maryland Higher Education Commission in consultation with the Board.

subsection.text: An applicant for a limited license to provide nail technician services shall:

paragraph.text: be at least 17 years old;
have successfully completed a 9th grade education or the equivalent; and
have received training by:

subparagraph.text: serving as a registered apprentice for at least 3 months as provided under §§ 5–404 and 5–405 of this title; or

successfully completing at least 250 hours of instruction in providing nail technician services in a cosmetology school approved by the State Department of Education or the Maryland Higher Education Commission in consultation with the Board.

subsection.text: If an applicant is licensed to practice as an esthetician or nail technician in another state or foreign country, the applicant meets the training requirements of this section if the applicant has held a limited license in the other state or foreign country and has actively practiced in the other state or foreign country for a period of 6 months.
An applicant for a limited license shall pass an examination given by the Board under this subtitle.

section.text: An applicant for a license:

paragraph.text: shall submit to the Board an application on the form that the Board provides; and

except as provided in § 5–308 of this subtitle, shall pay to the Board or the Board’s designee the appropriate examination fee established by the Board in accordance with § 5–205 of this title in an amount not to exceed the cost of the required examination.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 5-307.1 of this subtitle, an applicant is entitled to be examined as provided in this section if the applicant:

paragraph.text: otherwise qualifies for a license under this title; and
pays an examination fee, as established by the Board in accordance with §§ 5-205 and 5-306 of this title, to the Board or the Board’s designee.

subsection.text: The Board periodically shall give examinations to applicants at the times and places that the Board determines.
The Board shall give each qualified applicant notice of the time and place of examination.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Board shall determine the subjects, scope, and form of and the passing score for examinations given under this subtitle.

subparagraph.text: An examination may consist of written and practical parts.

An applicant may take a written examination when the applicant has completed at least 1,380 hours of the 1,500 hours of training in a cosmetology school required under § 5-304(a)(4)(i)2 of this subtitle.

An applicant who has completed 1,500 hours of training as specified in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph may take the written and practical parts of an examination during one administration of the examination.

subsection.text: The Board or the Board’s designee shall mail to each applicant notice of the applicant’s examination result.
The Board may use a testing service to administer the examinations required for licensure.
If the Board uses a testing service, the testing service, subject to the requirements set by the Board, may:

paragraph.text: set the time and place of examinations;
provide notice of the time and place of an examination to an applicant; and
furnish any other information that the Board may require the testing service to provide.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of this section, the Board may waive any examination requirement of this subtitle for an individual who is licensed to practice as a cosmetologist or a limited practice cosmetologist in another state.
The Board may grant a waiver under this section only if the applicant:

paragraph.text: pays to the Board an application fee established by the Board in accordance with § 5-205 of this title; and
provides adequate evidence that the applicant:

subparagraph.text: meets the qualifications otherwise required by this subtitle; and
became licensed in the other state after passing, in that or any other state, an examination that is at least equivalent to the examination for which the applicant is seeking a waiver.

section.text: If an applicant qualifies for a license under this subtitle, the Board shall send the applicant a notice that states that:

paragraph.text: the applicant has qualified for the license; and
the Board will issue the license to the applicant on receipt of a license fee established by the Board in accordance with § 5-205 of this title.

subsection.text: Subject to subsections (b) and (c) of this section and while a license to practice cosmetology is in effect, it authorizes the licensee to practice cosmetology.
While a limited license to provide esthetic services is in effect, it authorizes the licensee to provide only esthetic services.
While a limited license to provide nail technician services is in effect, it authorizes the licensee to provide only nail technician services.
The initial term of a license is 2 years.
A license expires on the date set by the Board unless the license is renewed for an additional term as provided in this section.
At least 1 month before a license expires, the Board shall mail to the licensee, at the last known address of the licensee:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

subparagraph.text: the date on which the current license expires;
the date by which the Board must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the license expires; and
the amount of the renewal fee.

subsection.text: Before a license expires, the licensee periodically may renew it for an additional 2–year term, if the licensee:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be licensed;
pays to the Board a renewal fee established by the Board in accordance with § 5–205 of this title; and
submits to the Board a renewal application on the form that the Board provides.

subsection.text: The Board shall renew the license of and issue a renewal certificate to each licensee who meets the requirements of this section.

paragraph.text: If an individual who, on or before September 30, 1999, holds a limited license to provide esthetic services files an application to renew the license, the Board shall grant a waiver of the requirement for completion of hours of instruction under § 5–305(c)(3)(ii) of this subtitle that are in addition to the hours of instruction required on or before that date.

If an individual who, on or before September 30, 1999, holds a limited license to provide manicuring services files an application to renew the license, the Board shall grant a waiver of the requirement for completion of hours of instruction under § 5–305(d)(3)(ii) of this subtitle that are in addition to the hours of instruction required on or before that date.

subsection.text: The Board shall reinstate the license of an individual who, for any reason, has failed to renew the license if the individual:

paragraph.text: applies to the Board for reinstatement within 5 years after the license expires;
meets the renewal requirements of § 5-311 of this subtitle; and
pays to the Board a reinstatement fee established by the Board in accordance with § 5-205 of this title, in addition to the renewal fee required under § 5-311 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: If an individual has failed to renew a license for any reason and then applies to the Board for reinstatement more than 5 years after the license has expired, the Board shall reinstate the license only if the individual:

paragraph.text: meets the renewal requirements of § 5-311 of this subtitle;
passes the examination required by the Board; and
pays to the Board a reinstatement fee established by the Board in accordance with § 5-205 of this title, in addition to the renewal fee required under § 5-311 of this subtitle.

section.text: Each license issued under this subtitle shall be displayed conspicuously by the licensee in the office or place of employment of the licensee.

paragraph.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 5-315 of this subtitle, the Board may deny a license to any applicant, reprimand any licensee, or suspend or revoke a license if the applicant or licensee:

subparagraph.text: fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a license for the applicant or licensee or for another;
fraudulently or deceptively uses a license;
is incompetent;
engages in dishonest, unethical, immoral, or unprofessional conduct;
is addicted to alcohol or drugs to the extent of being unfit to practice cosmetology;
advertises by means of knowingly false or deceptive statements;
under the laws of the United States or of any state, is convicted of:

sub-subparagraph.text: a felony; or
a misdemeanor that is directly related to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to practice cosmetology;

subparagraph.text: violates any provision of this title or any regulation adopted by the Board under this title; or
fails to pay a civil penalty imposed by the Board under § 5-610 of this title.

Instead of or in addition to reprimanding a licensee or suspending or revoking a license under this subsection, the Board may impose a penalty not exceeding $300 for all violations cited on a single day.
To determine the amount of the penalty imposed under this subsection, the Board shall consider:

sub-subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the good faith of the violator;
the violator’s history of previous violations;
the deleterious effect of the violation on the complainant, the public, and the cosmetology industry; and
any other factors relevant to the determination of the financial penalty.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: The Board shall consider the following facts in the granting, denial, renewal, suspension, or revocation of a license or the reprimand of a licensee when an applicant or licensee is convicted of a felony or misdemeanor described in subsection (a)(1)(vii) of this section:

paragraph.text: the nature of the crime;
the relationship of the crime to the activities authorized by the license;
with respect to a felony, the relevance of the conviction to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to practice cosmetology;
the length of time since the conviction; and
the behavior and activities of the applicant or licensee before and after the conviction.
The Board shall commence proceedings under this section on a complaint to the Board by a member of the Board or any person.
A complaint shall:

subparagraph.text: be in writing;
include the name and necessary contact information of the individual filing the complaint, as determined by the Board;
state specifically the facts on which the complaint is based;
be submitted to the Executive Director of the Board; and
be served on the person to whom it is directed:

sub-subparagraph.text: personally; or
by certified mail, return receipt requested, bearing a postmark from the United States Postal Service, to the person’s last known address as shown on the Board’s records.

paragraph.text: If service is made by certified mail, the person who mails the document shall file with the Board verified proof of mailing.

Except as provided in subsection (e) of this section, if the Board finds that a complaint alleges facts that are adequate grounds for action under this section, the Board shall act on the complaint as provided under § 5-315 of this subtitle to deny, suspend, or revoke a license, reprimand a licensee, or assess a penalty.
If the Board does not make the finding, the Board shall dismiss the complaint.

If the Board makes the finding under subsection (d)(1) of this section for a violation that relates to the sanitary practice of cosmetology, the Board shall provide the licensee an opportunity to correct the alleged violation.

If the licensee fails to correct each alleged violation within 10 days of written notification of the violation by the Board, the Board shall act on the complaint as provided under § 5-315 of this subtitle.
If the licensee corrects each alleged violation within 10 days of notice, the Board shall:

subparagraph.text: dismiss the complaint; and
provide the licensee written notification of the dismissal.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 10-226 of the State Government Article, before the Board takes any final action under § 5-314 or § 5-608.1 of this title, it shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Board.
The Board shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The hearing notice to be given to the individual shall be served at least 5 days before the hearing.
The individual may be represented at the hearing by counsel.

paragraph.text: The Board may issue a subpoena for the attendance of a witness to testify or the production of evidence in connection with any proceeding under this section.
A subpoena issued under this subsection shall be served by:

subparagraph.text: certified mail; or
the sheriff of the county where the person to be served resides or has a principal place of business.

subsection.text: If, after due notice, the individual against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, nevertheless the Board may hear and determine the matter.

section.text: The Board may reinstate the license of an individual whose license has been suspended or revoked under § 5-314 of this subtitle if the individual:

paragraph.text: applies to the Board for reinstatement of the license; and
provides to the Board adequate evidence that the applicant is qualified to have the license reinstated.

section.text: An individual shall be registered by the Board before the individual may serve as an apprentice in a beauty salon in the State.
An applicant for registration shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the Board an application on the form that the Board provides; and
pay to the Board an application fee established by the Board in accordance with § 5-205 of this title.

section.text: The Board shall register and issue a certificate of registration to each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle.
While registration as an apprentice is in effect, the registration authorizes the individual to learn to practice cosmetology or any limited practice of cosmetology:

paragraph.text: in a:

subparagraph.text: beauty salon that holds a beauty salon permit; or
barbershop that holds a barbershop permit; and

paragraph.text: under the supervision of:

subparagraph.text: if learning to practice cosmetology, a licensed senior cosmetologist;
if learning to provide esthetic services, a licensed senior cosmetologist or a licensed esthetician with 2 years’ experience; and
if learning to provide nail technician services, a licensed senior cosmetologist or a licensed nail technician with 2 years’ experience.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in subsection (g) of this section, the initial term of registration as an apprentice is 2 years.
Unless registration as an apprentice is renewed for one additional 2–year term as provided in this section, the registration expires on the date set by the Board.
At least 1 month before the registration of an individual expires, the Board shall mail to the individual, at the last known address of the individual:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

subparagraph.text: the date on which the current registration expires;
the date by which the Board must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the registration expires; and
the amount of the renewal fee.

subsection.text: Before the registration of an individual expires, the individual may renew it for an additional term, if the individual:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be registered;
pays to the Board a renewal fee established by the Board in accordance with § 5–205 of this title; and
submits to the Board a renewal application on the form that the Board provides.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in subsection (g) of this section, an individual registered as an apprentice may renew the registration only one time for a 2–year term.
The Board shall renew the registration of and issue a renewal certificate to each individual who meets the requirements of this section.

A registration as an apprentice for any limited practice of cosmetology expires 12 months after the date of its issuance unless the limited practice apprentice registration is renewed for one 1–year term.

section.text: Each registered individual shall display the certificate of registration conspicuously in the individual's place of employment or training.

paragraph.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 5-408 of this subtitle, the Board may deny registration as an apprentice to any applicant, reprimand any individual registered as an apprentice, or suspend or revoke the registration of an individual registered as an apprentice:

subparagraph.text: for any applicable ground under § 5-314 of this title;
if the applicant or individual fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain registration for the applicant or individual or for another; or
if the applicant or individual fraudulently or deceptively uses a certificate of registration.

Instead of or in addition to reprimanding an individual registered as an apprentice or suspending or revoking a registration, the Board may impose a penalty not exceeding $300 for all violations cited on a single date.
To determine the amount of penalty imposed under this subsection, the Board shall consider:

sub-subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the good faith of the violator;
the violator’s history of previous violations;
the deleterious effect of the violation on the complainant, the public, and the cosmetology industry; and
any other factors relevant to the determination of the penalty.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: The Board shall commence proceedings under this section on a complaint to the Board by a member of the Board or any person.

paragraph.text: A complaint shall:

subparagraph.text: be in writing;
be signed by the complainant;
state specifically the facts on which the complaint is based;
be submitted to the Executive Director of the Board; and
be served on the person to whom it is directed:

sub-subparagraph.text: personally; or
by certified mail, return receipt requested, bearing a postmark from the United States Postal Service, to the person’s last known address as shown on the Board’s records.

paragraph.text: If service is made by certified mail, the person who mails the document shall file with the Board verified proof of mailing.

Except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, if the Board finds that a complaint alleges facts that are adequate grounds for action under this section, the Board shall act on the complaint as provided under § 5-408 of this subtitle to deny, suspend, or revoke a certificate of registration, reprimand an apprentice, or assess a penalty.
If the Board does not make the finding, the Board shall dismiss the complaint.

If the Board makes the finding under subsection (c)(1) of this section for a violation that relates to the sanitary practice of cosmetology, the Board shall provide the apprentice an opportunity to correct the alleged violation.

If the apprentice fails to correct each alleged violation within 10 days of written notification of the violation by the Board, the Board shall act on the complaint as provided under § 5-408 of this subtitle.
If the apprentice corrects each alleged violation within 10 days of notice, the Board shall:

subparagraph.text: dismiss the complaint; and
provide the apprentice written notification of the dismissal.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 10-226 of the State Government Article, before the Board takes any final action under § 5-407 of this subtitle, it shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Board.
The Board shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The hearing notice to be given to the individual shall be served at least 5 days before the hearing.
The individual may be represented at the hearing by counsel.

paragraph.text: The Board may issue a subpoena for the attendance of a witness to testify or the production of evidence in connection with any proceeding under this section.
A subpoena issued under this subsection shall be served by:

subparagraph.text: certified mail; or
the sheriff of the county where the person to be served resides or has a principal place of business.

subsection.text: If, after due notice, the individual against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, nevertheless the Board may hear and determine the matter.

section.text: The Board may reinstate the registration of an individual whose registration has been suspended or revoked under § 5-407 of this subtitle if the individual:

paragraph.text: applies to the Board for reinstatement of the registration; and
provides to the Board adequate evidence that the applicant is qualified to have the registration reinstated.

subsection.text: A person shall hold a beauty salon permit issued by the Board before the person may operate a beauty salon in the State.
A beauty salon may operate as a limited practice beauty salon by offering cosmetology services limited to:

paragraph.text: providing esthetic services; or
providing nail technician services.

subsection.text: A separate beauty salon permit is required for each beauty salon that a person operates.
To qualify for a beauty salon permit, an applicant shall meet the requirements of this section.
An applicant shall own or lease the beauty salon for which the application is made.
As a condition of the issuance of a beauty salon permit, the beauty salon for which the application is made shall pass the inspection conducted under § 5-520 of this subtitle.
The applicant shall meet any other requirements that the Board sets, by regulation, for applicants for beauty salon permits.
An applicant for a beauty salon permit shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the Board an application on the form that the Board provides;
pay to the Board an application fee established by the Board in accordance with the provisions of § 5-205 of this title; and
pay to the Board an inspection fee established by the Board in accordance with the provisions of § 5-205 of this title.

subsection.text: In addition to any other information required on the application form, the form shall require the applicant to indicate if the application is for a limited practice beauty salon.
For each beauty salon permit for which a person applies, the person shall submit a separate application and pay a separate application fee.
The Board shall issue a beauty salon permit to each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle.
A beauty salon permit for the limited practice of cosmetology shall specify the limited cosmetology services for which the permit is issued.
The Board shall issue a beauty salon permit and a barbershop permit to an applicant of a single establishment if the applicant:

paragraph.text: meets the requirements of:

subparagraph.text: this title; and
Title 4 of this article;

paragraph.text: submits a separate application for each permit; and
pays a separate fee for each application.

subsection.text: While a beauty salon permit is in effect, it authorizes the beauty salon permit holder to operate the beauty salon.
While a beauty salon permit for the limited practice of cosmetology is in effect, it authorizes the holder to operate a beauty salon only for the limited purpose for which the permit is issued.
Unless a beauty salon permit is renewed for a 2-year term as provided in this section, the permit expires on the first October 31 that comes:

paragraph.text: after the effective date of the permit; and
in an odd-numbered year.

subsection.text: At least 1 month before a beauty salon permit expires, the Board shall mail to the beauty salon permit holder, at the last known address of the holder:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

subparagraph.text: the date on which the current permit expires;
the date by which the Board must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the permit expires; and
the amount of the renewal fee.

subsection.text: Before a beauty salon permit expires, the beauty salon permit holder periodically may renew it for an additional 2-year term, if the holder:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to hold the permit;
pays to the Board a renewal fee established by the Board in accordance with the provisions of § 5-205 of this title; and
submits to the Board a renewal application on the form that the Board provides.

subsection.text: The Board shall renew the beauty salon permit of and issue a renewal certificate to each beauty salon permit holder who meets the requirements of this section.
The Secretary may determine that permits issued under this subtitle shall expire on a staggered basis.
The Board may reinstate a beauty salon permit that has expired if the owner of the salon:

paragraph.text: applies to the Board for reinstatement within 45 days after the permit expires;
otherwise meets the requirements of § 5–506(c) of this subtitle; and
pays to the Board a reinstatement fee established by the Board in accordance with § 5–205 of this title, in addition to the renewal fee required under § 5–506(c)(2) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: If an owner of a salon has failed to renew a beauty salon permit and applies to the Board for reinstatement more than 45 days after the permit has expired, the Board shall reinstate the permit only if the salon owner qualifies for a beauty salon permit in accordance with §§ 5–502 and 5–503 of this subtitle.
The Board may adopt regulations to ensure that each cosmetology school approved by the State Board of Education or the Maryland Higher Education Commission is operated in a sanitary manner.
The regulations adopted under subsection (a) of this section shall provide for:

paragraph.text: the reporting of violations of the regulations to the Department of Education or the Maryland Higher Education Commission; and
the imposition of a fine not to exceed $300 for a violation of the regulations.

subsection.text: In determining the amount of financial penalty to be imposed under this section, the Board shall consider the following:

paragraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the good faith of the violator;
the violator’s history of previous violations;
the deleterious effect of the violation on the complainant, the public, and the barber industry; and
any other factors relevant to the determination of the financial penalty.

subsection.text: The Board shall commence proceedings to assess a penalty under this section on a complaint to the Board by a member of the Board or any person.

paragraph.text: A complaint shall:

subparagraph.text: be in writing;
include the name and necessary contact information of the individual filing the complaint, as determined by the Board;
state specifically the facts on which the complaint is based;
be submitted to the Executive Director of the Board; and
be served on the person to whom it is directed:

sub-subparagraph.text: personally; or
by certified mail, return receipt requested, bearing a postmark from the United States Postal Service, to the person’s last known address as shown on the Board’s records.

paragraph.text: If service is made by certified mail, the person who mails the document shall file with the Board verified proof of mailing.

Except as provided in subsection (f) of this section, if the Board finds that a complaint alleges facts that are adequate grounds for action under this section, the Board shall act on the complaint as provided under § 5-523 of this subtitle to assess a penalty.
If the Board does not make the finding, the Board shall dismiss the complaint.

If the Board makes the finding under subsection (e)(1) of this section for a violation that relates to the sanitary condition of a cosmetology school or the sanitary practice of cosmetology, the Board shall provide the owner of the school an opportunity to correct the alleged violation.

If the owner fails to correct each alleged violation within 10 days of written notification of the violation by the Board, the Board shall act on the complaint as provided under § 5-523 of this subtitle.
If the owner corrects each alleged violation within 10 days of notice, the Board shall:

subparagraph.text: dismiss the complaint; and
provide the owner written notification of the dismissal.

paragraph.text: The Board may appoint inspectors to conduct inspections.
Subject to the State budget, each inspector is entitled to:

subparagraph.text: reasonable compensation set by the Board for each day on which the inspector is engaged in the duties of the appointment; and
reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations.

paragraph.text: The Board shall inspect beauty salons.
The Board shall inspect the facilities of applicants for beauty salon permits before the beauty salon:

subparagraph.text: initially opens for business;
opens for business at a new location; or
continues business under a new owner.

paragraph.text: A beauty salon that remodels and reopens with the same owner is not subject to the inspection requirement of this subsection.

The Board or an inspector may enter and inspect a cosmetology school approved by the State Board of Education or the Maryland Higher Education Commission at any time during business hours to determine the sanitary condition of the cosmetology school.
If, during an inspection of a cosmetology school, an inspector finds an unsanitary condition, the inspector promptly shall report the condition to the Board.
A beauty salon shall allow an inspector, on presentation of credentials, to enter and inspect the facility at any time during business hours.
During inspection of a beauty salon, the owner, lessee, or manager of the beauty salon shall accompany the inspector.
An inspector shall make an inspection report after an inspection and give a copy to the individual who accompanied the inspector during the inspection.
The individual shall sign the inspection report for the beauty salon or cosmetology school to acknowledge receipt of a copy of the report.

section.text: Each beauty salon permit holder shall display the beauty salon permit conspicuously in the beauty salon for which the permit is issued.

paragraph.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 5-523 of this subtitle, the Board may deny a beauty salon permit to any applicant, reprimand any permit holder, or suspend or revoke a beauty salon permit:

subparagraph.text: for any applicable ground under § 5-314 of this title;
if the applicant or holder fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a beauty salon permit for the applicant or holder or for another;
if the applicant or holder fraudulently or deceptively uses a beauty salon permit; or
if the holder fails to pay a civil penalty imposed by the Board under § 5-610 of this title.
Instead of or in addition to reprimanding a permit holder or suspending or revoking a beauty salon permit, the Board may impose a penalty not exceeding $300 for all violations cited on a single date.
To determine the amount of penalty imposed under this subsection, the Board shall consider:

sub-subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the good faith of the violator;
the violator’s history of previous violations;
the deleterious effect of the violation on the complainant, the public, and the cosmetology industry; and
any other factors relevant to the determination of the financial penalty.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: The Board shall commence proceedings under this section on a complaint to the Board by a member of the Board or any person.

paragraph.text: A complaint shall:

subparagraph.text: be in writing;
be signed by the complainant;
state specifically the facts on which the complaint is based;
be submitted to the Executive Director of the Board; and
be served on the person to whom it is directed:

sub-subparagraph.text: personally; or
by certified mail, return receipt requested, bearing a postmark from the United States Postal Service, to the person’s last known address as shown on the Board’s records.

paragraph.text: If service is made by certified mail, the person who mails the document shall file with the Board verified proof of mailing.

Except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, if the Board finds that a complaint alleges facts that are adequate grounds for action under this section, the Board shall act on the complaint as provided under § 5-523 of this subtitle to deny, suspend, or revoke a license, reprimand a licensee, or assess a penalty.
If the Board does not make the finding, the Board shall dismiss the complaint.

If the Board makes the finding under subsection (c)(1) of this section for a violation that relates to the sanitary condition of a beauty salon or the sanitary practice of cosmetology, the Board shall provide the owner of the salon an opportunity to correct the alleged violation.

If the owner fails to correct each alleged violation within 10 days of written notification of the violation by the Board, the Board shall act on the complaint as provided under § 5-523 of this subtitle.
If the owner corrects each alleged violation within 10 days of notice, the Board shall:

subparagraph.text: dismiss the complaint; and
provide the owner written notification of the dismissal.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 10-226 of the State Government Article, before the Board takes any final action under § 5-509, § 5-522, or § 5-608.1 of this title, it shall give the person against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Board.
The Board shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The hearing notice to be given to the person shall be served at least 5 days before the hearing.
The person may be represented at the hearing by counsel.

paragraph.text: The Board may issue a subpoena for the attendance of a witness to testify or the production of evidence in connection with any proceeding under this section.
A subpoena issued under this subsection shall be served by:

subparagraph.text: certified mail; or
the sheriff of the county where the person to be served resides or has a principal place of business.

subsection.text: If, after due notice, the person against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, nevertheless the Board may hear and determine the matter.

section.text: The Board may reinstate the beauty salon permit of a person whose beauty salon permit has been suspended or revoked under § 5-522 of this subtitle if the person:

paragraph.text: applies to the Board for reinstatement of the beauty salon permit; and
provides to the Board adequate evidence that the applicant is qualified to have the beauty salon permit reinstated.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, a person may not practice, attempt to practice, or offer to practice cosmetology in the State unless licensed by the Board to practice cosmetology.
A person may not operate a beauty salon in the State unless the person holds a beauty salon permit issued by the Board.
A person may not serve as an apprentice unless registered by the Board as an apprentice.

paragraph.text: Unless authorized under this title to practice cosmetology, a person may not represent to the public, by use of a title, including “licensed cosmetologist” or “licensed hairdresser”, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person is authorized to practice cosmetology in the State.

If an individual is authorized under this title to engage in the limited practice of cosmetology, the individual may represent to the public that the individual is authorized to practice cosmetology in a manner restricted to that limited practice.

subsection.text: Unless an establishment holds a beauty salon permit under this title, a person may not represent to the public, by title, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the establishment is a beauty salon.

Except as provided in §§ 5–302 and 5–303 of this title and subsection (b) of this section, a person may not practice cosmetology, provide esthetic services, or provide nail technician services in any place other than:

paragraph.text: a beauty salon that holds a beauty salon permit; or
a barbershop that holds a barbershop permit issued under Title 4 of this article.
A licensed cosmetologist, esthetician, or nail technician may practice cosmetology and provide services in:

subparagraph.text: a facility in which beautification–oriented medical services, authorized by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, are provided;
the residence of an individual confined to the residence by reason of a physical or mental infirmity;
an assisted living facility as defined in § 19–1801 of the Health – General Article;
a hospice facility defined in § 19–901(c) of the Health – General Article;
a nursing home as defined in § 19–1401(e) of the Health – General Article; or
a hospital as defined in § 19–301 of the Health – General Article or a similar institution.

paragraph.text: To practice in any of the locations specified in this subsection:

subparagraph.text: the licensed cosmetologist, esthetician, or nail technician shall be sponsored by a beauty salon in which the cosmetologist, esthetician, or nail technician is authorized to practice;
the patron to whom the services are rendered shall be a customer of the beauty salon; and
the services shall be rendered by appointment through the beauty salon.

section.text: An owner or lessee of a beauty salon may not allow any individual to:

paragraph.text: use as a residence any room that is used wholly or partly as a beauty salon; or
sleep in any room that is used wholly or partly as a beauty salon.

subsection.text: An owner or lessee of a beauty salon may not knowingly:

paragraph.text: employ in the beauty salon an individual with an infectious or contagious disease that presents a hazard to a patron; or
after discovering an individual has an infectious or contagious disease that presents a hazard to a patron, continue to employ the individual in the beauty salon.
An individual who knows that the individual has an infectious or contagious disease that presents a hazard to a beauty salon patron may not practice cosmetology.
An individual who knows that another individual has an infectious or contagious disease that presents a hazard to a beauty salon patron may not practice cosmetology on that other individual.

subsection.text: An individual may not practice cosmetology in a careless or negligent manner so as to:

paragraph.text: cause an infection; or
impart an infectious or contagious disease that presents a hazard to a beauty salon patron.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a school of cosmetology approved by the State Department of Education or the Maryland Higher Education Commission may not allow a student to practice cosmetology on the public.

A school of cosmetology approved by the State Department of Education or the Maryland Higher Education Commission may allow a student to practice cosmetology in accordance with § 5-302 or § 5-303 of this title.
A person may not use or possess methyl methacrylate liquid monomer (MMA) in a beauty salon in this State.

To determine whether a person is in violation of subsection (a) of this section, an inspector may chemically test products or take samples of products at random or when the inspector suspects that a product is illegal.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not to exceed $1,000 for all violations cited on a single day.

section.text: The Board may prohibit or restrict the use or possession of lasers in beauty salons.

subsection.text: A person who violates any provision of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $100 or imprisonment not exceeding 30 days or both.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided by this title, the Board may impose on a person who violates any provision of this title a penalty not exceeding $1,000 for all violations cited on a single day.
In setting the amount of the penalty, the Board shall consider:

subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the harm caused by the violation;
the good faith of the violator;
any history of previous violations by the violator; and
any other relevant factors.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: Following an inspection of a beauty salon, if a Board inspector determines that a licensee or permit holder has violated this title or a regulation adopted by the Board, the inspector may issue a citation to the licensee or permit holder.
A citation issued by a Board inspector shall be in writing and shall state:

paragraph.text: a brief description of each violation;
the amount of a civil penalty, as prescribed by regulation, for each violation; and
as provided in this section:

subparagraph.text: the time within which the civil penalty is to be paid;
the opportunity to contest the citation; and
the finality of the citation if it is not contested.

subsection.text: The citation shall be served on the licensee or permit holder alleged to have committed the violation by:

paragraph.text: hand-delivery; or
certified mail to the last known address of the licensee or permit holder.

subsection.text: Subject to subsections (e) and (f) of this section, the civil penalty set forth in a citation shall be paid within 60 days of its receipt.

A citation and the applicable civil penalty shall be considered a final order of the Board unless, within 60 days of being served with the citation, the licensee or permit holder notifies the Board in writing of an intent to contest the citation.

paragraph.text: Upon the receipt of a written notice of a licensee or permit holder’s intent to contest a citation, the Board shall hold a hearing, in accordance with § 5-315 or § 5-523 of this title, regarding the cited violations.
A hearing held in accordance with paragraph (1) of this subsection may not be delegated to the Office of Administrative Hearings under Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Board shall establish by regulation a schedule of civil penalties for violations of this title and regulations adopted by the Board.
The civil penalties imposed under this subsection may not exceed $300 for all violations cited on a single day.

section.text: This title may be cited as the “Maryland Cosmetologists Act”.

Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, this title and all regulations adopted under this title shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2021.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Assignment of local license” means any procedure by which a licensee grants to another person a right to use a local license to enable that person to engage in the business of providing electrical services.
“Assignment of local license” includes any procedure by which:

subparagraph.text: a licensee agrees to be the representative of another person; and
by virtue of that agreement, the other person is authorized to engage in the business of providing electrical services.

subsection.text: “Engage in the business of providing electrical services” means to engage in providing electrical services for compensation.
“License” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a license issued by the State Board or a local jurisdiction to provide electrical services.
“Licensed master electrician” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a master electrician who is licensed by the State Board or a local jurisdiction to provide electrical services.
“Local board” means a board that a local jurisdiction of the State creates to regulate any aspect of the electrical trade.
“Local license” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a license that is issued by a local board to provide electrical services as a master electrician.

“Master electrician” means an individual who has the experience, knowledge, and skill to provide electrical services in all aspects of the electrical trade, in a manner that complies with applicable plans, specifications, codes, or law.

paragraph.text: “Provide electrical services” means to provide any service in the electrical trade.
“Provide electrical services” includes installing, repairing, or altering any electrical wiring, fixture, appliance, apparatus, raceway, or conduit that:

subparagraph.text: generates, transmits, transforms, or uses electrical energy in any form for light, heat, power, or communication; and
is located within a plant, substation, or elsewhere.

subsection.text: “State Board” means the State Board of Master Electricians.
“State license” means a license that is issued by the State Board to a master electrician.

section.text: The policy of the State is to regulate, throughout the State, those persons who provide electrical services or engage in the business of providing electrical services, to safeguard the life, health, property, and public welfare of the citizens of the State.

subsection.text: This title does not affect the right of any local jurisdiction of the State:

paragraph.text: to regulate the quality and character of work of a person who engages in the business of providing electrical services by establishing a system of licenses, permits, fees, and inspections designed to:

subparagraph.text: ensure compliance with and implementation of State and local building laws; or
enforce other local laws protecting public health and safety;

paragraph.text: to require a person who engages in the business of providing electrical services to submit any plan or specification for approval before the electrical services are provided;
to establish a local board;
except as provided in §§ 6-504 and 6-602 of this title, to require an examination before issuing a license to provide electrical services within the local jurisdiction; or
to collect, from a person who is licensed with a local board, fees for:

subparagraph.text: an examination for a license to provide electrical services;
issuance and renewal of the license; or
an inspection.

subsection.text: If a local jurisdiction licenses any class of electricians other than master electricians, that class is also under the control and supervision of the local board.

This title may not be construed to waive any requirement of an ordinance or regulation that sets out the type of work to be performed by a person who engages in the business of providing electrical services as required under State or local building laws.

section.text: There is a State Board of Master Electricians in the Department.

paragraph.text: The State Board consists of 9 members appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.
Of the 9 members of the State Board:

subparagraph.text: 6 shall be licensed master electricians; and
3 shall be consumer members.

paragraph.text: Of the 6 master electrician members:

subparagraph.text: 1 shall be from Baltimore City;
1 shall be from the area that consists of Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne’s, Somerset, Talbot, Wicomico, and Worcester counties;
1 shall be from the area that consists of Baltimore, Cecil, and Harford counties;
1 shall be from the area that consists of Anne Arundel, Calvert, Charles, and St. Mary’s counties;
1 shall be from the area that consists of Montgomery and Prince George’s counties; and
1 shall be from the area that consists of Allegany, Carroll, Frederick, Garrett, Howard, and Washington counties.

paragraph.text: The consumer members shall be from the State at large.
A member of the State Board may not reside in the same county as another member.

subsection.text: Each member of the State Board shall be a citizen and resident of the State.
Each master electrician member of the State Board shall:
