paragraph.text: hold an active State license; and
be engaged actively in providing electrical services as a master electrician for at least 5 consecutive years immediately before appointment.

subsection.text: Each consumer member of the State Board:

paragraph.text: shall be a member of the general public;
may not be a licensee or otherwise be subject to regulation by the State Board;
may not be required to meet the qualifications for the professional members of the State Board; and
may not, within 1 year before appointment, have had a financial interest in or have received compensation from a person regulated by the State Board.

subsection.text: While a member of the State Board, a consumer member may not:

paragraph.text: have a financial interest in or receive compensation from a person regulated by the State Board; or
grade an examination given by or for the State Board.

subsection.text: Before taking office, each appointee to the State Board shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 3 years and begins on July 1.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the State Board on October 1, 1989.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member may not be reappointed for more than 2 consecutive 3-year terms.

subsection.text: The Governor may remove a member for incompetence or misconduct.
From among its members, the State Board annually shall elect a chairman, a vice chairman, and a secretary.

paragraph.text: The manner of election of officers shall be as the State Board determines.
The terms of the officers are for 1 year and begin on July 1.

subsection.text: A majority of the authorized membership of the State Board is a quorum.

paragraph.text: The State Board shall meet at least once a month, at the times that it determines, in the office of the State Board.
The State Board may hold special meetings as necessary.

subsection.text: Subject to the State budget, each member of the State Board is entitled to:

paragraph.text: an annual salary of $3,600; and
reimbursement for reasonable expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations.

subsection.text: The State Board may employ a staff in accordance with the State budget.

section.text: In addition to any powers and duties set forth elsewhere, the State Board shall:

paragraph.text: twice a year hold a seminar and invite members from each local licensing jurisdiction to discuss any industry or licensing problems; and
adopt regulations to establish:

subparagraph.text: application and examination fees;
continuing education requirements; and
application deadlines.

subsection.text: In connection with a proceeding, the State Board or a hearing officer whom the State Board designates:

paragraph.text: may hold hearings;
may administer oaths; and
by deposition in the same manner as provided in civil cases in the State or otherwise, may take testimony.
The State Board or its designee may issue a subpoena.
The police department of Baltimore City or the sheriff of a county shall serve a subpoena issued under this subsection.
If a person fails to comply with a subpoena issued under this subsection, on petition of the State Board, a circuit court may compel compliance with the subpoena.

If the State Board concludes that conduct alleged to be a violation of this title may result in irreparable harm to a person, the State Board may sue to enforce a provision of this title by ex parte, interlocutory, or final injunction.
The State Board shall bring suit under this subsection in the circuit court for the county where:

subparagraph.text: the violation allegedly is occurring; or
the principal place of business of the alleged violator is located.

paragraph.text: In seeking an injunction under this subsection, the State Board is not required to allege or prove that an adequate remedy at law does not exist.

section.text: The State Board shall pay all money collected under this title into the General Fund of the State.
The State Board exercises its powers, duties, and functions subject to the authority of the Secretary.

subsection.text: Each county shall:

paragraph.text: adopt regulations that have qualifications comparable to § 6–304, to provide for the licensing and regulation of master electricians; or

subparagraph.text: require a State license for providing electrical services as a master electrician; and
enforce the provisions of this title.

subsection.text: Each municipal corporation shall:

paragraph.text: adopt regulations that have qualifications comparable to, or more stringent than, § 6–304 of this subtitle to provide for the licensing and regulation of master electricians;
adopt the electrical rules and regulations of the county in which the municipal corporation is located; or

subparagraph.text: require a State license for providing electrical services as a master electrician; and
enforce the provisions of this title.

subsection.text: Each licensed master electrician shall display the State license number or the county license number of the licensee on each vehicle used on the job for providing electrical services.

A county or municipal corporation may not adopt a resolution or enact a law that requires a person licensed under this subtitle who is compliant with subsection (c) of this section to display additional license numbers on each vehicle used on the job for providing electrical services.

In a local jurisdiction that requires a local license, the State license, while the State license is in effect, serves only as a mechanism that helps a licensee in obtaining a local license under §§ 6-601 and 6-602 of this title.
If a county or municipal corporation does not require a local license, the State license, while the State license is in effect, authorizes the licensee to:

paragraph.text: provide electrical services as a master electrician; or
be the representative of another person who engages in the business of providing electrical services.

subsection.text: This subtitle does not require an individual to hold a State license while the individual provides electrical services as an employee or subordinate of a master electrician licensed by the State Board if:

paragraph.text: the individual provides electrical services while under the control and supervision of the licensee; and
the licensee is responsible for the electrical services that the individual provides.

subsection.text: This subtitle does not require:

paragraph.text: a public utility company to employ a master electrician to represent the company while the company is engaging in the business of providing electrical services to a facility of the company that:

subparagraph.text: is regulated by the Public Service Commission; and
is located on any premises, roadway, or right-of-way in which the company has a lawful interest; or

paragraph.text: an employee of a public utility company to hold a State license while the employee provides electrical services to a facility of the company that:

subparagraph.text: is regulated by the Public Service Commission; and
is located on any premises, roadway, or right-of-way in which the company has a lawful interest.

subsection.text: To qualify for a State license, an applicant shall be an individual who meets the requirements of this section.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the applicant shall have been engaged or employed regularly and principally in providing electrical services for all types of electrical equipment and apparatus for at least 7 years while under the direction and supervision of:

subparagraph.text: a master electrician; or
a similarly qualified employee of a governmental unit.

paragraph.text: The State Board may allow an applicant up to 3 years of credit toward the experience required under paragraph (1) of this subsection, if the State Board determines that the applicant has completed a formal course of study or professional training in electrical installation comparable to the required experience.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, the applicant shall pass an examination given by the State Board under this subtitle.
The State Board may investigate the qualifications of each applicant to determine whether the applicant meets the requirements of this section.

section.text: An applicant for a State license shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the State Board an application on the form that the State Board provides; and
pay to the State Board or the State Board’s designee an examination fee set by the Board in an amount not to exceed the cost of the required examination.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 6-306.1 of this subtitle, an applicant who otherwise qualifies for a State license is entitled to be examined as provided in this section.
The State Board shall give examinations to qualified applicants at least twice a year, at the dates, times, and places that the State Board determines.

paragraph.text: At least 15 days before the examination, the State Board shall notify each applicant whether the applicant is eligible to be examined under this section.
The notice shall specify the passing score for the examination.
The State Board shall determine the subjects and scope of the examination from a list of questions submitted by the Maryland Uniform Electrical Licensing Examination Committee, Inc.
The State Board shall choose examination questions that:

subparagraph.text: test the applicant’s knowledge of all applicable codes, laws, or principles of electrical installation; and
are constructed to determine the fitness of the applicant for a State license.

paragraph.text: The State Board may appoint a committee to develop examination questions.

subsection.text: The form of the examination shall be objective and written.
The passing score for the examination shall be 70%.
Within 45 days after the examination, the State Board shall mail to each applicant notice of the applicant’s examination score.

On written request to the State Board, an applicant who failed an examination may review the answers that the applicant gave and the scores for those answers, at a time and place that the State Board determines.

paragraph.text: If an applicant fails to appear for a scheduled examination, the applicant may reapply for an examination.
The applicant:

subparagraph.text: shall submit to the State Board an application for reexamination on the form that the State Board provides; and
unless, for good cause, the State Board waives payment of the examination fee, shall again pay the examination fee under § 6-305 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The State Board may use a testing service to administer the examinations given under this title.
If the State Board uses a testing service, the testing service, subject to the requirements set by the State Board, may:

paragraph.text: set the time and place of examinations;
give qualified applicants notice of the time and place of examinations; and
furnish any other information that the State Board may require the testing service to provide.

subsection.text: Subject to the limitations in this section, the State Board shall waive the examination requirements of this subtitle for an individual who holds a local license.
The State Board shall grant a waiver under this section only if the applicant:

paragraph.text: pays the application fee established by the Board under § 6-205 of this title;
provides adequate evidence that the applicant:

subparagraph.text: meets the qualifications otherwise required by this subtitle; and
is licensed in a local jurisdiction after:

sub-subparagraph.text: passing, in that local jurisdiction, an examination that is equivalent to the examination for which the applicant is seeking the waiver; and
meeting, in that local jurisdiction, requirements that are equivalent to the licensing requirements of this subtitle; and

paragraph.text: submits a statement from the local jurisdiction certifying:

subparagraph.text: the applicant is in good standing with the local jurisdiction;
the applicant obtained the local license by taking an examination equivalent to the examination given by the State Board; and
the date of the local examination.

subsection.text: An initial State license that is obtained under this section may not be reinstated unless the requirements of § 6-312 of this subtitle are met.

Subject to the limitations in this section, on the affirmative vote of at least a majority of the authorized membership of the State Board, the State Board may waive the examination requirements of this subtitle for an individual who is licensed to provide electrical services as a master electrician in another state.
The State Board may grant a waiver under this section only if the applicant:

paragraph.text: pays the appropriate application fee set by the Board under § 6-205(2) of this title; and
provides adequate evidence that the applicant:

subparagraph.text: meets the qualifications otherwise required by this subtitle;
holds an active license in good standing in the other state;
holds a license that is equivalent to the State license; and

meets a 7-year experience requirement in providing electrical services, at least 4 years of which must have been gained prior to licensure in the other state, while under the supervision of a master electrician or similarly qualified employee of a governmental unit.

subsection.text: The State Board may grant a waiver only if the state in which the applicant is licensed waives the examination of licensees of this State to a similar extent as this State waives the examination requirements for individuals licensed in that state.

The Board may allow an applicant up to 3 years credit toward the experience required under subsection (b)(2) of this section, if the State Board determines that the applicant has completed a formal course of study or professional training in electrical installation comparable to the required experience.
If an applicant qualifies for a State license under this subtitle, the State Board shall send the applicant a notice that states that:

paragraph.text: the applicant has qualified for a State license; and
the State Board will issue a State license to the applicant on receipt of:

subparagraph.text: $20; and
proof of general liability and property damage insurance as required under § 6-604 of this title.

paragraph.text: If, at the time of application, an applicant intends to assign to another person a local license that is obtained by use of a State license, the applicant shall identify on the application the person to whom the applicant is assigning the local license.

On payment of the State license fee and receipt of the proof of insurance required under § 6-604 of this title, the State Board shall issue a State license to each applicant who meets the requirements of this title.

subsection.text: The State Board shall include on each State license that the State Board issues:

paragraph.text: the name of the licensee; and
if the licensee assigns a local license to another person who engages in the business of providing electrical services, the name of the person.

subsection.text: Unless a State license is renewed for a 2-year term as provided in this section, the State license expires on the first June 30 that comes:

paragraph.text: after the effective date of the State license; and
in an odd-numbered year.

subsection.text: At least 1 month before a State license expires, the State Board shall mail to the State licensee, at the last known address of the State licensee:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

subparagraph.text: the date on which the current State license expires;
the date by which the State Board must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the State license expires; and
the amount of the renewal fee.

subsection.text: Before a State license expires, the State licensee periodically may renew it for an additional 2–year term, if the State licensee:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be licensed;
pays to the State Board a renewal fee of $25;
complies with continuing education requirements established by the State Board in regulation; and
submits to the State Board a renewal application on the form that the State Board provides.

subsection.text: The State Board shall renew the State license of each State licensee who meets the requirements of this section.
A State license to provide electrical services is not transferable.
The Secretary may determine that State licenses issued under this subtitle shall expire on a staggered basis.
The State Board shall place a State licensee on inactive status and issue an inactive status certificate to the State licensee, if the State licensee:

paragraph.text: submits to the State Board an application for inactive status on the form that the State Board provides;
pays to the State Board any applicable inactive status application fee;
except for the insurance requirements of § 6-604 of this title, qualifies for an active State license; and
returns the State license to the State Board.

subsection.text: The State Board shall place an applicant for an initial State license on inactive status and issue an inactive status certificate to the applicant, if the applicant:

paragraph.text: submits to the State Board an application for inactive status on the form that the State Board provides;
pays to the State Board an inactive status application fee of an amount equal to the State license fee under § 6-309 of this subtitle; and
except for the insurance requirements of § 6-604 of this title, qualifies for an active State license.
A licensee on inactive status may not use a State license to obtain a local license for providing electrical services as a master electrician in a local jurisdiction of the State.
In a county that requires a State license, a licensee on inactive status may not provide electrical services as a master electrician.
Unless the individual applies for another 2-year term as provided in this subsection, an individual on inactive status loses that status on the first June 30 that comes:

subparagraph.text: after the inactive status registration certificate is issued to the licensee; and
in an odd-numbered year.

paragraph.text: At least 1 month before the inactive status of an individual expires, the State Board shall mail to the individual, at the last known address of the individual:

subparagraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

sub-subparagraph.text: the date on which the inactive status expires;
the date by which the State Board must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the inactive status expires; and
the amount of the renewal fee.

paragraph.text: Before the inactive status expires, an individual on inactive status periodically may renew it for an additional 2-year term, if the individual:

subparagraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be placed on inactive status;
except for an electrical inspector, pays to the State Board a renewal fee of $50; and
submits to the State Board a renewal application on the form that the Board provides.

paragraph.text: After an inactive status expires, the former licensee may reapply for inactive status only if the former licensee:

subparagraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be placed on inactive status;
pays to the Board a reapplication fee of $100; and
reapplies to the Board for inactive status within 2 years after initial expiration of inactive status on a form that the Board provides.

paragraph.text: The State Board shall renew the inactive status of each individual or grant the reapplication for inactive status of each former licensee who meets the requirements of this subsection.

subsection.text: If a former licensee on inactive status who has failed to renew the inactive status within 2 years of its expiration reapplies for that status, the State Board shall require the former licensee to comply with the requirements for obtaining a State license under §§ 6-304, 6-307, and 6-503 of this title as well as the requirements for inactive status under this section.
The State Board shall reactivate the State license of an individual who is on inactive status, if the individual:

paragraph.text: meets the renewal requirements that are in effect when the individual requests the reactivation of the State license;
submits to the State Board an application for reactivation on the form that the State Board provides; and
pays to the State Board a reactivation fee of $50.

subsection.text: The State Board shall reinstate the State license of a master electrician who is not on inactive status and who has failed to renew the State license for any reason, if the master electrician:

paragraph.text: applies to the State Board for reinstatement within 2 years after the State license expires;
meets the renewal requirements of § 6-310 of this subtitle; and
in addition to the renewal fee required under § 6-310 of this subtitle, pays to the State Board a reinstatement fee of:

subparagraph.text: $25 for up to and including a 30-day late renewal;
$50 for up to and including a 60-day late renewal; or
$100 for a late renewal over 60 days.

subsection.text: If a master electrician who has failed to renew the State license for any reason applies for reinstatement more than 2 years after the State license has expired, the State Board shall require the master electrician to pay a reinstatement fee of $100, and comply with the requirements for obtaining a State license under §§ 6-304, 6-307, and 6-503 of this title.
An individual may not have any financial interest in any electrical business while employed by the State, a county, or a local government as an electrical inspector.

paragraph.text: On appointment or employment as an electrical inspector, the individual:

subparagraph.text: shall place the State license of the individual on inactive status; and
except for the renewal fee, shall meet the inactive status requirements of § 6-311 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The State Board may issue an electrical inspector identification card to an electrical inspector who has placed the State license on inactive status.
The State Board may not charge a fee to issue the identification card.

subsection.text: The State Board may change the status of an electrical inspector to individual inactive status, if the electrical inspector:

paragraph.text: meets the inactive status requirements of § 6-311 of this subtitle; and
pays an inactive status fee of $50.

subsection.text: On termination of the appointment or employment of an individual as an electrical inspector, the State Board shall reactivate the State license of the individual who is on inactive status, without examination, if the individual meets the reactivation requirements for a State license under § 6-311(f) of this subtitle, including payment of the reactivation fee.

section.text: Within 10 days after the change, each State licensee shall give the State Board written notice of a change of:

paragraph.text: the name of the State licensee;
the address of:

subparagraph.text: the State licensee; or
the person to whom the State licensee assigns a local license; or

paragraph.text: the employment of the State licensee, including a change in the assignment of a local license.

section.text: The State Board may investigate or act in a disciplinary proceeding against a licensed master electrician notwithstanding:

paragraph.text: a lapse, by operation of law, of the State license of the master electrician;
a suspension of the State license of the master electrician by order of the State Board or a court; or
a voluntary surrender of the State license of the master electrician to the State Board.

subsection.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 6-317 of this subtitle, the State Board may deny a State license to any applicant, reprimand any State licensee, or suspend or revoke a State license if the applicant or State licensee:

paragraph.text: fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a State license for the applicant, State licensee, or another person;
fraudulently or deceptively uses a State license;
transfers the authority granted by a State license to another person;
engages in an unfair or deceptive trade practice, as defined in § 13-301 of the Commercial Law Article;
willfully or deliberately disregards and violates a building code, electrical code, or law of the State or a local jurisdiction;
under the laws of the United States or of any state, is convicted of:

subparagraph.text: a felony; or
a misdemeanor that is directly related to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to provide electrical services;

paragraph.text: aids or abets a person to evade a provision of this title;
willfully or deliberately disregards disciplinary action taken by a local jurisdiction;
fails in a material respect to comply with a provision of this title;
fails to train and control adequately a person who, while under the supervision of the State licensee, sells or estimates electrical work;
fails to maintain a local license under § 6-601 of this title; or
fails to maintain the general liability and property damage insurance required under § 6-604 of this title.

subsection.text: Allowing a State license to be used by another person is, in a disciplinary proceeding under this section, prima facie evidence that a State licensee transferred the authority granted by a State license to another person.

The Board shall consider the following facts in the granting, denial, renewal, suspension, or revocation of a license or the reprimand of a licensee when an applicant or licensee is convicted of a felony or misdemeanor described in subsection (a)(6) of this section:

paragraph.text: the nature of the crime;
the relationship of the crime to the activities authorized by the license;
with respect to a felony, the relevance of the conviction to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to provide electrical services;
the length of time since the conviction; and
the behavior and activities of the applicant or licensee before and after the conviction.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 10-226 of the State Government Article, before the State Board takes any final action under § 6-316 of this subtitle, it shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the State Board.
The State Board shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
If, after due notice, the individual against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, nevertheless the State Board may hear and determine the matter.

section.text: Any person aggrieved by a final decision of the State Board in a contested case, as defined in § 10-202 of the State Government Article, may take an appeal as allowed in §§ 10-222 and 10-223 of the State Government Article.

subsection.text: The State Board may not suspend a State license for more than 1 year.
The State Board may not revoke a State license for less than 1 year.
If a State license is suspended, the State Board may allow the licensee to complete a contract to provide electrical services that is in progress and uncompleted at the time of suspension.

paragraph.text: If a State license is revoked, the State Board may reinstate the State license after 1 year.
A State license that has been revoked may be reinstated under this subsection if:

subparagraph.text: the individual whose State license has been revoked submits a written request to the State Board;
the State Board holds a hearing on the request; and
the State Board makes a determination to reinstate the State license.

section.text: Within 30 days after taking action, the State Board shall give each local board or building official notice of the name of each master electrician whose State license has been suspended, revoked, or reinstated by the State Board.

paragraph.text: When a county or municipal corporation that requires a local license initiates a disciplinary action against a licensed master electrician, the county or municipal corporation shall report the disciplinary action to the State Board within 30 days of commencement of the action.

When the State Board receives notice of a local disciplinary action against a licensed master electrician, the State Board shall provide notice of the disciplinary action to each local licensing jurisdiction.

subsection.text: Each local licensing jurisdiction shall submit a report to the State Board on the number of complaints against master electricians licensed in the local jurisdiction on or before December 1 of each year.
Subject to the limitations in this subtitle, an individual who holds a State license or qualifies for a State license may use the State license to:

paragraph.text: obtain a local license; and
assign that local license to another person, including a sole proprietorship, who engages in the business of providing electrical services.

Subject to the limitations in this section, if an individual obtains a State license on the basis of a local license under Subtitle 5 of this title and that local license has been assigned to a person who engages in the business of providing electrical services, the individual shall identify on the State license the person to whom that local license has been assigned.

Subject to the limitations in this section, if an individual obtains a local license on the basis of a State license and intends to assign that local license to a person who engages in the business of providing electrical services, the individual shall identify on the State license the person to whom that local license is to be assigned.
If, at the time of application for a State license, an individual intends to assign a local license obtained on the basis of the State license, the individual shall:

subparagraph.text: meet the requirements for issuance of a State license under § 6-309 of this title;
include, on the application form submitted to the State Board, the name of the person to whom the local license is to be assigned;
pay the appropriate State license fee under § 6-309 of this title; and
submit to the State Board proof of general liability and property damage insurance as required under § 6-604 of this title.

paragraph.text: If an individual obtains a State license on the basis of a local license that has been assigned, the individual shall:

subparagraph.text: meet the requirements for issuance of a State license under § 6-309 of this title;
include, on an application form submitted to the State Board, the name of the person to whom the local license has been assigned;
pay the appropriate State license fee under § 6-309 of this title; and
submit to the State Board proof of general liability and property damage insurance as required under § 6-604 of this title.

paragraph.text: If, after issuance of a State license to an individual, the individual intends to assign a local license obtained on the basis of the State license, the individual shall:

subparagraph.text: meet the notification requirements of § 6-314 of this title;
submit to the State Board an application for identification of the assignment on the State license;
pay to the State Board an identification fee of $50;
submit to the State Board proof of general liability and property damage insurance as required under § 6-604 of this title; and
return the State license.

paragraph.text: If an individual obtains a local license by the use of the State license of the individual, the local license may be assigned at any 1 time to only 1 person who engages in the business of providing electrical services.

If at any time an individual holds 2 or more current local licenses that were obtained by the use of a State license, the individual may assign those local licenses only if the assignment is made to the same person.

subsection.text: Subject to the limitations in this section and § 6-314 of this title, a master electrician who is licensed by the State Board and who assigns a local license to a person who engages in the business of providing electrical services may change that assignment.
To change an assignment of a local license, an applicant shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the State Board an application on the form that the State Board provides;
pay to the State Board a change of status fee of $50;
submit to the State Board proof of the change of status of the local license; and
return the State license to the State Board.

subsection.text: On payment of the change of status fee, the State Board shall issue a new license to the applicant.
The State Board shall give each local jurisdiction notice of any change in the status of a local license obtained by the use of a State license that will affect the status of the State license.

section.text: In this subtitle, “reciprocal license”:

paragraph.text: means a license to provide electrical services issued by:

subparagraph.text: the State Board on the basis of a license issued by a local jurisdiction; or
a local jurisdiction on the basis of a license issued by:

sub-subparagraph.text: the State Board; or
another local jurisdiction; and

paragraph.text: includes any type or class of license that the State Board or a local jurisdiction issues to provide electrical services.

subsection.text: Subject to the limitations in this title, the State Board may reciprocate with a local jurisdiction to waive any of the qualifications required for any license issued under this title for an applicant for a reciprocal license.

Subject to the limitations in this subtitle, each local jurisdiction may reciprocate with the State Board or another local jurisdiction to waive any local examination requirement and the qualifications required for taking a local examination for an applicant for a reciprocal license.
Subject to the limitations in this subtitle, an individual may qualify for a reciprocal license from the State Board if the individual:

paragraph.text: holds a license from a local jurisdiction of the State to provide electrical services in the local jurisdiction;
applies for a reciprocal license of the same class or type that the State Board issues; and
at the time of application, does not have:

subparagraph.text: the same class or type of license suspended or revoked by a local jurisdiction of the State; or
a record of outstanding violations of the regulations of a local jurisdiction of the State.

subsection.text: The State Board shall waive any of the qualifications required for a license under this title for an individual who:

paragraph.text: holds a license, from a local jurisdiction of the State, of the same class or type as the license for which the applicant is seeking a waiver; and
meets the waiver requirements of subsection (c) of this section.

subsection.text: The State Board shall grant a waiver under this section for an applicant who holds a license from a local jurisdiction only if the applicant:

sub-subparagraph.text: qualified for the license by passing an examination given in the local jurisdiction; and
has held the license for at least 1 year immediately before the date of application; or
qualified for the license other than by passing an examination in the local jurisdiction; and
has held the license for at least 2 years immediately before the date of application;

paragraph.text: submits a written statement from the local jurisdiction certifying:

subparagraph.text: if the license is issued on the basis of an examination, the date of issuance of the license; and
the licensee:

sub-subparagraph.text: is in good standing with the local jurisdiction; and
has no record of outstanding violations of regulations of the local jurisdiction;

paragraph.text: pays any reciprocal license fee required under this title;
if required, submits proof of general liability insurance to the State Board; and
complies with any other licensing requirements of the State Board.

subsection.text: Subject to the limitations in this subtitle, an individual may qualify for a reciprocal license from a local jurisdiction of the State if the individual:

paragraph.text: is licensed by another local jurisdiction of the State to provide electrical services in that local jurisdiction;
applies for a reciprocal license of the same class or type as the license that the individual holds in that local jurisdiction; and
at the time of application, does not have:

subparagraph.text: a license of the same class or type suspended or revoked by a local jurisdiction of the State; or
a record of outstanding violations of the regulations of a local jurisdiction of the State.

subsection.text: A local jurisdiction of the State that issues a license to provide electrical services shall waive any of the licensing qualifications of the local jurisdiction for an individual who:

subparagraph.text: is a resident of the State; or
meets the legal requirements of the State for establishing a principal place of business in the State;

paragraph.text: holds a license, from another local jurisdiction of the State, of the same class or type as the license for which the applicant is seeking a waiver; and
meets the waiver requirements of subsection (c) of this section.

subsection.text: A local jurisdiction shall grant a waiver under this section for an applicant who holds a license from another local jurisdiction only if the applicant:

sub-subparagraph.text: qualified for the license by passing an examination given in that local jurisdiction; and
has held the license for at least 1 year immediately before the date of application; or
qualified for the license other than by passing an examination in that local jurisdiction; and
has held the license for at least 2 years immediately before the date of application;

paragraph.text: submits a written statement from the local jurisdiction certifying:

subparagraph.text: if a license is issued on the basis of an examination, the date of issuance of the license; and
the licensee:

sub-subparagraph.text: is in good standing with the local jurisdiction; and
has no record of outstanding violations of the regulations of the local jurisdiction;

paragraph.text: pays any reciprocal license fee required by the local jurisdiction;
if required:

subparagraph.text: executes a bond to the local jurisdiction; or
submits proof of general liability insurance to the local jurisdiction; and

paragraph.text: complies with any other licensing requirements of the local jurisdiction.

subsection.text: Before a reciprocal license expires, the licensee periodically may renew it for an additional term, if the licensee:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be licensed;
pays a renewal fee to:

subparagraph.text: the State Board as required under this title; or
the local jurisdiction from which the reciprocal license is sought; and

paragraph.text: meets any other requirement for renewal set by:

subparagraph.text: the State Board; or
the local jurisdiction from which the reciprocal license is sought.

subsection.text: A reciprocal license issued to an individual who has failed to renew the license may not be reinstated.
A reciprocal license issued under this subtitle is not transferable.

Subject to subsection (b) of this section, an individual who holds a reciprocal license may assign it to a person who engages in the business of providing electrical services if the individual is employed principally by the person.
An individual may reassign the reciprocal license of the individual once in a fiscal year.

section.text: Within 60 days after the issuance of a State license to an individual, the individual shall hold a local license issued by the local jurisdiction where the individual:

paragraph.text: resides;
has a principal business office; or
has a resident agent.

subsection.text: Subject to the limitations in this section, a local jurisdiction shall waive its examination requirements for an individual who is licensed by the State Board to provide electrical services as a master electrician.
A local jurisdiction shall grant a waiver under this section only if the applicant:

paragraph.text: pays any license fee that the local jurisdiction requires; and
provides adequate evidence that the applicant:

subparagraph.text: is licensed as a master electrician under this title after passing an examination given by the State Board or complies with § 6-307 of this title;
holds an active State license; and
in place of any bond requirement of a local jurisdiction, meets the insurance requirements of § 6-604 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Within 10 working days after payment of any local license fee, a local jurisdiction shall issue a local license to each applicant who meets the requirements of this section.
A master electrician may obtain an electrical permit or any other similar permit from a local jurisdiction, if the master electrician:

paragraph.text: holds an active local license, if required, or a State license;
shows proof of the State license; and
pays any permit fee that the local jurisdiction requires.

subsection.text: Before a local jurisdiction issues an electrical permit or similar permit to a master electrician under this section, the local jurisdiction shall give the master electrician notice of any local electrical requirements with which the master electrician shall comply while providing electrical services in that local jurisdiction.
On payment of the permit fee that the local jurisdiction requires, the local jurisdiction shall issue the appropriate permit to each applicant who meets the requirements of this section.
This section does not apply to a State licensee on inactive status.
A master electrician who is licensed by the State Board and provides electrical services or a person to whom the master electrician assigns a local license under this title shall:

paragraph.text: maintain general liability insurance in the amount of at least $300,000;
maintain property damage insurance in the amount of at least $100,000; and
submit proof of the required insurance to the State Board.
An applicant for a State license shall submit proof of the insurance required under this section to the State Board with the license application.
The State Board may not issue a State license to an applicant to whom the insurance requirements of this section would apply unless the applicant submits proof of the insurance.

subsection.text: Unless an applicant meets the insurance requirements of this section, the State Board may not renew a State license of the applicant to whom the insurance requirements of this section would apply.
If the insurance required under this section is canceled, the insurer shall notify the State Board within 10 days after the date of cancellation.

If a local jurisdiction requires an applicant for a local license to execute a bond to the local jurisdiction, the applicant may satisfy the bond requirement by submitting proof of the insurance required under this section.

section.text: A licensed master electrician or a person to whom a master electrician assigns a local license may employ an individual who is not a licensed master electrician under this title to provide electrical services if the individual provides the services only while under the supervision and control of a licensed master electrician.

subsection.text: The General Assembly intends that the revenues of the State Board be sufficient to meet its costs, including reasonably apportioned Department overhead.
The Secretary shall:

paragraph.text: monitor the fees and other revenue of the State Board for compliance with the intent of this section; and
recommend adjustments, if necessary.

section.text: This title may be cited as the “Maryland Master Electricians Act”.

Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, this title and all regulations adopted under this title shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2023.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the State Board of Stationary Engineers.
“Boiler” means:

paragraph.text: a closed vessel in which water is heated, steam is generated, steam is superheated, or a combination of these functions is accomplished, under pressure or vacuum for use externally to the vessel by the direct application of heat from the combustion of fuels or from electricity or nuclear energy; or
a fired unit for heating or vaporizing liquids other than water if the unit is separate from a processing system and is complete within itself.

subsection.text: “Heating boiler” means:

paragraph.text: a steam boiler that operates at pressures not exceeding 15 psig; or
a hot water boiler that operates at pressures not exceeding 160 psig or temperatures not exceeding 250 degrees Fahrenheit.
“License” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a license issued by the Board to perform the functions of a stationary engineer.
“License” includes, unless the context requires otherwise:

subparagraph.text: a Grade 5 license;
a Grade 4 license;
a Grade 3 license;
a Grade 2 license; and
a Grade 1 license.

paragraph.text: “Provide stationary engineer services” means to oversee the operation of a power plant, plant of machinery, or boiler, each generating pressure of more than 15 psi and operating at 30 or more horsepower.
“Provide stationary engineer services” does not include overseeing the operation of a heating boiler.

subsection.text: “Stationary engineer” means an individual who is licensed by the Board to provide stationary engineer services in accordance with the license grades described in § 6.5–302 of this title.

section.text: The purpose of this title is to establish a licensing program to ensure that qualified individuals provide stationary engineer services to:

paragraph.text: protect the public;
provide for the safe operation of power plants, plants of machinery, and boilers; and
promote high professional standards.

section.text: The provisions of this title and any regulations adopted under this title may not supersede the authority of the Board of Boiler Rules to implement boiler and pressure vessel safety standards established under Title 12, Subtitle 9 of the Public Safety Article or any regulations adopted under that subtitle.
There is a State Board of Stationary Engineers in the Department.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of eight members appointed by the Governor with the advice of the Secretary and the Senate.
Of the eight members of the Board:

subparagraph.text: three shall be stationary engineers;
one shall be a representative from the boiler manufacture and design industry;
one shall be a boiler owner;
two shall be consumer members; and
one shall be the Chief Boiler Inspector of the State, or the Chief Boiler Inspector’s designee, who shall be an ex officio, nonvoting member of the Board.

subsection.text: Each member of the Board shall be:

paragraph.text: a citizen of the United States; and
a resident of the State.
At least two of the engineer members of the Board shall hold a Grade 1 stationary engineer license.
Each engineer member of the Board shall:

subparagraph.text: have at least 10 years practical experience in running steam engines, boilers, and appliances pertaining to stationary and portable engines; and
hold a State license at all times during the member’s term on the Board.

subsection.text: Each consumer member of the Board:

paragraph.text: shall be a member of the general public;
may not be a licensee or otherwise be subject to regulation by the Board; and
may not have had within 1 year before appointment a financial interest in or have received compensation from a person regulated by the Board.

subsection.text: Before taking office, each appointee to the Board shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 3 years and begins on July 1.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on October 1, 2005.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
Each member of the Board is eligible for reappointment but may not serve more than two consecutive terms.

subsection.text: The Governor may remove a member for incompetence, misconduct, neglect of duties, or other sufficient cause.
From among its members, the Board shall elect a chair and other officers as necessary.
The manner of election and the term of an officer shall be as the Board determines.
A majority of the voting members then serving on the Board is a quorum.

paragraph.text: The Board shall meet at least twice a year at a location and in an office provided by the State.
The Board may hold special meetings as provided in its regulations.
The Board shall meet with and consult the Board of Boiler Rules as necessary but not less than two times each year.

subsection.text: A member of the Board:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Board may employ a staff in accordance with the State budget.
The Board shall:

paragraph.text: adopt regulations to carry out the provisions of this title;
administer examinations;
issue licenses;
maintain a list of all licensees; and
maintain a record of its proceedings.

subsection.text: The Board shall make available through written, electronic, or other means:

paragraph.text: to each applicant for a license, a copy of the Maryland Stationary Engineers Act and the Board’s regulations; and

on each renewal of a license, to each licensee, a copy of any amendments to the Maryland Stationary Engineers Act and the Board’s regulations that took effect during the 2-year period ending on the date of renewal.

subsection.text: The Board may investigate any complaint that alleges a violation of this title.
On receipt of the results of an investigation made under this section, the Board shall promptly take action that is appropriate under this title to ensure compliance with the title.

paragraph.text: If the Board concludes that any conduct alleged to be in violation of this title will result in harm to a citizen of the State, the Board may seek a permanent or temporary injunction with respect to the conduct from the circuit court of any county in which the alleged violation occurs.
In seeking an injunction under this subsection, the Board is not required to:

subparagraph.text: post bond;
allege or prove that an adequate remedy at law does not exist; or
allege or prove that substantial or irreparable damage would result from the continued violation of the provision.

paragraph.text: A member of the Board may not be held personally liable for any action taken under this subsection in good faith and with reasonable grounds.

subsection.text: The Board, or a hearing officer designated by the Board, may administer oaths, hold hearings, and take testimony about all matters within the jurisdiction of the Board.

paragraph.text: The Board or its designee may issue a subpoena for the attendance of a witness to testify or the production of evidence in connection with:

subparagraph.text: a disciplinary action brought under § 6.5-314 of this title; and
a proceeding brought for an alleged violation of this title.

paragraph.text: If a person fails to comply with a subpoena issued under this subsection, on petition of the Board, a court of competent jurisdiction may compel compliance with the subpoena.

subsection.text: A member of the Board may not be held personally liable for any action taken under this section.
Subject to subsections (b) and (c) of this section, the Board may set reasonable fees for its services.
Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, revenues generated by the Board shall be at least equal to the direct and indirect costs associated with the operation of the Board.
The Board shall require the following fees for the issuance or renewal of the following licenses:

paragraph.text: Grade 1 license - $65;
Grade 2 or Grade 3 license - $50; and
Grade 4 or Grade 5 license - $35.

subsection.text: The Board shall pay all money collected under this title into the General Fund of the State.

section.text: The Board exercises its powers, duties, and functions subject to the authority of the Secretary.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, an individual shall be licensed by the Board to provide stationary engineer services before the individual may provide stationary engineer services in the State.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “resource recovery facility” means a facility that processes solid waste to produce valuable resources, including steam, electricity, metals, or refuse–derived fuel.

An individual who provides stationary engineer services at a resource recovery facility that generates steam or electricity is not required to be licensed by the Board to provide stationary engineer services if the individual is certified to operate a resource recovery facility under regulations adopted by the Secretary of the Environment.

subsection.text: A Grade 5 stationary engineer licensee may oversee the operation of a boiler that:

subparagraph.text: can be operated at 30 to 99 horsepower; and
is located in a building not open for public use;

paragraph.text: is inspected in accordance with the boiler laws and regulations by a special inspector or a deputy boiler inspector;
if not equipped with a 24–hour computerized monitoring system and automatic controls, is visited by a Grade 5 licensee at least once every 24 hours that the boiler is in operation; and
if equipped with a 24–hour computerized monitoring system and automatic controls, is visited by a Grade 5 licensee at least once per week that the boiler is in operation, if the licensee:

subparagraph.text: is responsible for the safe operation of the equipment at all times;
is available to observe the monitoring equipment or devices and make the necessary adjustments at least once every 24 hours; and
maintains a daily inspection log.

subsection.text: A Grade 4 stationary engineer licensee may oversee the operation of a boiler that:

subparagraph.text: can operate at 30 to 99 horsepower; and
is located in a building open for public use;

paragraph.text: is inspected in accordance with the boiler laws and regulations by a special inspector or a deputy boiler inspector;
if not equipped with a 24–hour computerized monitoring system and automatic controls, is attended by a Grade 4 licensee as follows:

subparagraph.text: at all times that the boiler is in operation; or
if located in a school:

sub-subparagraph.text: at all times during regular school hours; and
only when at least 150 students, faculty, or members of the public occupy the building where the boiler is located during nonregular school hours;

paragraph.text: if equipped with a 24–hour computerized monitoring system and automatic controls, is attended by a Grade 4 licensee as follows:

subparagraph.text: if located in a hospital, hotel, residential facility, or other building generally open to the public, is visited at least once every 8 hours that the building is open for public use, if the licensee:

sub-subparagraph.text: is responsible for the safe operation of such equipment at all times;
is available to observe the monitoring equipment or devices and make necessary adjustments at least once every 24 hours; and
maintains a daily inspection log; and

subparagraph.text: if located in a school, is visited at least once every 8 hours:

sub-subparagraph.text: during regular school hours; and
during nonregular school hours when the school building in which the boiler is located is occupied by at least 150 students, faculty, or members of the public, if the licensee:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: is responsible for the safe operation of such equipment at all times;
is available to observe the monitoring equipment or devices and make necessary adjustments at least once every 24 hours; and
maintains a daily inspection log.

subsection.text: A Grade 3 stationary engineer licensee may oversee the operation of a boiler that:

paragraph.text: can operate at 100 to 299 horsepower;
is inspected in accordance with the boiler laws and regulations by a special inspector or a deputy boiler inspector;
if not equipped with a 24–hour computerized monitoring system and automatic controls, has a Grade 3 licensee in attendance at all times that the boiler is in operation; and
if equipped with a 24–hour computerized monitoring system and automatic controls, is attended by a Grade 3 licensee as follows:

subparagraph.text: if not located in a building open for public use, does not require regular full–time attendance or scheduled visitation, if the licensee:

sub-subparagraph.text: is responsible for the safe operation of such equipment at all times;
is available to observe the monitoring equipment or devices and make necessary adjustments at least once every 24 hours; and
maintains a daily inspection log; and

subparagraph.text: if located in a school, hospital, hotel, residential facility, or other building generally open to the public, is visited at least once every 8 hours that the building is open for public use, if the licensee:

sub-subparagraph.text: is responsible for the safe operation of such equipment at all times;
is available to observe the monitoring equipment or devices and make necessary adjustments at least once every 24 hours; and
maintains a daily inspection log.

subsection.text: A Grade 2 stationary engineer licensee may oversee the operation of a boiler that:

paragraph.text: can operate at 300 to 499 horsepower;
is inspected in accordance with the boiler laws and regulations by a special inspector or a deputy boiler inspector;
if not equipped with a 24–hour computerized monitoring system and automatic controls, has a Grade 2 licensee in attendance at all times that the boiler is in operation; and
if equipped with a 24–hour computerized monitoring system and automatic controls, is attended by a Grade 2 licensee as follows:

subparagraph.text: if not located in a building open for public use, does not require regular full–time attendance or scheduled visitation, if the licensee:

sub-subparagraph.text: is responsible for the safe operation of such equipment at all times;
is available to observe the monitoring equipment or devices and make necessary adjustments at least once every 24 hours; and
maintains a daily inspection log; and

subparagraph.text: if located in a school, hospital, hotel, residential facility, or other building generally open to the public, is visited at least once every 8 hours that the building is open for public use, if the licensee:

sub-subparagraph.text: is responsible for the safe operation of such equipment at all times;
is available to observe the monitoring equipment or devices and make necessary adjustments at least once every 24 hours; and
maintains a daily inspection log.

subsection.text: A Grade 1 stationary engineer licensee may oversee the operation of a boiler that:

paragraph.text: can operate at 500 or more horsepower;
is inspected in accordance with the boiler laws and regulations by a special inspector or a deputy boiler inspector;
if not equipped with a 24–hour computerized monitoring system and automatic controls, has a Grade 1 licensee in attendance at all times that the boiler is in operation; and
if equipped with a 24–hour computerized monitoring system and automatic controls and is attended by a Grade 1 licensee as follows:

subparagraph.text: if not located in a building open for public use, does not require regular visitation, if the licensee:

sub-subparagraph.text: is responsible for the safe operation of such equipment at all times;
is available to observe the monitoring equipment or devices and make necessary adjustments at least once every 24 hours; and
maintains a daily inspection log; and

subparagraph.text: if located in a school, hospital, hotel, residential facility, or other building generally open to the public, is visited at least once every 8 hours that the building is open for public use, if the licensee:

sub-subparagraph.text: is responsible for the safe operation of such equipment at all times;
is available to observe the monitoring equipment or devices and make necessary adjustments at least once every 24 hours; and
maintains a daily inspection log.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, to qualify for licensure as a stationary engineer, an applicant shall meet the requirements of this section and pass an examination administered by the Board.

In addition to the other qualifications for a license set forth in this subtitle, an applicant shall qualify under this section by meeting the educational and experience requirements set forth in subsection (c) of this section.

paragraph.text: An applicant for the Grade 1 stationary engineer’s examination qualifies under this section if the applicant possesses at least one of the following qualifications:

subparagraph.text: 5 years of documented experience as an active Grade 2 stationary engineer under the direction and control of a Grade 1 stationary engineer, toward which an applicant may receive:

sub-subparagraph.text: 1 year of credit for 6 credit hours of classes or continuing education units in boiler safety or operations; and
1 year of credit for holding a current active license as a:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: master plumber;
master heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration contractor; or
master restricted heating, ventilation, and air-conditioning contractor;

subparagraph.text: a 4-year degree in mechanical engineering from an accredited university or college;
licensure as a professional engineer including:

sub-subparagraph.text: 1 year of documented experience as a professional engineer; and
1 year of documented experience as a Grade 2 stationary engineer under the direction and control of a Grade 1 stationary engineer; or

subparagraph.text: a valid marine engineer’s certificate or a chief petty officer’s certificate from the United States Navy with documentation of steam boiler engineer training.

paragraph.text: An applicant for a Grade 2 stationary engineer’s examination qualifies under this section if the applicant possesses at least one of the following qualifications:

subparagraph.text: 36 months of documented experience as an active Grade 3 engineer under the direction and control of a licensed Grade 2 or Grade 1 stationary engineer, that may include:

sub-subparagraph.text: 1 year of credit for 6 credit hours of classes or continuing education units in boiler safety or operations; and
1 year of credit for holding a current active license as a:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: master plumber;
master heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration contractor; or
master restricted heating, ventilation, and air-conditioning contractor;

subparagraph.text: a 4-year degree in mechanical engineering from an accredited university or college;
licensure as a professional engineer and 6 months of documented experience as a Grade 3, Grade 4, or Grade 5 stationary engineer; or
a valid marine engineer’s certificate or chief petty officer’s certificate from the United States Navy.

paragraph.text: An applicant for a Grade 3 stationary engineer’s examination qualifies under this section if the applicant possesses at least one of the following qualifications:

subparagraph.text: 2 years of documented experience as an active Grade 4 or Grade 5 stationary engineer;
1 year of documented experience as an active Grade 4 or Grade 5 engineer and 6 credit hours or continuing education units of classes in boiler operations or safety; or
a valid marine engineer’s certificate or chief petty officer’s certificate from the United States Navy.

paragraph.text: An applicant for a Grade 4 stationary engineer’s examination qualifies under this section if the applicant possesses at least one of the following qualifications:

subparagraph.text: 6 months of documented experience as an active Grade 5 stationary engineer; or
3 credit hours or continuing education units of classes in boiler operations or safety.

paragraph.text: An applicant for a Grade 5 stationary engineer’s examination qualifies under this section if the applicant possesses a high school diploma or graduate equivalence diploma.

subsection.text: The Board may authorize an applicant to take a license examination if the Board determines that the work experience of the applicant is substantially equivalent to the work experience requirements of a licensee for the license level requested by the applicant.
In evaluating the work experience of an applicant, the Board shall consider:

paragraph.text: the size of the operation or plant at which the applicant acquired the work experience;
the type of machinery the applicant used in acquiring the work experience; and

subparagraph.text: the job responsibilities or duties of the applicant; and
the time period in which the applicant held each job responsibility or duty.

subsection.text: An applicant may receive not more than 2 years of work experience credit under this section if the Board determines that the work experience is acquired through:

paragraph.text: a formal course of study; or
professional training.

subsection.text: An applicant for a license shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the Board:

subparagraph.text: an application on the form that the Board provides; and
any relevant document that the Board requires; and

paragraph.text: pay to the Board or the Board’s designee:

subparagraph.text: a nonrefundable application fee of $25; and
an examination fee set by the Board in an amount not to exceed the cost of the required examination.

subsection.text: An application shall be made under oath.

If the Board finds that an application form and the accompanying documentation do not demonstrate that the applicant meets the requirements for a license under this subtitle, the Board may require the applicant to submit additional information or documentation.
The Board shall examine all engineers who are at least 18 years old and who otherwise qualify for examination.
The Board periodically shall offer the examinations required under this subtitle to qualified applicants at the times and places that the Board determines.
The Board shall give each qualified applicant notice of the time and place of examination.
The Board shall determine the subjects, scope, and form of and passing scores for examinations given under this subtitle.
The Board may use a testing service to administer the examination required under this subtitle.
If the Board uses a testing service, the testing service, subject to the requirements set by the Board, shall:

paragraph.text: set the time and place of the examination;
give qualified applicants notice of the time and place of the examination;
charge an examination fee not to exceed the cost of administering the examination; and
furnish any information that the Board may require the testing service to provide.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section, the Board may authorize an applicant to take an examination for:

paragraph.text: a Grade 1 stationary engineer license if the individual lawfully provided stationary engineering services in the State in accordance with § 6.5–302(e) of this subtitle for 5 or more consecutive years immediately prior to the date of application;

a Grade 2 stationary engineer license if the individual lawfully provided stationary engineering services in the State in accordance with § 6.5–302(d) of this subtitle for 3 or more consecutive years immediately prior to the date of application;

a Grade 3 stationary engineer license if the individual lawfully provided stationary engineering services in the State in accordance with § 6.5–302(c) of this subtitle for 2 or more consecutive years immediately prior to the date of application; or

a Grade 4 stationary engineer license if the individual lawfully provided stationary engineering services in the State in accordance with § 6.5–302(b) of this subtitle for 6 or more consecutive months immediately prior to the date of application.

subsection.text: The Board may authorize an individual to take an examination under this section only if the applicant submits to the Board:

paragraph.text: an examination application on the form that the Board provides;
an application fee set by the Board;
proof of eligibility for the applicable application; and
an application for the applicable license in accordance with the provisions of this title.

subsection.text: Subject to the limitations in subsections (b) and (c) of this section, on the affirmative vote of a majority of its voting members then serving, the Board may waive the examination requirements of this title for an individual who is licensed in another state or in a locality in another state to provide stationary engineer services.
The Board may grant a waiver under this section only if the applicant:

paragraph.text: pays to the Board the nonrefundable application fee required under § 6.5–304 of this subtitle; and
provides adequate evidence that the applicant:

subparagraph.text: meets the qualifications otherwise required by this subtitle;
holds an active license in good standing in the other state or the locality;
holds a license that is equivalent to the State license; and

became licensed in the other state or the locality after meeting the state’s or locality’s requirements that are at least equivalent to the licensing requirements of the State, including the number of years of work experience equivalent to the experience required under § 6.5–303(c) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Board may grant a waiver only if the state or the locality in which the applicant is licensed waives the examination of licensees of this State to a similar extent as the State waives the examination requirements for individuals licensed in that state or locality.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “BRAC” means the Base Realignment and Closure process as announced by the United States Department of Defense.
Notwithstanding the provisions of subsections (a), (b), and (c) of this section, the Board shall grant a waiver to an applicant who files a request before July 1, 2012, if the applicant:

subparagraph.text: pays to the Board the nonrefundable application fee required under § 6.5–304 of this subtitle;
holds an active stationary engineer’s license in good standing from Virginia or New Jersey, or from a locality of one of those states, that is equivalent to the State license;
has experience in the provision of stationary engineer services that meets the time requirements of § 6.5–303 of this subtitle; and
has relocated to the State as a family member of a BRAC employee.

subsection.text: The use of unauthorized material by an applicant during an examination shall cause the immediate rejection of the application and shall bar the applicant from reexamination for at least 1 year.

paragraph.text: An applicant who fails an examination or fails to appear for a scheduled examination shall file a new application and pay a new application fee.
An examination fee is nonrefundable.

subsection.text: An applicant who takes an examination required by this title shall be notified of the results of the examination as soon as practicable.
If an applicant fails an examination given under this subtitle, the applicant may retake the examination.
If an applicant qualifies for a license under this subtitle, the Board shall send the applicant a notice that states that:

paragraph.text: the applicant has qualified for a license; and
the Board will issue a license to the applicant on receipt of the appropriate license fee required under § 6.5-207 of this title.

subsection.text: On payment of the license fee, the Board shall issue a license to each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle.
The Board shall include on each license that the Board issues:

paragraph.text: the full name of the licensee;
the license grade level; and
the registration number assigned by the Board to the licensee.

section.text: While a license is in effect, it authorizes the licensee to provide stationary engineer services in accordance with the licensee’s grade level.

A licensee shall provide the Board written notice of any change of name or address from the name or address that appears on the current license, at least 10 working days before the change is to take effect.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (e) of this section and unless a license is renewed for a 2-year term as provided in this section, the license expires every other year on the anniversary of the date of issuance of the license.

paragraph.text: At least 1 month before a license expires, the Board shall mail to the licensee, at the last known address of the licensee:

subparagraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

sub-subparagraph.text: the date on which the current license expires;
the date by which the Board must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the license expires; and
the amount of the renewal fee as required under § 6.5-207 of this title.

paragraph.text: The failure of a licensee to receive the notice as provided for in this subsection does not prevent the license from expiring as specified under subsection (a) of this section.

subsection.text: Before a license expires, the licensee periodically may renew it for an additional 2-year term, if the licensee:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be licensed;
pays to the Board the appropriate license renewal fee required under § 6.5-207 of this title; and
submits to the Board a renewal application on the form that the Board provides.
The Board shall renew the license of and issue a renewal certificate to each licensee who meets the requirements of this section.
The Board shall include on each renewal certificate that the Board issues the date on which the current license expires.

subsection.text: The Secretary may determine that licenses issued under this subtitle shall expire on a staggered basis.
The Board shall reinstate the license of an individual who, for any reason, has failed to renew the license, if the individual:

paragraph.text: applies to the Board for reinstatement within 2 years after the license expires;
meets the renewal requirements of § 6.5-312 of this subtitle and pays to the Board all past due renewal fees; and
except as otherwise provided in subsection (c) of this section, pays to the Board a reinstatement fee of $100, in addition to all past due renewal fees.
If an individual has failed to renew a license for any reason and then applies to the Board for reinstatement more than 2 years after the license has expired, the Board may:

subparagraph.text: require the individual to reapply for a license in the same manner as an applicant applies for an original license under this subtitle; or
subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, reinstate the license.

paragraph.text: The Board may reinstate a license under paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection only if the individual:

subparagraph.text: meets the renewal requirements of § 6.5-312 of this subtitle and pays to the Board all past due renewal fees;
if required by the Board, states reasons why reinstatement should be granted; and
except as otherwise provided in subsection (c) of this section, pays to the Board a reinstatement fee of $100, in addition to all past due renewal fees.

subsection.text: The Board may waive a reinstatement fee for a licensee who provides evidence satisfactory to the Board that the licensee did not provide stationary engineer services during the time the license lapsed.

paragraph.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 6.5-315 of this subtitle, the Board, on the affirmative vote of a majority of its members then serving, may deny a license to any applicant, reprimand any licensee, or suspend or revoke a license if the applicant or licensee:

subparagraph.text: fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a license for the applicant or licensee or for another;
fraudulently or deceptively uses a license;
under the laws of the United States or of any state, is convicted of:

sub-subparagraph.text: a felony; or
a misdemeanor that is directly related to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to provide services as a stationary engineer;

subparagraph.text: fails to control or supervise adequately a person who, while under the supervision of a licensee, provides services as a stationary engineer;
permits a licensee to provide services as a stationary engineer outside the scope of that individual’s license grade;
permits an individual to provide services as a stationary engineer without the appropriate license issued by the Board;
is under the influence of drugs or alcohol while operating an engine, boiler, or other type of power equipment;
is guilty of negligence, incompetence, or misconduct while providing stationary engineer services;
violates any regulation adopted under this title; or
violates any provision of this title.
Instead of or in addition to reprimanding a licensee or suspending or revoking a license under this subsection, the Board may impose a penalty not exceeding $5,000 for each violation.
To determine the amount of the penalty imposed under this subsection, the Board shall consider:

sub-subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the harm caused by the violation;
the good faith of the licensee; and
any history of previous violations by the licensee.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: The Board shall consider the following facts in the granting, denial, renewal, suspension, or revocation of a license or the reprimand of a licensee when an applicant or licensee is convicted of a felony or misdemeanor described in subsection (a)(1)(iii) of this section:

paragraph.text: the nature of the crime;
the relationship of the crime to the activities authorized by the license;
with respect to a felony, the relevance of the conviction to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to provide services as a stationary engineer;
the length of time since the conviction; and
the behavior and activities of the applicant or licensee before and after the conviction.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 10-226 of the State Government Article, before the Board takes any final action under § 6.5-314 of this subtitle, it shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Board.
The Board shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
If, after due notice, the individual against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, the Board may hear and determine the matter.
