section.text: A person aggrieved by a final action of the Board may take an appeal as specified under §§ 10-222 and 10-223 of the State Government Article.

Except as otherwise provided in this title, a person may not perform, attempt to perform, or offer to perform the functions of a stationary engineer in the State unless licensed by the Board in the appropriate grade to provide such services.
A person may not:

paragraph.text: use or attempt to use the license of another individual; or
impersonate another individual who holds a license.

subsection.text: A person may not allow an individual to provide services as a stationary engineer if the individual does not hold an appropriate license issued by the Board.
A person may not allow an individual to provide services as a stationary engineer outside the scope of that individual’s license grade.
A person who violates § 6.5-401, § 6.5-402, or § 6.5-403 of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to:

paragraph.text: a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or both; and
on a second or subsequent conviction, a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 2 years or both.
Except as otherwise provided by this title, the Board may impose on a person who violates any provision of this title a penalty not exceeding $5,000 for each violation.
In setting the amount of the penalty, the Board shall consider:

subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the harm caused by the violation;
the good faith of the violator;
any history of previous violations by the violator; and
any other relevant factors.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

section.text: This title may be cited as the “Maryland Stationary Engineers Act”.

Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, this title and all regulations adopted under this title shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2014.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the State Board of Foresters.

paragraph.text: Notwithstanding § 5–101 of the Natural Resources Article, “forestry” means the application, for compensation, of scientific techniques to the planting, conservation, protection, and management of trees and related resources for their continuing use, whether found in large numbers and areas commonly known as forests, woodlands, and woodlots or in small groupings and individual trees in suburban and urban settings.
“Forestry” includes:

subparagraph.text: consultation, investigation, evaluation, or planning of any forestry activity that is described under paragraph (1) of this subsection; or
having responsibility for any forestry activity that is described under paragraph (1) of this subsection.

paragraph.text: “Forestry” does not include:

subparagraph.text: the services of a tree expert, as defined under § 5–415(c) of the Natural Resources Article;
practices and services generally provided by:

sub-subparagraph.text: an arboriculturist;
a gardener;
a horticulturist;
a landscape contractor;
a landscape gardener;
a nurseryman; or
an orchardist; or

subparagraph.text: the cutting, hauling, handling, or processing of forest products.

subsection.text: “License” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a license issued by the Board to practice forestry.
“Licensed forester” means, unless the context requires otherwise, an individual who is licensed by the Board to practice forestry.

section.text: The purposes of this title are to benefit and protect the public and to promote the public welfare by regulating persons who practice forestry in the State.
There is a State Board of Foresters in the Department.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of 7 members.
Of the 7 members of the Board:

subparagraph.text: 5 shall be licensed foresters; and
2 shall be consumer members.

paragraph.text: The Governor shall appoint the members with the advice and consent of the Senate.

The Governor shall appoint each of the licensed forester members from a list of at least 3 names of licensed foresters submitted to the Governor by the Maryland members of the Maryland-Delaware Division of the Allegheny Society of American Foresters.

subsection.text: Each member of the Board shall be:

paragraph.text: a citizen of the United States; and
a resident of the State for at least 3 years.

subsection.text: Each licensed forester member of the Board shall have practiced forestry for at least 10 years.
Each consumer member of the Board:

paragraph.text: shall be a member of the general public;
may not be a licensee or otherwise be subject to regulation by the Board;
may not be required to meet the qualifications for the professional members of the Board; and
may not, within 1 year before appointment, have had a financial interest in or have received compensation from a person regulated by the Board.

subsection.text: While a member of the Board, a consumer member may not:

paragraph.text: have a financial interest in or receive compensation from a person regulated by the Board; or
grade any examination given by or for the Board.

subsection.text: Before taking office, each appointee to the Board shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 5 years and begins on July 1.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on October 1, 1989.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: The Governor may remove a member for:

paragraph.text: incompetence;
misconduct; or
habitual or willful neglect of duty.

subsection.text: From among its members, the Board annually shall elect a chairman, a vice chairman, and a secretary.
The manner of election of officers shall be as the Board determines.
The secretary of the Board shall be covered by a surety bond in the form and amount required by law.
A majority of the authorized membership of the Board is a quorum.

paragraph.text: The Board shall meet at least twice a year, at the times and places that the Board determines.
The Board may hold special meetings as provided in its bylaws, but the Board may not hold more than 1 meeting in a calendar month.

subsection.text: A member of the Board:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Board may employ a staff in accordance with the State budget.
Subject to the State budget, the Board may employ an investigative staff to investigate a charge that is made against a licensed forester and alleges facts that constitute:

paragraph.text: a ground for disciplinary action under this title; or
a violation of this title.

subsection.text: The Board may administer oaths.

paragraph.text: The Board may issue a subpoena for the attendance of a witness to testify or the production of evidence in connection with:

subparagraph.text: a disciplinary action under § 7-309 of this title; or
a proceeding brought for an alleged violation of this title.

paragraph.text: A subpoena shall be signed by the chairman of the Board and sealed with the seal of the Board.
If a person fails to comply with a subpoena issued under this subsection, on petition of the Board, a circuit court may compel compliance with the subpoena.

subsection.text: In addition to any powers set forth elsewhere, the Board may adopt:

paragraph.text: any bylaw for the conduct of the proceedings of the Board; and
any regulation to carry out this title.

subsection.text: In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere, the Board:

paragraph.text: shall administer this title;
shall adopt a seal; and
shall keep a record of its proceedings.

subsection.text: The Board shall keep a record that, for each application for a license, shows:

paragraph.text: the applicant’s:

subparagraph.text: name;
age;
residence;
place of business; and
educational and other qualifications;

paragraph.text: the date of the application;
whether the applicant was required to take an examination;
the action of the Board on the application;
the reason for the action; and
any other information the Board considers necessary.

subsection.text: The Board shall:

paragraph.text: keep a list of all licensed foresters that shows the name and place of business of each licensee;
provide a copy of the list:

subparagraph.text: on request, to any member of the public; and
every 2 years, on or before March 31, to:

sub-subparagraph.text: each licensee; and
the Secretary of State.

paragraph.text: With the advice of the established forestry associations, the Board shall adopt, by regulation, a code of ethics for practicing forestry.
The Board shall distribute a copy of the code of ethics:

subparagraph.text: to each applicant for a license; and
on each renewal of a license, to each licensee.

subsection.text: The Board shall adopt regulations that implement the continuing education requirement set forth in § 7-308(c)(2) of this title.

section.text: The Board shall pay all money collected under this title into the General Fund of the State.
The Board exercises its powers, duties, and functions subject to the authority of the Secretary.
Except as otherwise provided in this title, an individual shall be licensed by the Board before the individual may practice forestry in the State.

An individual who meets the educational requirements but does not meet the experience requirements under § 7-304 of this subtitle may practice forestry without a license if the individual practices forestry under the responsible charge of a licensed forester.
An individual who is licensed to practice forestry in another state or country may practice forestry in this State without a license if:

paragraph.text: the state or country in which the individual is licensed waives the license requirements for licensees of this State to a similar extent as this State waives the license requirements for individuals licensed in that state or country;
the individual submits to the Board evidence that the individual is licensed in the other state or country; and
the individual:

subparagraph.text: is not a resident of this State and does not maintain a place of business in this State; or
has become a resident of this State within the preceding 6 months.

subsection.text: To qualify for a license, an applicant shall be an individual who meets the requirements of this section.
An applicant shall have been graduated on completion of a 4-year curriculum in forestry from a college or university that is approved by the Board or accredited by the Society of American Foresters.
The applicant shall have at least 2 years of experience in forestry that indicates to the Board that the applicant is competent to practice forestry.
An applicant for a license shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the Board an application on the form that the Board provides; and
pay to the Board an application fee of $45.
In addition to any other information required on an application form, the form shall require:

subparagraph.text: a statement about the education of the applicant;
a statement about the experience of the applicant in practicing forestry; and
a list of at least 5 references, which shall include at least 3 foresters who have personal or professional knowledge of the applicant’s experience in practicing forestry.

paragraph.text: An application shall be made under oath.

subsection.text: If an applicant qualifies for a license under this subtitle, the Board shall mail the applicant a notice that states that:

paragraph.text: the applicant has qualified for a license;
on receipt of a $55 license fee, the Board will issue a license to the applicant; and

if the applicant fails to pay the license fee within 30 days after receipt of the notice, the applicant forfeits the right to be issued a license and, to obtain a license, may be required to submit a new application and to pay a new application fee.
On payment of the license fee, the Board shall issue a license to each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle.
If an applicant fails to pay the license fee within 30 days after the receipt of notice that the applicant has qualified, the Board may:

subparagraph.text: deny the applicant a license under that application; and
require the applicant to submit a new application and again to pay the application fee required under § 7-305 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Board shall include on each license that the Board issues:

paragraph.text: the full name of the licensee;
the registration number assigned by the Board to the licensee; and
the signature of the chairman of the Board.

subsection.text: Subject to any regulation that the Board adopts, it shall replace any lost, mutilated, or destroyed license certificate on:

paragraph.text: request of the licensee; and
payment of a replacement fee of $5.

section.text: While a license is in effect, it authorizes the licensee to practice forestry.

subsection.text: Unless a license is renewed for a 2-year term as provided in this section, the license expires on the first September 30 that comes:

paragraph.text: after the effective date of the license; and
in an even-numbered year.

subsection.text: At least 30 days before a license expires, the Board shall mail to the licensee, at the last known address of the licensee:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

subparagraph.text: the date on which the current license expires;
the date by which the Board must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the license expires; and
the amount of the renewal fee.

paragraph.text: Before a license expires, the licensee periodically may renew it for an additional 2-year term, if the licensee:

subparagraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be licensed;
except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, pays to the Board a renewal fee of $100; and
submits to the Board a renewal application on the form that the Board provides.

sub-subparagraph.text: Except as provided in sub-subparagraph 2 of this subparagraph, the Board may not renew a license unless the licensee meets the continuing education requirements of this section.
The continuing education requirement does not apply to:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: the first renewal of a license by a licensee; or
a licensee who has inactive status or who has applied for inactive status.

subparagraph.text: To qualify for renewal of a license, for each 2-year license term of a license, a licensee shall complete successfully at least 8 hours of instruction provided through programs that the Board approves.

subsection.text: A licensee serving on active duty in the armed forces of the United States is exempt from the renewal fee required by this section.
The Board shall renew the license of each licensee who meets the requirements of this section.
The Secretary may determine that licenses issued under this subtitle shall expire on a staggered basis.

paragraph.text: A licensee may apply to the Board for inactive status.
The Board shall grant inactive status to a licensee if the licensee:

subparagraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be licensed; and
pays to the Board an inactive license fee of $25.

paragraph.text: An individual may return to active status if the individual meets the requirements for renewal of a license under this section.

Subject to the hearing provisions of § 7-311 of this subtitle, the Board, on the affirmative vote of a majority of its authorized members, may deny a license to any applicant, reprimand any licensee, or suspend or revoke a license if the applicant or licensee:

subparagraph.text: fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a license for the applicant or licensee or for another;
fraudulently or deceptively uses a license;
is guilty of gross negligence, incompetence, or misconduct in practicing forestry;
under the laws of the United States or of any state is convicted of:

sub-subparagraph.text: a felony; or
a misdemeanor that is directly related to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to practice forestry;

subparagraph.text: has had a license to practice forestry in another state revoked or suspended by the other state for a cause that would justify revocation or suspension under this title, except for the failure to pay a license or registration renewal fee;
knowingly violates any provision of the code of ethics adopted by the Board; or
knowingly violates any provision of this title.
Instead of or in addition to reprimanding a licensee or suspending or revoking a license under this subsection, the Board may impose a penalty not exceeding $5,000 for each violation.
To determine the amount of the penalty imposed under this subsection, the Board shall consider:

sub-subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the harm caused by the violation;
the good faith of the licensee; and
any history of previous violations by the licensee.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: The Board shall consider the following facts in the granting, denial, renewal, suspension, or revocation of a license or the reprimand of a licensee when an applicant or licensee is convicted of a felony or misdemeanor described in subsection (a)(1)(iv) of this section:

paragraph.text: the nature of the crime;
the relationship of the crime to the activities authorized by the license;
with respect to a felony, the relevance of the conviction to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to practice forestry;
the length of time since the conviction; and
the behavior and activities of the applicant or licensee before and after the conviction.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of this section, the Board shall commence proceedings under § 7-309 of this subtitle on complaint made to the Board by a member of the Board or any other person.

paragraph.text: A complaint shall be:

subparagraph.text: in writing; and
submitted to the secretary of the Board.

paragraph.text: If the complaint is made by any person other than a member of the Board, the complaint shall be made under oath by the person who submits the complaint.

subsection.text: If the Board finds that a complaint alleges facts that are adequate grounds for action under § 7-309 of this subtitle, the Board shall act on the complaint as provided under § 7-311 of this subtitle. If the Board does not make that finding, it shall dismiss the complaint.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 10-226 of the State Government Article, before the Board takes any final action under § 7-309 of this subtitle, it shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Board.
A hearing shall be held within 3 months after the complaint is made.

subsection.text: The Board shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
At least 30 days before the hearing, the hearing notice and a copy of the complaint shall be:

paragraph.text: served personally on the individual; or
sent by certified mail to the last known address of the individual.

subsection.text: The individual may be represented at the hearing by counsel.
If, after due notice, the person against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, nevertheless the Board may hear and determine the matter.

section.text: Any person aggrieved by a final decision of the Board in a contested case, as defined in § 10-202 of the State Government Article, may take an appeal as allowed in §§ 10-222 and 10-223 of the State Government Article.

subsection.text: Subject to any regulation that the Board adopts, the Board may reinstate a license that has been revoked.
A license may be reinstated under this section only on:

paragraph.text: the basis of evidence submitted to the Board after the revocation and not available, before the revocation, to the individual seeking reinstatement;
the affirmative vote of a majority of the authorized members of the Board; and
payment to the Board of a fee of $5.

subsection.text: Each licensed forester shall obtain a seal for use as required under § 7-402 of this subtitle.
The seal shall:

paragraph.text: be of a design determined by the Board; and
include:

subparagraph.text: the legend “Licensed Forester”; and
the name of the licensed forester who holds the seal.

section.text: Before a licensed forester issues to any person any plan, map, specification, or report, the licensed forester who prepared or approved the document shall endorse on the document the licensed forester’s:

paragraph.text: name;
registration number; and
seal.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, a person may not practice, attempt to practice, or offer to practice forestry in the State unless licensed by the Board.

Unless authorized under this title to practice forestry, a person may not represent to the public, by use of a title, including “licensed forester”, “professional forester”, “registered professional forester”, or “registered forester”, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person is authorized to practice forestry in the State.
An individual may not use or attempt to use the license of another.

subsection.text: Unless a document is prepared by or under the responsible charge of a licensed forester, the licensed forester may not endorse the document as provided under § 7-402 of this title.

While the license of an individual is suspended, revoked, or expired, a person may not endorse a document, as provided under § 7-402 of this title, with the name, seal, or registration number of the individual.

section.text: A person may not give false information to the Board in an attempt to obtain a license.

subsection.text: A person who violates any provision of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $5,000.

paragraph.text: The Board may impose on a person who violates any provision of this title a penalty not exceeding $5,000 for each violation.
In setting the amount of the penalty, the Board shall consider:

subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the harm caused by the violation;
the good faith of the violator;
any history of previous violations by the violator; and
any other relevant factors.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

section.text: This title may be cited as the “Maryland Foresters Act”.

Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, this title and all regulations adopted under this title shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2015.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the State Board of Certified Interior Designers.
“Certificate” means a certificate issued by the Board to use the title “certified interior designer”.
“Certificate fee” means, as applicable, the fee paid in connection with the issuance and renewal of a certificate and issuance of a reciprocal certificate.
“Certified interior design services” means interior design services provided by a certified interior designer.
“Certified interior designer” means an interior designer who is certified by the Board.
“Design coordination” means the review and coordination of services provided by individuals licensed or certified under Titles 3, 8, 9, 14, and 15 of this article.

“Interior design services” means rendering or offering to render services for a fee or other valuable consideration, in the preparation and administration of interior design documents (including drawings, schedules and specifications) which pertain to the planning and design of interior spaces including furnishings, layouts, fixtures, cabinetry, lighting fixtures, finishes, materials, and interior construction not materially related to or materially affecting the building systems, all of which shall comply with applicable laws, codes, regulations, and standards. The scope of work described herein shall not be construed as authorizing the planning and design of engineering and architectural interior construction as related to the building systems, including structural, electrical, plumbing, heating, ventilating, air conditioning or mechanical systems and shall not be construed as authorizing the practice of architecture or engineering as defined in Title 3 or Title 14 of this article. The interior design plans as described above are not to be construed as those architectural plans which may be required to be filed with any county or municipality.
“Public use” means the use of a building or other structure for the primary purpose of human use or habitation.
“Residential use” means the use of a building or other structure as a dwelling.

section.text: This title does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a person who does not use the title “certified interior designer” on any card, device, sign, stationery, or other means of identification or communication; or
an architect licensed in this State.

subsection.text: A certified interior designer may render or offer to render interior design services described in § 8-101 of this subtitle provided that services pertain to a building or other structure that is intended for public use or residential use.
A certified interior designer may perform design coordination for a project or portion of a project provided that the certified interior designer:

paragraph.text: holds a current certificate issued by the Board; and
has adequate experience in, and understanding of, achieving the purpose of the project or portion of the project being coordinated.

section.text: There is a State Board of Certified Interior Designers in the Department.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of 7 members.
Of the 7 members of the Board:

subparagraph.text: 5 shall be certified interior designers;
1 shall be an architect licensed by the State Board of Architects who provides interior design services; and
1 shall be a consumer member.

paragraph.text: The Governor shall appoint the members of the Board with the advice of the Secretary and the advice and consent of the Senate.

subsection.text: Each member of the Board shall be a resident and citizen of the State.
Each interior designer member shall have provided interior design services for at least 5 years immediately before appointment.
The architect member shall have practiced in the State for at least 5 years immediately before appointment.
The consumer member of the Board:

paragraph.text: shall be a member of the general public;
may not be a certified interior designer or otherwise be subject to regulation by the Board;
may not be required to meet the qualifications for the professional members of the Board; and
may not, within 1 year before appointment, have had a financial interest in or have received compensation from an individual regulated by the Board.

subsection.text: While a member of the Board, the consumer member may not:

paragraph.text: have a financial interest in or receive compensation from an individual regulated by the Board; or
grade any examination given by or for the Board.

subsection.text: Before taking office, each appointee to the Board shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 3 years and begins on July 1.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on July 1, 1991.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: A member of the Board may not be held personally liable for any actions taken or decisions made in good faith as a member of the Board.
The Governor may remove a member for incompetence or misconduct.
From among its members, the Board annually shall elect a chairman and a secretary.
The manner of election of officers shall be as the Board determines.
A member may serve no more than three consecutive years as an officer of the Board.
A majority of the members then serving on the Board is a quorum.
The Board shall determine the times and places of its meetings and hearings.
A member of the Board:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Board may employ a staff in accordance with the State budget.

section.text: At least annually, the chairman of the Board, the chairman of the State Board of Architects, the chairman of the State Board of Examiners of Landscape Architects, the chairman of the State Board for Professional Engineers, and the chairman of the State Board for Professional Land Surveyors shall meet to discuss issues of mutual importance to the design professions.
To enforce this title, the Board may:

paragraph.text: conduct investigations and hold hearings on any matter covered by this title, at any time and place in the State;
administer oaths;
examine witnesses; and
receive evidence.

subsection.text: In addition to the powers set forth elsewhere, the Board may adopt regulations to carry out this title.
In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere, the Board shall:

paragraph.text: keep a record of its proceedings; and
adopt, by regulation, a code of ethics for certified interior designers.

subsection.text: In this section, “code official” means a public official responsible for the review of building permit documents or the issuance of building permits.
The Board shall:

paragraph.text: keep a list of the names and mailing addresses of all certificate holders;
provide each code official with a copy of the list annually; and
provide any other person who makes a request with a copy of the list at a reasonable fee set by the Board.
The Board shall provide all certificate holders and code officials with a periodic newsletter not less than semiannually on the activities of the Board.

The Board shall publish, on the Department website, the newsletter jointly with the State Board for Professional Engineers, the State Board of Architects, the State Board of Examiners of Landscape Architects, and the State Board for Professional Land Surveyors.

subsection.text: The Board shall distribute:

paragraph.text: to each applicant for a certificate and each code official, a copy of the Maryland Certified Interior Designers Act and the Board’s rules and regulations;

on each renewal of a certificate, to each certificate holder, a copy of any amendments to the Maryland Certified Interior Designers Act and the Board’s rules and regulations that took effect during the 2-year period ending on the date of renewal; and
to each code official, a copy of any amendments to the Maryland Certified Interior Designers Act and the Board’s rules and regulations.

subsection.text: A certificate holder shall designate the certificate holder’s mailing address at the time of issuance of the certificate and on each renewal of the certificate.

paragraph.text: The Board may set reasonable fees for its services.

The fees charged shall be set so as to produce funds to approximate the cost of maintaining the Board and shall be based on the calculations performed by the Secretary under § 2–106.2 of the Business Regulation Article.

subsection.text: The Board shall publish the fee schedule set by the Board by regulation.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay all fees collected under this title to the Comptroller of the State.
The Comptroller shall distribute the fees to the State Occupational and Professional Licensing Design Boards’ Fund established in § 2–106.1 of the Business Regulation Article.

subsection.text: The Board shall publish annually a list including the name and address of each individual:

paragraph.text: who has been certified; or
whose certification has been suspended or revoked within 3 years before the publication.

section.text: The Board exercises its powers, duties, and functions subject to the authority of the Secretary.

Except as otherwise provided in this title, an individual shall be certified by the Board before the individual may use the title “certified interior designer” or the term “certified interior design services”.

subsection.text: To qualify for a certificate, an applicant shall be an individual who meets the requirements of this section.
The applicant shall be of good character and reputation.
The applicant shall be at least 18 years old.
The applicant shall:

paragraph.text: file an application and pay a nonrefundable application fee in accordance with § 8–303 of this subtitle;
have satisfied education and experience requirements necessary to qualify for the National Council of Interior Design Qualification Examination, or its equivalent, as determined by the Board; and
have passed the National Council of Interior Design Qualification Examination, or its equivalent.

section.text: An applicant for a certificate shall:

paragraph.text: submit an application to the Board on the form that the Board provides; and
pay to the Board or the Board’s designee a nonrefundable application fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of this section, the Board may waive any examination requirement of this subtitle for an individual who is licensed or certified as an interior designer in another state.
The Board may grant a waiver under this section only if the applicant:

paragraph.text: pays to the Board:

subparagraph.text: the nonrefundable application fee set by the Board; and
the certificate fee set by the Board; and

paragraph.text: provides adequate evidence that the applicant:

subparagraph.text: meets the qualifications otherwise required by this subtitle; and
became licensed or certified in the other state after meeting qualifications that are substantially equivalent to those required for a certificate in this State.

subsection.text: The Board may grant a waiver under this section only if the state in which the applicant is licensed or certified waives the examination of certified interior designers of this State to a similar extent as this State waives the examination requirements for individuals licensed or certified in that state.

section.text: On payment of the certificate fee set by the Board, the Board shall issue a certificate to each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle for a certificate.
While a certificate is in effect, it authorizes the certificate holder to use the title “certified interior designer” or the term “certified interior design services”.

subsection.text: Unless a certificate is renewed for a 2–year term as provided in this section, a certificate expires on the first June 30 that comes:

paragraph.text: after the effective date of the certificate; and
in an even–numbered year.

subsection.text: At least 30 days before the certificate expires, the Board shall mail to the certificate holder, at the last known address of the certificate holder:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form;
a notice that states:

subparagraph.text: the date on which the current certificate expires; and
the date by which the Board must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the certificate expires; and

paragraph.text: the amount of the certificate fee.

subsection.text: Before the certificate expires, the certificate holder periodically may renew it for an additional 2–year term, if the certificate holder:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be certified;
pays to the Board a certificate fee set by the Board;
submits to the Board a renewal application on the form that the Board provides; and
submits to the Board any documentation required by the Board to verify that the certificate holder has complied with the continuing education requirements under § 8–308 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Board shall renew the certificate of each certificate holder who meets the requirements of this section.
The Secretary may determine that certificates issued under this subtitle shall expire on a staggered basis.

paragraph.text: To qualify for renewal of a certificate under this subtitle, a certificate holder shall earn during each 2-year certificate term at least one continuing education unit in two or more courses that the Board approves.
A continuing education unit consists of 10 hours of study.

subsection.text: A certificate holder who is granted a certificate during the second year of a certificate term may renew the certificate for the next full term if the certificate holder earns at least one-half of a continuing education unit in one or more courses that the Board approves.

section.text: The Board shall reinstate the certificate of an interior designer who has failed to renew the certificate for any reason if the interior designer:

paragraph.text: meets the renewal requirements under § 8–307 of this subtitle;
pays to the Board the reinstatement fee as set by the Board;
submits to the Board a reinstatement application on the form that the Board provides; and
earns two continuing education units in courses approved by the Board in a 2–year period immediately preceding the request for reinstatement.

Subject to the hearing provisions of § 8-312 of this subtitle, the Board may deny a certificate to any applicant, reprimand any certificate holder, or suspend or revoke a certificate if the applicant or certificate holder:

subparagraph.text: fraudulently or deceptively obtains or renews or attempts to obtain or renew a certificate for the applicant or certificate holder or for another;
fraudulently or deceptively uses the title “certified interior designer” or the term “certified interior design services”;
under the laws of the United States or of any state, is convicted of:

sub-subparagraph.text: a felony; or
a misdemeanor that is directly related to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or certificate holder to perform certified interior design services;

subparagraph.text: is guilty of any fraud, gross negligence, incompetence, or misconduct in the use of the title “certified interior designer” or the term “certified interior design services”;
signs or seals any interior design documents after a certificate holder’s certificate expires or has been suspended or revoked by the Board;
violates any regulation that the Board adopts; or
violates any provision of this title.
Instead of or in addition to reprimanding a certificate holder or suspending or revoking a certificate under this subsection, the Board may impose a penalty not exceeding $5,000 for each violation.
To determine the amount of the penalty imposed under this subsection, the Board shall consider:

sub-subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the harm caused by the violation;
the good faith of the certificate holder; and
any history of previous violations by the certificate holder.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: The Board shall consider the following facts in the granting, denial, renewal, suspension, or revocation of a certificate or the reprimand of a certificate holder when an applicant or certificate holder is convicted of a felony or misdemeanor described in subsection (a)(1)(iii) of this section:

paragraph.text: the nature of the crime;
the relationship of the crime to the activities authorized by the certificate;
with respect to a felony, the relevance of the conviction to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to perform interior design services;
the length of time since the conviction; and
the behavior and activities of the applicant or certificate holder before and after the conviction.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of this section, the Board shall bring proceedings under § 8-310 of this subtitle on the complaint made to the Board by a member of the Board or any other individual.

paragraph.text: A complaint shall:

subparagraph.text: be in writing; and
state specifically the facts on which the complaint is based.

paragraph.text: If the complaint is made by any individual other than a member of the Board, the complaint shall be made under oath by the individual who submits the complaint.

subsection.text: If the Board finds that the complaint alleges facts that are adequate grounds for action under § 8-310 of this subtitle, the Board shall act on the complaint as provided under § 8-312 of this subtitle. If the Board does not make that finding, it shall dismiss the complaint.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 10-226 of the State Government Article, before the Board takes any final action under § 8-310 of this subtitle, it shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Board.
A hearing shall be held:

subparagraph.text: in accordance with regulations adopted by the Board; and
within a reasonable time not to exceed 6 months after the complaint is made.

subsection.text: The Board shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Board may administer oaths in connection with any proceeding under this section.
At least 30 days before the hearing, the hearing notice and a copy of the complaint shall be:

paragraph.text: served personally on the individual; or
sent by mail to the last known address of the individual.

subsection.text: The individual may be represented at the hearing by counsel.
If, after due notice, the individual against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, nevertheless the Board may hear and determine the matter.

section.text: Any person aggrieved by a final decision of the Board in a contested case, as defined in § 10-202 of the State Government Article, may take an appeal as allowed in §§ 10-222 and 10-223 of the State Government Article.

A certified interior designer shall state in each of the designer’s interior design documents that the document is not an architectural or engineering drawing, specification, or design and is not to be used for construction of any load-bearing column, load-bearing framing, or load-bearing wall or structure.
A certified interior designer shall disclose to a client or a prospective client the way that compensation, including commission, is to be paid for certified interior design services.

subsection.text: Before a certified interior designer issues to a client or submits to a public authority any interior design document, including drawings, plans, schedules, reports, or specifications, the certified interior designer who prepared or approved the document shall sign, seal, and date the document.
Any interior design document issued or submitted as described in subsection (a) of this section shall be identified as the interior design document.
Each certified interior designer shall obtain a seal for use as required under § 8-403 of this subtitle.
The seal shall:

paragraph.text: be of a design determined by the Board; and
include:

subparagraph.text: the legend “certified interior designer”; and
the name of the certified interior designer who holds the seal.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, a person may not use the title “certified interior designer” or the term “certified interior design services” unless certified by the Board.

subsection.text: A person who violates § 8-501 of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000.

paragraph.text: The Board may impose on a person who violates § 8-501 of this subtitle a penalty not exceeding $5,000 for each violation.
In setting the amount of the penalty, the Board shall consider:

subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the harm caused by the violation;
the good faith of the violator;
any history of previous violations by the violator; and
any other relevant factors.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

section.text: This title may be cited as the “Maryland Certified Interior Designers Act”.

Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, this title and all regulations adopted under this title shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2024.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the State Board of Examiners of Landscape Architects.
“Design coordination” means the review and coordination of services provided by individuals licensed or certified under Titles 3, 8, 9, 14, and 15 of this article.
“Landscape architect” means an individual who practices landscape architecture.
“License” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a license issued by the Board to practice landscape architecture.
“License fee” means, as applicable, the fee paid in connection with the issuance and renewal of a license or the issuance of a reciprocal license.
“Licensed landscape architect” means a landscape architect who is licensed by the Board to practice landscape architecture.
“Permit” means a permit issued by the Board to allow a partnership or corporation to operate a business through which an individual may practice landscape architecture.
“Permit fee” means, as applicable, the fee paid in connection with the issuance and renewal of a permit.

paragraph.text: “Practice landscape architecture” means:

subparagraph.text: to provide any service or creative work in the analysis or design of land and natural resources that requires training and experience in the application of the biological, physical, mathematical, and social sciences; and

to perform design coordination of a project or portion of a project provided that the licensed landscape architect holds a current license issued by the Board and has adequate education and experience in, and understanding of, the project or portion of the project being coordinated.

paragraph.text: “Practice landscape architecture” includes:

subparagraph.text: consultation, research, analysis, assessment, selection, and allocation of land and natural resources;
development of graphic, written, digital, and other appropriate criteria to govern the planning and design of land development and construction programs, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: preparation, review, and analysis of master plans, site plans, and land development plans;
reconnaissance, planning, design, and preparation of construction documents;
construction, observation, administration, and project management;
preservation, restoration, conservation, reclamation, rehabilitation, and management of land and natural resources;
preparation of feasibility and site selection studies, environmental studies, and cost estimate reports; and
design and analysis of grading and drainage, irrigation, erosion and sediment control systems, and pedestrian and vehicular circulation systems; and

subparagraph.text: in conjunction with site plan preparation, the performance of the following:

sub-subparagraph.text: determining a grade;
determining drainage; and
preparing and designing stormwater drainage systems provided that the preparation and design:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: are in accordance with design manuals, details, and standards accepted by the State or local authorities; and
do not require a hydraulic or structural design of system components.

subsection.text: “Responsible charge” means direct control and personal supervision of landscape architecture services that requires initiative, professional skill, and independent judgment.

section.text: The purposes of this title are to safeguard public welfare, health, and property and to promote the public good by regulating persons who practice landscape architecture in the State.
This title does not limit the right of a nurseryman, general contractor, or landscape contractor to design, plan, locate, plant, or arrange plantings or other ornamental features.
There is a State Board of Examiners of Landscape Architects in the Department.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of 5 members.
Of the 5 members of the Board:

subparagraph.text: 3 shall be licensed landscape architects; and
2 shall be consumer members.

paragraph.text: The Governor shall appoint the members with the advice of the Secretary and the advice and consent of the Senate.

subsection.text: Each landscape architect member shall be a licensed landscape architect who has practiced landscape architecture in the State for at least 5 years.
Each consumer member of the Board:

paragraph.text: shall be a member of the general public;
may not be a licensee or otherwise be subject to regulation by the Board;
may not be required to meet the qualifications for the professional members of the Board; and
may not, within 1 year before appointment, have had a financial interest in or have received compensation from a person regulated by the Board.

subsection.text: While a member of the Board, a consumer member may not:

paragraph.text: have a financial interest in or receive compensation from a person regulated by the Board; or
grade any examination given by or for the Board.

subsection.text: Before taking office, each appointee to the Board shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 3 years and begins on July 1.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on October 1, 1989.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: The Governor may remove a member for incompetence or misconduct.
From among its members, the Board annually shall elect a chairman and a secretary.
The manner of election of officers shall be as the Board determines.
A majority of the authorized membership of the Board is a quorum.
The Board shall meet at least twice a year, at the times and places that the Board determines.
A member of the Board:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Board may employ a staff in accordance with the State budget.

section.text: At least annually, the chairman of the Board, the chairman of the State Board of Architects, the chairman of the State Board of Certified Interior Designers, the chairman of the State Board for Professional Engineers, and the chairman of the State Board for Professional Land Surveyors shall meet to discuss issues of mutual importance to the design professions.

subsection.text: To enforce this title, the Board may:

paragraph.text: conduct investigations and hold hearings on any matter covered by this title, at any time and place in the State;
administer oaths;
examine witnesses; and
receive evidence.

subsection.text: Subject to the State budget, the Board may employ an investigative staff to:

paragraph.text: investigate a complaint; and
perform any other related duty, as assigned by the Board.
The Board may issue a subpoena for the attendance of a witness to testify or the production of evidence in connection with:

subparagraph.text: any disciplinary action under § 9-310 of this title; or
any proceeding brought for an alleged violation of this title.

paragraph.text: A subpoena shall be signed by the Chairman of the Board and sealed with the seal of the Board.
If a person fails to comply with a subpoena issued under this subsection, on petition of the Board, a circuit court may compel compliance with the subpoena.
The Board may sue in the name of the State to enforce any provision of this title by injunction.
In seeking an injunction under this subsection, the Board is not required to:

subparagraph.text: post bond; or
allege or prove either that:

sub-subparagraph.text: an adequate remedy at law does not exist; or
substantial or irreparable damage would result from the continued violation of the provision.

paragraph.text: A member of the Board may not be held personally liable for any action taken under this subsection in good faith and with reasonable grounds.

subsection.text: In addition to any powers set forth elsewhere, the Board may adopt:

paragraph.text: any regulation to carry out this title; and
a seal.

subsection.text: In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere, the Board shall keep a record of its proceedings.

paragraph.text: With the advice of the established landscape architect associations, the Board shall adopt, by regulation, a code of ethics for practicing landscape architecture.
The Board shall distribute a copy of the code of ethics:

subparagraph.text: to each applicant for a license; and
on each renewal of a license, to each licensee.

paragraph.text: In addition to complying with the publication requirements of Title 10, Subtitle 1 of the State Government Article, the Board shall distribute a copy of any amendment to the code of ethics to each licensee.

subsection.text: In this section, “code official” means a public official responsible for the review of building permit documents or the issuance of building permits.
The Board shall:

paragraph.text: keep a list of the names and mailing addresses of all licensees;
provide each code official with a copy of the list annually; and
provide any other person who makes a request with a copy of the list at a reasonable fee set by the Board.
The Board shall provide all licensees and code officials with a periodic newsletter not less than semiannually on the activities of the Board.

The Board shall publish, on the Department website, the newsletter jointly with the State Board for Professional Engineers, the State Board of Architects, the State Board of Certified Interior Designers, and the State Board for Professional Land Surveyors.

subsection.text: The Board shall distribute:

paragraph.text: to each applicant for a license and each code official, a copy of the Maryland Landscape Architects Act and the Board’s rules and regulations;

on each renewal of a license, to each licensee, a copy of any amendments to the Maryland Landscape Architects Act and the Board’s rules and regulations that took effect during the 2-year period ending on the date of renewal; and
to each code official, a copy of any amendments to the Maryland Landscape Architects Act and the Board’s rules and regulations.

subsection.text: A licensee shall designate the licensee’s mailing address at the time of issuance of the license and on each renewal of the license.
The Board may set reasonable fees for its services.

The fees charged shall be set so as to produce funds to approximate the cost of maintaining the Board and shall be based on the calculation performed by the Secretary under § 2–106.2 of the Business Regulation Article.
The Board shall publish the fee schedule set by the Board by regulation.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay all fees collected under this title to the Comptroller of the State.
The Comptroller shall distribute the fees to the State Occupational and Professional Licensing Design Boards’ Fund established in § 2–106.1 of the Business Regulation Article.

section.text: Any person aggrieved by any final action of the Board may take an appeal as allowed in §§ 10-222 and 10-223 of the State Government Article.
The Board exercises its powers, duties, and functions subject to the authority of the Secretary.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, an individual shall be licensed by the Board before the individual may practice landscape architecture in the State.
This section does not apply to:

paragraph.text: an individual who practices landscape architecture while performing official duties as an employee of the federal government;
an individual while practicing landscape architecture under the supervision of a licensed landscape architect, if the individual does not assume responsible charge of design or supervision; or

an individual while practicing landscape architecture as an employee of a person who is authorized to practice landscape architecture, if the employee does not assume responsible charge of design or supervision.

subsection.text: To qualify for a license, an applicant shall be an individual who meets the requirements of this section.
An applicant shall be at least 18 years old.
An applicant shall meet the educational and experience requirements under § 9-303 of this subtitle.
Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, the applicant shall pass the examination given by the Board under this subtitle.

Before an applicant takes the examination given by the Board, the applicant shall qualify under this section by meeting the educational and experience requirements set forth in subsection (b), (c), (d), or (e) of this section.
An applicant qualifies under this section if the applicant:

paragraph.text: has been graduated from a college or school of landscape architecture that holds accredited status from the national Landscape Architectural Accreditation Board; and
has at least 2 years of work experience in landscape architecture that is:

subparagraph.text: under the responsible charge of a licensed landscape architect or other authorized individual; and
otherwise satisfactory to the Board.

subsection.text: An applicant qualifies under this section if the applicant:

paragraph.text: has been graduated on completion of at least a 4–year curriculum in a design–related discipline from a college or university that is accredited by, or is a constituent unit of an institution accredited by, the Middle States Association of Colleges and Schools or the equivalent regional accrediting association of other regional areas; and
has at least 4 years of work experience in landscape architecture that is:

subparagraph.text: under the responsible charge of a licensed landscape architect or other authorized individual; and
otherwise satisfactory to the Board.

subsection.text: An applicant qualifies under this section if the applicant:

paragraph.text: has been graduated on completion of at least a 4–year curriculum in a nondesign–related discipline from a college or university that is accredited by, or is a constituent unit of an institution accredited by, the Middle States Association of Colleges and Schools or the equivalent regional accrediting association of other regional areas; and
has at least 6 years of practical work experience in landscape architecture that is:

subparagraph.text: under the responsible charge of a licensed landscape architect or other authorized individual; and
otherwise satisfactory to the Board.

paragraph.text: An applicant qualifies under this section if the applicant:

subparagraph.text: is a high school graduate or the equivalent; and
has at least 8 years of practical work experience in landscape architecture that is:

sub-subparagraph.text: under the responsible charge of a licensed landscape architect or other authorized individual; and
otherwise satisfactory to the Board.

paragraph.text: The Board may count each full year of study at a college or school of landscape architecture that meets the criteria set forth in subsection (b) of this section as one of the years of the work experience required under this subsection.

section.text: An applicant for a license shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the Board an application on the form that the Board provides; and
pay to the Board or the Board’s designee:

subparagraph.text: a nonrefundable application fee set by the Board; and
an examination fee set by the Board in an amount not to exceed the cost of the required examination.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 9-305.1 of this subtitle, an applicant who otherwise qualifies for a license is entitled to be examined as provided in this section.
The Board shall give written examinations to qualified applicants at least once a year at the time and place that the Board determines.
The Board shall give each qualified applicant notice of the time and place of examination.

paragraph.text: The Board shall determine, by regulation, the subjects, scope, and form of and the passing score for examinations given under this title.
The Board shall structure the examination to test the competency of an applicant to plan, design, and supervise the installation of landscape projects.
The Board may supplement a written examination given under this section with an oral examination.

subsection.text: The Board may use a testing service to administer the examinations given under this title.
If the Board uses a testing service under this subsection, the testing service, subject to the requirements set by the Board, may:

paragraph.text: set the time and place of examinations;
give qualified applicants notice of the time and place of examinations; and
furnish any other information that the Board may require the testing service to provide.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of this section, the Board may waive any requirement of this subtitle for an applicant who is licensed to practice landscape architecture in another state.
The Board may grant a waiver under this section only if the applicant:

paragraph.text: pays to the Board:

subparagraph.text: the nonrefundable application fee set by the Board; and
the license fee set by the Board; and

paragraph.text: provides adequate evidence that, at the time the applicant was licensed in the other state, the applicant was required to pass an examination and meet qualifications that were substantially equivalent to the examination and qualifications in this State.

subsection.text: The Board may grant a waiver under this section only if the state in which the applicant is licensed waives the examination and qualifications of licensees of this State to a similar extent as this State waives the examination and qualification requirements for individuals licensed in that state.
If an applicant qualifies for a license under this subtitle, the Board shall send the applicant a notice that states that:

paragraph.text: the applicant has qualified for a license; and
on receipt of the license fee set by the Board, the Board will issue a license to the applicant.

subsection.text: On payment of the license fee, the Board shall issue a license to each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle.
While a license is in effect, it authorizes the licensee to practice landscape architecture.
A licensed landscape architect is not authorized to practice architecture, engineering, or land surveying.
Unless a license is renewed for a 2–year term as provided in this section, the license expires on the first June 30 that comes:

paragraph.text: after the effective date of the license; and
in an even–numbered year.

subsection.text: At least 1 month before a license expires, the Board shall mail to the licensee, at the last known address of the licensee:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

subparagraph.text: the date on which the current license expires;
the date by which the Board must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the license expires; and
the amount of the license fee.

subsection.text: Before a license expires, the licensee periodically may renew it for an additional 2–year term, if the licensee:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be licensed;
pays to the Board the license fee set by the Board; and
submits to the Board a renewal application on the form that the Board provides.

subsection.text: The Board shall renew the license of each licensee who meets the requirements of this section.
The Secretary may determine that licenses issued under this subtitle shall expire on a staggered basis.

paragraph.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 9–312 of this subtitle, the Board, on the affirmative vote of a majority of its members then serving, may deny a license to any applicant, reprimand any licensee, or suspend or revoke a license if:

subparagraph.text: the applicant or licensee fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a license for the applicant or licensee or for another;
the applicant or licensee fraudulently or deceptively uses a license;
under the laws of the United States or of any state, the applicant or licensee is convicted of:

sub-subparagraph.text: a felony; or
a misdemeanor that is directly related to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to practice landscape architecture;

subparagraph.text: the applicant or licensee is guilty of gross negligence, incompetence, or misconduct while practicing landscape architecture;

the applicant or licensee has had a license to practice landscape architecture in another state revoked or suspended by the other state for a cause that would justify revocation or suspension under this title, except for the failure to pay a license fee;
the applicant or licensee violates any regulation adopted by the Board; or
the applicant or licensee violates any provision of this title.
Instead of or in addition to reprimanding a licensee or suspending or revoking a license under this subsection, the Board may impose a penalty not exceeding $5,000 for each violation.
To determine the amount of the penalty imposed under this subsection, the Board shall consider:

sub-subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the harm caused by the violation;
the good faith of the licensee; and
any history of previous violations by the licensee.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: The Board shall consider the following facts in the granting, denial, renewal, suspension, or revocation of a license or the reprimand of a licensee when an applicant or licensee is convicted of a felony or misdemeanor described in subsection (a)(1)(iii) of this section:

paragraph.text: the nature of the crime;
the relationship of the crime to the activities authorized by the license;
with respect to a felony, the relevance of the conviction to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to practice landscape architecture;
the length of time since the conviction; and
the behavior and activities of the applicant or licensee before and after the conviction.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of this section, the Board shall commence proceedings under § 9-310 of this subtitle on a complaint made to the Board by a member or any other person.

paragraph.text: A complaint shall:

subparagraph.text: be in writing;
state specifically the facts on which the complaint is based; and
be submitted to the Secretary of the Board.

paragraph.text: If the complaint is made by any person other than a member of the Board, the complaint shall be made under oath by the person who submits the complaint.

subsection.text: If the Board finds that a complaint alleges facts that are adequate grounds for action under § 9-310 of this subtitle, the Board shall act on the complaint as provided under § 9-312 of this subtitle. If the Board does not make that finding, it shall dismiss the complaint.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 10-226 of the State Government Article, before the Board takes any final action under § 9-310 of this subtitle, it shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Board.
A hearing shall be set within a reasonable time, not exceeding 6 months, after the Board brings charges against a licensee.

subsection.text: The Board shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Board may administer oaths in connection with any proceeding under this section.
At least 30 days before the hearing, the hearing notice and a copy of the complaint shall be:

paragraph.text: served personally on the individual; or
mailed to the last known address of the individual.

subsection.text: The individual may be represented at the hearing by counsel.
If, after due notice, the individual against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, nevertheless the Board may hear and determine the matter.
Subject to any regulation that the Board adopts, the Board may reinstate a license that has been revoked.
A license may be reinstated under this section only on:

paragraph.text: the affirmative vote of a majority of the members of the Board then serving; and
payment to the Board of a reinstatement fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: The Board shall reinstate the license of an individual who, for any reason, has failed to renew the license, if the individual:

paragraph.text: applies to the Board for reinstatement within 2 years after the license expires;
meets the renewal requirements of § 9–309 of this subtitle; and
pays to the Board a reinstatement fee set by the Board.
If an individual has failed to renew a license for any reason and then applies to the Board for reinstatement more than 2 years after the license has expired, the Board may:

subparagraph.text: require the individual to reapply for a license in the same manner that an applicant applies for an original license under this subtitle; or
subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, reinstate the license.

paragraph.text: The Board may reinstate a license under paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection, if the individual:

subparagraph.text: meets the renewal requirements of § 9–309 of this subtitle;
if required by the Board, states reasons why reinstatement should be granted; and
pays to the Board a reinstatement fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: The Board may waive a reinstatement fee for a licensee who provides evidence satisfactory to the Board that the licensee did not practice landscape architecture during the time the license lapsed.

section.text: In this subtitle, “responsible member” means an officer of a corporation or partner who is appointed under § 9-404(b) of this subtitle to be in responsible charge of landscape architecture practiced through the corporation or partnership.

paragraph.text: Subject to the provisions of this subtitle, a licensed landscape architect may practice landscape architecture for others through:

subparagraph.text: a corporation as an officer, employee, or agent of the corporation; or
a partnership as a partner, employee, or agent of the partnership.

paragraph.text: Subject to the provisions of this subtitle, a corporation or partnership may provide landscape architectural services through a licensed landscape architect but may not use the title “landscape architect” in connection with the name of the corporation or partnership.

subsection.text: A licensed landscape architect who practices landscape architecture through a corporation or partnership under this subtitle is subject to all of the provisions of this title that relate to practicing landscape architecture.

paragraph.text: A corporation or partnership that provides landscape architectural services to others under this subtitle is not, by its compliance with this subtitle, relieved of any responsibility that the corporation or partnership may have for an act or omission of its officer, partner, employee, or agent.

An individual who practices landscape architecture through a corporation or partnership is not, by reason of the individual’s employment or other relationship with the corporation or partnership, relieved of any individual responsibility that the individual may have regarding that practice.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a corporation or partnership shall hold a permit issued by the Board before the corporation or partnership may operate a business through which landscape architecture is practiced.
A corporation may provide landscape architectural services for itself or for an affiliated corporation without a permit issued by the Board.
To qualify for a permit, a corporation or partnership shall meet the requirements of this section.

paragraph.text: A corporation or partnership shall have appointed at least 1 responsible member of the corporation or partnership.
A responsible member shall be in responsible charge of landscape architecture practiced through the corporation or partnership.
The responsible member shall be:

subparagraph.text: an officer of a corporation or a partner of a partnership; and
a licensed landscape architect.

subsection.text: An applicant for a permit shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the Board an application on the form that the Board provides; and
pay to the Board the nonrefundable application fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: In addition to any other information required on an application form, the form shall require the name and address of:

paragraph.text: each responsible member of a corporation or partnership;
each officer and shareholder of a corporation; and
each partner of a partnership.

section.text: The Board shall issue a permit to each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle and pays to the Board a permit fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section and while a permit is in effect, it authorizes the holder to:

paragraph.text: operate a business through which a licensed landscape architect practices landscape architecture; and
represent to the public that the business provides the services of a licensed landscape architect.

subsection.text: A permit authorizes the holder to provide a service that constitutes practicing landscape architecture only if the service is performed by an individual who is licensed or otherwise authorized to practice landscape architecture under this title.
Unless a permit is renewed for a 2–year term as provided in this section, the permit expires on the first June 30 that comes:

paragraph.text: after the effective date of the permit; and
in an even–numbered year.

subsection.text: At least 1 month before a permit expires, the Board shall mail to the permit holder, at the last known address of the holder:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

subparagraph.text: the date on which the current permit expires;
the date by which the Board must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the permit expires; and
the amount of the permit fee.

subsection.text: Before a permit expires, the permit holder periodically may renew it for an additional 2–year term, if the holder:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to a permit;
pays to the Board the permit fee set by the Board; and
submits to the Board a renewal application on the form that the Board provides.

subsection.text: The renewal application form shall require the same information required on the original application form under § 9–405(b) of this subtitle.
The Board shall renew the permit of each permit holder that meets the requirements of this section.

section.text: Within 1 month after the effective date of the change, a permit holder shall submit to the Board an application form that shows a change in the name of:

paragraph.text: a responsible member of the holder;
an officer or shareholder, if the holder is a corporation; or
a partner, if the holder is a partnership.

section.text: Before a licensed landscape architect issues to a client or submits to a public authority any final drawing, plan, specification, report, or other document, the licensed landscape architect who prepared or approved the document shall sign, seal, and date the document.
Except as otherwise provided in this title, a person may not practice, attempt to practice, or offer to practice landscape architecture in the State unless licensed by the Board.
Except for a licensed landscape architect who operates a business as a sole practitioner, a person may not operate a business through which landscape architecture is practiced unless:

paragraph.text: the business is a corporation or a partnership; and
the corporation or partnership holds a permit issued by the Board.

section.text: Unless authorized under this title to practice landscape architecture, a person may not represent to the public, by use of a title, including “landscape architect” or “licensed landscape architect”, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person is authorized to practice landscape architecture in the State.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section and unless a person holds a permit issued by the Board, the person may not represent to the public, by the use of a title, including “landscape architects”, “licensed landscape architects”, or “registered landscape architects”, by the use of the term “landscape architecture”, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person holds a permit or otherwise is authorized to operate a business through which landscape architecture is practiced in the State.
Subsection (a) of this section does not apply to a licensed landscape architect who operates the business as a sole practitioner.

section.text: A person may not give false information to the Board in an attempt to obtain a license.

subsection.text: A person who violates any provision of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $3,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.

paragraph.text: The Board may impose on a person who violates any provision of this title a penalty not exceeding $5,000 for each violation.
In setting the amount of the penalty, the Board shall consider:

subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the harm caused by the violation;
the good faith of the violator;
any history of previous violations by the violator; and
any other relevant factors.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

section.text: This title may be cited as the “Maryland Landscape Architects Act”.

Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, this title and all regulations adopted under this title shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2024.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.

“Certificate of Competence” means certification obtained by a person through any organization accredited by the American National Standards Institute (ANSI), or the National Commission for Certifying Agencies (NCCA) that states the holder of the certificate demonstrates knowledge of and training in safe crane operating procedures.
“Commissioner” means the Commissioner of Labor and Industry in the Division of Labor and Industry in the Department.

paragraph.text: “Crane” means a machine for lifting, lowering, and horizontally moving a load, that has a hoisting mechanism that is an integral part of the machine.
