“Crane” includes tower cranes.
“Crane” does not include:

subparagraph.text: aircraft;
a bucket truck;
a digger derrick truck;
a fork lift;
a knuckle boom;
a trolley boom;
a hydraulic crane;
a power–operated derrick; or
a public utility company line truck used by a public utility company in the construction or maintenance of its transmission and distribution lines.

subsection.text: “Crane operator” means a person who operates a crane.

paragraph.text: “Operate a crane” means to use mechanisms inside a crane to guide the machine in:

subparagraph.text: the lifting, moving, positioning, and placing of large and heavy objects, earth, or other materials; or
the driving of large objects or materials into the ground.

paragraph.text: “Operate a crane” includes:

subparagraph.text: the inspection of a crane;
assisting in the erection, adding to, or dismantling of a crane; and
the performance of routine maintenance on a crane.

paragraph.text: “Operate a crane” does not include the movement of a crane on a State highway from one location to another location.

section.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, a person may not:

paragraph.text: operate a crane in the State for the purpose of construction work or demolition work unless the person holds a Certificate of Competence; or
authorize a person to operate a crane in the State for the purpose of construction work or demolition work unless the operator holds a Certificate of Competence.

subsection.text: A crane operator who holds a Certificate of Competence shall:

paragraph.text: carry the Certificate of Competence while operating a crane in the State; and
make the Certificate of Competence available for inspection on request by the Commissioner, an agent of the Commissioner, or by a law enforcement officer.

subsection.text: The failure of a crane operator to make the Certificate of Competence available for inspection on request as required under paragraph (a)(2) of this subsection shall be presumptive evidence that the crane operator does not hold a Certificate of Competence.
In addition to the powers conferred under this title, the Commissioner may use all powers conferred by law to the Commissioner to implement and enforce the provisions of this title.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner or an agent of the Commissioner who has reason to believe that a person is or has been operating a crane in the State without a valid Certificate of Competence shall require the crane operator to provide proof that the crane operator holds a Certificate of Competence.

If a crane operator fails to provide proof of a valid Certificate of Competence under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Commissioner or the agent of the Commissioner shall issue a written notice to the person that:

subparagraph.text: states that there has been a violation of this title, or regulations adopted under it, if any; and
requires the operation of the crane to cease unless operated by a person holding a valid Certificate of Competence.

paragraph.text: If a person fails to comply with a written notice issued under paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Commissioner may bring an action to enforce the written notice in the county where the crane being operated is located or in the Circuit Court of Baltimore City.
A person aggrieved by a decision of the Commissioner under this section may appeal to a court of competent jurisdiction in accordance with the Maryland Rules.
A decision of the Commissioner may not be stayed by the filing of an appeal under this subsection.

section.text: A person who violates this title or regulations adopted under this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000.
The Commissioner shall adopt regulations to implement, administer, and enforce this title.
This title shall be known as the “Maryland Safe Crane Operators Act”.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Admission to the Bar” means, unless the context requires otherwise, authorization by the Court of Appeals to practice law in the State.
“Attorney at law” means a lawyer who, while practicing law, represents another person.
“Bar” means, unless the context requires otherwise, the Bar of the Court of Appeals of Maryland.
“Board” means the State Board of Law Examiners.

paragraph.text: “Court” means, unless the context requires otherwise:

subparagraph.text: the Court of Appeals;
the Court of Special Appeals;
a circuit court; and
the District Court of Maryland.

paragraph.text: “Court” does not include:

subparagraph.text: an orphans’ court; or
the Maryland Tax Court.

subsection.text: “Lawyer” means an individual who is admitted to the Bar.

paragraph.text: “Practice law” means to engage in any of the following activities:

subparagraph.text: giving legal advice;
representing another person before a unit of the State government or of a political subdivision; or
performing any other service that the Court of Appeals defines as practicing law.

paragraph.text: “Practice law” includes:

subparagraph.text: advising in the administration of probate of estates of decedents in an orphans’ court of the State;
preparing an instrument that affects title to real estate;
preparing or helping in the preparation of any form or document that is filed in a court or affects a case that is or may be filed in a court; or
giving advice about a case that is or may be filed in a court.

section.text: This title does not limit the right of:

paragraph.text: an individual to appear on the individual’s own behalf before a court or other unit of the State government;
a title insurance company to examine and to insure titles to real property;
a collection company to engage in the business of collecting or adjusting commercial claims; or
a lawyer who is employed on a regular salaried basis by a corporation to represent the corporation before a court or other unit of the State government.

subsection.text: Subject to this title, the Court of Appeals shall adopt rules that govern the standards and procedures for admission to the Bar.
The rules under this section shall include provisions for:

paragraph.text: a uniform system of Bar examination in the State;
the registration of each applicant for admission to the Bar;
the qualifications of each applicant for admission to the Bar;
the examination of the character of each applicant for admission to the Bar; and
the fees to be paid by an applicant.

section.text: There is a State Board of Law Examiners.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of 7 members.
Each member shall be a lawyer.
The Court of Appeals shall appoint the members of the Board.

subsection.text: Each member of the Board shall have been a lawyer for at least 5 years.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 5 years and begins on January 1.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on October 1, 1989.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
The Court of Appeals may reappoint a member.

subsection.text: A majority of the authorized membership of the Board is a quorum.

section.text: The Board shall pay all money collected under this title into the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided by law, before an individual may practice law in the State, the individual shall:

paragraph.text: be admitted to the Bar; and
meet any requirement that the Court of Appeals may set by rule.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a person while representing a landlord in a summary ejectment or a rent escrow proceeding in the District Court of Maryland;
a person while representing a tenant in a summary ejectment or a rent escrow proceeding in the District Court of Maryland if the person is:

subparagraph.text: a law student practicing in a clinical law program at a law school accredited by the American Bar Association with the in–court supervision of a faculty member; or
employed by a nonprofit organization receiving grants from the Maryland Legal Services Corporation and:

sub-subparagraph.text: the person has training and experience;
the person is supervised by a lawyer; and
the supervising lawyer’s appearance is entered in the proceeding;

paragraph.text: an insurance company while defending an insured through staff counsel;

an officer of a corporation, an employee designated by an officer of a corporation, a partner in a business operated as a partnership or an employee designated by a partner, a member of a limited liability company or an employee designated by a member of a limited liability company, or an employee designated by the owner of a business operated as a sole proprietorship while the officer, partner, member, or employee is appearing on behalf of the corporation, partnership, limited liability company, or business in a civil action in the District Court of Maryland if:

subparagraph.text: the action:

sub-subparagraph.text: is based on a claim that does not exceed the amount set under § 4–405 of the Courts Article for a small claim action; and
is not based on an assignment, to the corporation, partnership, or business, of the claim of another;

subparagraph.text: in the case of a designated employee, the employee:

sub-subparagraph.text: is not assigned on a full–time basis to appear in the District Court on behalf of the corporation, partnership, or business;

provides the court a power of attorney sworn to by the employer that certifies that the designated employee is an authorized agent of the corporation, partnership, limited liability company, or sole proprietorship and may bind the corporation, partnership, limited liability company, or sole proprietorship on matters pending before the court; and
is not an individual who is disbarred or suspended as a lawyer in any state; and

subparagraph.text: the corporation, partnership, limited liability company, or business does not contract, hire, or employ another business entity to provide appearance services;

paragraph.text: an individual who is authorized by a county employee to represent the employee at any step of the county’s grievance procedure; or

a director or an officer of a common ownership community while representing the common ownership community in a dispute, hearing, or other matter before a board or commission established to oversee one or more of the following common ownership communities:

subparagraph.text: a development subject to a declaration enforced by a homeowners association as defined in § 11B–101 of the Real Property Article;
a residential condominium as defined in § 11–101 of the Real Property Article; or
a cooperative housing corporation as defined in § 5–6B–01 of the Corporations and Associations Article.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “practice patent law”:

subparagraph.text: means to perform professional services that the Patent and Trademark Office requires to be performed by an individual registered to practice before that Office; and
includes preparing a copyright application or assignment and submitting it to the Copyright Office of the Library of Congress.

paragraph.text: While there is a Patent and Trademark Office in the State, an individual may practice patent law in the State if the individual is:

subparagraph.text: authorized to practice law in any other state; and
registered to practice patent law before the Patent and Trademark Office.

paragraph.text: Unless otherwise authorized under this title, an individual who practices patent law under this subsection may not:

subparagraph.text: appear as an attorney at law in a court; or
practice law generally in the State.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, this section does not apply to an individual while giving legal advice to a corporation in this State if the individual is:

subparagraph.text: employed by the corporation; and
admitted to the bar of any other state.

paragraph.text: An individual who gives legal advice under this subsection:

subparagraph.text: is subject to disciplinary proceedings as the Maryland Rules provide; and
may not appear before a unit of the State government or of a political subdivision unless a court grants the individual a special admission in accordance with § 10-215 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: To qualify for admission to the Bar, an applicant shall be an individual who meets the requirements of this section.
An applicant shall be of good character and reputation.
An applicant shall be at least 18 years old as of the date of admission.
An applicant shall:

paragraph.text: have completed the academic work necessary to meet the minimum requirements for admission to an American Bar Association approved law school; and
have a degree of juris doctor or its equivalent from a law school that the Board recognizes.

subsection.text: An applicant shall pass a written examination given by the Board under this subtitle.
An applicant shall meet any other qualification or requirement that the Court of Appeals establishes by rule.
An applicant for admission to the Bar shall submit to the Board a petition to the Court of Appeals on the form that the Board provides.
An applicant shall pay to the Board:

paragraph.text: an examination fee, as set by the Court of Appeals, not exceeding:

subparagraph.text: $250 for fiscal year 2009; and
$400 for fiscal year 2010 and thereafter; and

paragraph.text: any other fee set by the Court of Appeals.
An applicant who otherwise qualifies for admission to the Bar is entitled to be examined as provided under this section.
Notwithstanding § 10-207(c) of this subtitle, an individual under the age of 18 years may take the examination.

subsection.text: Subject to the rules adopted by the Court of Appeals, the Board periodically shall give examinations to applicants at the times and places that the Board determines.
The Board shall give each applicant notice of the time and place of examination.
Subject to the rules adopted by the Court of Appeals, the Board shall determine the subjects, scope, and form of and the passing score for examinations.
The Board shall report to the Court of Appeals:

paragraph.text: the results of each examination that the Board gives; and
recommendations about the character and reputation of each applicant who passes the examination.

subsection.text: An applicant who is a member of the bar of another state may become a member of the Bar of this State if the applicant:

paragraph.text: is of good character and reputation;
provides adequate evidence that, for at least 5 of the 7 years immediately before applying for admission to the Bar, the applicant was practicing law or teaching law or was a judge;
pays the application fee set by the Court of Appeals; and
passes an examination given by the Board.

subsection.text: The Court of Appeals may adopt rules to govern:

paragraph.text: the content and administration of an examination given under this section;
the determination of the character and reputation of applicants; and
any other matter necessary to provide for the admission to the Bar of applicants under this section.

section.text: If an applicant meets the requirements of this Part II of this subtitle, the Court of Appeals shall pass an order of admission of the applicant to the Bar.
On admission to the Bar, a lawyer shall take the following oath or affirmation in open court:

“I do solemnly (swear) (affirm) that I will at all times demean myself fairly and honorably as an attorney and practitioner at law; that I will bear true allegiance to the State of Maryland, and support the laws and Constitution thereof, and that I will bear true allegiance to the United States, and that I will support, protect and defend the Constitution, laws and government thereof as the supreme law of the land; any law, or ordinance of this or any state to the contrary notwithstanding.”

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section and while an admission to the Bar is in effect, the admission authorizes a lawyer to practice law in any court.
Before a lawyer may practice law, the lawyer shall satisfy any additional requirement set by rule of the Court of Appeals.

section.text: The Court of Appeals may revoke an order of admission to the Bar that is obtained fraudulently or deceptively.

subsection.text: Subject to subsections (b) and (c) of this section, on a motion filed as required by rules adopted by the Court of Appeals, a court may grant special admission to practice law in a particular case to an individual who is:

paragraph.text: admitted to the bar of another state; and
employed by a party in the case before:

subparagraph.text: a court or other unit of the State government; or
a unit of a political subdivision of the State.

subsection.text: A special admission to practice law may be granted only:

paragraph.text: by the court hearing the case for which an individual requests the special admission; or
if the case is before a unit other than a court, by:

subparagraph.text: the circuit court for the county where the unit has its principal office; or
any circuit court to which the case may be appealed.

subsection.text: An individual may practice law under this section only in connection with the case for which the special admission is granted.
An individual who practices law under this section is subject to disciplinary proceedings as the Maryland Rules provide.

section.text: Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, this subtitle shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2020.

subsection.text: In this Part I of this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Attorney trust account” means an account that a lawyer or law firm maintains at a financial institution for the deposit of trust money.
“Attorney trust account” includes an escrow account.

subsection.text: “Beneficial owner” means a person, other than the client of a lawyer, for whose benefit a lawyer is entrusted to hold trust money.
“Trust money” means a deposit, payment, or other money that a person entrusts to a lawyer to hold for the benefit of a client or a beneficial owner.
Unless a lawyer or the firm of the lawyer maintains an attorney trust account in accordance with this subtitle and the Maryland Rules, the lawyer may not accept trust money.
Each attorney trust account shall be maintained at an approved financial institution, as provided in the Maryland Rules.

paragraph.text: An attorney trust account may be an interest bearing or noninterest bearing account.
An attorney trust account may be:

subparagraph.text: a savings account;
a checking account;
an account that is subject to negotiable orders of withdrawal; or
any combination of these accounts.

paragraph.text: A lawyer who deposits trust money in a noninterest bearing account is not liable for damages that relate to the loss of interest on the trust money if the deposit is made in compliance with:

subparagraph.text: the provisions of this Part I of this subtitle; and
the applicable provisions of the Maryland Rules of Professional Conduct.

subsection.text: Subject to this section a lawyer shall deposit trust money in an attorney trust account, all interest on which is payable to the Maryland Legal Services Corporation Fund established under § 11–402 of the Human Services Article.

A lawyer shall deposit trust money in an interest bearing account under this section whenever the lawyer reasonably expects that, for the period that the lawyer expects to hold the trust money, the interest that it would earn:

paragraph.text: would not exceed $50; or

subparagraph.text: would exceed $50; but
would not cover the cost of administering an interest bearing account on which interest is payable to the client or beneficial owner.

subsection.text: The Administrative Office of the Courts, in consultation with the Maryland Legal Services Corporation, may waive the provisions of subsection (b) of this section with respect to a lawyer or law firm that demonstrates that it will cost the Maryland Legal Services Corporation Fund more in service charges to open and maintain an attorney trust account with the interest payable to the Maryland Legal Services Corporation Fund than will be generated in interest by the attorney trust account.

paragraph.text: At least quarterly, each financial institution that has an account described under this section shall:

subparagraph.text: deduct from the total interest accumulated in the account any service charge due on the account; and
pay the net interest to the Maryland Legal Services Corporation Fund.

paragraph.text: A financial institution:

subparagraph.text: may not charge against the individual accounts of a lawyer any service charges for trust moneys in an account under this section; and
may charge the Maryland Legal Services Corporation Fund.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a lawyer expeditiously shall deposit trust money into an attorney trust account.
Subsection (a) of this section does not apply if there is a court order to the contrary.
Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section or any other law, a lawyer may disburse, at settlement in a real estate transaction, trust money that the lawyer receives in the transaction.

section.text: Except for trust money that a lawyer is required to deposit in an attorney trust account that earns interest payable to the Maryland Legal Services Corporation, a lawyer may withdraw trust money from an attorney trust account and invest it:

paragraph.text: as the client or beneficial owner of the trust money instructs; or
as the lawyer and the client or beneficial owner of the trust money agree.

section.text: A lawyer may not use trust money for any purpose other than the purpose for which the trust money is entrusted to the lawyer.

A lawyer who willfully violates any provision of this Part I of this subtitle, except for the requirement that a lawyer deposit trust moneys in an attorney trust account for charitable purposes under § 10-303 of this subtitle, is subject to disciplinary proceedings as the Maryland Rules provide.
In this Part II of this subtitle, “Fund” means the Client Protection Fund of the Bar of Maryland.

subsection.text: The Court of Appeals may adopt rules that:

paragraph.text: establish a Client Protection Fund of the Bar of Maryland;
provide for the appointment of trustees to administer the Fund; and
provide for the operation of the Fund.

subsection.text: The purpose of the Fund is to maintain the integrity of the legal profession by paying money to reimburse losses caused by defalcations of lawyers.
By rule, the Court of Appeals may:

paragraph.text: require a lawyer to pay an annual fee, not exceeding $20, to the Fund; and
specify the penalties, including suspension and disbarment, for practicing law without having paid the annual fee.

subsection.text: The Fund may raise and collect money through voluntary contributions or other means.
The trustees appointed under § 10-311 of this subtitle shall:

paragraph.text: receive contributions to the Fund; and
manage the assets of the Fund.

subsection.text: To the extent the trustees consider reimbursement proper and reasonable, the trustees may use the Fund to reimburse a person for a loss that was caused by a defalcation of a lawyer if:

paragraph.text: the lawyer caused the loss while acting for the person as an attorney at law or a fiduciary; and
the person cannot recover the money under a bond.

subsection.text: The trustees may enforce a claim for restitution arising by subrogation, assignment, or otherwise against any person whose actions gave rise to a claim that the Fund pays.
By August 31 of each year, the Fund shall provide a list of lawyers who have paid an annual fee to the Fund during the previous fiscal year to:

paragraph.text: the Department of Assessments and Taxation, to assist the Department in identifying new businesses within the State; and

the Comptroller, to assist the Comptroller in determining whether each lawyer on the list has paid all undisputed taxes and unemployment insurance contributions payable to the Comptroller or the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.

subsection.text: The list provided under this section shall:

paragraph.text: be provided free of charge; and
include, for each person on the list:

subparagraph.text: the name and mailing address of the person; and
the federal tax identification number of the person or, if the person does not have a federal tax identification number, the Social Security number of the person.

subsection.text: If the Comptroller determines that a lawyer has not paid all undisputed taxes and unemployment insurance contributions payable to the Comptroller or the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation and the lawyer does not make payment or provide for payment in a manner satisfactory to the unit responsible for collection within 60 days after receiving notice of the delinquency from the Comptroller, or within any longer period authorized for good cause by the unit responsible for collection, the Comptroller may refer the matter to Bar Counsel under Maryland Rule 16–731.

section.text: The Attorney General may investigate, as provided in this subtitle, a complaint of an unauthorized practice of law.

paragraph.text: Each investigation conducted under this subtitle is confidential.

Except as otherwise provided in this section, a person who participates in an investigation may not disclose the name of a person under investigation, the name of a witness, or any other information obtained in the investigation.

subsection.text: A person who participates in an investigation may disclose information to:

paragraph.text: the person under investigation; and
a person to whom disclosure is required in the discharge of an official duty.

section.text: Whenever the Attorney General conducts an investigation under this subtitle, the Attorney General shall provide to the person under investigation:

paragraph.text: a written statement that specifies the conduct under investigation; and
an opportunity to be heard and to present evidence on the conduct under investigation.

subsection.text: In an investigation under this subtitle, the Attorney General, a deputy attorney general, or any assistant attorney general whom the Attorney General designates may:

paragraph.text: issue a subpoena for the attendance of a witness to testify or the production of evidence;
administer oaths; and
examine witnesses.

subsection.text: The laws that relate to civil actions govern the attendance and compensation of witnesses in an investigation under this subtitle.
If a person fails to comply with a subpoena or refuses to testify about a material matter, on petition of the Attorney General, a circuit court may compel compliance with the subpoena.

section.text: In an investigation under this subtitle, an officer of the State or of a political subdivision of the State or a deputy, clerk, or employee of the officer shall provide the information and help requested by the Attorney General, a deputy attorney general, or any assistant attorney general whom the Attorney General designates.

subsection.text: The Attorney General or Bar Counsel appointed under Maryland Rule 16-712 may sue to enjoin an unauthorized person from practicing, attempting to practice, or offering to practice law.

paragraph.text: If the Attorney General brings an action under this section, Bar Counsel may intervene for good cause at any stage of the proceeding.
If Bar Counsel brings an action under this section, the Attorney General may intervene for good cause at any stage of the proceeding.

section.text: The remedies and procedures set forth in this subtitle are in addition to and not in substitution for other remedies and procedures that address the unauthorized practice of law.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section, an attorney at law has a lien on:

paragraph.text: a cause of action or proceeding of a client of the attorney at law from the time the cause of action arises or the proceeding begins; and
a settlement, judgment, or award that a client receives as a result of legal services that the attorney at law performs.

subsection.text: A lien under this section attaches only if, and to the extent that, under a specific agreement between an attorney at law and a client, the client owes the attorney at law a fee or other compensation for legal services that produced the settlement, judgment, or award.
A lien under this section is subordinate only to:

paragraph.text: a prior lien for wages due to an employee of the client for work related to the settlement, judgment, or award; or
a lien for taxes that the client owes the State.

subsection.text: An attorney at law may retain property subject to a lien under this section and bring an action for execution under the lien only in accordance with rules that the Court of Appeals adopts.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Lawyer counseling committee” means a group of individuals that:

subparagraph.text: is recognized by the Court of Appeals;
is a standing committee of the Maryland State Bar Association or of a local bar association;
consists of lawyers and other individuals necessary to carry out the functions of the committee; and
evaluates and helps a lawyer in need of treatment and rehabilitation for:

sub-subparagraph.text: substance abuse; or
any other physical, emotional, or mental condition that adversely affects the ability of the lawyer to practice law in accordance with the rules adopted by the Court of Appeals.

paragraph.text: “Local bar association” means:

subparagraph.text: in Baltimore City, the Bar Association of Baltimore City; or
in each county, the bar association with the greatest number of members who are residents of the county and who maintain their principal office for the practice of law in that county.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not apply to a proceeding before the Attorney Grievance Commission or a disciplinary proceeding against a lawyer before a circuit court or the Court of Appeals.

The proceedings, records, and files of a lawyer counseling committee are not admissible into evidence or discoverable in an action that arises out of a matter that the lawyer counseling committee is or has been reviewing.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other law, a member of a lawyer counseling committee shall have the immunity from liability and may not be subject to any disciplinary proceeding as described in § 5-416 of the Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article.
Except as otherwise provided by law, a person may not practice, attempt to practice, or offer to practice law in the State unless admitted to the Bar.
While an individual is on inactive status or disbarred or while the individual’s right to practice law is suspended or revoked, the individual may:

paragraph.text: discharge existing obligations;
collect and distribute accounts receivable; or
perform any other act that is necessary to conclude the affairs of a law practice but that does not constitute practicing law.

subsection.text: It is not a defense to a charge of a violation of this section that the defendant acted through an officer, director, partner, trustee, agent, or employee who is a lawyer.

section.text: Unless authorized by law to practice law in the State, a person may not represent to the public, by use of a title, including “lawyer”, “attorney at law”, or “counselor at law”, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person is authorized to practice law in the State.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a lawyer while employed as a part–time master for juvenile cases; or
an individual while:

subparagraph.text: performing an affirmative duty required by law; or
engaging in an activity related to a case in which the individual is a party or has a property interest.

subsection.text: Even if an individual has been admitted to the Bar, the individual may not practice law while employed:

paragraph.text: except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, as a sheriff or deputy sheriff;
in a jail or penitentiary, as:

subparagraph.text: a warden or deputy warden; or
a superintendent or deputy superintendent;

paragraph.text: as a bailiff;
as a clerk or deputy clerk of any court or an employee of a clerk;
as a register or deputy register of wills or an employee of a register of wills; or
as an officer or employee in a juvenile court.

subsection.text: An individual employed as a sheriff or deputy sheriff in Washington County who has been admitted to the Bar may practice law in a county other than Washington County.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not apply to the settlement of small estates as set forth in Title 5, Subtitle 6 of the Estates and Trusts Article.

In Prince George’s County, a sheriff, deputy sheriff, warden, deputy warden, clerk, or employee of any court may not prepare or help in the preparation of any form or document that is filed in a court in that county or that affects a case that is or may be filed in a court in that county.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Law enforcement agency” means an agency that is listed in § 3–101(e) of the Public Safety Article.
“Motor vehicle accident” has the meaning stated in § 27–401 of the Insurance Article.
“Report” means a report completed by a police officer of a law enforcement agency that:

subparagraph.text: indicates that a motor vehicle accident occurred; and
includes information about a person involved in the motor vehicle accident, including the person’s name, telephone number, and address.

subsection.text: Without an existing relationship or interest in an issue:

paragraph.text: a person may not, for personal gain, solicit another person to sue or to retain a lawyer to represent the other person in a lawsuit;
a person who is not a lawyer may not, for personal gain, access a report for the purpose of soliciting another person to sue or to retain a lawyer to represent the other person; and
a lawyer, except as provided in the Rules of Professional Conduct, may not:

subparagraph.text: for personal gain, solicit another person to sue or to retain the lawyer to represent the person in a lawsuit;

directly or indirectly employ or in any way compensate or agree to employ or compensate any person as an expert witness or otherwise for the purpose of having that person solicit or attempt to solicit clients for the lawyer;
knowingly represent a person who retained the lawyer as a result of solicitation prohibited under this section; or
cause a case to be instituted without the authority of a client.

subsection.text: Any solicitation involving acts described in this section is prima facie evidence that the person soliciting is acting for gain.

section.text: A sheriff, deputy sheriff, constable, police officer, or other law enforcement official may not solicit clients for a lawyer in a place where individuals are held while awaiting trial for criminal offenses.

subsection.text: This section applies only to the following forms of communication:

paragraph.text: an audio recording;
a computer on-line transmission;
a facsimile transmission;
a letter or other form of written communication;
a telegraphic transmission;
a telephonic transmission; and
a video recording.

subsection.text: A lawyer may not send a communication, directly or through an agent, to a prospective client for the purpose of obtaining professional employment if the communication concerns an action for personal injury or wrongful death, or otherwise relates to an accident or disaster involving the person to whom the communication is sent or the person’s relative, unless the accident or disaster occurred more than 30 days before the date the communication is sent.
This section does not apply to a communication sent by a lawyer to a prospective client at the request of the prospective client.

paragraph.text: This section applies only to a communication:

subparagraph.text: in a form described under subsection (c) of this section;
sent by a lawyer, directly or through an agent or employee, to a prospective client for the purpose of obtaining professional employment; and
if the communication concerns:

sub-subparagraph.text: an action for personal injury or wrongful death, or otherwise relates to an accident or disaster involving the person to whom the communication is sent or the person’s relative; or
a criminal prosecution, or a prosecution of a traffic offense that is punishable by a period of incarceration, involving the person to whom the communication is sent or the person’s relative.

paragraph.text: This section does not apply to a direct marketing communication that is not related to:

subparagraph.text: a specific accident or disaster described under paragraph (1)(iii)1 of this subsection; or
a specific criminal prosecution or traffic offense described under paragraph (1)(iii)2 of this subsection.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to a communication sent to a prospective client at the request of the prospective client.
This section applies only to the following forms of communication:

paragraph.text: an audio recording;
a computer on-line transmission;
a facsimile transmission;
a letter or other form of written communication;
a telegraphic transmission;
a telephonic transmission; and
a video recording.
Each communication shall include the words “this is an advertisement” in a prominent place at the beginning and end of each communication as required in this subsection.
In a communication sent by computer on-line transmission, facsimile, mail, or telegraph, the required wording shall appear in conspicuous print size and in a freestanding form:

subparagraph.text: on the outside of the envelope, if any; and
at the beginning and end of the contents of the communication.

paragraph.text: If the form of the communication is a self-mailing brochure or pamphlet, the required wording shall appear on the address panel of the brochure or pamphlet.
In a video recording communication, the required wording:

subparagraph.text: shall appear conspicuously in the communication for at least five seconds at the beginning and for at least five seconds at the end of the communication; and
of the audio recording portion, if any, of the communication shall meet the requirements of paragraph (5) of this subsection.

paragraph.text: In an audio recording communication, the required wording shall appear, at the beginning and end of the communication, in a tone, volume, clarity, and speed of delivery at least substantially equivalent to the quality of the tone, volume, clarity, and speed of the audio elsewhere in the communication.

subsection.text: A written communication may not be in the form of, or include, legal pleadings or legal documents.
A communication may not reveal on the envelope, or on the outside of a self-mailing brochure or pamphlet, the nature of the prospective client’s legal matter.
In addition to meeting the requirements of this section, a communication shall comply with Maryland Rules of Professional Conduct 7.1 through 7.4.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “Bar Counsel” means the principal executive officer of the disciplinary system for lawyers under the Maryland Rules.
Subject to the provisions of this subsection, a person who sends a communication shall, within 3 days after the date that the communication is sent, file the following with the Bar Counsel:

subparagraph.text: a copy of the communication, together with a sample copy of the envelope, if any, used in conjunction with the communication; and
the name of the person to whom the communication was sent and the person’s mailing address, telephone number, or telecommunication address to which the communication was sent.

paragraph.text: If communications identical in content are sent to two or more persons, a person may comply with the provisions of paragraph (2) of this subsection by filing with the Bar Counsel within 3 days after the date that the communication was sent a single copy of the communication together with a list of the names and the applicable mailing addresses, telephone numbers, or telecommunication addresses of the persons to whom the communication was sent.

If the person periodically sends an identical communication to additional persons, the person may comply with the provisions of paragraph (2) of this subsection by filing with Bar Counsel lists of additional names and the applicable mailing addresses, telephone numbers, or telecommunication addresses not less than monthly.
A communication may not state or imply that a communication is approved by the Bar Counsel, the State, or any unit of the State.

subsection.text: A lawyer, or a person acting as an agent or employee of the lawyer, may not send, or knowingly permit to be sent, on a lawyer’s behalf, on the behalf of a lawyer’s firm, partner, or associate, or on behalf of any other lawyer affiliated with the lawyer, a communication that does not meet the requirements of this section.

paragraph.text: A corporation, partnership, or any other association that violates § 10-601 or § 10-602 of this subtitle is subject to a fine not exceeding $5,000.

An officer, director, partner, trustee, agent, or employee who acts to enable a corporation, partnership, or association to violate § 10-601 or § 10-602 of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.

Except as provided in paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subsection, a person who violates § 10-601 of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.

subsection.text: A person who willfully violates any provision of Subtitle 3, Part I of this title, except for the requirement that a lawyer deposit trust moneys in an attorney trust account for charitable purposes under § 10-303 of this title, is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or both.

Except as provided in subsections (a) and (b) of this section, a person who violates any provision of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.

section.text: This title may be cited as the “Maryland Lawyers Act”.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Association” means the Association of Maryland Pilots.
“Board” means the State Board of Pilots.

paragraph.text: “License” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a license issued by the Board to provide pilotage.
“License” includes, unless the context requires otherwise, a limited license.
“Licensed pilot” means a pilot who is licensed by the Board to provide pilotage.
“Licensed pilot” includes the holder of a limited license.
“Limited license” means a license issued by the Board to provide pilotage as limited by § 11–407 of this title.
“Limited license” includes a 40–foot–draft limited license, a 36–foot–draft limited license, and a 32–foot–draft limited license.

subsection.text: “Pilot” means an individual who provides pilotage.
“Pilot-in-training” means an individual who is engaged in training, under the supervision of a licensed pilot, to provide pilotage.

paragraph.text: “Provide pilotage” means to pilot a vessel under the provisions of this title when the vessel is underway on the navigable waters of the State, including when the vessel is towing or being towed by another vessel.
“Provide pilotage” includes:

subparagraph.text: maneuvering a vessel during berthing or unberthing operations; and
shifting a vessel within a port with tug assistance.

section.text: There is a State Board of Pilots in the Department.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of 9 members.
Of the 9 members of the Board:

subparagraph.text: 1 shall be the Secretary, as an ex officio member, or a designee of the Secretary;
1 shall be the President of the Association;
3 shall be retired or licensed pilots who have at least 5 years’ experience providing pilotage;
2 shall be members of the steamship industry who actively employ pilots;
1 shall be a representative of the ship docking tugboat industry in the Port of Baltimore; and
1 shall be a consumer member.

paragraph.text: The Governor shall appoint each member under paragraph (2)(iii), (iv), (v), and (vi) of this subsection with the advice of the Secretary.

subsection.text: A designee of the Secretary:

paragraph.text: may not be or ever have been employed in the shipping or maritime industry; and
may not have or ever have had a financial interest in the shipping or maritime industry.

subsection.text: The consumer member of the Board:

paragraph.text: shall be a member of the general public;
may not be or ever have been employed or have or ever have had a financial interest in the shipping or maritime industry;
may not be a licensee or otherwise be subject to regulation by the Board;
may not, within 1 year before appointment, have had a financial interest in or have received compensation from a person regulated by the Board; and
may not be required to meet the qualifications for the professional members of the Board.

subsection.text: While a member of the Board, the consumer member may not:

paragraph.text: have a financial interest in or receive compensation from a person regulated by the Board; or
grade any examination given by or for the Board.

subsection.text: Before taking office, each appointee to the Board shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The term of an appointed member is 2 years and begins on June 1.
The terms of appointed members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on October 1, 1989.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
An appointed member may not serve more than 2 terms consecutively.

subsection.text: The Governor may remove a member for incompetence or misconduct.

section.text: From among the members of the Board, the Governor shall appoint a chairperson.

subsection.text: A majority of the authorized membership of the Board is a quorum.
The Board shall determine the times and places of its meetings.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection and to the State budget, each member of the Board is entitled to:

subparagraph.text: compensation of $500 per year, to be paid out of money that the Board collects; and
reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations.

paragraph.text: The Secretary or designee of the Secretary is not entitled to compensation under this subsection.

subsection.text: The Board may employ a staff in accordance with the State budget.
In addition to any powers set forth elsewhere, the Board may adopt regulations and pass orders to govern and regulate licensed pilots.
In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere, the Board shall:

paragraph.text: adopt a seal; and
be responsible for safety in providing pilotage.

subsection.text: The Board shall receive all fees and other charges collectible under §§ 11-406 and 11-408 of this title.
Except as otherwise provided by law, the Board shall pay all moneys collected under this title into the General Fund of the State.
The compensation of the Board and reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations shall be as provided in the State budget.

section.text: The Board exercises its powers, duties, and functions subject to the authority of the Secretary.

subsection.text: There is an incident committee within the Board.
The chairperson of the Board shall appoint one pilot member of the Board and one steamship industry member of the Board to the incident committee.
The incident committee shall:

paragraph.text: review all complaints filed with the Board and all reports of incidents filed by a licensed pilot; and
make a recommendation to the full Board on the disposition of each matter.

subsection.text: Before making a recommendation, the incident committee may request the Department to appoint an individual with experience in the investigation of maritime casualties to prepare a report on the underlying facts of a complaint or incident arising under § 11-409(a)(5) of this title.

section.text: An individual shall be appointed by the Board before the individual may serve as a pilot-in-training.
The Board shall keep a list of all applicants who qualify to be pilots-in-training.
To be included on the list of applicants who qualify to be pilots-in-training, an applicant shall:

paragraph.text: be at least 21 years old;
provide the Board with proof of recent satisfactory completion of the physical requirements for a first-class pilot license, as determined by the U.S. Coast Guard;
agree to participate in a U.S. Coast Guard approved random drug testing program;
have one or more of the following maritime credentials:

subparagraph.text: a degree from a 4-year course of study at an accredited maritime institution acceptable to the Board, and a current license as third mate, or greater grade, of steam and motor vessels, any gross tons upon oceans;
a current license as a master of steam and motor vessels, any gross tons upon oceans, that is issued by the U.S. Coast Guard and that contains an appropriate radar endorsement; or

a minimum of 5 years’ experience in the maritime industry working on vessels in the deck department as a licensed master or mate on tugs or inspected vessels, of which at least 2 years’ experience shall be as the master of a ship-assist harbor tug; and

paragraph.text: pass any mental or physical examination that the Board requires to verify that the applicant is mentally and physically capable of providing pilotage.

section.text: An applicant for appointment as a pilot-in-training shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the Board an application on the form that the Board provides; and
pay to the Board an application fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: The Board shall place the name of each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle on the list of qualified applicants.
From the list of qualified applicants, the Board may choose and appoint the number of pilots-in-training that the Board considers necessary to protect the commercial interests of the State.

section.text: Appointment as a pilot-in-training authorizes the individual to engage in training, under the supervision of a licensed pilot, to provide pilotage.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, an individual shall be licensed by the Board before the individual may provide pilotage in the State.
An individual may provide pilotage to a vessel in distress until a licensed pilot comes on board and offers to provide pilotage.
A person who provides pilotage without a license is liable for any damages that result.

section.text: Subject to the provisions of this subtitle, the Board may issue:

paragraph.text: a license;
a 40–foot–draft limited license;
a 36–foot–draft limited license; and
a 32–foot–draft limited license.

subsection.text: To qualify for a limited license, an applicant shall be an individual who meets the requirements of this section.
An applicant shall have trained as a pilot–in–training for at least 2 years.

An applicant shall possess sufficient ability, skill, and experience for a 32–foot–draft limited license, a 36–foot–draft limited license, or a 40–foot–draft limited license as determined by the Board through observation of the applicant’s performance providing pilotage.
An applicant shall meet any other requirements that the Board establishes.
To qualify for an unlimited license, an applicant shall be an individual who meets the requirements of this section.
An applicant who did not hold a limited license prior to October 1, 2004, shall have held a limited license and have provided pilotage for at least 3 years.
An applicant shall possess sufficient ability, skill, and experience for the unlimited license as determined by the Board through observation of the applicant’s performance providing pilotage.
An applicant shall meet any other requirements that the Board establishes.

section.text: To apply for a license, an applicant shall submit to the Board an application on the form that the Board provides.

subsection.text: If an applicant qualifies for a license under this subtitle, the Board shall send the applicant a notice that states that:

paragraph.text: the applicant has qualified for a license; and
the Board will issue the appropriate license to an applicant on receipt of a license fee of:

subparagraph.text: $600 for an unlimited license;
$300 for a 40–foot–draft limited license;
$300 for a 36–foot–draft limited license; or
$200 for a 32–foot–draft limited license.

subsection.text: On payment of the license fee, the Board shall issue an appropriate license to each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle.
The Board shall seal each license that the Board issues with its official seal.
An individual who holds an unlimited docking master license as of September 30, 2004, shall be issued an unlimited license upon completion of an application on the form that the Board provides.

The Board shall set by regulation the training and experience requirements that must be met before a pilot who previously held a docking master license may be assigned work in addition to the berthing and unberthing of vessels with tug assistance and the shifting of a vessel within a port with tug assistance.

The Board shall set by regulation the training and experience requirements that must be met before a pilot who previously provided pilotage service as defined in § 11-101(i)(1) of this title may be assigned work that includes the berthing and unberthing of vessels with tug assistance or the shifting of a vessel within a port with tug assistance.
While an unlimited license is in effect, it authorizes the licensee to provide pilotage for vessels of any draft.

paragraph.text: While a 40–foot–draft limited license is in effect, it authorizes the licensee to provide pilotage for vessels not exceeding 40–foot–draft.
While a 36–foot–draft limited license is in effect, it authorizes the licensee to provide pilotage for vessels not exceeding 36–foot–draft.
While a 32–foot–draft limited license is in effect, it authorizes the licensee to provide pilotage for vessels not exceeding 32–foot–draft.

subsection.text: A license shall be effective for 2 years from the date it is issued.
At least 1 month before a license expires, the Board shall mail to the licensee, at the last known address of the licensee:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

subparagraph.text: the date on which the current license expires;
the date by which the Board must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the license expires; and
the amount of the renewal fee.

subsection.text: Before a license expires, the licensee periodically may renew it for an additional 2–year term, if the licensee:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be licensed;
pays to the Board a renewal fee of:

subparagraph.text: $600 for an unlimited license;
$300 for a 40–foot–draft limited license;
$300 for a 36–foot–draft limited license; or
$200 for a 32–foot–draft limited license; and

paragraph.text: submits to the Board a renewal application on the form that the Board provides.

subsection.text: The Board shall renew the license of a licensee who meets the requirements of this section.
Subject to the hearing provisions of § 11-410 of this subtitle, the Board may deny a license to any applicant, reprimand any licensee, or suspend or revoke a license if the applicant or licensee:

paragraph.text: fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a license for the applicant or licensee or for another;
fraudulently or deceptively uses a license;
under the laws of the United States or of any state, is convicted of:

subparagraph.text: a felony; or
a misdemeanor that is directly related to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to provide pilotage;

paragraph.text: pilots or attempts to pilot a vessel while under the influence of:

subparagraph.text: alcohol;
narcotics; or
any other substance that impairs the physical or mental ability of the pilot to perform in a safe manner;

paragraph.text: pilots a vessel in a negligent or reckless manner;
anchors a vessel during a pilotage transit unless:

subparagraph.text: the anchorage was ordered by the master of the vessel; or
the anchorage was necessary for reasons of safety or prudent navigation;

paragraph.text: violates the conflict-of-interest provisions of § 11-603 of this title;
violates any regulation adopted by the Board; or
violates any order passed by the Board.
Subject to the hearing provisions of § 11-410 of this subtitle, the Board shall revoke the license of any pilot who does not provide pilotage for 1 year.
Notwithstanding paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Board may not revoke a license under this subsection if the failure of the pilot to provide pilotage was due to:

subparagraph.text: sickness of the pilot; or
assignment to administrative duties.

subsection.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 11-410 of this subtitle, the Board shall revoke the license of a pilot who, after receiving notice, refuses to aid a vessel in distress:

paragraph.text: within 18 nautical miles south of Cape Henry;
within 18 nautical miles east of Cape Henry;
in the Chesapeake Bay; or
in the ports of Maryland.
Instead of or in addition to suspending or revoking a license under subsection (a) of this section, the Board may impose a penalty not to exceed $2,000 for each violation.
To determine the amount of the penalty imposed under this subsection, the Board shall consider:

subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the harm caused by the violation;
the good faith of the licensee; and
any history of previous violations by the licensee.

subsection.text: The Board shall consider the following facts in the granting, denial, renewal, suspension, or revocation of a license or the reprimand of a licensee when an applicant or licensee is convicted of a felony or misdemeanor described in subsection (a)(3) of this section:

paragraph.text: the nature of the crime;
the relationship of the crime to the activities authorized by the license;
with respect to a felony, the relevance of the conviction to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to provide pilotage;
the length of time since the conviction; and
the behavior and activities of the applicant or licensee before and after the conviction.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 10-226 of the State Government Article, before the Board takes any final action under § 11-409 of this subtitle, it shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Board.
The Board shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Board may administer oaths in connection with any proceeding under this section.
If, after due notice, the individual against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, nevertheless the Board may hear and determine the matter.

section.text: Any person aggrieved by a final decision of the Board in a contested case, as defined in § 10-202 of the State Government Article, may take an appeal as allowed in §§ 10-222 and 10-223 of the State Government Article.

subsection.text: Each American vessel engaged in foreign trade and each foreign vessel shall employ a licensed pilot to pilot the vessel when it is underway on the navigable waters of the State, including when the vessel is towing or being towed by another vessel.
A vessel that is not required to employ a licensed pilot under subsection (a) of this section may voluntarily employ a licensed pilot when the vessel is underway on the navigable waters of the State.
The Public Service Commission shall establish pilotage fees in accordance with § 4–303 of the Public Utilities Article.

paragraph.text: Regardless of whether the employment is required under § 11-501(a) of this subtitle or voluntary under § 11-501(b) of this subtitle, a vessel that employs a licensed pilot to provide pilotage shall pay the licensed pilot the full pilotage fee.
Regardless of whether the vessel uses the services of the pilot for the entire pilotage, a vessel that employs a licensed pilot to provide pilotage shall pay the licensed pilot the full pilotage fee.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any contract between a licensed pilot who has provided pilotage for a vessel and the master, owner, charterer, or agent of the vessel or any other party, the vessel, its tackle, apparel, and furniture, and the master, owner, charterer, and agent of the vessel shall be jointly and severally liable for payment of the pilotage fee to the licensed pilot.

A licensed pilot who has provided pilotage for a vessel shall have a lien for the amount of the pilotage fee due, enforceable in a court of competent jurisdiction, on the vessel and its tackle, apparel, and furniture.

If a vessel fails to employ a licensed pilot to provide pilotage as required under § 11-501(a) of this subtitle, the vessel and its master, owner, charterer, and agent shall be jointly and severally liable for payment of the full pilotage fee as if a licensed pilot had been employed.

section.text: Pilotage fees due shall be paid to the Association as collection agent for its members.

subsection.text: A pilot is eligible for payments as an inactive pilot under § 11-505 of this subtitle if the pilot:

subparagraph.text: chooses to be placed on the list of inactive pilots maintained by the Association; and
has been, for at least 25 years:

sub-subparagraph.text: a member in good standing of the Association; and
licensed by the Board to provide pilotage for vessels of unlimited draft; or
has been certified by two physicians chosen by the Board to be permanently incapable of providing pilotage; or
has had a federal or State pilot’s license revoked for physical disability; and

subparagraph.text: before becoming permanently disabled, the pilot was:

sub-subparagraph.text: a member in good standing of the Association; and
licensed by the Board to provide pilotage for vessels of any draft.

subsection.text: A pilot is eligible for reduced payments as an inactive pilot under § 11-505 of this subtitle if the pilot:

paragraph.text: chooses to be placed on the list of inactive pilots maintained by the Association; and
has been, for at least 20 years:

subparagraph.text: a member in good standing of the Association; and
licensed by the Board to provide pilotage for vessels of unlimited draft.

subsection.text: Eligibility for payments as an inactive pilot shall cease if:

paragraph.text: a pilot who was declared permanently incapable of providing pilotage becomes capable of providing pilotage; or
a pilot who had a federal or State pilot’s license revoked for physical disability has the license reissued.

subsection.text: Time of service as a licensed docking master on or before September 30, 2004, shall be included in determining a pilot’s eligibility for payment as an inactive pilot.
A pilot who held an unlimited docking master license on October 1, 2000, is eligible for reduced payments as an inactive pilot under § 11-505 of this subtitle if the pilot:

paragraph.text: chooses to be placed on the list of inactive pilots maintained by the Association; and
has been, for at least 5 years:

subparagraph.text: a member in good standing of the Association or of the Association of Maryland Docking Pilots; and
licensed by the Board to provide pilotage for vessels of unlimited draft.

subsection.text: Each month, the Association shall distribute the pilotage fees that the Association collects in the following order:

paragraph.text: within 10 days after the close of each month, the Association shall:

subparagraph.text: account to the Board for that month for the amount determined under subsections (b) and (c) of this section for distribution to the pilots who, at the beginning of that month, were eligible for payments as inactive pilots; and
distribute those moneys on behalf of the Board; and

paragraph.text: the balance of the pilotage fees collected shall be:

subparagraph.text: first, used by the Association to pay its expenses;
second, paid to the Maintenance and Replacement Fund under § 11-506 of this subtitle; and
finally, in accordance with the bylaws of the Association, paid to the regularly working licensed pilots who are members in good standing of the Association.

subsection.text: The amount to be distributed by the Association on behalf of the Board to eligible inactive pilots described under § 11-504(a) of this subtitle shall be computed by:

paragraph.text: determining the greater of:

subparagraph.text: 40% of the share payable under this subtitle for the month for which the payment is to be made to a regularly working licensed pilot; and

paragraph.text: multiplying the figure determined under item (1) of this subsection by the number of pilots in the Association who, at the beginning of the month for which the payment is to be made, were eligible for payments as inactive pilots under this subsection.

subsection.text: The amount to be distributed by the Association on behalf of the Board to eligible inactive pilots described under § 11-504(b) of this subtitle shall be computed as follows:

paragraph.text: for each pilot determining the greater of:

sub-subparagraph.text: 32% of the share payable under this subtitle for the month for which the payment is to be made to a regularly working licensed pilot; and

1.6% of the share payable under this subtitle for the month for which the payment is to be made to a regularly working licensed pilot in addition for each year of service in excess of 20 years and up to 25 years; and

paragraph.text: totaling the sums determined under item (1) of this subsection for each pilot in the Association who, at the beginning of the month for which the payment is to be made, was eligible for payment as an inactive pilot under this subsection.

subsection.text: The amount to be distributed by the Association on behalf of the Board to eligible inactive pilots described under § 11-504(e) of this subtitle shall be 1.6% of the share payable under this subtitle for the month for which the payment is to be made to a regularly working licensed pilot for each full year of service following October 1, 2000.
The Board of Supervisors of the Association shall maintain a Maintenance and Replacement Fund for the replacement and repair of the major equipment of the Association.
The State Board of Pilots shall determine a percentage of the pilotage fees collected by the Association to be set aside in the Fund.
The Board of Supervisors of the Association shall obtain written approval from the State Board of Pilots for any expenditures from the Fund.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the balance in the Fund shall remain at or above $500,000.

subparagraph.text: The balance of the Fund may fall below $500,000 for expenditures authorized by the Board.
The balance of the Fund may not remain below $500,000 for more than 10 consecutive years.
At no time shall the balance of the Fund fall below $100,000.

subsection.text: The Board of Supervisors of the Association shall deposit the moneys authorized under subsection (b) of this section into the Maintenance and Replacement Fund.

paragraph.text: The Board of Supervisors of the Association shall hold the Maintenance and Replacement Fund in trust.
The Association:

subparagraph.text: may invest or hold the Fund in any manner that the Association finds desirable, in light of the nature and purpose of the Fund;
may place control and management of the Fund, or a part of the Fund, with a bank or trust company that is subject to State or federal regulation; and
is not limited to investments in property that has been designated, under any law of the State, as strictly suitable for investment of a trust fund.

subsection.text: Assets held in trust under this section are not subject to attachment or execution.

section.text: If an individual who is not a licensed pilot assists a vessel in distress and then turns the vessel over to a licensed pilot as provided in § 11-401(b) of this title, the Association shall pay the individual 50% of any pilotage fee received for the pilotage of the vessel.

subsection.text: The Association shall submit to the Board:

paragraph.text: an annual financial audit of payments to pilots under § 11-505 of this subtitle; and
an annual financial audit of the Maintenance and Replacement Fund under § 11-506 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Board shall keep copies of the financial audits received under subsection (a) of this section.
For purposes of subsection (b) of this section, the Department of the Environment shall prepare copies of the State regulations that govern the disposal of waste from vessels in the Chesapeake Bay.

Whenever a licensed pilot boards a vessel to provide pilotage, the licensed pilot shall present to the master of the vessel a copy of the State regulations that govern the disposal of waste from vessels in the Chesapeake Bay.

If a licensed pilot is detained for any reason on a vessel that has employed the pilot to provide pilotage, the master of the vessel shall pay the cost of the pilot’s maintenance and the daily rate of pay for an unlimited license pilot as determined by the bylaws of the Association for each day the pilot is detained.

If a licensed pilot is quarantined by order of a health officer because of conditions on a vessel that has employed the pilot to provide pilotage, the master of the vessel shall pay the pilot the cost of the pilot’s maintenance and the daily rate of pay for an unlimited license pilot as determined by the bylaws of the Association for each day that the pilot is quarantined.
If a master of a vessel carries a licensed pilot to sea under circumstances that are beyond the control of the pilot, the master shall:

paragraph.text: pay the pilot the daily rate of pay for an unlimited license pilot as determined by the bylaws of the Association until the return of the pilot;
provide first class accommodations and maintenance for the pilot; and
at the first opportunity, return the pilot by first class passage to the home port of the pilot.

subsection.text: The master, owner, charterer, and agent of a vessel shall be jointly and severally liable for any payments due under this section.
A licensed pilot may not engage in conduct that constitutes a conflict of interest.
A conflict of interest exists in situations in which:

paragraph.text: except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, a licensed pilot solicits or accepts financial or other consideration of value from a tugboat, towing, vessel-assist, vessel-owning, or vessel-chartering company, or an agent or officer of that company, or from any other entity providing services in the port community;

a licensed pilot takes any action with the intent to benefit or harm the economic interests of a tugboat, towing, vessel-assist, vessel-owning, or vessel-chartering company, or any other entity providing services in the port community;
a licensed pilot allows personal financial interests to conflict with professional responsibilities;
a licensed pilot solicits business for a tugboat, towing, vessel-assist, vessel-owning, or vessel-chartering company, or any other entity providing services in the port community; or

a licensed pilot discourages a person from engaging the services of a tugboat, towing, vessel-assist, vessel-owning, or vessel-chartering company, or any other entity providing services in the port community.

subsection.text: A conflict of interest does not exist in situations in which:

paragraph.text: remuneration is paid to the pilot through the Association in return for the provision of pilotage services; or
there is an exchange of nominal social pleasantries between the licensed pilot and any entity providing services to the port community.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, a person may not provide, attempt to provide, or offer to provide pilotage in the State unless licensed by the Board.

Unless authorized under this title to provide pilotage, a person may not represent to the public, by use of a title, including “pilot”, “bay pilot”, “licensed pilot”, “State licensed pilot”, or “Maryland pilot”, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person is authorized by the State to provide pilotage.
After receiving notice, a licensed pilot may not refuse to aid a vessel that is in distress:

paragraph.text: within 18 nautical miles south of Cape Henry;
within 18 nautical miles east of Cape Henry;
in the Chesapeake Bay; or
in ports of Maryland.

section.text: A licensed pilot may not take part in a port-wide job action or strike.
Unless a person is a licensed pilot, the person may not use a boat as a pilot boat.
The master of a vessel may not fail to employ a pilot as required under § 11-501 of this title.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a person who violates any provision of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or both.
A licensed pilot who violates any provision of § 11-601(b) of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $100.

section.text: This title may be cited as the “Maryland Pilots Act”.

Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, this title and all regulations adopted under this title shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2022.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Apprentice natural gas fitter” means, unless the context requires otherwise, an individual who is licensed by the Board to assist a master natural gas fitter in providing natural gas services while:

paragraph.text: under the direction and control of the master natural gas fitter; and
in training to become a journeyman natural gas fitter.

subsection.text: “Apprentice plumber” means, unless the context requires otherwise, an individual who is licensed by the Board to assist a master plumber or a holder of a limited master plumber license in providing plumbing services while:

paragraph.text: under the direction and control of the master plumber or holder of the limited master plumber license; and
in training to become a journey plumber.

subsection.text: “Board” means the State Board of Plumbing.
“Certified propane gas fitter” means an individual who has been certified by the Board to provide propane gas services.
“Gas” means natural gas, propane gas, or any other gas used for any purpose, including residential, medical, commercial, or industrial purposes.

“Journey plumber” means, unless the context requires otherwise, an individual who is licensed by the Board to provide plumbing services while under the direction and control of a master plumber or holder of a limited master plumber license.

“Journeyman natural gas fitter” means, unless the context requires otherwise, an individual who is licensed by the Board to provide natural gas services while under the direction and control of a master natural gas fitters license.
“Lead–free” means:

paragraph.text: containing not more than 0.2% lead for solder and flux;
except as provided in item (3) of this subsection, containing not more than:

subparagraph.text: 4% lead by dry weight for individual plumbing fittings and fixtures; or
8% lead by dry weight for individual pipes and pipe fittings;

paragraph.text: containing a percentage of lead for plumbing fittings and fixtures that is in compliance with standards established under 42 U.S.C.A. § 300g–6(e) of the federal Safe Drinking Water Act; and

containing not more than a weighted average lead content of 0.25% for the wetted surfaces of a pipe, pipe fitting, plumbing fitting, or fixture intended to dispense water for human consumption through drinking or cooking.
“License” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a license issued by the Board to:

subparagraph.text: provide plumbing services;
assist in providing plumbing services;
provide propane gas services; or
provide natural gas services.

paragraph.text: “License” includes, unless the context requires otherwise, each of the following licenses:

subparagraph.text: a master plumber license;
a journey plumber license;
an apprentice plumber license;
a limited license;
a propane gas fitter certificate;
a master natural gas fitters license;
a journeyman natural gas fitters license; and
an apprentice natural gas fitters license.

paragraph.text: “Limited license” means a license issued by the Board as limited by § 12–310 of this title to:

subparagraph.text: provide plumbing services as a master plumber; or
provide plumbing services as a journey plumber.

paragraph.text: “Limited license” includes:

subparagraph.text: a limited master plumber license; and
a limited journey plumber license.

subsection.text: “Master natural gas fitter” means, unless the context requires otherwise, an individual who is licensed by the Board to provide natural gas services.

paragraph.text: “Master plumber” means, unless the context requires otherwise, an individual who is licensed by the Board to provide plumbing services and natural gas services.
“Master plumber” includes a master plumber gas fitter.

“Provide natural gas services” means the installation, maintenance, extension, alteration, and removal of piping, gas–fired equipment, appliances, or appurtenances in connection with a natural gas supply system downstream of the gas utility point of delivery.
“Provide natural gas services” does not include the installation, maintenance, extension, alteration, or removal of any of the following with respect to the plumbing water supply and drainage system:

subparagraph.text: fixtures that require additional energy sources, including clothes washers, dishwashers, food grinders, humidifiers, ice pumps, sterilizers, water coolers, and water heaters; and
operational devices, including aerators, backflow preventers, expansion tanks, filters, flow controls, heat exchangers, interceptors, meters, separators, and relief valves.

paragraph.text: “Provide plumbing services” means to install, maintain, extend, alter, or remove piping, a plumbing fixture, a plumbing appliance, a plumbing appurtenance, or other plumbing apparatus:

subparagraph.text: within or adjacent to a building, structure, or property; and
in connection with:

sub-subparagraph.text: a public or private disposal system, sanitary drainage facility, or storm drainage facility;
a venting system; or
a public or private water supply system.
