the submission of a facsimile of any trademark that the applicant intends to use while conducting the business of the private detective agency; and
as the Secretary considers appropriate, any other information to assist in the evaluation of:

sub-subparagraph.text: an individual applicant; or
if the applicant is a firm, any firm member.

subsection.text: The application form provided by the Secretary shall contain a statement advising the applicant that willfully making a false statement on an application is a misdemeanor, subject to a fine or imprisonment or both, as provided under §§ 13-705 and 13-707 of this title.

paragraph.text: If the applicant is an individual, the application form shall be signed, under oath, by the individual.
If the applicant is a firm, the application form shall be signed, under oath, by the representative member, as the representative member, and by all the other firm members.
If the applicant is an individual, the application shall be accompanied by at least three names of individuals who can attest to the character of the applicant.
If the applicant is a firm, the application shall be accompanied by at least three names of individuals who can attest to the character of each firm member.

subsection.text: An applicant for a license who intends to employ at least 5 individuals as private detectives shall submit with the application proof of commercial general liability insurance, including errors and omissions and completed operations with a $1,000,000 total aggregate minimum, as required under § 13-604 of this title.
In addition to meeting the other requirements of this section, a nonresident applicant shall submit a consent and any related document, as required by § 13-605 of this title.

section.text: The Secretary may not issue a license to an applicant whose trade or fictitious name or trademark is so similar to that used by another licensee that the public may be confused or misled by the similarity.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall issue a license to each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle.
The Secretary shall issue an agency license certificate to each licensed private detective agency and a branch office certificate for each proposed branch office.
The Secretary shall include on each agency license certificate that the Secretary issues:

subparagraph.text: the full name of the licensee;
the location of the principal office and of each branch office of the licensed private detective agency;
the date of issuance of the license;
the date on which the license expires; and
the name and address of the representative member, if the licensee is a firm.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall include on each branch office certificate:

subparagraph.text: the full name of the licensee;
the location of the principal office of the licensee and of the agency branch office for which the certificate is issued;
the date of issuance of the branch office certificate;
the date on which the license of the licensee expires; and
the name and agency address of the representative member, if the licensee is applying on behalf of a firm.

section.text: While a license is in effect, it authorizes the licensee to:

paragraph.text: conduct a business that provides private detective services for compensation;
maintain an office for the conduct of the business at each location stated in the agency license certificate;
employ individuals as private detectives to provide private detective services to the public on behalf of the licensee; and
represent the licensee to the public as a private detective agency.

subsection.text: By regulation, the Secretary shall stagger the terms of the licenses.
Unless a license is renewed for a 2-year term as provided in this section, the license expires on the day that the Secretary sets.
At least 1 month before a license expires, the Secretary shall mail to the licensee, at the last known address of the licensee:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

subparagraph.text: the date on which the current license expires;

that the Secretary must receive the renewal application and the statements required under § 13-309 of this subtitle, at least 15 days before the license expiration date, for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the license expires;
the amount of the renewal fee;

that, if the statements required under § 13-309 of this subtitle are not received at least 15 days before the license expiration date, a fee of $10 per day shall be charged against the licensee until the statements are received; and
that the submission of a false statement in the renewal application or in the annual statements is cause for revocation of the license.

subsection.text: A licensee periodically may renew the license for an additional 2-year term, if the licensee:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be licensed;
pays to the Secretary:

subparagraph.text: a renewal fee of:

sub-subparagraph.text: $200, if the licensee is an individual; or
$400, if the licensee is a firm; and

subparagraph.text: any late fee required under § 13-309 of this subtitle; and

paragraph.text: submits to the Secretary:

subparagraph.text: a renewal application on the form that the Secretary provides; and
the statements required under § 13-309 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall renew the license of each licensee who meets the requirements of this section.
As a condition for license renewal, a licensee shall submit to the Secretary with the renewal application:

paragraph.text: a certification or, as authorized by the Secretary, other documentation that the licensed private detective agency has paid, for the past 3 years, all withholding and Social Security taxes;

a certification or, as authorized by the Secretary, other documentation that the licensed private detective agency has paid, for the past 3 years, all other obligations payable for the employees of the licensed private detective agency to the State or the federal government;

a certificate from an insurance carrier or, as authorized by the Secretary, other documentation showing that the licensed private detective agency has in effect workers’ compensation insurance for its covered employees, as defined in § 9-101 of the Labor and Employment Article; and

a receipt from the Comptroller’s Office or, as authorized by the Secretary, other documentation showing that the State income tax of the licensed private detective agency has been paid for the past 3 years.

subsection.text: If the Secretary does not receive the documents required under subsection (a) of this section at least 15 days before the license expiration date, the Secretary shall charge the licensee a late fee of $10 per day until the documents are received.
The Secretary may inspect any of the business records of a licensee that relate to any matter that is subject to certification or documentation under this section.
Each licensee shall maintain an office in the State.
Each licensee shall keep in an office in the State all files or other records that:

paragraph.text: are made in the State; and
relate to an investigation in the State.
Within 5 days after the change, a licensee shall submit to the Secretary written notice of:

subparagraph.text: the addition of a branch office; and
any change in the address of an existing office.

paragraph.text: The licensee shall submit with the notice:

subparagraph.text: the agency license certificate; and
if the proposed change affects an existing branch office, the branch office certificate for that office.

paragraph.text: The Secretary may:

subparagraph.text: endorse the change on the agency license certificate and, if applicable, on the branch office certificate of the affected branch office; or
issue a new agency license certificate and, if applicable, a new branch office certificate, both of which shall set forth the same date as the original agency license certificate.

subsection.text: Within 5 days after the occurrence, a firm shall submit to the Secretary written notice of:

paragraph.text: the withdrawal of any firm member; and
the death of any firm member.

subsection.text: Each licensee shall display at all times:

paragraph.text: the agency license certificate in a conspicuous place in the principal office of the private detective agency; and
each branch office certificate in a conspicuous place in the agency branch office for which the certificate was issued.
If an agency license certificate or branch office certificate is lost or destroyed, the licensee immediately shall notify the Secretary.
On receipt of notice of the loss or destruction of an agency license certificate or branch office certificate, the Secretary may issue a duplicate.

subsection.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 13-315 of this subtitle, the Secretary may deny a license to any applicant, reprimand any licensee, fine any licensee or agency, or suspend or revoke a license if the applicant or licensee:

paragraph.text: fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a license for the applicant or licensee or for another;
fraudulently or deceptively uses a license;
aids an individual to obtain or to attempt to obtain fraudulently or deceptively certification under this title as a private detective;
while not licensed, solicits to engage in or willfully engages in a business providing private detective services in the State;
while not licensed, willfully advertises:

subparagraph.text: as a private detective agency; or
the provision of private detective services;

paragraph.text: willfully makes a false statement or misrepresentation that an individual is or was in the employ of the applicant or licensee;
willfully makes a false statement or misrepresentation in any renewal application, in any annual statement, or in any other report or document that the Secretary requires to be submitted;
fails to notify the Secretary about any change among the firm members or in the address of the principal office or any branch office of a licensee;
fails to maintain the liability insurance required under § 13-604 of this title; or
violates any other provision of this title.

subsection.text: For purposes of this section, an act or omission of any principal, agent, or employee of an applicant or licensee may be construed to be the act or omission of the applicant or licensee, as well as of the principal, agent, or employee.
Subject to this section, the Secretary shall commence proceedings under § 13-313 of this subtitle on the Secretary’s own complaint or on a complaint made to the Secretary by any person.

paragraph.text: A complaint shall:

subparagraph.text: be in writing;
be signed by the complainant; and
state specifically the facts on which the complaint is based.

paragraph.text: If a complaint is made by any person other than the Secretary, the complaint shall be made under oath by the person who submits the complaint.

On receipt of a complaint that alleges facts that are grounds for action under § 13-313 of this subtitle, the Secretary shall appoint an officer of the Department of State Police, with the rank of lieutenant or above, as the investigating officer for the complaint.
The investigating officer may assign responsibility for conducting the investigation to other members of the Department of State Police.

On conclusion of the investigation, the investigating officer shall determine whether there is a reasonable basis to believe that there are grounds for disciplinary action under § 13-313 of this subtitle.
If the investigating officer finds a reasonable basis as provided under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Secretary shall act on the complaint as provided under § 13-315 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 10-226 of the State Government Article, before the Secretary takes any final action under § 13-313 of this subtitle, the Secretary shall give the person against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Secretary.
The Secretary shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Secretary may administer oaths in connection with any proceeding under this section.
The hearing notice to be given to the person shall be written and sent at least 10 days before the hearing.
The person may be represented at the hearing by counsel.
If, after due notice, the person against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, nevertheless the Secretary may hear and determine the matter.

Within 5 days after the Secretary suspends or revokes the license of a person, the person shall surrender to the Secretary the agency license certificate and each branch office certificate of the person.
The Secretary may not refund to a person whose license is suspended or revoked any fee paid under this title.

Except as provided under subsection (b) of this section, an individual shall be certified by the Secretary as a private detective before the individual personally may provide any private detective service in the State.
An individual who is not certified as a private detective may provide private detective services in the State if:

paragraph.text: the individual is employed by or has applied for employment with a licensed private detective agency;

the licensed private detective agency has submitted to the Secretary the application of the individual for certification as a private detective, fingerprint cards, and fees required under § 13-403 of this subtitle;
after a preliminary background investigation, the Secretary determines that the provision of private detective services by the individual would not result in a potential threat to public safety; and
the Secretary has not denied the application.

section.text: An individual qualifies for certification as a private detective if the individual:

paragraph.text: holds a license;
is a firm member of a licensed private detective agency; or

subparagraph.text: is an employee of or an applicant for employment with a licensed private detective agency; and
meets the qualifications set forth under § 13-403 of this subtitle.

section.text: To qualify for certification as a private detective, an employee of or applicant for employment with a licensed private detective agency shall:

paragraph.text: meet the standards set by the Secretary;
submit to the Secretary:

subparagraph.text: a sworn application on the form the Secretary provides; and
the fingerprints required under § 13-304(c)(2)(i) of this title; and

paragraph.text: pay to the Secretary:

subparagraph.text: an application fee of $15; and
the fees required under § 13-304(c)(2) of this title.

section.text: The Secretary shall certify as a private detective each individual who meets the requirements of this subtitle.

subsection.text: By regulation, the Secretary shall stagger the terms of the certifications under this subtitle.
Unless a certification is renewed for a 3-year term as provided in this section, the certification expires on the date the Secretary sets.
At least 90 days before a certification expires, the applicant shall deliver to the Secretary:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form;
the amount of the renewal fee; and
the amount of any late fee, as determined by the Secretary.

subsection.text: An individual periodically may renew the certification for an additional 3-year term, if the individual:

paragraph.text: is otherwise entitled to be certified;
pays to the Secretary:

subparagraph.text: a renewal fee of $10;
the fee authorized under § 10-221(b)(7) of the Criminal Procedure Article for access to Maryland criminal history records;
the mandatory processing fee required by the Federal Bureau of Investigation for a national criminal history records check; and
any late fee required under this subtitle; and

paragraph.text: submits to the Secretary:

subparagraph.text: a renewal application on the form the Secretary provides; and
two complete sets of the applicant’s legible fingerprints taken on forms approved by the Director of the Central Repository and the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

subsection.text: In accordance with §§ 10-201 through 10-234 of the Criminal Procedure Article, the Central Repository shall forward to the applicant and the Department of State Police a printed statement of the applicant’s criminal history records information.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, if a complete application for renewal of certification as required under this subtitle is not received by the Secretary at least 30 calendar days before the certification expires, the Secretary shall assess a late fee of $5 per day until the application is received by the Secretary, unless the applicant did not make timely renewal because of incapacity, hospitalization, being called to active military duty, or other hardship.
The total amount of late fees assessed under this subsection may not exceed $150.
The Secretary may not certify any applicant under this title if the applicant has outstanding late fee obligations.
The Secretary shall renew the certification of each individual who meets the requirements of this section.

Within 5 days after the Secretary refuses to renew the certification of an individual as a private detective, the Secretary shall send written notice of the refusal to the individual who submitted the renewal application.

section.text: While certification of an individual as a private detective is in effect, the certification authorizes the individual to provide private detective services only:

paragraph.text: on behalf of the private detective agency through which the individual obtained the certification; and
while that private detective agency is licensed under this title.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall issue to each individual who is certified as a private detective under this subtitle a certification card that identifies the individual as a certified private detective.

paragraph.text: Subject to this subsection, the Secretary shall determine the form and content of the certification card.
The certification card shall be of a size and made of materials appropriate for its intended use, as provided under § 13-407 of this subtitle.
The certification card shall contain:

subparagraph.text: a statement that in substance specifies that the individual is certified by the Secretary as a private detective;
the name of the licensed private detective agency with or by which the individual is associated or employed; and
any information that the Secretary considers appropriate to:

sub-subparagraph.text: identify the individual; or
specify the authority of the individual.

subsection.text: At any time that a certified private detective provides a private detective service, the private detective shall carry the certification card issued under § 13-406 of this subtitle.
On request of a law enforcement officer, a certified private detective shall show the private detective’s certification card.

section.text: A certified private detective may wear or carry a badge only if:

paragraph.text: the Secretary authorizes the wearing or carrying of the badge;
the design of the badge is approved by the Secretary; and
the badge is issued by the licensed private detective agency through which the private detective is certified.

section.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 13-411 of this subtitle, the Secretary may deny certification as a private detective to any applicant, reprimand or fine any individual certified as a private detective, or suspend or revoke the certification of an individual:

paragraph.text: for any applicable ground under § 13-313 of this title;
if the applicant or individual fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain certification as a private detective for the applicant or individual or for another; or
if the applicant or individual fails to maintain the standards set by the Secretary for certification as a private detective.

subsection.text: Subject to this section, the Secretary shall commence proceedings under § 13-409 of this subtitle on the Secretary’s own complaint or on a complaint made to the Secretary by any person.

paragraph.text: A complaint shall:

subparagraph.text: be in writing;
be signed by the complainant; and
state specifically the facts on which the complaint is based.

paragraph.text: If a complaint is made by any person other than the Secretary, the complaint shall be made under oath by the person who submits the complaint.

On receipt of a complaint that alleges facts that are grounds for action under § 13-409 of this subtitle, the Secretary shall appoint an officer of the Department of State Police, with the rank of lieutenant or above, as the investigating officer for the complaint.
The investigating officer may assign responsibility for conducting the investigation to other members of the Department of State Police.

On conclusion of the investigation, the investigating officer shall determine whether there is a reasonable basis to believe that there are grounds for disciplinary action under § 13-409 of this subtitle.
If the investigating officer finds a reasonable basis as provided under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Secretary shall act on the complaint as provided under § 13-411 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 10-226 of the State Government Article, before the Secretary takes any final action under § 13-409 of this subtitle, the Secretary shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Secretary.
The Secretary shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Secretary may administer oaths in connection with any proceeding under this section.
The hearing notice to be given to the individual shall be written and sent at least 10 days before the hearing.
The individual may be represented at the hearing by counsel.
If, after due notice, the individual against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, nevertheless the Secretary may hear and determine the matter.

section.text: Within 5 days after the Secretary suspends or revokes the certification of an individual as a private detective, the individual shall surrender to the Secretary the certification card and badge, if any, of the individual.
A private detective agency is responsible for the acts of each of its employees while the employee is conducting the business of the agency.

subsection.text: The offices of each private detective agency shall be supervised by an individual who:

paragraph.text: holds, as an individual, the license of the private detective agency; or
is the representative member of the private detective agency appointed under § 13-302(b) of this title.

subsection.text: If a private detective agency is a firm, the agency shall notify the Secretary about:

paragraph.text: the identity of the individual serving as the representative member of the agency; and
each vacancy in that position.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a private detective agency shall appoint a representative member within 90 days after a vacancy occurs in the position.
If the vacancy is caused by the death of or an incapacitating injury to the representative member, the private detective agency shall appoint a replacement within 180 days after the vacancy occurs.

subsection.text: If a licensed private detective agency fails to appoint a representative member as required under subsection (c) of this section, the license of the private detective agency:

paragraph.text: is suspended automatically; and
shall remain suspended until the agency complies with the requirements.

subsection.text: The Secretary may adopt regulations to carry out this section.
A private detective agency that employs 5 or more individuals as private detectives shall:

paragraph.text: maintain commercial general liability insurance, including errors and omissions and completed operations with a $1,000,000 total aggregate; and
submit proof of the required insurance to the Secretary.

If an applicant for a license intends to employ 5 or more individuals as private detectives, the applicant shall submit proof of the liability insurance required under subsection (a) of this section to the Secretary with the license application.
The Secretary may not issue a license to an applicant to whom the insurance requirements of this section would apply unless the applicant submits proof of the insurance.

subsection.text: If the insurance required for a private detective agency under this section is canceled, forfeited, or otherwise terminated, both the private detective agency and the insurer shall notify the Secretary.
If a private detective agency fails to maintain the liability insurance required under this section, the license of the private detective agency:

paragraph.text: is suspended automatically;
shall remain suspended until the agency complies with the requirements under subsection (a) of this section; and
may not be reinstated until the agency submits proof of the required insurance to the Secretary.

subsection.text: A nonresident applicant for a license shall submit to the Secretary of State a consent, as provided under this section.
The consent required under this section shall:

paragraph.text: specify that service of process on the Secretary of State shall bind the applicant in any action, suit, or proceeding brought against the applicant;
specify that an action, suit, or proceeding may be brought against the applicant in any county where:

subparagraph.text: the cause of action arose; or
the plaintiff resides; and

paragraph.text: be signed by the representative member of the applicant.

subsection.text: In addition to submitting a consent, a nonresident applicant shall submit to the Secretary of State a certified copy of a resolution adopted by the firm that confirms that the firm members, board of directors, or other managing board of the firm authorized the representative member to execute and submit the consent on behalf of the firm.
An applicant who is required under this section to submit a consent or a consent and authorization to the Secretary of State shall submit copies of the signed documents to the Secretary.
The Secretary may not issue a license to a nonresident applicant, unless the nonresident applicant complies with the requirements of subsections (a) through (d) of this section.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, service of process on the Secretary of State binds a person who has submitted a consent to the Secretary of State, as required under this section.

If service of process is made on the Secretary of State as authorized under this section, the person initiating the action, suit, or proceeding immediately shall send a copy, by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the principal office in the State of the person against whom the action, suit, or proceeding is directed.
As to any person who submits a consent as required under this section, any action, suit, or proceeding may be brought in any county where:

subparagraph.text: the cause of action arose; or
the plaintiff resides.

subsection.text: A private detective agency may not divulge information obtained while providing services unless:

paragraph.text: directed by the client for whom the services are provided;
authorized by subsection (b) of this section; or
required by law.

subsection.text: If, while providing services, a private detective agency obtains any information about a criminal offense, the private detective agency may divulge the information to:

paragraph.text: a law enforcement officer;
the Attorney General or a representative of the Attorney General; or
a State’s Attorney or a representative of a State’s Attorney.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, an individual who is employed by a private detective agency may not divulge to anyone other than to authorized staff of the agency any information that:

paragraph.text: was acquired by the employee or other agency staff while providing services for the agency; and
relates to the assignment for which services are provided.

subsection.text: An employee of a private detective agency may divulge information that is restricted under subsection (c) of this section:

paragraph.text: as directed by the private detective agency; or
on a request made by the Secretary in the course of an investigation by the Secretary.

subsection.text: In this section, “agency equipment” means a badge, clothing, or other equipment that:

paragraph.text: belongs to a private detective agency; and
bears the name, trade name, or trademark of the private detective agency.

subsection.text: If a private detective agency issues agency equipment for use by an individual who is associated with or employed by the agency, the individual shall return the agency equipment to the agency within 10 days after:

paragraph.text: the termination of the individual’s association or employment with the agency; or
the written request of an authorized representative of the agency.

section.text: If a certified private detective loses a certification card, the private detective immediately shall give the Secretary notice of the loss and the circumstances regarding the loss.

subsection.text: A person may not engage in, attempt to engage in, offer to engage in, or solicit to engage in a business for the purpose of providing private detective services in the State unless licensed as a private detective agency by the Secretary.
An individual may not provide, attempt to provide, offer to provide, or solicit to provide private detective services in the State unless certified as a private detective by the Secretary.

Unless authorized under this title to engage in business for the purpose of providing private detective services, a person may not represent to the public, by use of a title, including “licensed private detective agency”, “private detective agency”, “private detectives”, or “private investigators”, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person is authorized to engage in the business of providing private detective services in the State.

Unless an individual is certified as a private detective under this title, the individual may not represent to the public, by use of a title, including “certified private detective”, “licensed private detective”, “private detective”, or “private investigator”, by use of a badge or identification card, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the individual is authorized to provide private detective services in the State.

Except as authorized under this title, a private detective agency may not provide any person with a badge or a certification card or other document indicating that any individual is a private detective.
A certified private detective may not lend the private detective’s certification card or badge to another person or allow another person to use or display the card or badge.
Regardless of any association that an individual may have with a private detective agency, unless authorized under this title, the individual may not wear or carry a badge that:

paragraph.text: represents that the individual is a private detective; or
otherwise represents that the individual is associated with a private detective agency.
A licensee may not display or allow to be displayed the agency license certificate at any location other than the principal office of the licensee, as specified in the certificate.
A licensee may not display or allow to be displayed a branch office certificate at any location other than the branch office specified in the certificate.

subsection.text: A licensee may not knowingly alter, deface, or destroy or knowingly allow the alteration, defacement, or destruction of an agency license certificate or branch office certificate.

section.text: A person may not willfully make a false statement on any application form, annual statement, or other document submitted to the Secretary under this title.
An individual whom a licensee employs as a private detective may not willfully make a false statement or report to the licensee about any case conducted or services provided by the licensee.

subsection.text: A person who violates any provision of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.

The fines assessed under §§ 13-313 and 13-409 of this title may not exceed $5,000 per violation, or a maximum aggregate of $10,000 for a 2-year license term, and shall be paid to the Secretary within 10 days after final adjudication of any hearing or upon the waiver of any hearing.

Notwithstanding the provisions of §§ 13-313 and 13-409 of this title, the Secretary may fine either the licensed agency or the individual working on behalf of the licensed agency, but not both, for the same violation.

section.text: This title may be cited as the “Maryland Private Detectives Act”.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the State Board for Professional Engineers.
“Design coordination” means the review and coordination of services provided by individuals licensed or certified under Titles 3, 8, 9, 14, and 15 of this article.
“License” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a license issued by the Board to practice engineering.
“License fee” means, as applicable, the fee paid in connection with the issuance and renewal of a license and the issuance of a reciprocal license.

paragraph.text: “Practice engineering” means to provide any service or creative work the performance of which requires education, training, and experience in the application of:

subparagraph.text: special knowledge of the mathematical, physical, and engineering sciences; and
the principles and methods of engineering analysis and design.

paragraph.text: In regard to a building or other structure, machine, equipment, process, works, system, project, or public or private utility, “practice engineering” includes:

subparagraph.text: consultation;
design;
evaluation;
inspection of construction to ensure compliance with specifications and drawings;
investigation;
planning; and
design coordination.

paragraph.text: “Practice engineering” does not include the exclusive and sole performance of nontechnical management activities.

subsection.text: “Professional engineer” means, unless the context requires otherwise, an engineer who is licensed by the Board to practice engineering.

paragraph.text: “Responsible charge” means direct control and personal supervision of engineering that requires initiative, professional skill, and independent judgment.
“Responsible charge” includes responsible engineering teaching.

section.text: The purposes of this title are to safeguard life, health, and property and to promote the public welfare by regulating persons who practice engineering in the State.

subsection.text: All engineering documents prepared in connection with the alteration, construction, design, or repair of a building, structure, building engineering system and its components, machine, equipment, process, works, subsystem, project, public or private utility, or facility in the built or economic environment where the skills of a professional engineer are required, shall be signed, sealed, and dated by the professional engineer who prepared or approved the documents.
A professional engineer may perform design coordination for a project or portion of a project provided that the professional engineer:

paragraph.text: holds a current license issued by the Board; and
has adequate experience in, and understanding of, achieving the purpose of the project or portion of the project being coordinated.

section.text: There is a State Board for Professional Engineers in the Department.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of eight members.
Of the eight members of the Board:

subparagraph.text: six shall be engineers; and
two shall be consumer members.

paragraph.text: Of the six engineer members of the Board:

subparagraph.text: one shall be a chemical engineer;
two shall be civil engineers;
one shall be an electrical engineer;
one shall be a mechanical engineer; and
one shall be a professional engineer appointed without regard to specific professional practice who shall represent other designations of professional engineering.

paragraph.text: The Governor shall appoint the members with the advice of the Secretary and with the advice and consent of the Senate.

subparagraph.text: The Governor shall appoint each of the engineer members from a single list of at least 3 names of engineers submitted by the local chapters of the applicable professional organization, as set forth in this paragraph and any list of qualified individuals that may have been submitted to the Governor by any person who is a resident of the State.
For the chemical engineer member, the list shall be submitted by the American Institute of Chemical Engineers.
For the civil engineer members, the list shall be submitted by the American Society of Civil Engineers.
For the electrical engineer member, the list shall be submitted by the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers.
For the mechanical engineer member, the list shall be submitted by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.
For the one engineer member identified in paragraph (3)(v) of this subsection, the list shall be submitted by the Maryland Society of Professional Engineers.

subsection.text: Each member of the Board shall be:

paragraph.text: a citizen of the United States; and
a resident of the State.
Each engineer member of the Board shall have:

subparagraph.text: practiced engineering for at least 12 years; and
been in responsible charge of important engineering work for at least 5 years.

paragraph.text: Each engineer member of the Board shall be licensed as a professional engineer in this State at all times during the member’s term on the Board.

subsection.text: Each consumer member of the Board:

paragraph.text: shall be a member of the general public;
may not be a licensee or otherwise be subject to regulation by the Board;
may not be required to meet the qualifications for the professional members of the Board; and
may not, within 1 year before appointment, have had a financial interest in or have received compensation from a person regulated by the Board.

subsection.text: While a member of the Board, a consumer member may not:

paragraph.text: have a financial interest in or receive compensation from a person regulated by the Board; or
grade any examination given by or for the Board.

subsection.text: Before taking office, each appointee to the Board shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 5 years and begins on July 1.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on October 1, 2011.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: The Governor may remove a member for incompetence, misconduct, neglect of duties, or other sufficient cause.
From among its members, the Board annually shall elect a chairman, a vice chairman, and a secretary.
The manner of election of officers shall be as the Board determines.
A majority of the authorized membership of the Board is a quorum.

paragraph.text: The Board shall meet at least twice a year, at the times and places that the Board determines.
The Board may hold special meetings as provided in its bylaws.
Notice of meetings of the Board shall be given as required in its bylaws.

subsection.text: A member of the Board:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Board may employ a staff in accordance with the State budget.

section.text: At least annually, the chairman of the Board, the chairman of the State Board of Architects, the chairman of the State Board of Certified Interior Designers, the chairman of the State Board of Examiners of Landscape Architects, and the chairman of the State Board for Professional Land Surveyors shall meet to discuss issues of mutual importance to the design professions.

subsection.text: With the advice of the established engineering societies, the Board shall adopt, by regulation, a code of ethics for practicing engineering.
The Board shall distribute:

paragraph.text: to each applicant for a license, a copy of the Maryland Professional Engineers Act and the Board’s rules and regulations; and

on each renewal of a license, to each licensee, a copy of any amendments to the Maryland Professional Engineers Act and the Board’s rules and regulations that took effect during the 2-year period ending on the date of renewal.

subsection.text: Subject to the State budget, the Board may employ an investigative staff to:

paragraph.text: investigate a complaint; and
perform any other related duty, as assigned by the Board.
The Board may issue a subpoena for the attendance of a witness to testify or the production of evidence in connection with:

subparagraph.text: any disciplinary action under § 14-317 of this title; or
any proceeding brought for an alleged violation of this title.

paragraph.text: A subpoena shall be signed by the chairman of the Board and sealed with the seal of the Board.
If a person fails to comply with a subpoena issued under this subsection, on petition of the Board, a circuit court may compel compliance with the subpoena.
The Board may sue in the name of the State to enforce any provision of this title by injunction.
In seeking an injunction under this subsection, the Board is not required to:

subparagraph.text: post bond; or
allege or prove either that:

sub-subparagraph.text: an adequate remedy at law does not exist; or
substantial or irreparable damage would result from the continued violation of the provision.

paragraph.text: A member of the Board may not be held personally liable for any action taken under this subsection in good faith and with reasonable grounds.

subsection.text: On request of any person and payment of a verification fee set by the Board, the Board shall certify the licensing status and qualifications of any individual who is the subject of the request.
Each certification under this section:

paragraph.text: shall include a statement of the licensing status of the individual who is the subject of the request; and
may include:

subparagraph.text: information about the examination results and other qualifications of that individual;
information about the dates of issuance and renewal of the license of that individual;
information about any disciplinary action taken against that individual; and
if authorized by that individual, information about any complaint against that individual.

paragraph.text: In addition to any powers set forth elsewhere, the Board may adopt:

subparagraph.text: any bylaw for the conduct of the proceedings of the Board; and
any regulation to carry out this title, subject to the limitation under paragraph (2) of this subsection.

paragraph.text: The Board may not adopt any regulation that would restrict or otherwise would affect competitive bidding for engineering services.

subsection.text: In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere, the Board shall:

paragraph.text: administer this title;
adopt a seal;
keep a record of its proceedings; and
keep a file on each applicant for:

subparagraph.text: a license; and
certification under § 14-310 of this title.

subsection.text: In this section, “code official” means a public official responsible for the review of building permit documents or the issuance of building permits.
The Board shall:

paragraph.text: keep a list of the names and mailing addresses of all licensees and certificate holders;
provide each code official with a copy of the list annually; and
provide any other person who makes a request with a copy of the list at a reasonable fee set by the Board.
The Board shall provide all licensees, certificate holders, and code officials with a periodic newsletter not less than semiannually on the activities of the Board.

The Board shall publish, on the Department website, the newsletter jointly with the State Board of Architects, the State Board of Examiners of Landscape Architects, the State Board of Certified Interior Designers, and the State Board for Professional Land Surveyors.

subsection.text: The Board shall distribute:

paragraph.text: to each applicant for a license or a certificate and each code official, a copy of the Maryland Professional Engineers Act and the Board’s rules and regulations;

on each renewal of a license or certificate, to each licensee or certificate holder, a copy of any amendments to the Maryland Professional Engineers Act and the Board’s rules and regulations that took effect during the 2-year period ending on the date of renewal; and
to each code official, a copy of any amendments to the Maryland Professional Engineers Act and the Board’s rules and regulations.

subsection.text: A licensee or certificate holder shall designate the licensee’s or certificate holder’s mailing address at the time of issuance of the license or certificate and on each renewal of the license or certificate.

paragraph.text: The Board may set reasonable fees for its services.

The fees charged shall be set so as to produce funds to approximate the cost of maintaining the Board and shall be based on the calculations performed by the Secretary under § 2–106.2 of the Business Regulation Article.

subsection.text: The Board shall publish the fee schedule set by the Board by regulation.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay all fees collected under this title to the Comptroller of the State.
The Comptroller shall distribute the fees to the State Occupational and Professional Licensing Design Boards’ Fund established in § 2–106.1 of the Business Regulation Article.

section.text: Any person aggrieved by any final action of the Board may take an appeal as allowed in §§ 10-222 and 10-223 of the State Government Article.
The Board exercises its powers, duties, and functions subject to the authority of the Secretary.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, an individual shall be licensed by the Board before the individual may practice engineering in the State.
This section does not apply to:

paragraph.text: an individual who practices engineering while performing official duties as an officer or employee of the federal government;

a regular employee of a public utility company while providing engineering services to any facility of the company that the State or federal government regulates to safeguard life, health, and property;
an officer or employee of a corporation, while the officer or employee practices engineering under the conditions authorized under § 14-302 of this subtitle;
an employee or other subordinate of a professional engineer, while the subordinate practices engineering under the conditions authorized under § 14-303(a)(1) of this subtitle; or

an employee of an individual who is not a professional engineer but who, nevertheless, is authorized to practice engineering, while the employee practices engineering under the conditions authorized under § 14-303(a)(2) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: An officer or employee of a corporation may practice engineering without a license if:

paragraph.text: the corporation is engaged in research and development engineering for the federal government; and
the work of the officer or employee relates to that research and development engineering.

subsection.text: An officer or employee of a corporation may practice engineering without a license if:

paragraph.text: the corporation is engaged in:

subparagraph.text: manufacturing;
industrial processes;
industrial engineering; or
maintenance and repair of structures or equipment used in industrial processes or manufacturing; and

paragraph.text: the work of the officer or employee relates to the products or systems of the corporation or its subsidiaries or affiliates.

subsection.text: An officer or employee of a corporation may practice engineering under this section only as the practice relates to the officer’s or employee’s work for the corporation.
Subject to this section, the following individuals may practice engineering without a license:

paragraph.text: an employee or other subordinate of a professional engineer; and
an employee of an individual who is not licensed but is otherwise authorized under this title to practice engineering without supervision.

subsection.text: The authority to practice engineering under this section applies only while the employee or other subordinate works under the responsible charge of the licensee or other authorized individual.
To qualify for a license, an applicant shall be an individual who meets the requirements of this section.
The applicant shall be of good character and reputation.
The applicant shall meet the educational and experience requirements under and, except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, shall pass each examination required under § 14-305 of this subtitle.

In addition to the other qualifications for a license set forth in this subtitle, an applicant shall qualify under this section by meeting the educational and experience requirements set forth in subsection (b), (c), or (d) of this section.

paragraph.text: An applicant qualifies under this section if the applicant:

subparagraph.text: has been graduated from a college or university on completion of at least a 4–year curriculum in engineering, or its equivalent, that the Board approves;

subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, has at least 4 years of work experience in engineering that is satisfactory to the Board and that indicates to the Board that the applicant may be competent to practice engineering;
has passed the examination in the fundamentals of engineering given by the Board under this subtitle; and
after passing the examination in fundamentals, has passed the examination in the principles and practice of engineering given by the Board under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: If an applicant has completed graduate study in engineering that is satisfactory to the Board, it may allow the applicant up to a 1–year credit toward the experience requirement of paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection.

subsection.text: An applicant qualifies under this section if the applicant:

paragraph.text: has been graduated from a college or university on completion of at least a 4–year curriculum in engineering, or its equivalent, that the Board has not approved;
has at least 8 years of work experience in engineering that is satisfactory to the Board and that indicates to the Board that the applicant may be competent to practice engineering;
has passed the examination in the fundamentals of engineering given by the Board under this subtitle; and
after passing the examination in fundamentals, has passed the examination in the principles and practice of engineering given by the Board under this subtitle.
An applicant qualifies under this section if the applicant:

subparagraph.text: subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, has at least 12 years of work experience in engineering that is satisfactory to the Board, in at least 5 years of which the applicant has been in responsible charge, if the collective experience indicates to the Board that the applicant may be competent to practice engineering; and
has passed the examination in the principles and practice of engineering given by the Board under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: If an applicant has completed 1 or more years of a college or university curriculum in engineering that the Board approves, it may allow, for each of those years, a 1–year credit towards the experience requirement of paragraph (1)(i) of this subsection.

If an applicant has completed 1 or more years of a college or university curriculum in engineering that has not been approved by the Board, the Board may allow, for each of those years, a credit of up to 6 months towards the experience requirement under paragraph (1)(i) of this subsection.

subsection.text: If an applicant has taught undergraduate or graduate courses in the practice of engineering or has directed engineering research and projects in the applicant’s field in a college or university offering an engineering curriculum that is approved by the Board, the Board may count the teaching experience as work experience for purposes of the experience requirements under any subsection of this section.
An applicant for a license shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the Board:

subparagraph.text: an application on the form that the Board provides; and
any relevant document that the Board requires; and

paragraph.text: pay to the Board or the Board’s designee:

subparagraph.text: a nonrefundable application fee set by the Board; and
an examination fee set by the Board in an amount not to exceed the cost of the required examinations.

paragraph.text: The application form shall require:

subparagraph.text: a statement about the education of the applicant;
a statement about the engineering experience of the applicant;
a list of at least 5 references, which, unless excused by the Board, shall include at least 3 professional engineers who have personal knowledge of the applicant’s engineering experience; and
any other relevant information that the Board requires.

paragraph.text: An application shall be made under oath.

subsection.text: If the Board finds that an application form and the accompanying documentation do not demonstrate that the applicant meets the requirements for a license under this subtitle, the Board may require the applicant to submit additional information or documentation.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 14-307.1 of this subtitle, an applicant who otherwise qualifies for a license is entitled to be examined as provided in this section.
Subject to § 14-310 of this subtitle, an individual may take the examination in the fundamentals of engineering before meeting other qualifications for a license.

subsection.text: The Board periodically shall give the examinations required under this subtitle to qualified applicants at the times and places that the Board determines.
The Board shall give each qualified applicant notice of the time and place of examination.

paragraph.text: As provided under § 14–305 of this subtitle, the Board shall give the following 2 separate examinations:

subparagraph.text: the examination in the fundamentals of engineering; and
the examination in the principles and practice of engineering.

paragraph.text: The Board shall determine the subjects, scope, and form of and method of grading and passing scores for examinations given under this subtitle.
The Board shall structure the examinations to test the ability of an applicant to design, plan, and direct engineering works in order to ensure the safety of life, health, and property.

subsection.text: The Board may use a testing service to administer the examinations required under this subtitle.
If the Board uses a testing service, the testing service, subject to the requirements set by the Board, may:

paragraph.text: set the time and place of examinations;
give qualified applicants notice of the time and place of examinations; and
furnish any other information that the Board may require the testing service to provide.
If an applicant fails an examination given under this subtitle, the Board shall mail notice of the failure to the applicant.
The notice required under this subsection shall be mailed to the address that the applicant last gave to the Board.
Subject to the provisions of this subsection, an applicant who fails an examination may review the applicant’s answers and model answers to the examination.
To conduct a review under this subsection, an applicant shall submit a written request to the Board within 60 days after the date on which the Board mails notice of the applicant’s failure.
An applicant who does not request review in accordance with paragraph (2) of this subsection waives the right to review under this subsection.
The Board shall confirm the test score of any applicant who fails an examination given under this subtitle if the applicant:

subparagraph.text: submits a written request to the Board in accordance with its regulations; and
pays to the Board the fee set by the Board.

paragraph.text: The Board shall adopt regulations that set procedures for confirmation of test scores under this subsection.
Subject to this subsection, an applicant who fails an examination 3 times may have a conference with a member of the Board.
To have a conference under this subsection, an applicant shall submit a written request to the Board within 45 days after the date on which the Board mails notice of the applicant’s 3rd failure.
An applicant who does not request a conference in accordance with paragraph (2) of this subsection waives the right to have a conference under this subsection.

subsection.text: Subject to this section, if an applicant fails an examination given under this subtitle, the applicant may retake the examination.
Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, an applicant for reexamination shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the Board a request for reexamination on the form that the Board provides; and
pay to the Board or the Board’s designee the reexamination fee set by the Board in an amount not to exceed the cost of the examination.

subsection.text: An applicant who fails 2 reexaminations given under this section may take the examination again only on a new application for a license that is submitted to the Board at least 2 years after the applicant last failed a reexamination.
A reexamination fee paid under subsection (b)(2) of this section is not refundable.

Subject to this section, an individual may apply to the Board to take the examination in the fundamentals of engineering given by the Board under this subtitle, before the individual completes the requirements set forth in § 14–305(b) and (c) of this subtitle.
To take the fundamentals of engineering examination early:

paragraph.text: the applicant shall be in the process of completing a curriculum at a college or university, as required under § 14–305(b) or (c) of this subtitle, and the college or university shall provide to the Board evidence that the college or university expects the applicant to complete the curriculum within 6 months after the next scheduled administration of the fundamentals of engineering examination; or
the applicant shall have been graduated from a college or university on completion of a curriculum, as required under § 14–305(b) or (c) of this subtitle.
An applicant for early examination shall:

subparagraph.text: submit to the Board an application on the form that the Board provides; and
pay to the Board or the Board’s designee:

sub-subparagraph.text: a nonrefundable application fee set by the Board; and
an examination fee set by the Board in an amount not to exceed the cost of the examination.

paragraph.text: The procedures and requirements for the application shall be the same as provided under § 14–306 of this subtitle for applications for licenses.

subsection.text: An applicant who meets the requirements of this section is entitled to take the fundamentals of engineering examination.
If an individual passes a fundamentals of engineering examination under this section and pays the Board a certification fee set by the Board, the Board shall:

paragraph.text: keep a record that the individual passed the examination; and
issue to the individual a certificate that states that the individual is an engineer–in–training because the individual has passed the examination and that sets forth:

subparagraph.text: the full name of the individual;
a certificate number assigned by the Board to the individual; and
the signatures of the chairman and secretary of the Board, under seal of the Board.

subsection.text: If an individual takes and fails a fundamentals of engineering examination under this section, the individual shall have the same rights regarding notice, review procedures, and reexamination provided to an applicant under §§ 14–308 and 14–309 of this subtitle.

Subject to the provisions of this section, the Board may issue a license by reciprocity to practice engineering in this State to an individual who is currently licensed to practice engineering in another state or territory of the United States or in a foreign country.
The Board may issue a license under this section only if the applicant:

paragraph.text: is of good character and reputation;
pays to the Board:

subparagraph.text: a nonrefundable application fee set by the Board; and
a license fee set by the Board; and

paragraph.text: provides adequate evidence that:

subparagraph.text: at the time the applicant was licensed by the other state, territory, or foreign country, the applicant met requirements that were equivalent to those then required by the laws of this State; or
at the time of application for licensure by reciprocity under this section, the applicant meets the requirements currently required by the laws of this State.

subsection.text: An engineer who is licensed by the Board by reciprocity may not be required to maintain licensure in any other state, territory, or foreign country as a condition of maintaining the license granted by the Board.
If an applicant qualifies for a license under this subtitle, the Board shall send the applicant a notice that states that:

paragraph.text: the applicant has qualified for a license; and
on receipt of a license fee set by the Board, the Board will issue a license to the applicant.

subsection.text: On payment of the license fee, the Board shall issue a license to each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle.
The Board shall include on each license that the Board issues:

paragraph.text: the full name of the licensee; and
the registration number assigned by the Board to the licensee.

subsection.text: Subject to any regulation that the Board adopts, it shall replace any lost, mutilated, or destroyed license certificate on:

paragraph.text: request of the licensee; and
payment of the replacement fee set by the Board.

section.text: While a license is in effect, it authorizes the licensee to practice engineering.

subsection.text: Unless a license is renewed for a 2–year term as provided in this section, the license expires on the first June 30 that comes:

paragraph.text: after the effective date of the license; and
in an even–numbered year.
At least 1 month before a license expires, the Board shall mail to the licensee, at the last known address of the licensee:

subparagraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

sub-subparagraph.text: the date on which the current license expires;
the date by which the Board must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the license expires; and
the amount of the license fee.

paragraph.text: The failure of a licensee to receive the notice for which this subsection provides does not prevent the license from expiring as specified under subsection (a) of this section.

subsection.text: Before a license expires, the licensee periodically may renew it for an additional 2–year term, if the licensee:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be licensed;
pays to the Board a license fee set by the Board; and
submits to the Board a renewal application on the form that the Board provides.
The Board shall renew the license of and issue a renewal certificate to each licensee who meets the requirements of this section.
The Board shall include on each renewal certificate that the Board issues:

subparagraph.text: the date on which the current license expires; and
the signatures of the chairman and secretary of the Board, under seal of the Board.

subsection.text: The Secretary may determine that licenses issued under this subtitle shall expire on a staggered basis.

The Board shall adopt regulations to require a demonstration of continuing professional competency for a licensee as a condition of renewal of a license under this section in accordance with the following:

paragraph.text: continuing professional competency requirements do not apply to the first renewal of a license;
if a license expires on or before September 30, 2012, a licensee is not required to fulfill the continuing professional competency requirements;

if a license expires between October 1, 2012, and September 30, 2013, a licensee is required to fulfill 50% of the continuing professional competency requirements as provided in the regulations adopted by the Board under this subsection; and

if a license expires on or after October 1, 2013, a licensee is required to fulfill the full continuing professional competency requirements as provided in the regulations adopted by the Board under this subsection.

subsection.text: The Board shall reinstate the license of an individual who, for any reason, has failed to renew the license if the individual:

paragraph.text: applies to the Board for reinstatement within 2 years after the license expires;
meets the renewal requirements of § 14–314 of this subtitle; and
except as otherwise provided in subsection (c) of this section, pays to the Board a reinstatement fee set by the Board.
If an individual has failed to renew a license for any reason and then applies to the Board for reinstatement more than 2 years after the license has expired, the Board may:

subparagraph.text: require the individual to reapply for a license in the same manner as an applicant applies for an original license under this subtitle; or
subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, reinstate the license.

paragraph.text: The Board may reinstate a license under paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection only if the individual:

subparagraph.text: meets the renewal requirements of § 14–314 of this subtitle;
if required by the Board, states reasons why reinstatement should be granted; and
except as otherwise provided in subsection (c) of this section, pays to the Board a reinstatement fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: The Board may waive a reinstatement fee for a licensee who provides evidence satisfactory to the Board that the licensee did not practice engineering during the time the license lapsed.
The Board may issue a retired status license to an individual who:

paragraph.text: is currently licensed in Maryland as a professional engineer;
has been licensed as a professional engineer for at least 25 years, of which at least 5 years were in Maryland;
is not the subject of a pending disciplinary action related to the practice of engineering in this or any other state;
submits to the Board an application on the form approved by the Board; and
pays to the Board a fee as set by the Board.
The holder of a retired status license issued under this section may not engage in the practice of professional engineering.
The holder of a retired status license shall be permitted to use the designation of “Professional Engineer, Retired”.

subsection.text: The Board may reactivate the license of the holder of a retired status license if that individual:

paragraph.text: submits to the Board an application for reactivation on the form approved by the Board;
meets all applicable continuing competency requirements determined by the Board;
is not the subject of a pending disciplinary action related to the practice of engineering in this or any other state; and
pays to the Board a reactivation fee as set by the Board.

Subject to the hearing provisions of § 14–319 of this subtitle, the Board, on the affirmative vote of a majority of its members then serving, may deny a license to any applicant, reprimand any licensee, or suspend or revoke a license if:

subparagraph.text: the applicant or licensee fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a license for the applicant or licensee or for another;
the applicant or licensee fraudulently or deceptively uses a license;
under the laws of the United States or of any state, the applicant or licensee is convicted of:

sub-subparagraph.text: a felony; or
a misdemeanor that is directly related to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to practice engineering;

subparagraph.text: the applicant or licensee is guilty of gross negligence, incompetence, or misconduct while practicing engineering;

the applicant or licensee has had a license to practice engineering in another state revoked or suspended by the other state for a cause that would justify revocation or suspension under this title, except for the failure to pay a license fee;
the applicant or licensee violates any regulation adopted by the Board; or
the applicant or licensee violates any provision of this title.
Instead of or in addition to reprimanding a licensee or suspending or revoking a license under this subsection, the Board may impose a penalty not exceeding $5,000 for each violation.
To determine the amount of the penalty imposed under this subsection, the Board shall consider:

sub-subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the harm caused by the violation;
the good faith of the licensee; and
any history of previous violations by the licensee.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: The Board shall consider the following facts in the granting, denial, renewal, suspension, or revocation of a license or the reprimand of a licensee when an applicant or licensee is convicted of a felony or misdemeanor described in subsection (a)(1)(iii) of this section:

paragraph.text: the nature of the crime;
the relationship of the crime to the activities authorized by the license;
with respect to a felony, the relevance of the conviction to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to practice engineering;
the length of time since the conviction; and
the behavior and activities of the applicant or licensee before and after the conviction.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of this section, the Board shall commence proceedings under § 14-317 of this subtitle on a complaint made to the Board by a member or any other person.

paragraph.text: A complaint shall:

subparagraph.text: be in writing;
state specifically the facts on which the complaint is based; and
be submitted to the secretary of the Board.

paragraph.text: If the complaint is made by any person other than a member of the Board, the complaint shall be made under oath by the person who submits the complaint.

subsection.text: If the Board finds that a complaint alleges facts that are adequate grounds for action under § 14-317 of this subtitle, the Board shall act on the complaint as provided under § 14-319 of this subtitle. If the Board does not make that finding, it shall dismiss the complaint.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 10-226 of the State Government Article, before the Board takes any final action under § 14-317 of this subtitle, it shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Board.
A hearing shall be set down within a reasonable time, not exceeding 6 months, after the Board brings charges against a licensee.

subsection.text: The Board shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Board may administer oaths in connection with any proceeding under this section.
At least 30 days before the hearing, the hearing notice and a copy of the complaint shall be:

paragraph.text: served personally on the individual; or
mailed to the last known address of the individual.

subsection.text: The individual may be represented at the hearing by counsel.
If, after due notice, the individual against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, nevertheless the Board may hear and determine the matter.
Subject to any regulation that the Board adopts, it may reinstate a license that has been revoked.
A license may be reinstated under this section only on:

paragraph.text: the affirmative vote of a majority of the members of the Board then serving; and
payment to the Board of a reinstatement fee set by the Board.
Subject to the provisions of this section, a professional engineer may practice engineering for others through:

subparagraph.text: a corporation as an officer, employee, or agent of the corporation;
a limited liability company as a member, employee, or agent of the limited liability company; or
a partnership as a partner, employee, or agent of the partnership.

paragraph.text: Subject to the provisions of this section, a corporation, limited liability company, or partnership may provide engineering services through a professional engineer.

subsection.text: A professional engineer who practices engineering through a corporation, limited liability company, or partnership under this section shall be subject to all of the provisions of this title that relate to practicing engineering.

paragraph.text: A corporation, limited liability company, or partnership that provides engineering services under this section is not, by its compliance with this section, relieved of any responsibility that the corporation, limited liability company, or partnership may have for an act or omission of its officer, member, partner, employee, or agent.

An individual who practices engineering through a corporation, limited liability company, or partnership is not, by reason of the individual’s employment or other relationship with the corporation, limited liability company, or partnership, relieved of any individual responsibility that the individual may have regarding that practice.

subsection.text: Each professional engineer may obtain a seal for use as required under § 14-403 of this subtitle.
The seal shall:

paragraph.text: be of a design determined by the Board; and
include:

subparagraph.text: the legend “professional engineer”; and
the name and license number of the professional engineer who holds the seal.

subsection.text: Before a professional engineer issues to a client or submits to a public authority any plan, specification, or report, the professional engineer who prepared or approved the document shall endorse on the document the professional engineer’s:

paragraph.text: original signature and date of signature; and
seal or a facsimile of the seal.

subsection.text: A public authority may not accept any engineering plan, specification, or report unless the document is endorsed as required under subsection (a) of this section.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, a person may not practice, attempt to practice, or offer to practice engineering in the State unless licensed by the Board.

Unless authorized under this title to practice engineering without the supervision required under § 14-303 of this title, a person may not represent to the public, by use of a title, including “engineer”, “professional engineer”, “licensed engineer”, or “registered engineer”, by use of the term “engineering” in the name of the person’s business activity, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person is authorized to practice engineering in this State.
A person may not:

paragraph.text: use or attempt to use the license of another individual; or
impersonate another individual who holds a license.

subsection.text: Other than a professional engineer who obtains a seal as authorized under this title, a person may not use or attempt to use a seal.
While the license of an individual is suspended, revoked, or expired, a person may not endorse a document, as provided under § 14-402 of this title, with the name or seal of the individual.

section.text: A person may not give false information to the Board in an attempt to obtain a license.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided under this section, an individual whose license has been suspended or revoked under § 14-317 of this title may not practice engineering in any manner as:

paragraph.text: an associate, agent, employee, or other subordinate of a professional engineer; or
a principal, associate, agent, employee, or other subordinate of a corporation or partnership that provides engineering services.

subsection.text: The prohibition set forth under subsection (a) of this section does not apply to an individual while practicing engineering:

paragraph.text: as an officer or employee of the federal government, as provided under § 14-301(b)(1) of this title;
as an employee of a regulated utility company, as provided under § 14-301(b)(2) of this title; or
as an officer or employee of a corporation, subject to the conditions provided under § 14-302 of this title.

section.text: An individual who is authorized to practice engineering may not practice or offer to practice engineering in those areas of engineering in which the individual is not competent to practice.

subsection.text: A person who violates any provision of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $500 or imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or both.

paragraph.text: The Board may impose on a person who violates any provision of this title a penalty not exceeding $5,000 for each violation.
In setting the amount of the penalty, the Board shall consider:

subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the harm caused by the violation;
the good faith of the violator;
any history of previous violations by the violator; and
any other relevant factors.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

section.text: This title may be cited as the “Maryland Professional Engineers Act”.

Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, this title and all regulations adopted under this title shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2023.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the State Board for Professional Land Surveyors.
“Design coordination” means the review and coordination of services provided by individuals licensed or certified under Titles 3, 8, 9, 14, and 15 of this article.
“Land surveyor” means an individual who practices land surveying.

paragraph.text: “License” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a license issued by the Board to practice:

subparagraph.text: land surveying; or
property line surveying.

paragraph.text: “License” includes, unless the context requires otherwise:

subparagraph.text: a license to practice land surveying; and
a license to practice property line surveying.

subsection.text: “License fee” means, as applicable, the fee paid in connection with the issuance and renewal of a license and the issuance of a limited license, temporary license, and reciprocal license.
“Licensed property line surveyor” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a property line surveyor who is licensed by the Board to practice property line surveying.
