“Permit” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a permit issued by the Board to allow a corporation or partnership to operate a business through which an individual may practice land surveying or property line surveying.
“Permit fee” means, as applicable, the fee paid in connection with the issuance and renewal of a permit.

paragraph.text: “Practice land surveying” means any service, work, documentation, or practice, the performance or preparation of which requires the application of special knowledge of the principles of mathematics, the related physical and applied sciences, and the requirements of the relevant law, as applied to:

subparagraph.text: measuring, platting, and locating lines, angles, elevations, natural or artificial features in the air, on the surface of the earth, in underground work, and on the beds of bodies of water for the purpose of determining and reporting positions, topography, areas, and volumes;
the platting or replatting, establishing or reestablishing, locating or relocating, or setting or resetting the monumentation for boundaries of real property, easements, or rights–of–way;
platting, layout, and preparation of surveys, plats, plans, and drawings, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: site plans;
subdivision plans;
subdivision plats;
condominium plats;
right–of–way and easement plats; and
other recordable plats;

subparagraph.text: conducting horizontal and vertical control surveys, layout or stake–out of proposed construction, and the preparation and platting of as–constructed surveys;

utilizing measurement devices or systems, such as aerial photogrammetry, global positioning systems, land information systems, geographic information systems, or similar technology for evaluation or location of boundaries of real property, easements, or rights–of–way; and

in conjunction with the site development or subdivision of land, the preparation and design of plans for the following projects, provided that such preparation and design are in accordance with design manuals, details, and standards accepted by the State or local authority:

sub-subparagraph.text: road and street grades;
sediment and erosion control measures;
nonpressurized closed storm drainage and stormwater management systems; and
open conduit storm drainage and stormwater management systems.

paragraph.text: “Practice land surveying” does not include the design, preparation, or specifications for:

subparagraph.text: community water or wastewater treatment collection or distribution systems;
community pumping or lift stations; or
geotechnical or structural design components of sediment control or stormwater management ponds or basins.

paragraph.text: “Practice property line surveying” means to practice land surveying, except for the services excluded under paragraph (2) of this subsection.
“Practice property line surveying” does not include the performance of the services described in subsection (j)(1)(vi) of this section.

subsection.text: “Professional land surveyor” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a land surveyor who is licensed by the Board to practice land surveying.
“Property line surveyor” means an individual who practices property line surveying.

“Responsible charge” means direct control and personal direction of the investigation, design, construction, or operation of land surveying work that requires initiative, professional skill, and independent judgment.
A professional land surveyor may render or offer to render land surveying services described in § 15–101(j) of this subtitle.
A licensed property line surveyor may render or offer to render property line surveying services described in § 15–101(k) of this subtitle.

A professional land surveyor or a property line surveyor, as applicable, may perform design coordination for a project or portion of a project provided that the professional land surveyor or the property line surveyor:

paragraph.text: holds a current license issued by the Board; and
has adequate experience in, and understanding of, achieving the purpose of the project or portion of the project being coordinated.

section.text: There is a State Board for Professional Land Surveyors in the Department.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of 6 members.
Of the 6 members of the Board:

subparagraph.text: 3 shall be professional land surveyors;
1 shall be a licensed property line surveyor; and
2 shall be consumer members.

paragraph.text: The Governor shall appoint the members with the advice of the Secretary and with the advice and consent of the Senate.
The Governor may appoint each of the professional members from a list of at least 3 names submitted to the Secretary by the Maryland Society of Surveyors.

subsection.text: Each consumer member of the Board:

paragraph.text: shall be a member of the general public;
may not be a licensee or otherwise be subject to regulation by the Board;
may not be required to meet the qualifications for the professional members of the Board; and
may not, within 1 year before appointment, have had a financial interest in or have received compensation from a person regulated by the Board.

subsection.text: While a member of the Board, a consumer member may not:

paragraph.text: have a financial interest in or receive compensation from a person regulated by the Board; or
grade any examination given by or for the Board.

subsection.text: Before taking office, each appointee to the Board shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 5 years and begins on July 1.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on October 1, 1989.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: The Governor may remove a member for incompetence, misconduct, neglect of duties, or other good cause.
From among the members of the Board, the Governor shall appoint a chairman.
From among its members, the Board annually shall elect a vice chairman and a secretary.
The manner of election of officers shall be as the Board determines.
A majority of the authorized membership of the Board is a quorum.
The Board shall determine the times and places of its meetings.
A member of the Board:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Board may employ a staff in accordance with the State budget.

section.text: At least annually, the chairman of the Board, the chairman of the State Board of Architects, the chairman of the State Board of Certified Interior Designers, the chairman of the State Board of Examiners of Landscape Architects, and the chairman of the State Board for Professional Engineers shall meet to discuss issues of mutual importance to the design professions.

subsection.text: The Board shall adopt a code of ethics for practicing land surveying.
The Board shall distribute:

paragraph.text: a copy of the code of ethics to each applicant for a license; and
as the Board considers necessary, a copy of any amendment to the code of ethics to each licensee.

subsection.text: The Board shall administer and enforce this title.
The Board may issue a subpoena for the attendance of a witness to testify or the production of evidence in connection with:

paragraph.text: any disciplinary action under § 15-317 of this title; or
any proceeding brought for an alleged violation of this title.
The Board may sue to enforce any provision of this title by injunction.
In seeking an injunction under this subsection, the Board is not required to:

subparagraph.text: post bond; or
allege or prove either that:

sub-subparagraph.text: an adequate remedy at law does not exist; or
substantial or irreparable damage would result from the continued violation of the provision.

paragraph.text: A member of the Board may not be held personally liable for any action taken under this subsection in good faith and with reasonable grounds.

subsection.text: On request of any person and payment of a verification fee set by the Board, the Board shall certify the licensing or permit status and qualifications of any person who is the subject of the request.
Each certification under this section:

paragraph.text: shall include a statement of the licensing or permit status of the person who is the subject of the request; and
may include:

subparagraph.text: information about the examination results and other qualifications of that person;
information about the dates of issuance and renewal of the license or permit of that person;
information about any disciplinary action taken against that person; and
if authorized by that person, information about any complaint against that person.

subsection.text: In addition to any powers set forth elsewhere, the Board may adopt:

paragraph.text: any bylaw for the conduct of the proceedings of the Board; and
any regulation to carry out this title.

subsection.text: In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere, the Board shall:

paragraph.text: adopt a seal;
determine a type of marker, monument, stake, or other landmark that a licensee shall use in practicing land surveying and practicing property line surveying;
keep a record of its proceedings; and
by regulation, formalize minimum standards of practice for licensees.
The Board shall maintain a listing of the names and mailing addresses of all licensees and permit holders.
The Board may release this list to the public.

subsection.text: The licensee or permit holder shall designate the address at the time of issuance of the original license or permit and on the renewal of the license or permit.

paragraph.text: The Board shall provide all licensees, certificate holders, and code officials with a periodic newsletter not less than semiannually on the activities of the Board.

The Board shall publish, on the Department website, the newsletter jointly with the State Board for Professional Engineers, the State Board of Architects, the State Board of Certified Interior Designers, and the State Board of Examiners of Landscape Architects.
The Board may set reasonable fees for its services.

The fees charged shall be set so as to produce funds to approximate the cost of maintaining the Board and shall be based on the calculations performed by the Secretary under § 2–106.2 of the Business Regulation Article.

subsection.text: The Board shall publish the fee schedule set by the Board by regulation.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay all fees collected under this title to the Comptroller of the State.
The Comptroller shall distribute the fees to the State Occupational and Professional Licensing Design Boards’ Fund established in § 2–106.1 of the Business Regulation Article.

section.text: Any person aggrieved by any final action of the Board may take an appeal as allowed in §§ 10-222 and 10-223 of the State Government Article.
The Board exercises its powers, duties, and functions subject to the authority of the Secretary.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, an individual shall be licensed by the Board to practice land surveying before the individual may practice land surveying in the State.
Except as otherwise provided in this title, an individual shall be licensed by the Board to practice property line surveying before the individual may practice property line surveying in the State.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to:

paragraph.text: an individual who practices land surveying while performing official duties as an officer or employee of the federal government;

an employee or other subordinate of a licensee, while the subordinate practices land surveying or practices property line surveying under the conditions authorized under § 15-303(a)(1)(i) or (2)(i) of this subtitle; or

an employee of an individual who is not licensed but who, nevertheless, is authorized to practice land surveying or to practice property line surveying, while the employee practices land surveying or practices property line surveying under the conditions authorized under § 15-303(a)(1)(ii) or (2)(ii) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: On and after July 1, 1990, the Board may not issue a license to practice property line surveying.

Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, an individual who is licensed as a property line surveyor as of June 30, 1990, may continue to renew the license as provided under § 15-314 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Subject to this section, the following individuals may practice land surveying without a license:

subparagraph.text: an employee or other subordinate of a professional land surveyor; and
an employee of an individual who is not licensed but is otherwise authorized under this title to practice land surveying without supervision.

paragraph.text: Subject to this section, the following individuals may practice property line surveying without a license:

subparagraph.text: an employee or other subordinate of a licensed property line surveyor; and
an employee of an individual who is not licensed but is otherwise authorized under this title to practice property line surveying without supervision.

subsection.text: The authority to practice land surveying or property line surveying under this section applies only if the licensee or other authorized individual has, with respect to the investigation, design, construction, and operation of the surveying work of the employee or other subordinate, direct control and personal direction that requires initiative, professional skill, and independent judgment.
To qualify for a license, an applicant shall be an individual who meets the requirements of this section.
The applicant shall be of good character and reputation.
An applicant for a license to practice land surveying shall meet the educational and experience requirements under § 15-305 of this subtitle.
Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, an applicant shall pass each examination required under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: In addition to the other qualifications for a license to practice land surveying, an applicant shall qualify under this section by meeting the educational, experience, and examination requirements set forth in subsection (b), (c), (d), or (e) of this section.
An applicant shall complete the requirements of subsection (b), (c), (d), or (e) of this section in the order the requirements are listed.

subsection.text: An applicant qualifies under this section if the applicant:

paragraph.text: has been graduated from a college or university on completion of at least a 4-year curriculum in land surveying that the Board approves;
has passed a written examination in the fundamentals of land surveying;
has at least 2 years of experience in land surveying that is satisfactory to the Board and that indicates to the Board that the applicant may be competent to practice land surveying; and
has passed a written examination in the principles and practice of land surveying.

subsection.text: An applicant qualifies under this section if the applicant:

paragraph.text: has been graduated upon completion of at least a 4-year curriculum from a college or university that is accredited by, or is a constituent unit of an institution accredited by, the Middle States Association of Colleges and Schools or the equivalent regional accrediting association of other regional areas;
has passed a written examination in the fundamentals of land surveying;
has at least 4 years of experience in land surveying that is satisfactory to the Board and that indicates to the Board that the applicant may be competent to practice land surveying; and
has passed a written examination in the principles and practice of land surveying.
An applicant qualifies under this section if the applicant:

subparagraph.text: is a high school graduate or the equivalent;

subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, has at least 12 years of experience in land surveying that is satisfactory to the Board and that indicates to the Board that the applicant may be competent to practice land surveying; and
has passed a written examination in the principles and practices of land surveying.

paragraph.text: For each 30 semester hours or its equivalent that an applicant completes in land surveying courses that the Board approves, the Board may allow a 1-year credit towards the experience requirements of paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection for a maximum of 3 years.
An applicant qualifies under this section if the applicant:

subparagraph.text: is a high school graduate or the equivalent;

subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, has at least 4 years of experience in land surveying that is satisfactory to the Board and that indicates to the Board that the applicant may be competent to practice land surveying;
has passed a written examination in the fundamentals of land surveying;
has completed at least 4 years of experience in land surveying that is satisfactory to the Board and that indicates to the Board that the applicant may be competent to practice land surveying; and
has passed a written examination in the principles and practice of land surveying.

paragraph.text: For each 30 semester hours or its equivalent that an applicant completes in land surveying courses that the Board approves, the Board may allow a 1-year credit towards the experience requirements of paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection for a maximum of 3 years.

subsection.text: An applicant for a license shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the Board:

subparagraph.text: an application on the form that the Board provides; and
any relevant document that the Board requires; and

paragraph.text: pay to the Board or the Board’s designee:

subparagraph.text: a nonrefundable application fee set by the Board; and
an examination fee set by the Board in an amount not to exceed the cost of the required examination.

paragraph.text: The application form shall require:

subparagraph.text: a statement about the education of the applicant;
a statement about the experience of the applicant in land or property line surveying;
a list of at least 5 references that, unless excused by the Board, shall include:

sub-subparagraph.text: for a land surveyor applicant, at least 3 professional land surveyors who have personal knowledge of the applicant’s land surveying experience; and
for a property line surveyor applicant, at least 3 individuals, each of whom:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: is either a professional land surveyor or a licensed property line surveyor; and
has personal knowledge of the applicant’s property line surveying experience; and

subparagraph.text: any other relevant information that the Board requires.

paragraph.text: An application shall be made under oath.

subsection.text: If the Board finds that an application form and the accompanying documentation do not demonstrate that the applicant meets the requirements for a license under this subtitle, the Board may require the applicant to submit additional information or documentation.
Except as otherwise provided in § 15-307.1 of this subtitle, an applicant who otherwise qualifies for a license is entitled to be examined as provided in this section.
The Board periodically shall give the examinations required under this subtitle to qualified applicants at the times and places that the Board determines.
The Board shall give each qualified applicant notice of the time and place of examination.
As provided for applicants for a license to practice land surveying under § 15-305 of this subtitle, the Board shall give the following 2 separate examinations:

paragraph.text: a written examination in the fundamentals of land surveying; and
a written examination in the principles and practice of land surveying.
The Board shall determine the subjects, scope, and form of and method of grading and passing scores for the examinations given under this subtitle.
The Board shall structure the examinations to test the ability of an applicant to design, plan, and direct land surveying in order to ensure the safety of life, health, and property.

subsection.text: The Board may use a testing service to administer the examinations given under this title.
If the Board uses a testing service, the testing service, subject to the requirements set by the Board, may:

paragraph.text: set the time and place of examinations;
give qualified applicants notice of the time and place of examinations; and
furnish any other information that the Board may require the testing service to provide.
If an applicant fails an examination given under this subtitle, the Board shall mail notice of the failure to the applicant.
The notice required under this subsection shall be mailed to the address that the applicant last gave to the Board.
Subject to this subsection, an applicant who fails an examination may review the applicant’s answers and model answers to the examination.
To conduct a review under this subsection, an applicant shall submit a written request to the Board within 60 days after the date on which the Board mails notice of the applicant’s failure.
An applicant who does not request review in accordance with paragraph (2) of this subsection waives the right to review under this subsection.

subsection.text: The Board shall confirm the test score of any applicant who fails an examination given under this subtitle if the applicant submits a written request to the Board.
Subject to this section, if an applicant fails an examination given under this subtitle, the applicant may retake the examination.
Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, an applicant for reexamination shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the Board a request for reexamination on the form that the Board provides; and
pay to the Board or the Board’s designee a reexamination fee set by the Board in § 15-306(a)(2) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: An applicant, for a professional land surveyor license, who fails 2 reexaminations given under this section may take the examination again only if the applicant submits to the Board:

paragraph.text: a request for reexamination on the form provided by the Board; and
the appropriate documentation indicating the applicant’s updated work experience required by the Board.
A reexamination fee paid under subsection (b)(2) of this section is not refundable.
If an applicant does not take the reexamination that the applicant asked to take, the Board shall credit that fee toward any reexamination that the applicant later takes.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of this section, the Board may waive any examination requirement of this subtitle for an individual who is licensed to practice land surveying in another state.
The Board may grant a waiver under this section only if the applicant:

paragraph.text: is of good character and reputation;
pays to the Board:

subparagraph.text: the nonrefundable application fee set by the Board under § 15–306 of this subtitle; and
the license fee set by the Board; and

paragraph.text: provides adequate evidence that, at the time the applicant was licensed by the other state, the applicant met requirements that were equivalent to those then required by the laws of this State.

subsection.text: If an applicant qualifies for a license under this subtitle, the Board shall send the applicant a notice that states that:

paragraph.text: the applicant has qualified for a license; and
the Board will issue a license to the applicant, on receipt of a license fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: On payment of the license fee, the Board shall issue a license to each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle.
The Board shall include on each license that the Board issues:

paragraph.text: the full name of the licensee;
the registration number assigned by the Board to the licensee; and
the signatures of the chairman and secretary of the Board, under seal of the Board.

subsection.text: Subject to any regulation that the Board adopts, it shall replace any lost, mutilated, or destroyed license certificate on:

paragraph.text: request of the licensee; and
payment of the replacement fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: While a license to practice land surveying is in effect, it authorizes the licensee to practice land surveying.
While a license to practice property line surveying is in effect, it authorizes the licensee to practice property line surveying.
Unless a license is renewed for a 2–year term as provided in this section, the license expires on the first June 30 that comes:

paragraph.text: after the effective date of the license; and
in an odd–numbered year.
At least 1 month before a license expires, the Board shall mail to the licensee, at the last known address of the licensee:

subparagraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

sub-subparagraph.text: the date on which the current license expires;
the date by which the Board must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the license expires; and
the amount of the license fee.

paragraph.text: The failure of a licensee to receive the notice for which this subsection provides does not prevent the license from expiring as specified under subsection (a) of this section.

subsection.text: Before a license expires, the licensee periodically may renew it for an additional 2–year term, if the licensee:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be licensed;
pays to the Board a license fee set by the Board; and
submits to the Board a renewal application on the form that the Board provides.
The Board shall renew the license of and issue a renewal certificate to each licensee who meets the requirements of this section.
The Board shall include on each renewal certificate that the Board issues:

subparagraph.text: the date on which the current license expires; and
the signatures of the chairman and secretary of the Board, under seal of the Board.

subsection.text: The Secretary may determine that licenses issued under this subtitle shall expire on a staggered basis.

The Board shall adopt regulations to require a demonstration of continuing professional competency for a licensee as a condition of renewal of a license under this section in accordance with the following:

paragraph.text: a continuing professional competency requirement does not apply to the first renewal of a license;
if a license expires on or before September 30, 2002, a professional land surveyor or licensed property line surveyor is not required to fulfill the continuing professional competency requirement;

if a license expires between October 1, 2002 and September 30, 2003, a professional land surveyor or licensed property line surveyor is required to fulfill 50 percent of the continuing professional competency requirement as provided in the regulations adopted by the Board under this subsection; and

if a license expires on or after October 1, 2003, a professional land surveyor or licensed property line surveyor is required to fulfill the full continuing professional competency requirement as provided in the regulations adopted by the Board under this subsection.

subsection.text: The Board shall reinstate the license of an individual who, for any reason, has failed to renew the license if the individual:

paragraph.text: applies to the Board for reinstatement within 2 years after the license expires;
meets the renewal requirements of § 15–314 of this subtitle; and
except as otherwise provided in subsection (d) of this section, pays to the Board a reinstatement fee set by the Board.
If an individual has failed to renew a license to practice land surveying for any reason and then applies to the Board for reinstatement more than 2 years after the license has expired, the Board:

subparagraph.text: may require the individual to reapply for a license in the same manner as an applicant applies for an original license under this subtitle; or
subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, may reinstate the license.

paragraph.text: The Board may reinstate a license under paragraph (1) of this subsection only if the individual:

subparagraph.text: meets the renewal requirements of § 15–314 of this subtitle;
if required by the Board, states reasons why reinstatement should be granted; and
except as otherwise provided in subsection (d) of this section, pays to the Board a reinstatement fee set by the Board.

paragraph.text: If an individual has failed to renew a license to practice property line surveying for any reason and then applies to the Board for reinstatement more than 2 years after the license has expired, the Board, subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, may reinstate the license.
The Board may reinstate a license under paragraph (1) of this subsection only if the individual:

subparagraph.text: meets the renewal requirements of § 15–314 of this subtitle;
if required by the Board, states reasons why reinstatement should be granted; and
except as otherwise provided in subsection (d) of this section, pays to the Board a reinstatement fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: The Board may waive a reinstatement fee for a licensee who provides evidence satisfactory to the Board that the licensee did not practice land surveying or property line surveying, as appropriate, during the time the license lapsed.
The Board may issue a retired status license to an individual who:

paragraph.text: is currently licensed in Maryland as a professional land surveyor or a property line surveyor;

has been either licensed as a professional land surveyor or a property line surveyor or was authorized to practice land surveying or property line surveying under § 15-303 of this subtitle for at least 25 years, of which 5 years were in Maryland;
is not the subject of a pending disciplinary action related to the practice of land surveying or property line surveying in this or another state;
submits to the Board an application on the form provided by the Board; and
pays to the Board a fee, as set by the Board.
The holder of a retired status license issued under this section may not engage in the practice of professional land surveying or property line surveying.
The holder of a professional land surveyor retired status license may use the designation of “retired professional land surveyor”.
The holder of a property line surveyor retired status license may use the designation of “retired property line surveyor”.

subsection.text: The Board may reactivate the license of a retired status license if that individual:

paragraph.text: submits to the Board an application for reactivation on the form approved by the Board;

meets all continuing competency requirements, not exceeding 48 credit hours, that would have been required for renewal of a license under § 15-314 of this subtitle if the licensee had not been placed on retired status;
pays to the Board a reactivation fee as set by the Board; and
is not the subject of a pending disciplinary action related to the practice of land surveying or property line surveying in this or any other state.

Subject to the hearing provisions of § 15–319 of this subtitle, the Board, on the affirmative vote of a majority of its members then serving, may deny a license to any applicant, reprimand any licensee, or suspend or revoke a license if:

subparagraph.text: the applicant or licensee fraudulently or deceptively obtains, renews, or attempts to obtain or renew a license or permit for the applicant or licensee or for another;
the applicant or licensee fraudulently or deceptively uses a license;
under the laws of the United States or of any state, the applicant or licensee is convicted of:

sub-subparagraph.text: a felony; or
a misdemeanor that is directly related to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to practice land surveying or property line surveying;

subparagraph.text: the applicant or licensee is guilty of gross negligence, incompetence, or misconduct while practicing land surveying or property line surveying;
the applicant or licensee violates any regulation adopted by the Board;
the applicant or licensee violates any provision of this title; or

the applicant or licensee has had a license to practice land surveying or property line surveying in another state revoked or suspended by the other state for a cause that would justify revocation or suspension under this title, except for the failure to pay a license fee.
Instead of or in addition to reprimanding a licensee or suspending or revoking a license under this subsection, the Board may impose a penalty not exceeding $5,000 for each violation.
To determine the amount of the penalty imposed under this subsection, the Board shall consider:

sub-subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the harm caused by the violation;
the good faith of the licensee; and
any history of previous violations by the licensee.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: The Board shall consider the following facts in the granting, denial, renewal, suspension, or revocation of a license or the reprimand of a licensee when an applicant or licensee is convicted of a felony or misdemeanor described in subsection (a)(1)(iii) of this section:

paragraph.text: the nature of the crime;
the relationship of the crime to the activities authorized by the license;
with respect to a felony, the relevance of the conviction to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to practice land surveying or property line surveying;
the length of time since the conviction; and
the behavior and activities of the applicant or licensee before and after the conviction.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of this section, the Board shall commence proceedings under § 15-317 of this subtitle on a complaint made to the Board by a member or any other person.

paragraph.text: A complaint shall:

subparagraph.text: be in writing;
state specifically the facts on which the complaint is based; and
be submitted to the secretary of the Board.

paragraph.text: If the complaint is made by any person other than a member of the Board, the complaint shall be made under oath by the person who submits the complaint.

subsection.text: If the Board finds that a complaint alleges facts that are adequate grounds for action under § 15-317 of this subtitle, the Board shall act on the complaint as provided under § 15-319 of this subtitle. If the Board does not make that finding, it shall dismiss the complaint.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 10-226 of the State Government Article, before the Board takes any final action under § 15-317 of this subtitle, it shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Board.
A hearing shall be set down within a reasonable time, not exceeding 6 months, after the Board has brought charges against the licensee.

subsection.text: The Board shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Board may administer oaths in connection with any proceeding under this section.
At least 30 days before the hearing, the hearing notice and a copy of the complaint shall be:

paragraph.text: served personally on the individual; or
mailed to the last known address of the individual.

subsection.text: The individual may be represented at the hearing by counsel.
If, after due notice, the individual against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, nevertheless the Board may hear and determine the matter.
Subject to any regulation that the Board adopts, it may reinstate a license that has been revoked.
A license may be reinstated under this section only on:

paragraph.text: the affirmative vote of a majority of the members of the Board then serving; and
payment to the Board of a reinstatement fee set by the Board.
Subject to the provisions of this section, a professional land surveyor may practice land surveying for others through:

subparagraph.text: a corporation as an officer, employee, or agent of the corporation;
a partnership as a partner, employee, or agent of the partnership; or
a limited liability company as a member, employee, or agent of the limited liability company.

paragraph.text: Subject to the provisions of this section, a licensed property line surveyor may practice property line surveying through:

subparagraph.text: a corporation as an officer, employee, or agent of the corporation;
a partnership as a partner, employee, or agent of the partnership; or
a limited liability company as a member, employee, or agent of the limited liability company.

paragraph.text: Subject to the provisions of this subtitle, a corporation, partnership, or limited liability company may provide land surveying services through a professional land surveyor or property line surveying services through a licensed property line surveyor.

A professional land surveyor who practices land surveying through a corporation, partnership, or limited liability company under this section shall be subject to all of the provisions of this title that relate to practicing land surveying.

A licensed property line surveyor who practices property line surveying through a corporation, partnership, or limited liability company under this section shall be subject to all of the provisions of this title that relate to practicing property line surveying.

A corporation, partnership, or limited liability company that provides land surveying services or property line surveying services under this section is not, by its compliance with this section, relieved of any responsibility that the corporation, partnership, or limited liability company may have for an act or omission of its officer, partner, member, employee, or agent.

An individual who practices land surveying or property line surveying through a corporation, partnership, or limited liability company, is not, by reason of the individual’s employment or other relationship with the corporation, partnership, or limited liability company, relieved of any individual responsibility that the individual may have regarding that practice.

section.text: A corporation, partnership, or limited liability company shall hold a permit issued by the Board before the corporation, partnership, or limited liability company may operate a business through which land surveying or property line surveying is practiced.
An applicant for a permit shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the Board an application on the form that the Board provides; and
pay to the Board a nonrefundable application fee set by the Board.

section.text: The Board shall issue a permit to each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle and pays to the Board a permit fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section and while a permit is in effect, it:

paragraph.text: authorizes the holder to:

subparagraph.text: operate a business through which land surveying is practiced; and
represent to the public that the holder provides the services of a professional land surveyor; or

paragraph.text: authorizes the holder to:

subparagraph.text: operate a business through which property line surveying is practiced; and
represent to the public that the holder provides the services of a licensed property line surveyor.

subsection.text: A permit authorizes the holder to provide a service that constitutes practicing land surveying or property line surveying only if the service is performed by an individual who is licensed or otherwise authorized under this title to practice.
Unless a permit is renewed for a 2–year term as provided in this section, the permit expires on the first June 30 that comes:

paragraph.text: after the effective date of the permit; and
in an odd–numbered year.

subsection.text: At least 1 month before a permit expires, the Board shall mail to the permit holder, at the last known address of the holder:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

subparagraph.text: the date on which the current permit expires;
the date by which the Board must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the permit expires; and
the amount of the permit fee.

subsection.text: Before a permit expires, the permit holder periodically may renew it for an additional 2–year term, if the holder:

paragraph.text: submits to the Board a renewal application on the form that the Board provides; and
pays to the Board a permit fee set by the Board.

subsection.text: The Board shall renew the permit of each permit holder who meets the requirements of this section.
Each professional land surveyor and each licensed property line surveyor may obtain a seal for use as required under § 15-502 of this subtitle.
The seal shall:

paragraph.text: be of a design determined by the Board; and
include:

subparagraph.text: the legend:

sub-subparagraph.text: “professional land surveyor”; or
“licensed property line surveyor”; and

subparagraph.text: the name of the licensee who holds the seal.

subsection.text: Before a professional land surveyor or licensed property line surveyor issues to a client or submits to a public authority any plan, plat, report, or specification, the professional land surveyor or licensed property line surveyor who prepared the document shall endorse on the document the licensee’s:

paragraph.text: name; and
seal or a facsimile of the seal.

subsection.text: A public authority may not accept any surveying plan, plat, report, or specification unless the document is endorsed as required under subsection (a) of this section.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, a person may not practice, attempt to practice, or offer to practice land surveying or property line surveying in the State unless licensed by the Board.
Except for a licensee who operates the business as a sole practitioner, a person may not operate a business through which land surveying or property line surveying is practiced, unless:

paragraph.text: the business is a corporation, a partnership, or a limited liability company; and
the corporation, partnership, or limited liability company holds a permit issued by the Board.

subsection.text: Unless authorized under this title to practice land surveying without the supervision required under § 15-303 of this title, a person may not represent to the public, by use of a title, including “land surveyor”, “professional land surveyor”, “licensed land surveyor”, or “registered land surveyor”, by use of the term “land surveying” in the name of the person’s business activity, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person is authorized to practice land surveying in the State.

Unless authorized under this title to practice property line surveying without the supervision required under § 15-303 of this title, a person may not represent to the public, by use of a title, including “licensed property line surveyor” or “property line surveyor”, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person is authorized to practice property line surveying in the State.

Subject to subsection (b) of this section and unless a person holds a permit issued by the Board, the person may not represent to the public, by use of the title “land surveyors”, “professional land surveyors”, “licensed land surveyors”, “registered land surveyors”, “property line surveyors”, “licensed property line surveyors”, or “registered property line surveyors”, by use of the term “land surveying” or “property line surveying”, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person holds a permit or otherwise is authorized to operate a business through which land surveying or property line surveying is practiced in the State.
Subsection (a) of this section does not apply to a professional land surveyor or licensed property line surveyor who operates a business as a sole practitioner.

section.text: A person may not:

paragraph.text: use or attempt to use the license of another individual; or
impersonate another individual who holds a license.

section.text: Other than a professional land surveyor or licensed property line surveyor who obtains a seal as authorized under this title, a person may not use or attempt to use a seal.
A person may not give false information to the Board in an attempt to obtain a license.
An individual whose license has been suspended or revoked under § 15-317 of this title may not practice land surveying or property line surveying in any manner as:

paragraph.text: an associate, agent, employee, or other subordinate of a professional land surveyor or licensed property line surveyor; or
a principal, associate, agent, employee, or other subordinate of a corporation, partnership, or limited liability company that provides land surveying or property line surveying services.

subsection.text: An individual who is authorized to practice land surveying may not practice or offer to practice land surveying in those areas of land surveying in which the individual is not competent to practice.

An individual who is authorized to practice property line surveying may not practice or offer to practice property line surveying in those areas of property line surveying in which the individual is not competent to practice.
A person who violates any provision of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $500 or imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or both.

paragraph.text: The Board may impose on a person who violates any provision of this title a penalty not exceeding $5,000 for each violation.
In setting the amount of the penalty, the Board shall consider:

subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the harm caused by the violation;
the good faith of the violator;
any history of previous violations by the violator; and
any other relevant factors.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

section.text: This title may be cited as the “Maryland Professional Land Surveyors Act”.

Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, this title and all regulations adopted under this title shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2024.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Appraisal” means an analysis, conclusion, or opinion about the nature, quality, utility, or value of interests in or aspects of identified real estate.
“Appraisal” includes:

subparagraph.text: a valuation appraisal;
an analysis assignment; and
a review assignment.

paragraph.text: “Appraisal” does not include an opinion to a potential seller or third party by a person licensed under Title 17 of this article about the recommended listing price or recommended purchase price of real estate, provided that the opinion is not referred to as an appraisal.

subsection.text: “Appraisal report” means any communication, oral or written, of an appraisal.

paragraph.text: “Certificate” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a certificate issued by the Commission that allows an individual to provide certified real estate appraisal services.
“Certificate” includes, unless the context requires otherwise, each of the following certificates:

subparagraph.text: a certificate to provide certified real estate appraisal services for general real estate; and
a certificate to provide certified real estate appraisal services for residential real estate.

subsection.text: “Certified appraisal report” means an appraisal report prepared and signed by a certified real estate appraiser.

paragraph.text: “Certified real estate appraiser” means, unless the context requires otherwise, an individual who is certified by the Commission to provide certified real estate appraisal services.
“Certified real estate appraiser” includes:

subparagraph.text: a certified real estate appraiser for general real estate; and
a certified real estate appraiser for residential real estate.

subsection.text: “Commission” means the State Commission of Real Estate Appraisers, Appraisal Management Companies, and Home Inspectors.

“Home inspection” means a written evaluation of one or more of the components of an existing residential building, including the heating system, cooling system, plumbing system, electrical system, structural components, foundation, roof, masonry structure, exterior and interior components, or any other related residential housing component.
“Home inspector” means an individual who provides home inspection services for compensation.
“License” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a license issued by the Commission to provide real estate appraisal services or to provide home inspection services.
“Licensed home inspector” means an individual who is licensed by the Commission to provide home inspection services.
“Licensed real estate appraiser” means an individual who is licensed by the Commission to provide real estate appraisal services.
“Provide certified real estate appraisal services” means to provide real estate appraisal services as a certified real estate appraiser.
“Provide home inspection services” means to provide home inspection services as a licensed home inspector.

“Provide real estate appraisal services” means to make for consideration an appraisal of real estate or prepare or sign an appraisal report in connection with a federally related transaction, as defined in the federal Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act of 1989.

paragraph.text: “Real estate” means any interest in real property that is located in the State or elsewhere.
“Real estate” includes:

subparagraph.text: an interest in a condominium; and
a time–share estate or a time–share license, as those terms are defined in § 11A–101 of the Real Property Article.

subsection.text: “Real estate appraiser trainee” means an individual who is licensed by the Commission to provide real estate appraisal services while:

paragraph.text: under the supervision of a supervising appraiser; and
in training to become a licensed real estate appraiser or certified real estate appraiser.

subsection.text: “Supervising appraiser” means a certified residential real estate appraiser or a certified general real estate appraiser who has the responsibility of supervising one or more real estate appraiser trainees.

paragraph.text: “Supervision” means the responsibility of a supervising appraiser to provide on–site direction or immediately available direction, through written instructions or by electronic means, to real estate appraiser trainees performing real estate appraisal services.

“Supervision” includes a supervising appraiser accepting direct responsibility for a real estate appraisal prepared by the real estate appraiser trainee while the trainee is under the supervising appraiser’s direction on a specific appraisal assignment.

section.text: There is a State Commission of Real Estate Appraisers, Appraisal Management Companies, and Home Inspectors in the Department.

paragraph.text: The Commission consists of 15 members.
Of the 15 members of the Commission:

subparagraph.text: at least 2 shall be certified general real estate appraisers;
2 shall be certified general real estate appraisers, certified residential real estate appraisers, or licensed real estate appraisers;
2 shall be representatives of a financial institution who are not certified or licensed real estate appraisers or home inspectors;
1 shall be a licensed home inspector who is a member of the American Society of Home Inspectors (ASHI);
1 shall be a licensed home inspector who is a member of the National Association of Home Inspectors;
2 shall be licensed home inspectors without regard to affiliation with or membership in any society or association;
4 shall be consumer members; and
1 shall be a representative of an appraisal management company registered under Subtitle 5B of this title.

paragraph.text: The Governor shall:

subparagraph.text: appoint the members with the advice of the Secretary and with the advice and consent of the Senate; and
consider demographic and geographic diversity when making appointments to the Commission.

subsection.text: Each member of the Commission shall be a citizen of the State.

paragraph.text: Each consumer member of the Commission:

subparagraph.text: shall be a member of the general public;
may not be a licensee, holder of a certificate, or otherwise be subject to regulation by the Commission;
may not be required to meet the qualifications for the professional members of the Commission; and
may not, within 1 year before appointment, have had a financial interest in or have received compensation from a person regulated by the Commission.

paragraph.text: While a member of the Commission, a consumer member may not:

subparagraph.text: have a financial interest in or receive compensation from a person regulated by the Commission; or
grade any examination given by or for the Commission.

subsection.text: Before taking office, each appointee to the Commission shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 3 years.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Commission on January 1, 1991.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member may not serve for more than 2 consecutive 3–year terms.

subsection.text: The Governor may remove a member for incompetence or misconduct.

paragraph.text: From among its members, the Commission annually shall elect a chairman and a vice chairman, provided:

subparagraph.text: if a chair is elected from among the real estate appraiser members, then the vice chairman shall be elected from among the licensed home inspector members; and
if a chair is elected from among the licensed home inspector members, then the vice chairman shall be elected from among the real estate appraiser members.

paragraph.text: At the end of a term, the chairman and vice chairman may be reelected.

subsection.text: The chairman shall perform the duties that this title and the Commission require.
While in office, the chairman shall be covered by a surety bond in the form and amount required by law.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, a majority of the members then serving on the Commission is a quorum.
A majority of the members then serving on the Commission is not a quorum unless 2 home inspector members and 2 real estate appraiser members are present.
The Commission shall meet at least once each calendar quarter, at the times and places that the Commission determines.
Each member of the Commission shall receive written notice of the time and place of a meeting at least 10 days before the scheduled date of the meeting.

Within a reasonable time after giving notice to the Commission, a member of the public is entitled to be heard, at a meeting of the Commission, on any matter within the jurisdiction of the Commission.

subsection.text: Each member of the Commission is entitled to:

paragraph.text: compensation in accordance with the State budget; and
reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.
The Secretary shall appoint the executive director of the Commission from a list of 3 nominees submitted by the Commission.
The executive director serves at the pleasure of the Secretary.
The executive director may not hold any position or engage in another business that:

subparagraph.text: interferes with the position of executive director; or
might conflict with the position of executive director.

paragraph.text: While employed by the Commission, the executive director may not:

subparagraph.text: be licensed in any state as a real estate appraiser or a home inspector;
engage in any act for which a license is required under this title; or
in connection with any real estate appraisal transaction or home inspection engagement, directly or indirectly receive or become entitled to receive any compensation, fee, or perquisite.

subsection.text: The executive director is entitled to:

paragraph.text: compensation in accordance with the State budget; and
reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The executive director is a special appointment in the State Personnel Management System.
While employed as executive director, the executive director shall be covered by a surety bond in the form and amount required by law.

section.text: The executive director shall:

paragraph.text: keep a record of each act, communication, and proceeding of the Commission; and
perform any other duty that the Commission considers appropriate.

subsection.text: The Commission, in accordance with the State budget, may employ:

paragraph.text: a general staff; and
an investigative staff to conduct investigations.

subsection.text: While employed by the Commission, an individual may not:

paragraph.text: be licensed in any state as a real estate appraiser or home inspector;
engage in any act for which a license is required under this title; or
in connection with any real estate appraisal transaction or home inspection engagement, directly or indirectly receive or become entitled to receive any compensation, fee, or perquisite.

subsection.text: To protect the interests of the public, the Commission shall promptly adopt, by regulation:

paragraph.text: appraisal standards of conduct for all individuals licensed or certified as real estate appraisers under this title, including standards regarding conflicts of interest and ethical conduct; and
a code of ethics and standards of practice for individuals licensed as home inspectors under this title.

subsection.text: The Commission shall promptly adopt at a minimum the uniform standards of professional appraisal practice of the appraisal foundation to meet the requirement under subsection (a) of this section.

At the request of a licensee or certificate holder, the Commission shall provide a copy of the appraisal standards it adopts to the licensed or certified real estate appraiser or a copy of home inspection standards it adopts to the licensed home inspector.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall administer and enforce the provisions of this title.
In connection with any action to enforce the provisions of this title, the Commission may:

subparagraph.text: hold hearings;
administer oaths;
issue a subpoena for the attendance of a witness to testify or the production of evidence; or
take depositions in the same manner as provided in civil cases in the State.

paragraph.text: The Police Department of Baltimore City, the sheriff of a county, or a private process server shall serve a subpoena issued under this subsection.
If a person fails to comply with a subpoena issued under this subsection, on petition of the Commission or another party, a circuit court may compel compliance with the subpoena.

If the Commission concludes that conduct alleged to be a violation of any provision of this title may result in irreparable harm to a person, the Commission may sue to enforce a provision of this title by ex parte, interlocutory, or final injunction.
In seeking an injunction under this subsection, the Commission is not required to:

subparagraph.text: post bond, if the injunction is sought against a person who does not hold a license issued under this title;
allege or prove that an adequate remedy at law does not exist; or
allege or prove that substantial or irreparable damage would result from the continued violation of the provision.

paragraph.text: Subject to the provisions of this section, the Commission shall conduct an investigation that relates to any complaint alleging that an unauthorized person has provided real estate appraisal services or home inspection services.
A complaint shall:

subparagraph.text: be in writing;
state specifically the facts on which the complaint is based; and
be submitted to the Commission.

paragraph.text: If a complaint is made by any person other than a member of the Commission, the complaint shall be made under oath by the person who submits the complaint.

subsection.text: A member of the Commission may not be held personally liable for any action taken under this section.
The Commission shall establish a Real Estate Appraisal Hearing Board.

paragraph.text: The Hearing Board shall consist of 3 members of the Commission, appointed by the Commission.
Of the 3 positions on the Real Estate Appraisal Hearing Board:

subparagraph.text: 1 shall be a representative of a financial institution;
1 shall be a consumer member; and
1 shall be an appraiser with a level of licensure or certification at least equal to the individual subject to the disciplinary action.

subsection.text: From among the members of the Hearing Board, the Commission shall designate a chairman.
The Commission shall establish a Home Inspector Hearing Board.

paragraph.text: The Hearing Board shall consist of 3 members of the Commission, appointed by the Commission.
Of the 3 positions on the Home Inspector Hearing Board:

subparagraph.text: 2 shall be licensed home inspectors; and
1 shall be a consumer member.

subsection.text: From among the members of the Hearing Board, the Commission shall designate a chairman.
The Commission shall establish an appraisal management company hearing board.

paragraph.text: The hearing board consists of three members of the Commission, appointed by the Commission.
Of the three positions on the appraisal management company hearing board:

subparagraph.text: one shall be a representative of a financial institution;
one shall be a consumer member; and
one shall be a representative of an appraisal management company.

subsection.text: From among the members of the hearing board, the Commission shall designate a chair.
The Commission shall refer to the appropriate hearing board for a hearing any matter for which a hearing may be required under § 16–701, § 16–701.1, or § 16–701.2 of this title.
The hearing board may exercise the same powers and shall conduct a hearing in accordance with the same procedures applicable to the Commission under § 16–602 of this title.

paragraph.text: The hearing board shall determine if there is a reasonable basis to believe that there are grounds for disciplinary action under this title against a licensee.

subparagraph.text: If the hearing board finds a reasonable basis as provided under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the hearing board shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: hold a hearing on the matter; and
file its finding with the Commission.

subparagraph.text: If the hearing board does not find a reasonable basis as provided under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the hearing board shall dismiss the complaint.

paragraph.text: A hearing board shall advise the Commission specifically of any action brought against a licensee as a result of monetary loss, misappropriation of money, or fraud.

subparagraph.text: Within 15 days after the filing of a decision by a hearing board, the Commission or any of its members may file an exception to the decision of the hearing board.
On the filing of an exception under subparagraph (i) of this paragraph, the Commission shall set a hearing on the matter.

paragraph.text: If an exception is not filed within the time allowed under paragraph (1)(i) of this subsection:

subparagraph.text: the decision of the hearing board shall be considered as the final decision of the Commission; and
any party aggrieved by the decision may take a judicial appeal as provided in this title.

subsection.text: The Commission shall keep an indexed record of:

paragraph.text: each application for licensure or certification;
each issuance of a license or certificate;
each reprimand of a licensed real estate appraiser or certified real estate appraiser or licensed home inspector; and
each suspension or revocation of a licensed real estate appraiser or certified real estate appraiser or licensed home inspector.

subsection.text: The Commission shall make available to the public:

paragraph.text: the record during business hours; and
on request, a copy of the record at a reasonable price that the Commission sets.

subsection.text: A licensed or certified real estate appraiser shall file with the Commission or a designee otherwise provided by law at the end of every calendar quarter a report listing the address and appraised value of residential real estate in Baltimore City upon which the appraiser performed an appraisal during the calendar quarter.
The report shall be open for inspection only to representatives of government agencies for investigation of fraudulent practices.
The Commission shall issue at least annually a roster that shows:

paragraph.text: the name of each licensed real estate appraiser trainee, licensed real estate appraiser, certified real estate appraiser, and licensed home inspector; and
the name and place of business of each licensed real estate appraiser, certified real estate appraiser, and licensed home inspector.

subsection.text: On request, the Commission shall make available to the public a copy of the roster at a reasonable price that the Commission sets.

section.text: On request, the Commission shall issue a document of good standing to a licensed real estate appraiser trainee, licensed real estate appraiser, certified real estate appraiser, or licensed home inspector who:

paragraph.text: is in good standing in the State; and
pays the issuance fee set by the Commission.

section.text: The Commission shall submit to the Secretary an annual report that includes:

paragraph.text: a statement of the total receipts and expenditures of the Commission; and
any other information that reflects the work of the Commission.

section.text: In addition to any powers set forth elsewhere, the Commission may:

paragraph.text: sponsor research and other educational activities about real estate appraising or home inspecting;
adopt any regulation to carry out the provisions of this title;
review and approve any on-site training programs, including programs that have been approved by national home inspection organizations;
keep a record of its proceedings; and
adopt an official seal to authenticate its proceedings, official records, licenses, and certificates.
Beginning on July 1, 2011, the Commission may set by regulation reasonable fees for its services.
The fees charged shall be:

subparagraph.text: set so as to produce funds to approximate the cost of maintaining the Commission; and
based on the calculations performed by the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation under § 2–106.8 of the Business Regulation Article.

subsection.text: The Commission shall publish the fee schedule set by the Commission.

paragraph.text: Beginning on July 1, 2011, the Commission shall pay all fees collected under this title to the Comptroller.

The Comptroller shall distribute the fees to the State Commission of Real Estate Appraisers, Appraisal Management Companies, and Home Inspectors Fund established in § 2–106.7 of the Business Regulation Article.

section.text: Any person aggrieved by a final decision of the Commission in a contested case, as defined in § 10-202 of the State Government Article, may take an appeal as allowed in §§ 10-222 and 10-223 of the State Government Article.
The Commission exercises its powers, duties, and functions subject to the authority of the Secretary.

All regulations adopted under this title by the Commission applicable to the provision of real estate appraisal services shall comply with the requirements of the federal Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act of 1989.

subsection.text: After June 30, 1991, and except as otherwise provided in this title, an individual shall be licensed by the Commission to provide real estate appraisal services before the individual may provide real estate appraisal services in the State.
This section does not apply to an individual who provides real estate appraisal services that are only incidental real estate appraisal services, including home inspectors and environmental auditors.

In addition to subsection (b) of this section, this section does not apply to an individual who provides real estate appraisal services that the Commission defines by regulation to be only incidental real estate appraisal services.
This section does not apply to an individual who is licensed to practice any business or occupation in the State while acting within the scope of the license.
To qualify for a real estate appraisal license, an applicant shall be an individual who meets the requirements of this section.
An applicant shall be of good character and reputation.
An applicant shall be at least 18 years old.

paragraph.text: An applicant shall satisfy the minimum real estate appraiser qualifications for licensure established under the federal Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act of 1989.
An applicant shall have completed at least 2,000 hours providing real estate appraiser services as a real estate appraiser trainee under the supervision of a licensed or certified appraiser.
Classroom hours of study required by this section may be conducted by:

subparagraph.text: an accredited university, college, or community or junior college;
an approved appraisal society, institute, or association; or
another school that the Commission approves.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall approve all courses of study required under this section.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, the applicant shall pass an examination given by the Commission or the Commission’s designee under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: If an applicant is not a resident of the State, the applicant shall submit to the Commission an irrevocable consent, as provided under this subsection.

The consent required under this section shall specify that service of process on the Secretary shall bind the applicant in any action about the provision of real estate appraisal services brought against the applicant in any county of the State.

subsection.text: The Commission shall adopt additional requirements under this section if necessary to comply with the minimum real estate appraiser qualifications established under the federal Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act of 1989.
The Commission may monitor and review any course of study approved under this section.
An applicant for a license shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the Commission an application on the form that the Commission provides; and
pay to the Commission a fee set by the Commission.

subsection.text: The Commission may require an applicant to be fingerprinted.
Except as otherwise provided in § 16-304.1 of this subtitle, an applicant who otherwise qualifies for a license is entitled to be examined as provided in this section.
The Commission periodically shall give examinations to qualified applicants at the times and places that the Commission determines.
The Commission shall give each qualified applicant notice of the times and places that the Commission determines.
To take an examination, an applicant shall pay an examination fee to the Commission or the Commission’s designee in an amount established by the Commission not to exceed the cost of the examination.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, the Commission shall determine the subjects, scope, form, and the passing score for examinations given under this subtitle.

The Commission shall structure the examinations for a real estate appraisal license to test the knowledge of an applicant of real estate appraisal theory and practice and the standards of conduct that the Commission adopts under § 16-208 of this title.

subsection.text: The Commission may use a testing service to administer the examinations given under this subtitle.
If the Commission uses a testing service, the testing service, subject to the requirements set by the Commission, may:

paragraph.text: set the time and place of examinations;
give qualified applicants notice of the time and place of examinations; and
furnish any other information that the Commission may require the testing service to provide.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of this section, the Commission may waive the examination requirements of this subtitle for an individual who is licensed to provide real estate appraisal services in another state.
The Commission may grant a waiver under this section only if the applicant:

paragraph.text: pays to the Commission the application fee set by the Commission under § 16-303 of this subtitle; and
provides adequate evidence that the applicant:

subparagraph.text: meets the qualifications otherwise required by this subtitle;
holds an active license in good standing in the other state; and
became licensed in the other state after meeting, in that state, requirements that are substantially equivalent to the licensing requirements of this State.

subsection.text: The Commission may grant a waiver only if the state in which the applicant is licensed waives the examination of licensees of this State to a similar extent as this State waives the examination requirements for individuals licensed in that state.
The Commission shall grant a license to each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle.
The Commission shall issue a license document and pocket card to each applicant who has been granted a license under this section.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Commission shall determine the size, form, and content of any license document or pocket card that the Commission issues.
The Commission shall include an expiration date on each license document that the Commission issues.

section.text: While a license is in effect, it authorizes the licensee to provide real estate appraisal services.

subsection.text: Unless a license is renewed for a 3-year term as provided in this section, the license expires on a staggered basis as determined by the Secretary.
At least 1 month before the license expires, the Commission shall send to the licensee, at the last known address of the licensee:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

subparagraph.text: the date on which the current license expires;
the date by which the Commission must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the license expires; and
the amount of the renewal fee.

subsection.text: Before a license expires, the licensee periodically may renew it for an additional 3–year term, if the licensee:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be licensed;
pays to the Commission a renewal fee set by the Commission; and
submits to the Commission:

subparagraph.text: a renewal application on the form that the Commission provides; and
adequate evidence of compliance with the continuing education requirements set under this subtitle for license renewal.

section.text: To qualify for renewal of a license under this subtitle, a licensee shall provide to the Commission adequate evidence that the licensee meets the minimum continuing education requirements established under the federal Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act of 1989.
The Commission shall reinstate the license of a real estate appraiser who has failed to renew the license, if the real estate appraiser:

paragraph.text: applies to the Commission for reinstatement within 2 years after the license expires;
meets the requirements of § 16–308 of this subtitle; and
in addition to the renewal fee required under § 16–308 of this subtitle, pays to the Commission a reinstatement fee set by the Commission.

subsection.text: The Commission shall:

paragraph.text: transmit to the Appraisal Subcommittee of the Federal Financial Institutions Examinations Council a roster of State certified and licensed appraisers as required by § 1109(a)(1) of the federal Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act of 1989; and
collect and transmit to the appropriate federal authority those fees required by § 1109(a)(2) of the federal Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act of 1989.
There is a Federal Appraisal Fee Fund within the Commission.
The Fund is a special account to be used to disburse moneys to the appropriate federal authority under subsection (a)(2) of this section.

subsection.text: A licensed real estate appraiser shall:

paragraph.text: maintain a principal place of business; and
in that principal place of business, display conspicuously the license issued under this subtitle.
Each licensee promptly shall give the Commission written notice of any change of name or address from that which appears on the current license.
On receipt of notice, the Commission shall issue to the licensee a new license for the unexpired term.
A licensee who is not a resident of the State may not be required to maintain a place of business in this State if the licensee maintains an active place of business in another state.

section.text: A licensed real estate appraiser may provide real estate appraisal services through a professional corporation in accordance with the Maryland Professional Service Corporation Act.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, an individual shall be licensed by the Commission as a home inspector before the individual may provide home inspection services in the State.
This title does not apply to:

paragraph.text: an individual who is employed as a building code enforcement official by the State or a political subdivision of the State, while acting within the scope of that employment;
an individual who is employed as a federal or State inspector, while acting within the scope of that employment;

a plumber, electrician, professional engineer, real estate appraiser, real estate broker or agent, or heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration contractor who is licensed in the State, while acting within the scope of that license;
a roofer, general contractor, remodeler, or structural pest control specialist, while acting within the scope of that occupation; or
any other professional whose services may be required in the building or remodeling of real property and who does not claim to be a licensed home inspector.

subsection.text: To qualify for a license as a home inspector, an applicant must be an individual who meets the requirements of this section.
Prior to July 1, 2002, an applicant for a home inspector license shall:

paragraph.text: meet two of the following conditions:

subparagraph.text: have completed a minimum of 48 hours of an on-site training course approved by a national home inspection organization or the Commission;
have completed a minimum of 2 years of relevant work experience, as determined by the Commission, immediately preceding the submission of an application;
have completed at least 100 home inspections for compensation; or
