subsection.text: A licensee acting as a presumed buyer’s agent shall orally disclose that fact to the seller or lessor or the licensee acting as the agent of the seller or lessor at their first contact.
Except as provided in § 17-533 of this subtitle, a brokerage relationship commences at the time that a client enters into a brokerage agreement and shall continue until:

paragraph.text: the completion of performance in accordance with the brokerage agreement; or
the earlier of:

subparagraph.text: any date of expiration as agreed on by the parties in the brokerage agreement or in any amendments to the brokerage agreement;
any mutually agreed on termination of the brokerage relationship;
a default by any party under the terms of the brokerage agreement; or
a termination under § 17-530 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The brokerage agreement shall:

paragraph.text: have a definite termination date that is effective automatically without notice from the client;
state the amount of compensation to be paid to the broker and whether the broker is authorized to receive the compensation from a person other than the client;
state whether the broker is authorized to cooperate with other brokers and share compensation with the other brokers and the amount of the compensation;
explain the events or conditions that will entitle the broker to a commission or other compensation; and
contain a provision for the cancellation of the brokerage relationship by either the client or the broker.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in the brokerage agreement, a licensee shall have no further duties or obligations to a client after the termination, expiration, or completion of performance of the brokerage relationship, except to:

paragraph.text: account for all trust money in the licensee’s possession in accordance with this title; and

except as otherwise provided by this title or another law, keep confidential all personal and financial information received from the client during the course of the brokerage relationship and any other information that the client requests during the brokerage relationship to be kept confidential, unless:

subparagraph.text: the client consents in writing to the disclosure of the information; or
the information becomes public from a source other than the licensee.

subsection.text: The payment or promise of payment of compensation to a licensed real estate broker by a seller, lessor, buyer, or lessee, or by a licensee acting for a seller, lessor, buyer, or lessee:

paragraph.text: is not determinative of whether a brokerage relationship has been created or exists; and
does not create or determine the existence of a brokerage relationship between a broker and a seller, lessor, buyer, lessee, or licensee.

subsection.text: A licensee may not be deemed to be an agent or subagent of or to have an agency relationship with a common source information company solely by reason of a licensee’s participation in a common source information company.
A licensee may not be deemed to be an agent or subagent of any client of another broker solely by reason of a licensee’s participation in or use of a common source information company.
A common source information company may not restrict access to its services to any licensee solely based on the size or type of licensee.
In this Part IV of this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Commercial real estate” means:

paragraph.text: real property improved by five or more single-family units;
improved and unimproved real property zoned for commercial, industrial, or nonresidential use by the local zoning authority of the county or municipality in which the property is located; and
unimproved real property zoned for improvement as multifamily units by the local zoning authority of the county or municipality in which the property is located.

subsection.text: “Commercial real estate” does not include:

paragraph.text: property zoned for agricultural use; or
single-family units, including a condominium or co-op unit, for sale or for lease, or otherwise conveyed or to be conveyed on a single basis.

subsection.text: “Nonresident real estate broker” means an individual, partnership, joint venture, limited liability company, limited liability partnership, or corporation that is not licensed under Subtitle 3 of this title but is licensed to provide real estate brokerage services in a jurisdiction other than this State.

“Nonresident real estate salesperson” means an individual who is not licensed under Subtitle 3 of this title but is licensed to provide real estate brokerage services and is affiliated with a nonresident real estate broker.

A nonresident real estate broker may engage in a transaction under this title with respect to commercial real estate located in this State and receive compensation provided the nonresident real estate broker:

paragraph.text: provides real estate brokerage services through a real estate broker licensed under this title;
enters into a written agreement with a licensed real estate broker in this State which:

subparagraph.text: specifies the terms of cooperation and compensation and includes a statement by the nonresident real estate broker that the nonresident real estate broker and the nonresident real estate salespersons licensed and affiliated with the nonresident real estate broker will both adhere to the laws of this State and this title; and
allocates the responsibility for the actions of the nonresident real estate broker in the transaction; and

paragraph.text: complies with the requirements of subsection (b) of this section.

subsection.text: Before a nonresident real estate broker may provide real estate brokerage services in this State, the nonresident real estate broker shall make written application to the Commission including:

paragraph.text: the name, address, and telephone number of the nonresident real estate broker;
the name, address, and telephone number of the business entity through which the nonresident real estate broker provides real estate brokerage services;

the name, address, and telephone number of each nonresident real estate salesperson who will offer or provide real estate brokerage services in this State on behalf of the nonresident real estate broker;
a copy of the agreement required by subsection (a) of this section;

written evidence that the nonresident real estate broker and each nonresident real estate salesperson listed under paragraph (3) of this subsection, are duly licensed in another jurisdiction, and that the license is valid, current, and active;

written consent signed by the nonresident real estate broker, individually and on behalf of the business entity, and by each nonresident real estate salesperson listed under paragraph (3) of this subsection, that service of process on the Executive Director of the Commission shall bind the applicant in any action, suit, or proceeding brought against the broker or salesperson;

written consent signed by the nonresident real estate broker and by each nonresident salesperson listed under paragraph (3) of this subsection, to submit to the jurisdiction of the Commission for the purposes of disciplinary action under § 17-322 of this title;
any other information that is requested by the Commission; and
a temporary license fee of $45.

subsection.text: The Commission shall issue a temporary license to a nonresident real estate broker who complies with the requirements of this section if the jurisdiction in which the real estate broker holds a current license:

paragraph.text: allows a Maryland broker to obtain a temporary license under similar circumstances; or
waives the examination and qualification requirements for licensure for individuals licensed in Maryland.

subsection.text: Upon approval by the Commission, a nonresident real estate broker may engage in a transaction in this State with respect to commercial real estate.

A nonresident real estate salesperson licensed in another jurisdiction and affiliated with a nonresident real estate broker may engage in a transaction in this State with respect to commercial real estate if:

paragraph.text: the nonresident real estate salesperson is licensed with and provides real estate brokerage services under the direct supervision of the nonresident real estate broker;
the nonresident real estate broker satisfies the requirements of § 17-537 of this subtitle; and
the nonresident real estate salesperson provides real estate brokerage services in the name of the nonresident real estate broker.

section.text: All trust money paid on account of a transaction involving commercial real estate in this State shall be received and deposited in the trust account of the Maryland broker in accordance with Part I of this subtitle.

By filing the written consent required under § 17-537(b)(6) of this subtitle, the nonresident real estate broker or nonresident real estate salesperson appoints the Executive Director of the Commission as agent to receive a subpoena, summons, or other process.

In this Part V of this subtitle, “team” means two or more licensed associate real estate brokers or licensed real estate salespersons, or any combination of licensed associate real estate brokers or licensed real estate salespersons, who:

paragraph.text: work together on a regular basis to provide real estate brokerage services;
represent themselves to the public as being part of one entity; and
designate themselves by a collective name such as team or group.

subsection.text: Each team shall designate a team leader who shall be:

paragraph.text: a licensed associate real estate broker; or
a licensed real estate salesperson who has at least 3 years of experience in providing real estate brokerage services.

subsection.text: The team leader shall:

paragraph.text: maintain a current list of all members and employees of the team; and
provide the list and any revisions of the list to the broker or the branch office manager of the brokerage with which the licensees are affiliated.

subsection.text: The real estate broker or branch office manager of a real estate broker shall:

paragraph.text: maintain copies of the lists; and
make the copies available to the Commission on request.

subsection.text: The team leader shall exercise reasonable and adequate supervision over the provision of real estate brokerage services by members of the team.

The responsibility of the team leader to supervise the associate real estate brokers and real estate salespersons on the team shall be in addition to the supervision responsibilities of the real estate broker and branch office manager of the real estate broker provided for in § 17–320 of this title.
The team leader and the members of the team shall adhere to all office rules, practices, and procedures established by the real estate broker and the branch office manager of the real estate broker.

A real estate broker or a designee of the real estate broker may designate two members of a team as intracompany agents for the seller and the buyer in the same transaction if the parties have first been advised in writing that the licensees are part of the same team and the team could have a financial interest in the outcome of the transaction.
If a broker’s designee designates intracompany agents under subsection (a) of this section, the broker’s designee may not be a member of the real estate team.

The name of the team may not contain the terms “real estate”, “real estate brokerage”, or any other term that would lead the public to believe that the team is offering real estate brokerage services independent of the real estate broker.
All advertising by the team must contain:

paragraph.text: the name of the brokerage displayed in a meaningful and conspicuous way;
the name of at least one of the licensee members of the team; and
the telephone number of the real estate broker or branch office manager of the real estate broker.

subsection.text: The team name in the advertisement must be directly connected to the name of the brokerage.

section.text: Team members must conduct all real estate brokerage activities from the office or branch office where their licenses are displayed as provided in § 17–317 of this title.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, a person may not provide, attempt to provide, or offer to provide real estate brokerage services unless licensed by the Commission as a real estate broker.

Except as otherwise provided in this title, a person may not, on behalf of a real estate broker, provide, attempt to provide, or offer to provide real estate brokerage services unless licensed by the Commission as an associate real estate broker or a real estate salesperson to provide real estate brokerage services for that real estate broker.

Unless authorized under this title to provide real estate brokerage services, a person may not represent to the public, by use of the title “licensed real estate broker”, by other title, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person is authorized to provide real estate brokerage services in the State.

Unless authorized under this title to provide real estate brokerage services on behalf of a real estate broker, a person may not represent to the public, by use of the titles “licensed associate real estate broker” or “licensed real estate salesperson”, by other title, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person is authorized to provide real estate brokerage services in the State on behalf of that real estate broker.

A real estate broker may not allow an associate real estate broker, a real estate salesperson, or any other unauthorized individual to provide real estate brokerage services independently as a real estate broker.
A real estate broker may not retain an unlicensed individual to provide real estate brokerage services on behalf of the real estate broker.
A licensed real estate broker may not lend the license certificate or pocket card of the broker to another individual.

Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a real estate broker, an associate real estate broker, or a real estate salesperson may not pay compensation, in any form, for the provision of real estate brokerage services to any person who is not licensed under this title.
This section does not prohibit the payment of compensation to:

paragraph.text: an individual:

subparagraph.text: who is licensed in another state; and
who meets the requirements of § 17-513 of this title;

paragraph.text: a professional service corporation formed under § 17-512 of this title; or
a limited liability company formed under § 17-512 of this title.

Except as otherwise provided in subsection (b) of this section, a real estate broker, an associate real estate broker, or a real estate salesperson may not pay or offer to pay a commission to a lawyer simply for the referral of a person as a possible party to a residential real estate transaction.

A real estate broker, an associate real estate broker, or a real estate salesperson may not solicit referral business from lawyers by a mass solicitation that offers to pay fees or commissions to the lawyers.

subsection.text: Subsection (a)(1) of this section does not apply to payments or offers of payments to lawyers who hold a real estate broker license under this title or are otherwise entitled to a commission.

Other than the commissions expressly prohibited, subsection (a) of this section does not prohibit the payment or the offer of a payment of a commission by a real estate broker, an associate real estate broker, or a real estate salesperson to a lawyer for any service that relates to a real estate transaction.

section.text: A real estate broker, an associate real estate broker, or a real estate salesperson may not post, on real property that is offered for sale or exchange, an outdoor sign or other advertisement on which the cost and capitalization of ground rent on the real property is shown in print or lettering that is smaller than the size of the print or lettering that is used to show the price of the real property.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in subsection (b) of this section, in a real estate transaction involving a single-family dwelling, a real estate broker, an associate real estate broker, a real estate salesperson, or a lawyer acting as a real estate broker may not require a buyer, as a condition of settlement, to employ a particular:

paragraph.text: title insurance company;
settlement company;
escrow company;
mortgage lender, or financial institution as defined in the Financial Institutions Article; or
title lawyer.

subsection.text: A seller may not be prohibited from offering owner financing as a condition of settlement.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “handicap” and “familial status” each have the meanings indicated in the federal Fair Housing Act.

Whether or not acting for monetary gain, a person may not knowingly induce or attempt to induce another person to sell or rent a dwelling or otherwise transfer real estate or knowingly discourage or attempt to discourage another person from buying real estate by:

subparagraph.text: making representations about the entry or prospective entry into a neighborhood of individuals of a particular race, color, sex, religion, handicap, familial status, or national origin;

making representations about the existing or potential proximity of real property owned or used by individuals of a particular race, color, sex, religion, handicap, familial status, or national origin; or

representing that the existing or potential proximity of real property owned or used by individuals of a particular race, color, sex, religion, handicap, familial status, or national origin will or may result in:

sub-subparagraph.text: the lowering of property values;
a change in the racial, religious, or ethnic character of the block, neighborhood, or area;
an increase in criminal or antisocial behavior in the area; or
a decline in the quality of schools serving the area.

subsection.text: A person may not provide financial assistance by loan, gift, or otherwise to another person if the person has actual knowledge that the financial assistance will be used in a transaction that results from a violation of subsection (a) of this section.

section.text: If one of the purposes of the solicitation or attempted solicitation is to change the racial composition of a neighborhood, a person may not solicit or attempt to solicit the listing of residential properties for sale or lease by:

paragraph.text: in person door-to-door solicitation;
telephone solicitation; or
mass distribution of circulars.

section.text: A person may not submit to the Commission any notice, statement, or other document under Subtitle 4 of this title that a person knows to be false or to contain any material misstatement of fact.
A person may not violate a suspension order issued under § 17-522 of this title.
A corporation, partnership, or other association may not:

paragraph.text: commit or cause any other person to commit any act that constitutes a ground for disciplinary action against a licensee under § 17-322 or § 17-328 of this title; or
violate or cause any other person to violate any other provision of this title.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of subsection (d) of this section, a person who violates any provision of the following sections of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction for a first offense is subject to a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both:
A corporation, partnership, or other association that violates § 17–612 of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine:

paragraph.text: not exceeding $5,000 for a first violation;
not exceeding $15,000 for a second violation; and
not exceeding $25,000 for a third or subsequent violation.
The Commission may impose on a person who violates any provision of this title a penalty not exceeding:

subparagraph.text: $5,000 for a first violation;
$15,000 for a second violation; and
$25,000 for a third or subsequent violation.

paragraph.text: In setting the amount of the penalty, the Board shall consider:

subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the harm caused by the violation;
the good faith of the violator;
any history of previous violations by the violator; and
any other relevant factors.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.
Any person found guilty of a second violation of any provision of the sections listed in subsection (a) of this section is subject to a fine not exceeding $15,000 or 2 years imprisonment or both.

Any person found guilty of a third or subsequent violation of any provision of the sections listed in subsection (a) of this section is subject to a fine not exceeding $25,000 or 3 years imprisonment or both.

section.text: A court shall report to the Commission for appropriate action under this title each conviction of a real estate broker, an associate real estate broker, or a real estate salesperson for a violation of any provision of the following sections of this title:
This title may be cited as the “Maryland Real Estate Brokers Act”.

Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, this title and all regulations adopted under this title shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2022.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Circumventional information” means information, including pass codes, that allows an individual to alter the operation of a security system.
“Circumventional information” does not include generic user or installation manuals.

subsection.text: “Firm” means a partnership or corporation.
“Firm member” means a partner of a partnership or an officer or director of a corporation.
“License” means a license issued by the Secretary or the Secretary’s designee to engage in the business of providing security systems services for compensation.
“Providing security systems services” means providing, on the premises of a person’s residential or commercial property, the service of:

paragraph.text: surveying the property for purposes of installing a security system;
physically installing, maintaining, or repairing a security system for the customer; or
responding to a distress call or an alarm sounding from a security system.

subsection.text: “Representative member” means a firm member who is appointed under this title to act on behalf of the firm.
“Secretary” means the Secretary of State Police or the Secretary’s designee.
“Security systems agency” means an individual or a firm that conducts a business that provides security systems services.
“Security systems technician” means a person who personally provides security systems services.

This title does not apply to an officer or employee of any unit of the United States, of any state, or of any county, municipal corporation, or other political subdivision of any state, while performing a duty of the office or employment.

paragraph.text: This title does not supersede any local law or ordinance in the State that establishes standards or qualifications for electricians or for electrical work involved in the installation of security systems or security alarms.
This title does not authorize an individual to perform electrical work that otherwise requires an electrician’s license under any State or local law or ordinance.

Except as provided in paragraph (4) of this subsection, this title supersedes any local law or ordinance in the State that requires registration, training, bonding, or insurance for security systems technicians or other individuals who have access to circumventional information.
This title does not preempt local governments from licensing or regulating security system agencies or security system users.
The licensing requirements of this title do not apply to a master electrician who:

subparagraph.text: currently is licensed in that occupation under State or local law; and
is acting only within the scope of that occupation.

paragraph.text: A master electrician may not:

subparagraph.text: personally provide security systems services unless the master electrician is registered as a security systems technician; or
obtain access to circumventional information unless the master electrician is registered as an individual with access to circumventional information.

subsection.text: This title does not apply to a person who sells security systems at a retail establishment or by means of a catalog or brochure for future delivery, provided that the person does not:

paragraph.text: enter the premises of the customer’s property; or
have access to circumventional information.

subsection.text: This title does not apply to a commercial property owner or its authorized agent performing the routine operation, including the changing of the passcodes, of a security system that protects the premises of the owner’s commercial property.
This title may not be construed to require:

paragraph.text: a person engaged in the business of providing security systems services for compensation to obtain more than one license under this title to provide security systems services;

a security systems technician, in addition to being registered under this title, to obtain a license under this title, if the security systems technician is employed by or under contract with a security systems agency; or
an individual who is licensed under this title to be registered under Subtitle 3A of this title.

section.text: Subject to the provisions of this title, the Secretary is responsible for:

paragraph.text: the licensing and regulation of security systems agencies in the State; and
the registration of security systems technicians and other individuals who have access to circumventional information.

subsection.text: In addition to any powers set forth elsewhere, the Secretary may:

paragraph.text: adopt regulations to carry out this title;
use any member of the Department of State Police, as necessary, to carry out and enforce this title; and
make inquiries and conduct an investigation regarding any applicant for a license or for registration.

subsection.text: In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere, the Secretary shall:

paragraph.text: adopt regulations that set standards for the licensure of security systems agencies;
adopt regulations that set standards for the registration of security systems technicians and other individuals who have access to circumventional information; and
keep a roster of individuals registered as security systems technicians or as individuals who have access to circumventional information.

section.text: The Secretary and all members of the Department of State Police:

paragraph.text: shall treat as confidential any information obtained through an investigation of an applicant for a license or for registration under this title; and

unless required by a court order, may not divulge to a person who is not a law enforcement officer any information obtained through an investigation of an applicant for a license or for registration under this title.

section.text: Except for the cost of the Maryland and national criminal records check, the Secretary shall pay all money collected under this title into the General Fund of the State.

Except as otherwise provided in this title, a person may not engage, or solicit to engage, in the business of providing security systems services in the State unless the person obtains a license and meets the requirements of § 18-401 of this title.

subsection.text: If the applicant for a license is a firm, the firm shall appoint a firm member as the representative member to make the application on behalf of the firm.
To qualify for a license, if an applicant is an individual, an applicant shall:

paragraph.text: be at least 18 years old; and
be of good moral character.

subsection.text: To qualify for a license, if the applicant is a firm, each firm member shall be:

paragraph.text: at least 18 years old; and
of good moral character.

subsection.text: The applicant shall meet any other requirements that the Secretary establishes for license applicants.
An applicant for a license shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the Secretary an application on the form that the Secretary provides;
submit the documents required by this section; and
pay to the Secretary an application fee of $150 which shall include the cost of the Maryland and national criminal records check.

subsection.text: The application form provided by the Secretary shall contain a statement advising the applicant that willfully making a false statement on an application is a misdemeanor, subject to a fine or imprisonment or both, as provided under § 18-504 of this title.
If the applicant is a firm, the representative member shall complete the application form and otherwise be responsible for the firm’s compliance with this section.

paragraph.text: The application shall be accompanied by at least two written recommendations for the applicant.
Each recommendation shall be signed, under oath, by a reputable citizen of the State.

An applicant for a license shall submit with the application a set of legible fingerprints of the applicant on a form approved by the Criminal Justice Information System Central Repository and the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
If the applicant is a firm, the applicant shall pay the cost of the fingerprint card records check for each firm member.

subsection.text: An applicant for a license shall submit with the application a copy of a bond or proof of insurance in accordance with the requirements of § 18-401 of this title.
The Secretary may waive the requirements of subsections (a)(2) and (3), (d), and (e) of this section and issue a license to an applicant who:

paragraph.text: provides adequate evidence that the applicant:

subparagraph.text: is licensed to engage in the business of providing security systems services in another state; and
became licensed in the other state:

sub-subparagraph.text: after meeting qualifications that are at least equivalent to those required in this State; and
after submitting to a State and national criminal records check; and

paragraph.text: pays to the Secretary a processing fee of $150.

subsection.text: Except for a license issued under § 18-303(g) of this subtitle, before issuing a license, the Secretary shall conduct a State and national criminal records check for each applicant who applies for a license.
If the applicant is a firm, the Secretary shall conduct a State and national criminal records check for each firm member.
The Secretary shall issue a license to each applicant who meets the requirements of this title.
The Secretary shall include on each license that the Secretary issues:

paragraph.text: the full name of the licensee;
the current address of the licensee;
the date of issuance of the license; and
the date on which the license expires.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, the Secretary shall issue to an individual licensee a pocket identification card that includes:

paragraph.text: a photograph of the licensee, supplied by the licensee; and
the license expiration date.
For each license issued under § 18-303(g) of this subtitle, the Secretary shall issue to an individual licensee a licensing certificate instead of a pocket identification card.
The licensing certificate shall be in a format approved by the Secretary.

subsection.text: While a license is in effect, it authorizes the licensee to engage in the business of providing security systems services.
An individual or a firm may qualify for a license as a security systems agency.
By regulation, the Secretary shall stagger the terms of the licenses.
Unless a license is renewed for a 3-year term as provided in this section, the license expires on the date the Secretary sets.
At least 1 month before a license expires, the Secretary shall mail to the agency, at the last known address of the agency:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

subparagraph.text: the date on which the current license expires;

that the Secretary must receive the renewal application and proof of insurance or bonding as required in § 18-401 of this title at least 15 days before the license expiration date for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the license expires;
the amount of the renewal fee;

that, if the complete renewal application and proof of insurance or bonding as required in § 18-401 of this title are not received at least 15 days before the license expiration date, a fee of $25 per day shall be charged against the agency until the day the license expires, at which time the agency shall be considered closed;
that an agency may not be issued a license under this title until all outstanding obligations are satisfied with the Secretary; and
that the submission of a false statement in the renewal application or the submission of altered or false documents that are otherwise required is cause for revocation of the agency license.

subsection.text: An agency periodically may renew the license for an additional 3-year term, if the license holder:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be licensed;
pays to the Secretary:

subparagraph.text: a renewal fee of $100;
the fee authorized under § 10-221(b)(7) of the Criminal Procedure Article for access to Maryland criminal history records;
the mandatory processing fee required by the Federal Bureau of Investigation for a national criminal history records check; and
any late fee required under this subtitle; and

paragraph.text: submits to the Secretary:

subparagraph.text: a renewal application on the form the Secretary provides;
two complete sets of the applicant’s legible fingerprints taken on forms approved by the Director of the Central Repository and the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation; and
satisfactory evidence of compliance with any other requirements under this section for renewal of registration.

subsection.text: In accordance with §§ 10-201 through 10-235 of the Criminal Procedure Article, the Central Repository shall forward to the applicant and the Department of State Police a printed statement of the applicant’s criminal history records information.

The Secretary may waive the national criminal history records check required under subsection (d) of this section for an applicant who was issued a license under § 18-303(g) of this subtitle if the applicant pays to the Secretary a processing fee of $100.

If the renewal application was submitted as required in subsection (d) of this section and the national criminal history records check required under this section is not completed before the licensee’s license expires, the Secretary shall allow the licensee to operate in a temporary license status if the licensee otherwise meets the requirements of this section.
A licensee may operate in a temporary license status at the time of renewal only if the renewal application and all required documents and fees were submitted by the expiration date of the license.
The temporary license status shall expire at the earlier of:

paragraph.text: the completion of the national criminal history records check of the applicant; or
the renewal or denial of the license.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall renew the license of each applicant who meets the requirements of this section.

paragraph.text: If the licensee is an individual, the licensee and each security systems technician employed by the licensee shall carry and display the license on demand of any customer or law enforcement officer.
If the licensee is a firm, each firm member and security systems technician employed by the firm shall carry and display a copy of the license on demand of any customer or law enforcement officer.

subsection.text: Each licensee shall record the license with the Secretary of State.
Each licensee shall give the Secretary written notice of any change of address within 10 business days after the change.

section.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 18-310 of this subtitle, the Secretary may deny a license to any applicant, reprimand any licensee, fine a licensee, or suspend or revoke a license if the applicant or licensee, or a firm member or employee of an applicant or licensee that is a firm:

paragraph.text: fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a license for the applicant or licensee or for another;
fraudulently or deceptively uses a license;
has a similar license denied, suspended, or revoked in another jurisdiction;
pleads guilty or nolo contendere to or is convicted of a felony, theft offense, or crime of moral turpitude;
aids an individual in obtaining or attempting to obtain fraudulently or deceptively licensure under this title as a security systems technician;
while not licensed, solicits to engage in or willfully engages in a business providing security systems services;
while not licensed, willfully advertises as a security systems technician;
willfully makes a false statement or misrepresentation in any renewal application or in any other document that the Secretary requires to be submitted; or
violates any other provision of this title or any regulation adopted by the Secretary under this title.

subsection.text: Before the Secretary takes any final action under § 18-309 of this subtitle, the Secretary shall give the person against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Secretary.
The Secretary shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The hearing notice to be given to the person shall be sent by certified mail to the last known address of the person at least 10 business days before the hearing.
The Secretary may administer oaths in connection with any proceeding under this section.
The person may be represented at the hearing by counsel.
If, after due notice, the person against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, nevertheless, the Secretary may hear and determine the matter.

section.text: Any person aggrieved by a final decision of the Secretary in a contested case, as defined in § 10-202 of the State Government Article, may take an appeal as allowed in Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
Except as otherwise provided in this title:

paragraph.text: an individual may not personally provide security systems services unless the individual is registered as a security systems technician;
a person licensed under this title may not employ or contract with an individual with access to circumventional information unless the individual is registered as required under this subtitle;
neither a licensee nor a registrant may provide access to circumventional information to an individual who is not registered under this subtitle; and
an employee of a person licensed under this title may not obtain access to circumventional information unless the employee is registered as an individual with access to circumventional information.

subsection.text: To qualify for registration as a security systems technician or other individual who has access to circumventional information, an applicant shall:

paragraph.text: be at least 18 years old; and
be of good moral character.

subsection.text: In addition to any other requirements and except for those applicants who survey properties only for the purpose of installing a security system, an applicant for registration as a security systems technician shall meet any training requirements that the Secretary establishes by regulation.

The State Department of Education, in conjunction with the Secretary, may establish by regulation a cooperative education program under which a minor may learn the security systems trade with on–site supervision by a security systems registrant under the auspices of cooperative education registration with the schools.
An applicant for registration shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the Secretary an application on the form that the Secretary provides;
submit the documents required by this section; and
pay to the Secretary:

subparagraph.text: an application fee that is the higher of $15 or an amount the Secretary determines based on actual processing costs; and
the cost of any background checks.

subsection.text: The application form provided by the Secretary shall contain a statement advising the applicant that willfully making a false statement on an application is a misdemeanor, subject to a fine or imprisonment or both, as provided under § 18-504 of this title.

An applicant for registration shall submit with the application a set of legible fingerprints of the applicant on forms approved by the Criminal Justice Information System Central Repository and the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
The Secretary may waive the requirements of this section and register an applicant who:

paragraph.text: provides adequate evidence that the applicant:

subparagraph.text: is licensed in another state to engage in the business of providing security systems services or registered in another state as a security systems technician or other individual who has access to circumventional information; and
became licensed or registered in the other state:

sub-subparagraph.text: after meeting qualifications that are at least equivalent to those required in this State; and
after submitting to a State and national criminal records check; and

paragraph.text: pays to the Secretary a processing fee that is the higher of $15 or an amount the Secretary determines based on actual processing costs.

subsection.text: A minor in an apprenticeship program approved by the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation or a cooperative education program established under § 18-3A-02 of this subtitle is not required to meet the criminal background check and fingerprint requirements of this section.
Except for registration under § 18-3A-03(d) of this subtitle, the Secretary shall conduct a State and national criminal records check of an applicant before registering the applicant.
An applicant shall pay to the Secretary the cost of any background checks before the applicant may be registered.
The Secretary shall register each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle.
The Secretary shall include on each registration that the Secretary issues:

paragraph.text: the full name of the registrant;
the current address of the registrant;
the date of issuance of the registration; and
the date on which the registration expires.

subsection.text: For all registrations other than temporary registrations, the Secretary shall issue to each registrant a pocket identification card that includes:

paragraph.text: a photograph of the registrant, supplied by the registrant; and
the expiration date of the registrant’s registration.

subsection.text: Each registrant shall give the Secretary written notice of any change of address within 10 business days after the change.

While an individual is registered as a security systems technician and employed by or under contract with a security systems agency licensed under this title, the individual is authorized to personally provide security systems services.

While an individual is registered as a security systems technician and employed by or under contract with a security systems agency licensed under this title, the individual is authorized to have access to circumventional information.
By regulation, the Secretary shall stagger the terms of the registrations under this subtitle.
Unless a registration is renewed for a 3-year term as provided in this section, the registration expires on the date the Secretary sets.
At least 90 days before a registration expires, the applicant shall deliver to the Secretary:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form;
the amount of the renewal fee; and
the amount of any late fee, as determined by the Secretary.

subsection.text: An individual periodically may renew a registration for an additional 3-year term if the individual:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be registered;
pays to the Secretary:

subparagraph.text: a renewal fee that is the higher of $15 or an amount which the Secretary determines based on the actual processing costs;
the fee authorized under § 10-221(b)(7) of the Criminal Procedure Article for access to Maryland criminal history records;
the mandatory processing fee required by the Federal Bureau of Investigation for a national criminal history records check; and
any late fee required under this subtitle; and

paragraph.text: submits to the Secretary:

subparagraph.text: a renewal application on the form the Secretary provides;
two complete sets of the applicant’s legible fingerprints taken on forms approved by the Director of the Central Repository and the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation; and
satisfactory evidence of compliance with any other requirements under this section for renewal of registration.

subsection.text: In accordance with §§ 10-201 through 10-235 of the Criminal Procedure Article, the Central Repository shall forward to the applicant and the Department of State Police a printed statement of the applicant’s criminal history records information.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, if a complete application for renewal of registration as required under this subtitle is not received by the Secretary at least 30 calendar days before the certification expires, the Secretary shall assess a late fee of $5 per day until the application is received by the Secretary.
The total amount of late fees assessed under this subsection may not exceed $150.
The Secretary may not register any applicant under this title if the applicant has outstanding late fee obligations.

subsection.text: The Secretary may waive the national criminal history records check required under subsection (d) of this section for an applicant who was registered under § 18-3A-03 of this subtitle if the applicant pays to the Secretary a processing fee of $15.

If the renewal application was submitted as required under this section and the national criminal history records check required under this section is not completed before a registration expires, the Secretary shall allow the applicant to operate in a temporary registration status if the applicant otherwise meets the requirements of this section.
The temporary registration status shall expire at the earlier of:

paragraph.text: the completion of the national criminal history records check of the applicant; or
the renewal or denial of the registration.
The Secretary shall renew the registration of each individual who meets the requirements of this section.

Within 5 days after the Secretary refuses to renew the registration of an individual under this title, the Secretary shall send written notice of the refusal to the individual who submitted the renewal application.
Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Secretary shall temporarily register any individual who:

subparagraph.text: does not have the training required under § 18-3A-02(b) of this subtitle but otherwise meets the requirements for registration under this title; or
does not have the State and national criminal records check required under § 18-3A-04(a) of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: If the Secretary determines after a preliminary background investigation that the issuance of a temporary registration to an individual would result in a potential threat to public safety, the Secretary may refuse to temporarily register that individual.

subsection.text: Temporary registration of a registrant under this section shall expire at the earlier of:

paragraph.text: if the temporary registration was issued pursuant to subsection (a)(1) of this section, acquisition by the registrant of the training required under § 18-3A-02(b) of this subtitle; or
if the temporary registration was issued pursuant to subsection (a)(2) of this section, completion of the State and national criminal records check required under § 18-3A-04(a) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: An applicant obtaining temporary registration under this section:

paragraph.text: shall receive a form of identification as determined by the Secretary; and
shall work under the supervision of an individual who has met the requirements of §§ 18-3A-02, 18-3A-03, and 18-3A-04 of this subtitle and is registered under § 18-3A-05 of this subtitle.

section.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 18-3A-10 of this subtitle, the Secretary may deny registration to any applicant, reprimand any registrant, fine any registrant, or suspend or revoke a registration if the applicant or registrant:

paragraph.text: fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a registration for the applicant or registrant or for another;
fraudulently or deceptively uses a registration;
has a similar license or registration denied, suspended, or revoked in another jurisdiction;
pleads guilty or nolo contendere to or is convicted of a felony, theft offense, or crime of moral turpitude;
aids an individual in obtaining or attempting to obtain fraudulently or deceptively registration under this title;

while not registered as a security systems technician and employed by or under contract with a security systems agency licensed under this title, solicits to engage in or willfully engages in personally providing security systems services;

while not registered as a security systems technician and employed by or under contract with a security systems agency licensed under this title, willfully advertises as a security systems technician;
willfully makes a false statement or misrepresentation in any renewal application or in any other document that the Secretary requires to be submitted; or
violates any other provision of this title or any regulation adopted by the Secretary under this title.

section.text: Before the Secretary denies the registration of an applicant under § 18-3A-09(4) of this subtitle, the Secretary shall consider the following factors:

paragraph.text: the length of time that has passed since the applicant pleaded guilty or nolo contendere or was convicted of the felony, theft offense, or crime of moral turpitude;
whether the applicant was a security systems technician prior to the requirement of registration under this subtitle; and
any evidence that the applicant has been a good citizen since the applicant pleaded guilty or nolo contendere or was convicted of the felony, theft offense, or crime of moral turpitude.
Before the Secretary takes any final action under § 18-3A-09 of this subtitle, the Secretary shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for either:

subparagraph.text: a hearing before the Secretary; or
a hearing before an advisory panel consisting of the following members appointed by the Secretary:

sub-subparagraph.text: a member of the Department of State Police;
a representative of the security systems industry;
one member who has engaged the services of a security systems agency; and
two members representing consumers.

paragraph.text: A hearing before an advisory panel under this section does not preclude a hearing before the Secretary.

subsection.text: The Secretary or the advisory panel shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The hearing notice to be given to the individual shall be sent by certified mail to the last known address of the individual at least 10 business days before the hearing.
The Secretary or the advisory panel may administer oaths in connection with any proceeding under this section.
The individual may be represented at the hearing by counsel.
If, after due notice, the individual against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, the Secretary or the advisory panel may, nevertheless, hear and determine the matter.

section.text: Any person aggrieved by a final decision of the Secretary in a contested case, as defined in § 10-202 of the State Government Article, may take an appeal as allowed in Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.

subsection.text: In order to obtain a license, an applicant shall:

subparagraph.text: execute a fidelity bond as provided in subsection (c) of this section; or
maintain general liability insurance as provided in subsection (d) of this section; and

paragraph.text: maintain in an office in the State, documents or other records that are made in the State or relate to a service performed in the State and make those records available for inspection by the Secretary for compliance with this title.

subsection.text: The Secretary may not issue or renew a license or registration unless the applicant, licensee, or registrant submits proof of compliance with subsection (a) of this section.

paragraph.text: The fidelity bond required by subsection (a)(1) of this section shall cover all individuals who:

subparagraph.text: are licensed to provide security systems services, are registered as security systems technicians, or have access to circumventional information; or
are applicants for a license or registration.

paragraph.text: The fidelity bond shall be used for the benefit of any person injured on the premises of a consumer of security systems services by any fraudulent or dishonest act of a licensee, a security systems technician, or other individual who has access to circumventional information that is willful or malicious.
The applicant for a license or registration shall submit a copy of the fidelity bond to the Secretary with the license or registration application.

subparagraph.text: The amount of the fidelity bond required under subsection (c)(1) of this section shall be at least $50,000.
The total liability of the surety to all insured persons under the fidelity bond may not exceed the sum of the fidelity bond.
If an employer’s fidelity bond is canceled, forfeited, or terminated by the surety, the surety shall immediately notify the Secretary.
If a surety fails to notify the Secretary as required by this paragraph, the fidelity bond shall continue in effect until the notice is given to the Secretary.

paragraph.text: General liability insurance required by subsection (a)(1)(ii) of this section shall be in the amount of at least $50,000.
An applicant for a license or registration shall submit proof of insurance meeting the requirements of paragraph (1) of this subsection to the Secretary with the application.
If the general liability insurance required under this section is canceled, the insured shall immediately notify the Secretary.

subsection.text: If an agency fails to maintain the required fidelity bond or liability insurance as required in this section, upon notification, the Secretary:

paragraph.text: shall suspend the license; and
may not reinstate the license until the agency submits proof of the required bond or insurance to the Secretary.

subsection.text: In addition to § 18-504 of this title, a court of competent jurisdiction may enjoin the operation of any employer who violates the requirements of this section.

section.text: The Department of State Police shall adopt regulations necessary to effectuate and enforce this subtitle. The regulations shall include a schedule of fines for violations of this subtitle that may be assessed by the Secretary under §§ 18-309 and 18-3A-09 of this title.
A person may not engage, attempt to engage, offer to engage, or solicit to engage in a business of providing security systems services in the State unless licensed by the Secretary.

Unless authorized under this title to engage in the business of providing security systems services, a person may not represent to the public, by use of the title “security systems agency” or “security systems technician”, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person is authorized to engage in the business of providing security systems services in the State.
A person may not willfully make a false statement on any application form or other document submitted to the Secretary under this title.

subsection.text: A person who violates any provision of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.

The fines assessed under §§ 18-309 and 18-3A-09 of this title may not exceed $5,000 per violation and shall be paid to the Secretary within 10 days after final adjudication of any hearing or the waiver of any hearing.

section.text: This title may be cited as the “Maryland Security Systems Technicians Act”.

Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, this title and all regulations adopted under this title shall terminate and be of no further force and effect after July 1, 2016.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Central Repository” means the Criminal Justice Information System Central Repository of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services.
“Certification card” means a card issued by the Secretary under § 19-405 of this title to an individual certified as a security guard.
“Firm” means a partnership or corporation.
“Firm member” means a partner of a partnership or an officer or director of a corporation.
“License” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a license issued by the Secretary to conduct a business to provide security guard services.
“Licensed security guard agency” means a person who is licensed by the Secretary to conduct a business that provides security guard services.
“Representative member” means a firm member who is appointed under § 19-302(b) of this title to act on behalf of the firm.
“Secretary”, unless the context requires otherwise, means the Secretary of State Police.

“Security guard” means an individual who provides security guard services to any person on behalf of a security guard agency, regardless of whether the individual is described as a security guard, watchman, or private patrolman or by other title.

paragraph.text: “Security guard agency” means a person who conducts a business that provides security guard services.
“Security guard agency” does not include a person that is primarily engaged in the business of owning, maintaining, or otherwise managing property.

subsection.text: “Security guard services” includes any activity that is performed for compensation as a security guard to protect any individual or property, except the activities of an individual while performing as:

paragraph.text: a marine guard or ship watchman, regardless of whether the guard or watchman is stationed aboard a ship or on a pier; or
a special police officer appointed and while performing under Title 3, Subtitle 3 of the Public Safety Article or § 16-16 of the Code of Public Local Laws of Baltimore City.

section.text: Subject to the provisions of this title, the Secretary is responsible for the licensing of security guard agencies and the regulation of those persons who provide security guard services in the State.

subsection.text: In addition to any powers set forth elsewhere, the Secretary may:

paragraph.text: adopt regulations to carry out this title;
use any member of the Department of State Police, as necessary, to carry out and enforce this title; and
make inquiries and conduct an investigation regarding any applicant:

subparagraph.text: for a license; or
for employment with a licensee as a security guard.

subsection.text: In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere, the Secretary shall:

paragraph.text: adopt regulations that set standards for the certification of employees of security guard agencies as security guards;
keep a roster of the individuals certified as security guards under this title, including on the roster:

subparagraph.text: the names of individuals certified;
the name of the licensed security guard agency with or by which each individual is associated or employed; and
any other information that the Secretary considers appropriate; and

paragraph.text: adopt by regulation a schedule of fines for violations of this title that may be assessed by the Secretary under §§ 19-313 and 19-408 of this title.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, a person shall be licensed by the Secretary as a security guard agency before the person may:

paragraph.text: conduct a business that provides security guard services in the State; and
solicit to engage in a business that provides security guard services in the State.

subsection.text: An individual or a firm may qualify for a license as a security guard agency.
To qualify for a license, an applicant shall meet the requirements of this section.
If the applicant is a firm, the firm shall appoint a firm member as the representative member to make the application on behalf of the firm.

paragraph.text: If the applicant is an individual, the applicant shall be of good character and reputation.
If the applicant is a firm, each firm member shall be of good character and reputation.

subsection.text: The individual applicant or the representative member shall be at least 25 years old.
The applicant shall meet the experience requirements of § 19-303 of this subtitle.
In this section, “organized police agency” means:

paragraph.text: a police department of the State or of a county or municipal corporation of the State;
a private police department that is allowed to enroll its officers in approved Maryland Police Training Commission schools and academies; or
a law enforcement agency of the United States, of any state, or of any county or municipal corporation of any state.

subsection.text: An individual applicant or, if the applicant is a firm, the representative member shall have:

paragraph.text: at least 5 years experience as a full-time private detective certified under Title 13 of this article;
at least:

subparagraph.text: 5 years of experience as a full-time police officer with an organized police agency; and
completed successfully a police officer training course that is recognized and approved by the Maryland Police Training Commission;

paragraph.text: at least 3 years of experience in an investigative capacity as a detective while serving as a police officer with an organized police agency;
at least:

subparagraph.text: 3 years of experience in an investigative capacity in any unit of the United States, of the State, or of a county or municipal corporation of the State for the purpose of law enforcement; and
completed successfully the police officer training that is recognized and approved by the Maryland Police Training Commission;

paragraph.text: at least:

subparagraph.text: 5 years of experience as a full-time fire investigator for a fire department or law enforcement agency of the State or of a county or municipal corporation of the State; and
completed successfully the training certified by the Maryland Police Training Commission or the Maryland Fire-Rescue Education and Training Commission; or

paragraph.text: at least:

subparagraph.text: 5 years of experience as a full-time correctional supervisor in a correctional facility in the State; and
completed successfully the training required by the Correctional Training Commission.

paragraph.text: An applicant for a license shall:

subparagraph.text: submit to the Secretary an application on the form that the Secretary provides;
submit the documents required under this section; and
pay to the Secretary the fees required under subsection (b) of this section.

paragraph.text: If the applicant is a firm, the representative member shall complete the application form and otherwise be responsible for the firm’s compliance with this section.
An applicant for a license shall pay to the Secretary an application fee of:

subparagraph.text: $200, if the applicant is an individual; or
$375, if the applicant is a firm; and
the fees authorized under subsection (c) of this section.
As part of the application for a license, the applicant shall submit to the Secretary the fingerprints required under subsection (c) of this section.
If the applicant is a firm, the applicant shall pay the cost of the fingerprint card record checks for each firm member.

paragraph.text: The Department of State Police shall apply to the Central Repository for a State and national criminal history records check for each applicant.
As part of the application for a criminal history records check, the Department of State Police shall submit to the Central Repository:

subparagraph.text: two complete sets of the applicant’s legible fingerprints taken on forms approved by the Director of the Central Repository and the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation;
the fee authorized under § 10-221(b)(7) of the Criminal Procedure Article for access to Maryland criminal history records; and
the mandatory processing fee required by the Federal Bureau of Investigation for a national criminal history records check.

paragraph.text: In accordance with §§ 10-201 through 10-235 of the Criminal Procedure Article, the Central Repository shall forward to the applicant and the Department of State Police a printed statement of the applicant’s criminal history record information.
Information obtained from the Central Repository under this section shall be:

subparagraph.text: confidential and may not be disseminated; and
used only for the purpose authorized by this section.

paragraph.text: The subject of a criminal history records check under this section may contest the contents of the printed statement issued by the Central Repository as provided in § 10-223 of the Criminal Procedure Article.
If the applicant is an individual, the application form provided by the Secretary shall require:

subparagraph.text: the name of the applicant;
the age of the applicant;
the address of the applicant; and
the current and previous employment of the applicant.

paragraph.text: If the applicant is a firm, the application form provided by the Secretary shall require:

subparagraph.text: a list of all of the firm members; and
for each firm member, the same information required regarding an individual applicant under paragraph (1) of this subsection.

paragraph.text: For all applicants, the application form shall require:

subparagraph.text: the address of the applicant’s proposed principal place of business and of each proposed branch office;
any trade or fictitious name that the applicant intends to use while conducting the business of the security guard agency;
the submission of a facsimile of any trademark that the applicant intends to use while conducting the business of the security guard agency; and
as the Secretary considers appropriate, any other information to assist in the evaluation of:

sub-subparagraph.text: an individual applicant; or
if the applicant is a firm, any firm member.

subsection.text: The application form provided by the Secretary shall contain a statement advising the applicant that willfully making a false statement on an application is a misdemeanor, subject to a fine or imprisonment or both, as provided under §§ 19-605 and 19-607 of this title.

paragraph.text: If the applicant is an individual, the application form shall be signed, under oath, by the individual.

If the applicant is a firm, the application form shall be signed, under oath, by the representative member, as the representative member, and shall provide proof to the Secretary that the representative member is a member of the firm.
If the applicant is an individual, the application shall be accompanied by at least three names of individuals who can attest to the character of the applicant.
If the applicant is a firm, the application shall be accompanied by at least three names of individuals who can attest to the character of each firm member.

subsection.text: An applicant for a license who intends to employ at least five individuals as security guards shall submit with the application proof of commercial general liability insurance, including errors and omissions and completed operations with a $1,000,000 total aggregate minimum, as required under § 19-504 of this title.
In addition to meeting the other requirements of this section, a nonresident applicant shall submit a consent and any related document, as required by § 19-505 of this title.

section.text: The Secretary may not issue a license to an applicant whose trade or fictitious name or trademark is so similar to that used by another licensee that the public may be confused or misled by the similarity.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall issue a license to each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle.
The Secretary shall issue an agency license certificate to each licensed security guard agency and a branch office certificate for each proposed branch office.
The Secretary shall include on each agency license certificate that the Secretary issues:

subparagraph.text: the full name of the licensee;
the location of the principal office and of each branch office of the licensed security guard agency;
the date of issuance of the license;
the date on which the license expires; and
the name of the representative member, if the licensee is a firm.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall include on each branch office certificate:

subparagraph.text: the full name of the licensee;
the location of the principal office of the licensee and of the agency branch office for which the certificate is issued;
the date of issuance of the branch office certificate;
the date on which the license of the licensee expires; and
the name and agency address of the representative member, if the licensee is applying on behalf of a firm.

section.text: While a license is in effect, it authorizes the licensee to:

paragraph.text: conduct a business that provides security guard services for compensation or for hire;
maintain an office for the conduct of business at each location stated in the security guard agency license certificate;
employ individuals as security guards to provide security guard services to the public on behalf of the licensee; and
represent the licensee to the public as a licensed security guard agency.

subsection.text: By regulation, the Secretary shall stagger the terms of the licenses.
Unless a license is renewed for a 3-year term as provided in this section, the license expires on the date the Secretary sets.
At least 1 month before a license expires, the Secretary shall mail to the licensee, at the last known address of the licensee:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

subparagraph.text: the date on which the current license expires;

that the Secretary must receive the renewal application and the statements required under § 19-309 of this subtitle, at least 15 days before the license expiration date, for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the license expires;
the amount of the renewal fee;

that, if the statements required under § 19-309 of this subtitle are not received at least 15 days before the license expiration date, a fee of $10 per day shall be charged against the licensee until the statements are received; and
that the submission of a false statement in the renewal application or in the annual statements is cause for revocation of the license.

subsection.text: A licensee periodically may renew the license for an additional 3-year term, if the licensee:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be licensed;
pays to the Secretary:

subparagraph.text: a renewal fee of:

sub-subparagraph.text: $200, if the licensee is an individual; or
$400, if the licensee is a firm;

subparagraph.text: payment for the cost of a fingerprint card record check by the Federal Bureau of Investigation; and
any late fee required under § 19-309 of this subtitle; and

paragraph.text: submits to the Secretary:

subparagraph.text: a renewal application on the form that the Secretary provides;
a complete set of the applicant’s legible fingerprints taken on federal fingerprint cards;
the statements required under § 19-309 of this subtitle and any other documentation that may be required by the Secretary to renew the agency license under this subtitle; and
two photographs of the applicant in a format approved by the Secretary.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall renew the license of each licensee who meets the requirements of this section.
As a condition for license renewal, a licensee shall submit to the Secretary with the renewal application:

paragraph.text: a certification or, as authorized by the Secretary, other documentation that the licensed security guard agency has paid, for the past 3 years, all withholding and Social Security taxes;

a certification or, as authorized by the Secretary, other documentation that the licensed security guard agency has paid, for the past 3 years, all other obligations payable for the employees of the licensed security guard agency to the State or the federal government;

a certificate from an insurance carrier or, as authorized by the Secretary, other documentation showing that the licensed security guard agency has in effect commercial general and workers’ compensation insurance for its covered employees, as defined in § 9-101 of the Labor and Employment Article; and

a certificate from the Comptroller’s Office or, as authorized by the Secretary, other documentation showing that the State income tax of the licensed security guard agency has been paid for the past 3 years.

subsection.text: If the Secretary does not receive the documents required under subsection (a) of this section at least 15 days before the license expiration date, the Secretary shall charge the licensee a late fee of $10 per day until the documents are received.
The Secretary may inspect any of the business records of a licensee that relate to any matter that is subject to certification or documentation under this section.
Each licensee shall maintain an office in the State.
Each licensee shall keep in an office in the State all files or other records that:

paragraph.text: are made in the State; and
relate to any business activities in the State.
Within 5 days after the change, a licensee shall submit to the Secretary written notice of:

subparagraph.text: the addition of a branch office; and
any change in the address or telephone number of an existing office.

paragraph.text: The licensee shall submit with the notice:

subparagraph.text: the agency license certificate; and
if the proposed change affects an existing branch office, the branch office certificate for that office.

paragraph.text: The Secretary may:

subparagraph.text: endorse the change on the agency license certificate and, if applicable, on the branch office certificate of the affected branch office; or
issue a new agency license certificate and, if applicable, a new branch office certificate, both of which shall set forth the same date as the original agency license certificate.

subsection.text: Within 5 days after the occurrence, a firm shall submit to the Secretary written notice of:

paragraph.text: the withdrawal of any firm member; and
the death of any firm member.

subsection.text: Each licensed security guard agency shall display at all times:

paragraph.text: the agency license certificate in a conspicuous place in the principal office of the security guard agency; and
each branch office certificate in a conspicuous place in the agency branch office for which the certificate was issued.
If an agency license certificate or branch office certificate is lost or destroyed, the licensee immediately shall notify the Secretary.
On receipt of notice of the loss or destruction of an agency license certificate or branch office certificate, the Secretary may issue a duplicate.

subsection.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 19-315 of this subtitle, the Secretary may deny a license to any applicant, reprimand any licensee, fine any licensee or agency, or suspend or revoke a license if the applicant or licensee:

paragraph.text: fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a license for the applicant or licensee or for another;
fraudulently or deceptively uses a license;
aids an individual to obtain or to attempt to obtain fraudulently or deceptively certification under this title as a security guard;
while not licensed, solicits to engage in or willfully engages in a business providing security guard services in the State;
while not licensed, willfully advertises:

subparagraph.text: as a security guard agency; or
the provision of security guard services;

paragraph.text: willfully makes a false statement or misrepresentation that an individual is or was in the employ of the applicant or licensee;
willfully makes a false statement or misrepresentation in any renewal application, in any annual statement, or in any other report or document that the Secretary requires to be submitted;
fails to notify the Secretary about any change among the firm members or in the address of the principal office or any branch office of a licensee;
fails to maintain the liability insurance required under § 19-504 of this title; or
violates any other provision of this title.

subsection.text: For purposes of this section, an act or omission of any principal, agent, or employee of an applicant or licensee may be construed to be the act or omission of the applicant or licensee, as well as of the principal, agent, or employee.
Subject to this section, the Secretary shall commence proceedings under § 19-313 of this subtitle on the Secretary’s own complaint or on a complaint made to the Secretary by any person.

paragraph.text: A complaint shall:

subparagraph.text: be in writing;
be signed by the complainant; and
state specifically the facts on which the complaint is based.

paragraph.text: If a complaint is made by any person other than the Secretary, the complaint shall be made under oath by the person who submits the complaint.

On receipt of a complaint that alleges facts that are grounds for action under § 19-313 of this subtitle, the Secretary shall appoint an officer of the Department of State Police, with the rank of lieutenant or above, as the investigating officer for the complaint.
The investigating officer may assign responsibility for conducting the investigation to other members of the Department of State Police.

On conclusion of the investigation, the investigating officer shall determine whether there is a reasonable basis to believe that there are grounds for disciplinary action under § 19-313 of this subtitle.
If the investigating officer finds a reasonable basis as provided under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Secretary shall act on the complaint as provided under § 19-315 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 10-226 of the State Government Article, before the Secretary takes any final action under § 19-313 of this subtitle, the Secretary shall give the person against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Secretary.
The Secretary shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Secretary may administer oaths in connection with any proceeding under this section.
The hearing notice to be given to the person shall be written and sent at least 10 days before the hearing.
The person may be represented at the hearing by counsel.
