If, after due notice, the person against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, nevertheless the Secretary may hear and determine the matter.

Within 5 days after the Secretary suspends or revokes the license of a person, the person shall surrender to the Secretary the agency license certificate and each branch office certificate of the person.
The Secretary may not refund to a person whose license is suspended or revoked any fee paid under this title.

Except as provided under subsection (b) of this section, a licensed security guard agency may provide an individual for hire as a security guard only if the individual is certified by the Secretary as a security guard.
A licensed security guard agency may provide an uncertified individual for hire as a security guard if:

paragraph.text: the security guard agency has submitted to the Secretary the application of the individual for certification as a security guard, fingerprint cards, and records fee as required under § 19-402(b) of this subtitle; and
the Secretary has not disapproved the application; or
the individual has obtained and currently possesses certification by the Maryland Police and Corrections Training Commission as a police officer.

subsection.text: To qualify for certification as a security guard, an individual shall:

paragraph.text: meet the standards set by the Secretary;
be an employee of or an applicant for employment with a licensed security guard agency;
be of good moral character and reputation;
submit to the licensed security guard agency, for forwarding to the Secretary:

subparagraph.text: a sworn application on the form the Secretary provides;
the fingerprints required under § 19-304(c) of this title; and
a nonrefundable application fee of $15; and

paragraph.text: pay to the licensed security guard agency, for forwarding to the Secretary, the fees authorized under § 19-304(c) of this title.

subsection.text: On receipt from an applicant for certification as a security guard, a licensed security guard agency shall forward to the Secretary the applicant’s application form, fingerprint cards, and criminal history records check fees.
The Secretary shall certify as a security guard each individual whose application has been submitted as required by this subtitle and who meets the requirements of this subtitle.

Within 5 days after the Secretary denies the application of an individual for certification as a security guard, the Secretary shall send written notice of the denial to the licensed security guard agency that submitted the application.

section.text: While certification of an individual as a security guard is in effect, the certification authorizes the individual to represent to the public that the individual is certified by the Secretary for employment as a security guard.

subsection.text: By regulation, the Secretary shall stagger the terms of the certifications.
Unless a certification is renewed for a 3-year term as provided in this section, the certification expires on the date the Secretary sets.
At least 90 days before a certification expires, the applicant shall mail to the Secretary:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form;
the amount of the renewal fee; and
the amount of any late fee, as determined by the Secretary.

subsection.text: An individual periodically may renew the certification for an additional 3-year term, if the individual:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be certified;
pays to the Secretary:

subparagraph.text: a renewal fee of $10;
payment for the cost of a fingerprint card record check by the Federal Bureau of Investigation; and
any late fee required under this subtitle; and

paragraph.text: submits to the Secretary a renewal application on the form that the Secretary provides.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, if a complete application for renewal of certification as required under this subtitle is not received by the Secretary on or before the first business day of the next calendar month immediately following the renewal date, the Secretary shall assess a late fee of $5 per day until the application is received by the Secretary.

subparagraph.text: The Secretary may not charge a late fee under paragraph (1) of this subsection if the applicant did not make timely renewal because of incapacity, hospitalization, being called to active military duty, or other hardship.
The total amount of late fees assessed against an applicant under this subsection may not exceed $150.

paragraph.text: The Secretary may not certify any applicant under this subtitle if the applicant has outstanding late fee obligations.
The Secretary shall renew the certification of each individual who meets the requirements of this section.

Within 5 days after the Secretary refuses to renew the certification of an individual as a security guard, the Secretary shall send written notice of the refusal to the individual who submitted the renewal application.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall issue to each individual who is certified as a security guard under this subtitle a certification card that identifies the individual as a certified security guard.

paragraph.text: Subject to this subsection, the Secretary shall determine the form and content of the certification card.
The certification card shall be of a size and made of materials appropriate for its intended use, as provided under § 19-406 of this subtitle.
The certification card shall contain:

subparagraph.text: a statement that in substance specifies that the individual is certified by the Secretary as a security guard;
any information that the Secretary considers appropriate to:

sub-subparagraph.text: identify the individual; or
specify the authority of the individual; and

subparagraph.text: the date on which the certification expires.

subsection.text: At any time that a certified security guard provides a security guard service, the security guard shall carry the certification card issued under § 19-405 of this subtitle.
On request of a law enforcement officer, a certified security guard shall show the security guard’s certification card.
Whenever a security guard is in uniform, the security guard may wear a badge that is:

paragraph.text: of a design approved by the Secretary; and
issued by the licensed security guard agency that employs the security guard.

subsection.text: Whenever a security guard is in uniform, the security guard shall clearly display and wear the clearance card issued by the Secretary which identifies the security guard.

section.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 19-410 of this subtitle, the Secretary may deny certification as a security guard to any applicant, reprimand or fine any individual certified as a security guard, or suspend, revoke, or refuse to renew the certification of an individual:

paragraph.text: for any applicable ground under § 19-313 of this title;
if the applicant or individual fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain certification as a security guard for the applicant or individual or for another;
if the applicant or individual fails to maintain the standards set by the Secretary for certification as a security guard; or
if, under the laws of the United States or of any state, the applicant or individual pleads guilty or nolo contendere to or is convicted of:

subparagraph.text: a felony; or
a misdemeanor that is directly related to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or individual to be certified as a security guard.

subsection.text: Subject to this section, the Secretary shall commence proceedings under § 19-408 of this subtitle on the Secretary’s own complaint or on a complaint made to the Secretary by any person.

paragraph.text: A complaint shall:

subparagraph.text: be in writing;
be signed by the complainant; and
state specifically the facts on which the complaint is based.

paragraph.text: If a complaint is made by any person other than the Secretary the complaint shall be made under oath by the person who submits the complaint.

On receipt of a complaint that alleges facts that are grounds for action under § 19-408 of this subtitle, the Secretary shall appoint an officer of the Department of State Police, with the rank of lieutenant or above, as the investigating officer for the complaint.
The investigating officer may assign responsibility for conducting the investigation to other members of the Department of State Police.

On conclusion of the investigation, the investigating officer shall determine whether there is a reasonable basis to believe that there are grounds for disciplinary action under § 19-408 of this subtitle.
If the investigating officer finds a reasonable basis as provided under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Secretary shall act on the complaint as provided under § 19-410 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 10-226 of the State Government Article, before the Secretary takes any final action under § 19-408 of this subtitle, the Secretary shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Secretary.
The Secretary shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Secretary may administer oaths in connection with any proceeding under this section.
The hearing notice to be given to the individual shall be written and sent at least 10 days before the hearing.
The individual may be represented at the hearing by counsel.
If, after due notice, the individual against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, nevertheless the Secretary may hear and determine the matter.

section.text: Within 5 days after the Secretary suspends or revokes the certification of an individual as security guard, the individual shall surrender to the Secretary the certification card of the individual.
A licensed security guard agency is responsible for the acts of each of its employees while the employee is conducting the business of the agency.

subsection.text: The offices of each security guard agency shall be supervised by an individual who:

subparagraph.text: holds, as an individual, the license of the security guard agency; or
is the representative member of the security guard agency appointed under § 19-302(b) of this title; and

paragraph.text: has been investigated and approved by the Secretary under this title.

subsection.text: If a security guard agency is a firm, the agency shall notify the Secretary about:

paragraph.text: the identity of the individual serving as the representative member of the agency; and
each vacancy in that position.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a security guard agency shall appoint a representative member within 90 days after a vacancy occurs in the position.
If the vacancy is caused by the death of or an incapacitating injury to the representative member, the security guard agency shall appoint a replacement within 180 days after the vacancy occurs.

subsection.text: If a licensed security guard agency fails to appoint a representative member as required under subsection (c) of this section, the license of the security guard agency:

paragraph.text: is suspended automatically; and
shall remain suspended until the agency complies with the requirements.

subsection.text: The Secretary may adopt regulations to carry out this section.
A security guard agency that employs five or more individuals as security guards shall:

paragraph.text: maintain commercial general liability insurance, including errors and omissions and completed operations with a $1,000,000 total aggregate minimum; and
submit proof of the required insurance to the Secretary.

If an applicant for a license intends to employ five or more individuals as security guards, the applicant shall submit proof of the liability insurance required under subsection (a) of this section to the Secretary with the license application.
The Secretary may not issue a license to an applicant to whom the insurance requirements of this section would apply unless the applicant submits proof of the insurance.

subsection.text: If the insurance required for a security guard agency under this section is canceled, forfeited, or otherwise terminated, both the security guard agency and the insurer shall notify the Secretary.
If a security guard agency fails to maintain the liability insurance required under this section, the license of the security guard agency:

paragraph.text: is suspended automatically;
shall remain suspended until the agency complies with the requirements; and
may not be reinstated until the agency submits proof of the required insurance to the Secretary.

subsection.text: A nonresident applicant for a license shall submit to the Secretary of State a consent, as provided under this section.
The consent required under this section shall:

paragraph.text: specify that service of process on the Secretary of State shall bind the applicant in any action, suit, or proceeding brought against the applicant;
specify that an action, suit, or proceeding may be brought against the applicant in any county where:

subparagraph.text: the cause of action arose; or
the plaintiff resides; and

paragraph.text: be signed by the representative member of the applicant.

subsection.text: In addition to submitting a consent, a nonresident applicant shall submit to the Secretary of State a certified copy of a resolution adopted by the firm that confirms that the firm members, board of directors, or other managing board of the firm authorized the representative member to execute and submit the consent on behalf of the firm.
An applicant who is required under this section to submit a consent or a consent and authorization to the Secretary of State shall submit copies of the signed documents to the Secretary.
The Secretary may not issue a license to a nonresident applicant, unless the nonresident applicant complies with the requirements of subsections (a) through (d) of this section.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, service of process on the Secretary of State binds a person who has submitted a consent to the Secretary of State, as required under this section.

If service of process is made on the Secretary of State as authorized under this section, the person initiating the action, suit, or proceeding immediately shall send a copy, by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the principal office in the State of the person against whom the action, suit, or proceeding is directed.
As to any person who submits a consent as required under this section, any action, suit, or proceeding may be brought in any county where:

subparagraph.text: the cause of action arose; or
the plaintiff resides.

subsection.text: A security guard agency may not divulge information obtained while providing services unless:

paragraph.text: directed by the client for whom the services are provided;
authorized by subsection (b) of this section; or
required by law.

subsection.text: If, while providing services, a security guard agency obtains any information about a criminal offense, the agency may divulge the information to:

paragraph.text: a law enforcement officer;
the Attorney General or a representative of the Attorney General; or
a State’s Attorney or a representative of a State’s Attorney.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, an individual who is employed by a security guard agency may not divulge to anyone other than to authorized staff of the agency any information that:

paragraph.text: was acquired by the employee or other agency staff while providing services for the agency; and
relates to the assignment in which services are provided.

subsection.text: An employee of a security guard agency may divulge information that is restricted under subsection (c) of this section:

paragraph.text: as directed by the security guard agency; or
on a request made by the Secretary in the course of an investigation by the Secretary.

subsection.text: In this section, “agency equipment” means a badge, clothing, or other equipment that:

paragraph.text: belongs to a security guard agency; and
bears the name, trade name, or trademark of the security guard agency.

subsection.text: If a security guard agency issues agency equipment for use by an individual who is associated with or employed by the agency, the individual shall return the agency equipment to the agency within 10 days after:

paragraph.text: the termination of the individual’s association or employment with the agency; or
the written request of an authorized representative of the agency.

section.text: If a certified security guard loses a certification card, the security guard immediately shall give the Secretary notice of the loss and the circumstances regarding the loss.

A person may not engage in, attempt to engage in, offer to engage in, or solicit to engage in the business of providing security guards for hire in the State unless licensed as a security guard agency by the Secretary.

subsection.text: Unless authorized under this title to engage in business for the purpose of providing security guard services, a person may not represent to the public, by use of a title, including “licensed security guard agency”, “security guard agency”, or “security guards”, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person is authorized to engage in the business of providing security guard services in the State.

Unless an individual is certified as a security guard under this title, the individual may not represent to the public, by use of a title, including “certified security guard”, or by use of a badge or identification card, that the individual is certified as a security guard under this title.
Except as authorized under this title, a security guard agency may not provide any person with a badge or a certification card or other document indicating that any individual is a security guard.
A certified security guard may not lend the security guard’s certification card or badge to another person or allow another person to use or display the card or badge.
Regardless of any association that an individual may have with a security guard agency, unless authorized under this title, the individual may not wear or carry a badge that:

paragraph.text: represents that the individual is a security guard; or
otherwise represents that the individual is associated with a security guard agency.
A licensee may not display or allow to be displayed the agency license certificate at any location other than the principal office of the licensee, as specified in the certificate.
A licensee may not display or allow to be displayed a branch office certificate at any location other than the branch office specified in the certificate.

subsection.text: A licensee may not knowingly alter, deface, or destroy or knowingly allow the alteration, defacement, or destruction of an agency license certificate or branch office certificate.

section.text: A person may not willfully make a false statement on any application form, annual statement, or other document submitted to the Secretary under this title.
An individual whom a licensee employs as a security guard may not willfully make a false statement or report to the licensee about services provided by the licensee.

subsection.text: A person who violates any provision of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.

The fines assessed under §§ 19-313 and 19-408 of this title may not exceed $5,000 per violation, or a maximum aggregate of $10,000 for a 2-year license term, and shall be paid to the Secretary within 10 days after final adjudication of any hearing or upon the waiver of any hearing.

Notwithstanding the provisions of §§ 19-313 and 19-408 of this title, the Secretary may fine either the licensed agency or the individual working on behalf of the licensed agency, but not both, for the same violation.

section.text: This title may be cited as the “Maryland Security Guards Act”.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.

“License” means a license issued by the Secretary to operate a business that provides monitoring services for a fee to individuals who are under a court order that requires monitoring by a private home detention monitoring agency.

“Licensed private home detention monitoring agency” means a person who is licensed by the Secretary to conduct a business that provides monitoring services for a fee to individuals who are under a court order that requires monitoring by a private home detention monitoring agency.

“Private home detention monitor” means an employee of a licensed private home detention monitoring agency who personally monitors individuals who are under a court order that requires monitoring by a private home detention monitoring agency.

“Private home detention monitoring agency” means a person who conducts a business that provides monitoring services for a fee to individuals who are under a court order that requires monitoring by a private home detention monitoring agency.
“Secretary” means the Secretary of Public Safety and Correctional Services.
In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere, the Secretary shall adopt and enforce regulations to carry out this title, including regulations that establish:

paragraph.text: minimum standards for electronic equipment capable of monitoring 24 hours per day individuals who are under a court order that requires monitoring by a private home detention monitoring agency;
minimum training and experience requirements for a private home detention monitoring agency licensee and for a private home detention monitor; and
the minimum number of private home detention monitors that shall be on duty in relation to the number of defendants being monitored.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall:

paragraph.text: maintain a roster of licensed private home detention monitoring agencies that includes:

subparagraph.text: a telephone number at which a person who operates a licensed private home detention monitoring agency can be reached during normal business hours; and
a telephone or pager number at which a person who operates a licensed private home detention monitoring agency can be reached during nonbusiness hours;

paragraph.text: annually disseminate the roster of licensed private home detention monitoring agencies to:

subparagraph.text: the administrative judge for the District Court in each district;
the administrative judge for the circuit court in each county; and
the Administrative Office of the Courts; and

paragraph.text: notify the agencies listed in paragraph (2) of this subsection when the license of a private home detention monitoring agency is suspended or revoked.

section.text: A person shall be licensed by the Secretary as a private home detention monitoring agency before operating a business that provides monitoring services for a fee to individuals who are under a court order that requires monitoring by a private home detention monitoring agency.

subsection.text: To qualify for a license, an applicant shall meet the requirements of this section.
The applicant and anyone the applicant employs as a private home detention monitor shall be of good character and reputation.
The applicant and all individuals employed as private home detention monitors shall satisfy the minimum training and experience requirements provided in regulations adopted by the Secretary.

paragraph.text: An applicant for a license shall submit to the Secretary:

subparagraph.text: an application on the form that the Secretary provides; and
an application fee of $500.

paragraph.text: The application fee is nonrefundable.

The application form provided by the Secretary shall contain a statement advising the applicant that willfully making a false statement on an application is a misdemeanor, subject to a fine or imprisonment or both, as provided under § 20-701 of this title.
The applicant shall sign the application under oath.

subsection.text: In addition to any other information that the Secretary requires, the applicant shall provide:

paragraph.text: the name, date of birth, and residence address of the applicant;
the address of the applicant’s proposed principal place of business and of each proposed branch office;
a telephone number at which the applicant can be reached during normal business hours;
a telephone or pager number that can be used to reach the applicant during nonbusiness hours; and
the name and permanent address of each individual the applicant intends to employ as a private home detention monitor.

subsection.text: An applicant for a license shall submit with the application form:

paragraph.text: a bond in accordance with the requirements of § 20-601 of this title; and
proof of liability insurance, as required under § 20-602 of this title.

section.text: Before an individual may begin working as a private home detention monitor:

paragraph.text: the private home detention monitoring agency shall submit to the Secretary, on the form that the Secretary provides, the name of the individual; and
the individual shall apply for State and national criminal history records checks under § 20-305 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: In this section, “Central Repository” means the Criminal Justice Information System Central Repository of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services.

An applicant for a license under this title and an individual whose name must be submitted under § 20-303(c)(5) of this subtitle shall apply to the Central Repository for State and national criminal history records checks on a form approved by the Director of the Central Repository.
For each individual applying for State and national criminal history records checks under subsection (b) of this section, the Central Repository shall:

paragraph.text: notify the Secretary of the receipt of the application for State and national criminal history records checks;
process the State and national criminal history records checks and forward to the Secretary and the individual a printed statement listing the finding of a felony conviction; and

process an update of the initial State criminal history records check and forward to the Secretary a revised printed statement listing the finding of a felony conviction for an offense occurring in the State after the date of the initial criminal history records check.

subsection.text: An individual applying for State and national criminal history records checks shall submit to the Central Repository:

paragraph.text: a complete set of legible fingerprints taken at any designated State or local law enforcement office in the State or other location approved by the Secretary;
the mandatory processing fee required by the Federal Bureau of Investigation for a national criminal history records check; and
the fee authorized under § 10-221(b)(7) of the Criminal Procedure Article for access to Maryland criminal history records.

subsection.text: A private home detention monitoring agency or an applicant for a license to operate a private home detention monitoring agency may pay the fees required in subsection (d) of this section for an individual it intends to employ as a private home detention monitor.
Information obtained by the Secretary under this section shall be confidential and may not:

paragraph.text: be used for any purpose other than that for which it was disseminated; and
be redisseminated.

subsection.text: This section applies to an individual required to apply for State and national criminal history records checks under this subtitle.
An individual may contest the finding of a felony conviction reported in a printed statement issued by the Department as provided in this section.

paragraph.text: In contesting the finding of a felony conviction, the individual shall contact the office of the Secretary, or a designee of the Secretary, and a hearing shall be convened within 20 workdays, unless subsequently waived by the individual.
The Secretary, or a designee of the Secretary, shall render a decision regarding the appeal within 5 workdays after the hearing.

subsection.text: For the purposes of this subtitle, the record of a felony conviction or a copy of the record certified by the clerk of the court or by a judge of the court in which the conviction occurred shall be conclusive evidence of the conviction.
Failure of the individual to appear at the scheduled hearing shall be considered grounds for dismissal of the appeal.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall issue a license to each applicant who satisfies the requirements of this title and any regulations adopted under this title.

subparagraph.text: The Secretary shall issue a private home detention monitoring agency license certificate to each licensed agency.
For each additional office the private detention monitoring agency proposes to operate, the Secretary shall issue a branch office certificate.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall include on each agency license certificate that the Secretary issues:

subparagraph.text: the full name of the licensee;
the location of the private home detention monitoring agency and of each branch office, if any;
the date of issuance of the license; and
the date on which the license expires.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall include on a branch office certificate:

subparagraph.text: the full name of the licensee;
the location of the principal office of the licensee and of the agency branch office for which the certificate is issued;
the date of issuance of the branch office certificate; and
the date on which the license of the licensee expires.

section.text: While a license is in effect, it authorizes the licensee to:

paragraph.text: operate, in accordance with applicable laws and regulations, a business that provides monitoring services for a fee to individuals who are under a court order that requires monitoring by a private home detention monitoring agency; and
employ qualified individuals to work as private home detention monitors on behalf of the licensee.

subsection.text: Unless a license is renewed for a 2-year term as provided in this section, the license expires on the date set by the Secretary.
At least 2 months before a license expires, the Secretary shall mail to the licensee, at the last known address of the licensee:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

subparagraph.text: the date on which the current license expires;
that the Secretary must receive the renewal application at least 21 days before the license expiration date, for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the current license expires;
the amount of the renewal fee; and
that the submission of a false statement in the renewal application or in the annual statements is cause for revocation of the license.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall renew the license of each licensee who satisfies the requirements of this title and any regulations adopted under this title.
As a condition for license renewal, a licensee shall submit to the Secretary with the renewal application:

paragraph.text: a certification or, as authorized by the Secretary, other documentation that the licensed private home detention monitoring agency has paid, for the past 2 years, all withholding and Social Security taxes;

a certification or, as authorized by the Secretary, other documentation that the licensed private home detention monitoring agency has paid, for the past 2 years, all other obligations employers are required to pay on behalf of their employees to the State or federal government;

a certificate of compliance issued by the State Workers’ Compensation Commission, or the number of a workers’ compensation insurance policy or binder as provided by § 9-105 of the Labor and Employment Article;

a receipt from the Comptroller’s Office or, as authorized by the Secretary, other documentation showing that the State income tax of the licensed private home detention monitoring agency has been paid for the past 2 years;

subparagraph.text: a bond in accordance with the requirements of § 20-601 of this title; and
proof of liability insurance, as required under § 20-602 of this title; and

paragraph.text: a renewal fee of $100.

subsection.text: If the Secretary does not receive the documents required under subsection (a) of this section at least 21 days before the current license expires, the Secretary may charge the licensee a late fee of $10 per day until the documents are received.
The Secretary may inspect any of the business records of a licensee that relate to any matter that is subject to certification or documentation under this section.
A licensee shall maintain an office in the State.
A licensee shall keep in an office in the State all files or other records that:

paragraph.text: are made in the State; and
relate to individuals monitored by the licensee.

subsection.text: Within 21 days after the change, a licensee shall submit to the Secretary written notice of:

paragraph.text: the addition of a branch office; and
a change in the address of the private home detention monitoring agency or branch office.

subsection.text: The licensee shall submit with the notice:

paragraph.text: a photocopy of the agency license certificate; and
if the proposed change affects an existing branch office, a photocopy of the branch office certificate for that office.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall issue a new agency license certificate and, if applicable, a new branch office certificate, both of which shall set forth the same expiration date as the original agency license certificate.
Each licensee shall have on the premises at all times:

paragraph.text: the agency license certificate in the office of the private home detention monitoring agency; and
the branch office certificate in the agency branch office for which the certificate was issued.
If an agency license certificate or branch office certificate is lost or destroyed, the licensee immediately shall notify the Secretary.
On receipt of notice of the loss or destruction of an agency license certificate or branch office certificate, the Secretary may issue a duplicate.

subsection.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 20-316 of this subtitle, the Secretary may deny a license to any applicant, reprimand any licensee, or suspend or revoke a license if the applicant or licensee:

paragraph.text: fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a license for the applicant or licensee or for another;
fraudulently or deceptively uses a license;
while not licensed, willfully engages in a business providing private home detention monitoring services in the State;
while not licensed, willfully advertises as a private home detention monitoring agency;
willfully makes a false statement or misrepresentation that an individual is or was in the employ of the applicant or licensee;
has a felony conviction;
knowingly employs or knowingly continues to employ a private home detention monitor after being notified by the Secretary that the individual has a felony conviction;
willfully makes a false statement or misrepresentation in any renewal application, in any annual statement, or in any other report or document that the Secretary requires to be submitted;
fails to notify the Secretary about any change in the address of the private home detention monitoring agency or any branch office of a licensee;
fails to maintain a bond as required by § 20-601 of this title;
fails to maintain the liability insurance required under § 20-602 of this title;
violates any other provision of this title; or
violates a regulation adopted under this title.

subsection.text: For purposes of this section, an act or omission of any principal, agent, or employee of an applicant or licensee may be construed to be the act or omission of the applicant or licensee, as well as of the principal, agent, or employee.

paragraph.text: Subject to this section, the Secretary shall commence proceedings under § 20-316 of this subtitle on the Secretary’s own complaint or on a complaint made to the Secretary by any person.
If a complaint is made by any person other than the Secretary, the complaint shall be made under oath by the person who submits the complaint.
A complaint shall:

subparagraph.text: be in writing;
be signed by the complainant; and
state specifically the facts on which the complaint is based.

subsection.text: On receipt of a complaint that alleges facts that are grounds for action under § 20-314 of this subtitle, the Secretary shall assign an employee to investigate the complaint.

paragraph.text: On conclusion of the investigation, the employee who conducted the investigation shall determine whether there is a reasonable basis to believe that there are grounds for disciplinary action under § 20-314 of this subtitle.

If the employee who conducted the investigation finds a reasonable basis as provided under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Secretary shall act on the complaint as provided under § 20-316 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 10-226 of the State Government Article, before the Secretary takes final action under § 20-314 of this subtitle, the Secretary shall give the person against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Secretary.
The Secretary shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Secretary may administer oaths in connection with any proceeding under this section.
The person may be represented at the hearing by counsel.
If, after due notice, the person against whom the action is contemplated does not appear, nevertheless the Secretary may hear and determine the matter.

section.text: Within 5 days after the Secretary suspends or revokes the license of a person, the person shall surrender to the Secretary the agency license certificate and each branch office certificate issued to the person.
When the Secretary makes a determination to suspend or revoke the license of a private home detention monitoring agency, the Secretary shall immediately notify:

paragraph.text: the administrative judge for the circuit court in each of the counties where the private home detention monitoring agency monitors individuals who are under a court order that requires monitoring by a private home detention monitoring agency; and

the administrative judge for the District Court in each of the districts where the private home detention monitoring agency monitors individuals who are under a court order that requires monitoring by a private home detention monitoring agency.

subsection.text: A private home detention monitoring agency shall:

paragraph.text: monitor individuals in accordance with any applicable orders of court;
monitor 24 hours a day and 7 days a week individuals who are under a court order that requires monitoring by a private home detention monitoring agency; and
utilize electronic equipment or other monitoring methods that meet or exceed standards established in regulations by the Secretary.

Upon determining that a defendant subject to private home detention monitoring under the provisions of § 5-201(b) of the Criminal Procedure Article has been missing for 24 hours, the private home detention monitoring agency responsible for monitoring the defendant shall, on the next business day, notify the court that ordered private home detention monitoring as a condition of the defendant’s pretrial release.

If the court that ordered private detention monitoring as a condition of a defendant’s pretrial release under the provisions of § 5-201(b) of the Criminal Procedure Article requests that it be notified if the defendant violates any other conditions of pretrial release, the private home detention monitoring agency responsible for monitoring the defendant shall provide the court with the requested notice.

subsection.text: Upon determining that an individual who is subject to private home detention monitoring as a condition of probation has been missing for 24 hours, the private home detention monitoring agency responsible for monitoring the individual shall, on the next business day, notify the Division of Parole and Probation.

section.text: A licensed private home detention monitoring agency is responsible for the acts of each of its employees while the employee is conducting the business of the agency.

paragraph.text: Subject to this section, an applicant for a license shall execute a bond that is conditioned on the faithful and honest conduct of the applicant and runs to the State for the benefit of any person injured by any wrongful act of the applicant that is willful or malicious.
The applicant shall submit the bond to the Secretary with the license application.
The amount of the bond required under subsection (a) of this section shall be at least $2,500.
The total liability of the surety to all insured persons under the bond may not exceed the penal sum of the bond.

subsection.text: A licensee shall keep in effect at all times a bond that meets the requirements of this section.
If a licensee’s bond is canceled, forfeited, or terminated by the surety, the surety immediately shall notify the Secretary.
If a surety fails to notify the Secretary as required by this subsection, the bond shall continue in effect until the notice is given to the Secretary.
The Secretary may adopt regulations requiring a private home detention monitoring agency to maintain a specific minimum amount of general liability insurance.
If the Secretary adopts regulations under subsection (a) of this section, a private home detention monitoring agency shall:

paragraph.text: submit proof of the insurance to the Secretary; and
notify the Secretary if the insurance is canceled, forfeited, or otherwise terminated.

subsection.text: If the Secretary adopts regulations under subsection (a) of this section, the Secretary may not issue a license to an applicant unless the applicant submits proof of the insurance required by regulation.
A person may not operate a private home detention monitoring agency in the State unless the Secretary has issued a license to the person.
A person who willfully and knowingly violates this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.
In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the State Board of Individual Tax Preparers.
“Fund” means the Individual Tax Preparers Fund established under § 21–208 of this title.
“In good standing” means an individual has not engaged in conduct that would justify censure, suspension, or disbarment from practice.
“Individual tax preparer” means an individual who is registered by the Board to provide individual tax preparation services.

“Provide individual tax preparation services” means to prepare, advise or assist in the preparation of, or assume final responsibility for another person’s preparation of a federal or State income tax return of another for valuable consideration.
“Registration” means, unless the context requires otherwise, an authorization issued by the Board to provide individual tax preparation services.
The purpose of this title is to establish a registration program to ensure that qualified individuals provide individual tax preparation services.
The following individuals are exempt from the requirements of this title:

paragraph.text: an individual in good standing with an active license issued by the State Board of Public Accountancy or a licensing authority in another state;
an individual in good standing and admitted to practice law in the State or in another state;
an individual employed by a local, state, or federal governmental agency but only in performance of official duties;
an individual enrolled to practice before the Internal Revenue Service who is governed under circular 230; and

an individual serving as an employee of or assistant to an individual tax preparer or an individual exempted under this subsection in the performance of official duties for the individual tax preparer or the individual exempted under this subsection.

section.text: There is a State Board of Individual Tax Preparers in the Department.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of eight members of which:

subparagraph.text: seven shall have at least 5 years of tax preparation experience; and
one shall be a member of a nonprofit tax program or nonprofit consumer advocate program.

paragraph.text: The Governor shall appoint the members with the advice of the Secretary, the Comptroller, and the Attorney General.
Members of the following groups shall be considered for membership on the Board:

subparagraph.text: a member of a nonprofit tax program or nonprofit consumer advocate program;
a commercial individual tax preparer who has been in practice in the State for more than 10 years and has at least 200 employees;
a member of the Maryland Association of Certified Public Accountants;
a member of the Maryland Society of Accountants, Inc.;
a member of the Maryland State Bar Association; and
a member of the National Association of Enrolled Agents.

subsection.text: Each member of the Board shall be:

paragraph.text: a citizen of the United States; and
a resident of the State.

subsection.text: Before taking office, each appointee to the Board shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 4 years and begins on July 1.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on June 1, 2008.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
Each member of the Board is eligible for reappointment but may not serve more than two consecutive terms.
The Governor may remove a member for incompetence, misconduct, neglect of duties, or other sufficient cause.
The Governor shall remove a member who ceases to meet the requirements under which the member was appointed, as provided under subsections (a) and (b) of this section.

subsection.text: From among its members, the Board shall elect a chair and other officers as necessary.
The manner of election and the term of an officer shall be as the Board determines.
A majority of the members then serving on the Board is a quorum.
The Board shall meet at least five times a year, with at least two meetings being held between January 1 and April 15.
Each member of the Board is entitled to:

paragraph.text: compensation in accordance with the State budget; and
reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Board may employ staff in accordance with the State budget.
In addition to any powers set forth elsewhere, the Board may adopt:

paragraph.text: any bylaw that is necessary to do the business of the Board; and
any regulation to carry out this title.

subsection.text: In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere, the Board shall:

paragraph.text: adopt rules of professional conduct as appropriate to establish a high standard of integrity and dignity for the practice of individual tax preparation;
select and administer examinations;
establish fees;
maintain a list of all authorized individual tax preparers registered by the Board;
maintain a record of its proceedings;
maintain records of all complaints regarding individual tax preparers in the State; and
report to the General Assembly, in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article.

subsection.text: The Board may investigate a complaint that alleges a violation of this title.
On receipt of the results of an investigation made under this section, the Board shall promptly take action that is appropriate under this title to ensure compliance with this title.

paragraph.text: If the Board concludes that conduct alleged to be in violation of this title will result in harm to a resident of the State, the Board may seek a permanent or temporary injunction with respect to the conduct from the circuit court of the county in which the alleged violation occurs.
In seeking an injunction under this subsection, the Board is not required to:

subparagraph.text: post bond;
allege or prove that an adequate remedy at law does not exist; or
allege or prove that substantial or irreparable damage would result from the continued violation.

paragraph.text: A member of the Board may not be held personally liable for action taken under this subsection in good faith with reasonable grounds.

subsection.text: The Board, or a hearing officer designated by the Board, may administer oaths, hold hearings, and take testimony about all matters within the jurisdiction of the Board.

paragraph.text: The Board or its designee may issue a subpoena for the attendance of a witness to testify or the production of evidence in connection with:

subparagraph.text: a disciplinary action brought under this title; or
a proceeding brought for an alleged violation of this title.

paragraph.text: If an individual fails to comply with a subpoena issued under this subsection, on petition of the Board, a court of competent jurisdiction may compel compliance with the subpoena.

subsection.text: The Board may set reasonable fees for the registration and renewal of registration of individual tax preparers.
Each individual tax preparer that registers under this title shall pay to the Board:

paragraph.text: a registration fee at the time of registration; or
a renewal fee at the time of renewal of registration.
The Board shall pay all fees collected under this section to the State Comptroller.
The Comptroller shall distribute the fees to the Fund.

subsection.text: There is an Individual Tax Preparers Fund.
The purpose of the Fund is to approximate the costs associated with the administration and enforcement of this title.
The Board shall administer the Fund.

paragraph.text: The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to § 7–302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The State Treasurer shall hold the Fund separately, and the Comptroller shall account for the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: revenue distributed to the Fund under § 21–207 of this subtitle;
money appropriated in the State budget to the Fund; and
any other money from any other source accepted for the benefit of the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund may be used only for costs associated with the administration and enforcement of this title.

paragraph.text: The State Treasurer shall invest the money of the Fund in the same manner as other State money may be invested.
Any investment earnings of the Fund shall be credited to the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: Expenditures from the Fund may be made only in accordance with the State budget.
On request of any person and payment of a registration fee set by the Board, the Board shall confirm the registration status and qualifications of any individual who is the subject of the request.
Each registration under this section:

paragraph.text: shall include a statement of the registration status of the individual who is the subject of the request; and
may include:

subparagraph.text: information about the examination results and other qualifications of that individual;
information about the dates of issuance of the registration of that individual; and
information about any disciplinary action taken against that individual.

section.text: The Board exercises its powers, duties, and functions subject to the authority of the Secretary.
An individual shall be registered by the Board before the individual may provide individual tax preparation services in the State.

subsection.text: To qualify for a registration, the applicant shall be an individual who meets the requirements of this section.
The applicant shall be of good character and reputation.
The applicant shall be at least 18 years old.
The applicant shall possess a high school diploma or have passed an equivalency examination.
Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, the applicant shall pass an examination given by the Board under this subtitle.

section.text: An applicant for a registration shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the Board an application on the form that the Board provides; and
pay to the Board or the Board’s designee an examination fee set by the Board in an amount not to exceed the cost of the required examination.

subsection.text: An applicant who otherwise qualifies for a registration is entitled to be examined as provided in this section.
The Board shall give examinations to applicants at least twice a year, at the times and places that the Board determines.
The Board shall give each qualified applicant notice of the time and place of examination.
The Board shall give the examination prepared by the Internal Revenue Service or an equivalent examination by an independent national or state regulatory authority as determined by the Board.
The Board shall adopt regulations that establish the passing score for an examination.

paragraph.text: The Board shall notify each applicant of the applicant’s examination score.
Any applicant who requests an appointment within 60 days after the date on which notification is sent may review the applicant’s answers to the examination.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of this section, an applicant who fails an examination given under § 21–304 of this subtitle may retake the examination.

paragraph.text: The Board may not limit the number of times an applicant may take an examination.
The Board may adopt regulations to set conditions for retaking the examination, including a requirement that the applicant:

subparagraph.text: wait a reasonable period between examinations; and
prepare to retake the examination in a specified manner.

paragraph.text: The Board shall set fees for reexamination so that:

subparagraph.text: the fee for reexamination on the entire examination does not exceed the cost of the required reexamination; and
the fee for reexamination on less than the entire examination is less than the fee set for the entire examination.

subsection.text: If an applicant qualifies for a registration under this subtitle, the Board shall send the applicant a notice that states that:

paragraph.text: the applicant has qualified for a registration; and
on receipt of a registration fee set by the Board, the Board will issue a registration to the applicant.

subsection.text: On payment of the registration fee, the Board shall issue a registration to each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle.

section.text: A registration authorizes, while the registration is in effect, the individual to provide individual tax preparation services.

subsection.text: Unless a registration is renewed for a 2–year term as provided in this section, the registration expires on the second December 31 that comes after the effective date of the registration.
At least 1 month before a registration expires, the Board shall mail to the individual, at the last known address of the individual:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

subparagraph.text: the date on which the current registration expires;
the date by which the Board must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the registration expires; and
the amount of the renewal fee.

subsection.text: Before a registration expires, the individual periodically may renew it for an additional 2–year term if the individual:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be registered;
pays to the Board a renewal fee, as set by the Board; and
submits to the Board:

subparagraph.text: a renewal application on the form that the Board provides; and
satisfactory evidence of compliance with the continuing education requirements set under this subtitle for registration renewal.

subsection.text: The Board shall renew the registration of each individual who meets the requirements of this section.
The Secretary may determine that registrations issued under this subtitle shall expire on a staggered basis.

paragraph.text: The Board shall adopt regulations that create, in accordance with this section, continuing education requirements as a condition to the renewal of a registration issued under this subtitle.
An individual shall complete at least 16 hours of continuing education activities every 2 years.

subsection.text: The continuing education requirements shall:

paragraph.text: ensure reasonable knowledge about the current trends in federal and State tax preparation services;
ensure that the programs approved for compliance with the continuing education requirements are available at reasonable intervals throughout the State; and
provide an individual with alternative ways by which to qualify through a variety of programs, which may include:

subparagraph.text: professional development programs;
technical sessions of professional societies or chapters;
college courses approved by the Board;
seminars provided by governmental units; and
other seminars or symposiums related to tax preparation services.

subsection.text: The Board may appoint a continuing education committee to help the Board in carrying out this section.

paragraph.text: The regulations adopted under this section shall provide a system for reporting and recording the program hours earned by the individual.
The Board may not require an individual to submit scores or grades earned during participation by the individual in a program.
The Board may enter into written agreements with qualified persons wishing to conduct approved programs.
A person seeking approval by the Board for this purpose shall:

subparagraph.text: submit to the Board an application on the form that the Board provides; and
pay an application fee, as set by the Board.

section.text: The Board shall adopt regulations for the reinstatement of the registration of an individual who has failed to renew a registration for any reason if the individual:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be registered;
complies with the continuing education requirement that the Board sets for this purpose; and
pays to the Board:

subparagraph.text: all past due renewal fees; and
a reinstatement fee, as set by the Board.

subsection.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 21–312 of this subtitle, the Board, on the affirmative vote of a majority of its members then serving, may deny a registration to any applicant, reprimand any registered individual, or suspend or revoke a registration if the applicant or registered individual:

paragraph.text: fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a registration for the applicant or registered individual or for another;
fraudulently or deceptively uses a registration;

under the laws of the United States or of any state, is convicted of a felony or a misdemeanor, either of which is directly related to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or registered individual to provide individual tax preparation services;
is guilty of negligence, incompetence, or misconduct while providing individual tax preparation services;
violates any regulation adopted under this title; or
violates any provision of this title.
In addition to reprimanding or suspending or revoking a registration under this subsection, the Board may impose a penalty not exceeding $5,000 for each violation.
To determine the amount of the penalty imposed under this subsection, the Board shall consider:

subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the harm caused by the violation;
the good faith of the registered individual; and
any history of previous violations by the registered individual.

paragraph.text: The Board shall use a penalty collected under this subsection to provide for the enforcement of this section.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 10–226 of the State Government Article, before the Board takes any final action under § 21–311 of this subtitle, it shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Board.
The Board shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
If, after due notice, the individual against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, the Board may hear and determine the matter.

section.text: An individual aggrieved by a final decision of the Board in a contested case, as defined in § 10–202 of the State Government Article, may take an appeal as allowed in §§ 10–222 and 10–223 of the State Government Article.
Except as otherwise provided in this title, a person may not provide, attempt to provide, or offer to provide individual tax preparation services in the State unless registered by the Board.

Unless authorized under this title to provide individual tax preparation services, an individual may not represent to the public, by use of a title, including “registered individual tax preparer” or “individual tax preparer”, by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the individual is authorized to provide individual tax preparation services in the State.

subsection.text: An individual tax preparer shall maintain for a length of time specified by the Board that is not more stringent than a length of time specified under federal law all records of personal income tax returns prepared by the individual tax preparer.

paragraph.text: Prior to rendering individual tax preparation services, an individual tax preparer shall disclose to the customer, in writing:

subparagraph.text: the individual tax preparer’s name, address, and telephone number;
that the individual tax preparer is not a certified public accountant, an enrolled agent, or a tax attorney;
services that the individual tax preparer is qualified to provide;
the individual tax preparer’s education and training, including examinations taken and successfully passed; and
any other information that the Board requires.

paragraph.text: A disclosure required under this subsection shall be provided to a customer:

subparagraph.text: at an initial meeting between the individual tax preparer and the customer; and
if the individual tax preparer maintains a website, on the website.

subsection.text: An individual tax preparer may not:

paragraph.text: fail to sign a customer’s individual tax return;
obtain the customer’s signature on an individual tax return or other authorizing document prior to the completion of the individual tax preparation services; or
disclose information received for the purposes of preparing a customer’s federal or State income tax return, unless:

subparagraph.text: consented to in writing by the customer;
expressly authorized by law;

subsection.text: A violation of this title is an unfair or deceptive trade practice within the meaning of Title 13 of the Commercial Law Article and is subject to the enforcement and penalty provisions contained in Title 13 of the Commercial Law Article.

In addition to the remedies provided in Title 13 of the Commercial Law Article, an individual who is aggrieved by a violation of this title may bring an action against a person who violates this title to recover:

paragraph.text: $500 for each violation; and
actual damages sustained as a result of the violation.

section.text: This title may be cited as the “Maryland Individual Tax Preparers Act”.

Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, this title and all regulations adopted under this title shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2016.
